Finally, we split one of the Porchetta paninis, which is their current special. The panini was topped with giardiniera, salsa verde, garlic mayo and provolone. First of all, these sandwiches are BIG and rich. Perfect for splitting if you're ordering fries and other things. The panini WAS fantastic though. DO. NOT. SKIP. THE. PANINIS. It came out piping hot and dripping fantastic sauces all melted together under the hot panini press. I'm bummed I will probably never get to eat this specific sandwich again! 

Overall, I was incredibly impressed with Duckfat. I feel like a lot of "hyped up" places eventually compromise on quality, but that is certainly not the case here. Since it was so busy when we visited, many people were placing carryout orders. They waited for the customer to arrive to box their fries so they were hot and not soggy. Their carryout option is great for larger parties! The area is quite small, so I imagine it is very difficult to get in without waiting forever. I really appreciated the attentive and courteous staff. I hope I can come back to Portland again soon for a repeat of this fabulous meal!

name: duckfat
review_text:
My friends and I went on a day trip to Portland from Boston to eat yummy food. Duckfat didn't disappoint us. We went early before 11am, but there was a still a line.

Ambiance: The place is smaller with limited tables and seats so we sat at the bar. It is a bit cramp, but it works. It's a place where you just eat and go.

Customer Service: The waitress that served us was very patient and explained everything in the menu and gave us some good recommendations. She had a smile on her the whole time! 

Food: We ordered the poutine and had a few sample sauces. My gosh, their fries and poutine is phenomenally good! Their sauce is the best! I remembered that one of their sauces have a wasabi taste to it.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Came to try out food here, walked in the door at 10:56 ( they open at 11) and was told to wait outside, a guy with glasses and dark hair basically closed the door and locked us out, yes he locked the door. my purse got stuck in the door as he closed it on us. Already not a great start, I found that extremely rude, I was shocked we couldn't just sit and read the menu. Not a good vibe. Normally I'd leave and eat somewhere else but the reviews of this place make we want to try the food too much to leave. 
After eating I was a bit disappointed, dont get me wrong, food was good, but with all the hype I was expecting to be blown away. I wasnt. But it was really good. Except the fries, way way way too salty, every bite I needed to drink some water. Wont be back. Oh well. On to the next one!

name: duckfat
review_text:
Always busy but for a reason. 

Tight menu, done well, service excellent with a great vibe in this homey restaurant. 

Fries, soups, poutine, paninis and salads. And of course you need to wash your meal down with a milk shake!

The duckfat fries are amazing. Four choices of dipping sauce including truffle catchup and chipotle mayo. The poutine looked fantastic as well and there were a lot being served this afternoon!

Paninis include Duck  Confit, Pulled Pork Cubano, Smoked Brisket and Turkey. 

Salads included an Arugula and Endive with bleu cheese and candies walnuts. It had a lightly tossed vinaigrette. 

Full bar available. But the more popular drinks were the milk shakes, craft sodas and gelato  floats.

Service was attentive and friendly.

name: duckfat
review_text: We cake in off season and later at night so we don't have to wait. Everything was good but not quite as good as everyone had mentioned. The milkshake was softer than most milkshakes. The fancy Ketchup was unique. Getting the panini and fries was a large quantity of food. The food is good and very rich.

name: duckfat
review_text: DELISH! Went for lunch on a Sunday and had a reasonable wait. The Brussel Sprout special was incredible. We split a large poutine and a large fry with the sauce samplers and it was the perfect amount of food. I also tried the special porchetta panini and it was SO. GOOD. Had to get a milkshake to go ...

name: duckfat
review_text:
This was a place recommended by my coworker. I was going to come as well because of the cool name. This restaurant is definitely unique in its own way. My coworker and I thought we were going to have some duck. Ultimately, we ordered some delicious food but wondered where the duck was at. They change their menus so the pictures you see on yelp may not be there when you are at the restaurant. If you see brussel sprouts, I highly recommend that dish! That was my favorite.

Overall, the staff was nice. This place does get packed and it is popular but the wait time wasn't bad.

name: duckfat
review_text:
I may need lipator now, but it was worth it!
I have eaten Poutine all over Canada, and the USA, there are many versions now, but many fall short. Without going to Montreal, or Vancouver, ME makes the best in the USA. 
This was my first time eating duck fat fried fries and man were they good. The gravy was clear and ethereal. The duck confit was very good as well. The Black Birch of Kittery ME also has a stand out version of this dish.
The sandwiches were looking bomb too. The large is very big!!! We barely finished it, and can both pack some food. I may recommend a small for us in the future. 
Nice local beer and drink list.
They do not take reservations, so come early, or late, or plan on waiting. They do have those beeper that are good for a block and a half roaming while you wait.
I would not take a vegetarian or vegan here, but- hey they have special restaurants in town for them too!

name: duckfat
review_text:
One word: Duckfat.

When I said to a colleague in Boston that I was headed to Portland for the weekend, he said, simply: Duckfat. 

That was my first indication that this was a thing. I yelped it, of course. And when I got to where I was staying, I said to the clerk that I was walking over to Duckfat for lunch. She pointed down the street in the general direction of. I asked for clarification. 

Oh, you'll see it, she said.

I didn't know what she meant but when I walked down the nearly deserted street and turned in the general direction of Duckfat, I looked down another nearly deserted street. And that's when I saw it: a crowd of people standing on the sidewalk in what otherwise looked like a ghost town. This must be it. 12:30 on a cold Friday afternoon, this place is jammed. I forged ahead. (Fast forward to me, with the blessing of the very busy hostess, finding a single seat at the bar. Yay! I hadn't eaten breakfast and had just finished a two-hour drive from Boston so I was ready.) 

Both hostess (who brought me menus and welcomes) and the bartender/server were great. Bartender (Charlie!) was helpful and friendly and attentive to the actual needs of eating/drinking. Every server seemed happy and good, so that's a plus. The turnover was swift -- I guess they'd have to be at lunchtime. 

But. The fries ($5.50) weren't as good as I expected. They're good, as most attentively cooked and freshly served fries are, but they're not good in the way that duck fat fries can be. I've had potato wedge fries cooked in duck fat both at a restaurant and at home (using the leftover oil from two deep-fried ducks), and both were wayway better than these fries. Those two had that peculiar rich duck flavor. The fries at Duckfat didn't. Or at least they had only a hint of it. It got me wondering about how much duck fat they actually used.... so I asked. The answer -- and, yeah, cheers for being open and honest and direct -- was 35% duck fat, 65% canola oil. Would they have tasted better with more duck fat? Would they have tasted better if I hadn't been subject to outsized expectations from all the hype? I'm wary of hype, so maybe I had my guard up. Maybe I wasn't going to like them enough, no matter what. I dunno. They were good, not great.The sauce (thai-something) was tasty but not as addictive as I expected. Again, the hype. (Maybe I should have asked for regular ketchup??)

The cubano panini ($12.50), however, was the best I've ever had. Totally awesome with layers of pickles and meat and sauce on a crusty bread of some sort. I ate half then and half for breakfast (after microwaving it for 33 seconds) and, I have to say, it was still amazing. For this? Five stars. 

And another star or two for the idea of Duckfat, an amazing storefront hustle. The place isn't that big. In fact, it's tiny. And the kitchen, even smaller, is probably just a deep-frier and a panini machine. They might as well be printing $100 bills back there. If this isn't a chain, it should be. I'd like to own one in Boston.

tl;dr: good food, good service, fast turnover; forget the hype, have a sandwich with fries.

name: duckfat
review_text: For years, I wanted to go to Duckfat. Finally made it happen, and it did not disappoint.  We had about a 15 minute wait for a seat. It is small inside, but they make the space work and you don't feel squished. We got fries, the Tahitian vanilla shake, and paninis. Andrew was our server, and he was great. Everything was top notch. The shake was one of the best I have ever had. We ordered one and they split it between two glasses for us. I loved the bread used on the paninis. The fries were perfect.  A little girl and her mom were seated next to us, and Andrew chatted with the girl telling her he would make her the most amazing grilled cheese ever. So good! Really understand the hype now. Worth it.

name: duckfat
review_text:
We read the reviews, and we can't resist a good poutine! We opted to split a large poutine with shredded duck, and it was delicious - and a generous size!

We also split the overnight duck panini, which had great flavor and a perfect crisp! A few bites were less saucy than others, but overall delicious.

Also, if you love a good milkshake, get the traditional Duckfat milkshake. It's not too sweet, and dipping your fries is perfect.

We expected a long wait, but we showed up at 4:30 off season, and we only waited ten minutes. Overall, a great experience, and we will be back!

name: duckfat
review_text:
I don't think the food lived up to the hype. And this place is plenty hyped about - we got there just as the restaurant opened in the morning, but there was already a line out the door. We received one of the buzzers and ended up waiting almost an hour to get seated.

The duckfat fries are pretty good, but not amazing. I really like the flight of sauces - great variety and creative flavors. The poutine was a disappointment... I've definitely had better poutine before. I also got a duck confit panini, which also turned out disappointing. It simply lacked flavor.

We got a salted caramel milkshake to go. That ended the meal on a good note, but not enough to make me want to visit again.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Oh Duckfat!  I've been here so many times and loved it but have yet to review it (trying to keep it low key as possible!)  This is a must eat stop in Portland.  The vibe is so relaxed inside and everything I have ever had here is so TASTY.  

True to their name, the duckfat is used to make the most delicious bites.  From fries, to poutine, to the fried brussel sprouts to the milkshakes- you cannot go wrong.  There are a handful of sauces that you can choose for the fries so you have many options if you want something with a kick, something sweet, or something light.  Definitely worth it to find the one or two that are right for you!

The fried brussel sprouts are by far my favorite!  They are so crispy and put together with so many different elements- there are crunchy garlic bits, bacon, and it is all balanced out with pickled apples.  Never would I have thought to pickle apples!  It gives it a nice acidic balance to cut the fat and salt.  

We've always been lucky and have been seated right away, but we typically go at times that are a little bit off from "normal" dining times.  You can always get take out which is also worth it!  If you want to go with a larger group- I suggest you line up outside before Duckfat opens!

name: duckfat
review_text:
Finally got around to trying this place! Overall super good, though I recommend timing it to avoid a wait, as I don't think it's worth an hour+ wait. 
The first time we went on a Sunday night before Christmas and got in right away. The next time was a Friday at 2pm, and there were 15+ people standing outside waiting. We went to the Frite Shack instead (n.b.: poutine not as good there. Lacking in the gravy, confit, and cheese curd departments) 

Anyway, here's what we had:
Poutine - added confit and a duck egg. Came to $18ish, but totally religious food experience. So good!! Loved every bite. 
Cubano - pretty good but not worth $12 with no sides
Duckfat original milkshake - best milkshake I've ever had. Incredible. They also split it into 2 glasses for us which I really appreciated. 
Cotechino - they make in-house charcuterie now. This one wasn't to my personal taste (strong anise flavor) but it was objectively good

So my verdict: come here for a snack(poutine!) and a beer or milkshake, but skip a full meal. The sandwiches aren't worth it. We decided to pair a slab from Micucci's with the poutine and it was perfect.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Duckfat is a cute restaurant located in Old Port Maine. It is the perfect place for a casual meal. This place serves the best sandwiches, poutine, and french fries with delicious sauces. The milkshakes are also dangerously good! I also like the selection of local craft beers. 

I tried the duck confit sandwich and one of the specials, the roast beef sandwich. The duck confit was super delicious. There was a good balance of flavors. Every bite was savory, sweet from the duck confit and acidic from the slaw. This was a perfect sandwich. The fries were also amazing! You get a choice of 1 sauce for the small order and 2 sauces for the large order. I tried the truffle ketchup because I love truffles! And truffles + fries are the perfect match. 

The restaurant is nice and cozy, there is a bar and long table against the wall of the restaurant and a few tables for parties for 4+. You can make friends with your neighbors during your meal!

name: duckfat
review_text: Fresh, crunchy salads, yummy milkshakes (that they will pour into individual cups to split) and creative sandwiches are a great reason to keep coming back. The place looks unassuming but don't forget you're here for the food.

name: duckfat
review_text: This is a very small restaurant and I'm assuming that they have fixed stools in order to fit in as many people as possible. This is not a good location for people with disabilities, the elderly or people who want normal type of seats. There are a couple tables outside the restaurant with normal tables and seating in an enclosed area where everyone enters/exits, which is not climate controlled. I did notice there is 1 tall table inside. (Could be another one. Unsure.)  I did not get to see the type of seating to that table. All other seating is a counter at a wall. My stool leaned back causing me to constantly slide back and it was on a corner towards the end. Not comfortable. They have hooks under the counters for bags/purses and wall hooks in the back for coats and yes, you do need that, because there's not enough room to put your stuff anywhere around you. May be worth waiting for one of the tables. You cannot go in and get a table without your entire party being present. Staff is very nice. The fries and sauces were very good. All of us had paninis. The bread was good, but I was not a fan of the pulled pork Cubano to a point that I just couldn't eat it. This does not mean you won't like it. Everyone has their own tastebuds. The BGT was ok. It's also important to point out that the paninis do not come with a side. While they were ok, I did not think $12.50 for a small panini that was "simply ok" to be of value. $70 for 3 people for lunch (no alcohol beverages) was steep for what we got. They forgot to order our chocolate shake. We reminded them when we they brought us boxes for our leftovers and opted to have it to go, because we were at the point of leaving after being there for an hour. The shake was thick. It was good, but not the best and not worth getting it, again.

name: duckfat
review_text:
My boyfriend and I ate at Duckfat two days in a row, and it was the best part of our weekend visit to Portland. The duck confit panini is one of the best sandwiches I've ever had, and you can't go wrong with their fries in any iteration - the poutine is great for a warm, heavier option, while their duck fat fries come with your choice of two sauces and are so addictive. As far as the sauces go, definitely try the truffle ketchup! Duckfat's milkshakes are also exceptional, and their little donuts make for a good dessert option (if you're able to eat dessert after your meal).
Extra tip: sometimes the wait is exceptionally long, but if you do take-out you can go to a park and enjoy the food much sooner!

name: duckfat
review_text:
This place was bombastic, baby, fantastic! Everything is done so well, fresh and tasty! We ordered the poutine fries with confit, bbq sandwich, tomato bisque and a root beer soda, followed by a cherry soda. Everything, everything was just so delicious. I can see why this was a James Beard Chef nominee because everything was just so good! 

These poutine fries were better than the ones I had in Vancouver, Canada, the country of poutine! The BBQ sandwich was finger lickin', not sharin' good! The tomato bisque was housemade and tummy warming good - I've made it and I know how painstaking it is to make a good bowl of 'mato soup. 

The sodas were my favorite! I have been looking everywhere for root beer made from the roots and behold! Duck Fat delivers! And it is fricken' perfection! I lament that I live so far (Hawaii). 

Go here, go NOW.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Marked this place as a must on my trip to Portland, so was very determined to try food fried in duck fat that everyone seems so crazy about.
 
Stopped by on a rainy Friday around 4pm. The tiny place was jammed packed with a line outside. The wait time was over an hour. Decided to come another time, when there would be less people. Ha. Returned on Saturday around 2pm. The wait time for a table for two is 1.5-2 hours. TWO hours!! And everyone around the block is waiting for a table as well, so you know that wait won't magically shrink to 30 mins or even an hour. A lot of people ordered take out and created impromptu picnics on the grass right across from the restaurant. That's an option if you're pressed for time but resolute to try the food. My bf persuaded me to leave and not waste half our Saturday on waiting.

Despite so many futile attempts, I was resolute to make it to this local favorite before leaving back to NYC. Sunday morning, our last day in Portland, we arrived at 11am, right when the place opened. We were seated right away. FINALLY! Within half an hour, the place filled up to the brim. The restaurant is tiny, fits no more than 40 people at the time, and is insanely popular. If you don't want to spend over an hour waiting, recommend getting here right around opening time.
 
The ambiance is super casual, good for a quick and informal bite. Tiny space, so they tried to squish as many wooden tables as possible. Very loud noise levels. There's outdoor seating area as well.
 
The service is swift, warm, and welcoming. Everyone is super courteous despite the hustle and bustle of this tiny, overpacked place. Our waitress was very helpful with menu recommendations. Our food came from the kitchen at mega speed.

Now let's talk food. After all this wait and hype, my expectations were UP there. And have to admit that we left stuffed and content.
 
Large Fries ($8) come with two sauces. We got truffle ketchup and garlic mayo, which was solid, but everything fades in comparison to truffle ketchup--GET IT! The fries are a perfect golden color, crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside. My bf and I devoured everything to the last tiny fry.
 
Mocha milkshake ($6.75) was sinfully delicious. Made with local gelato, it was very smooth, not watery, rich, not too sweet.
 
Slow roasted Pulled pork panini ($12) with mustard pickles, swiss, and garlic-mustard mayo was my bf's favorite. Fail proof--if you like juicy, tender meat, go with this. Perfect flavor profile. Thoroughly enjoyed this delicious, sweet & savory combination.

Overnight Duck confit panini ($13.50) with spicy Asian slaw, miso mayo, cilantro was not as juicy as the pork cubano, but I still loved it. Delicious duck and great pairing with Asian slaw and miso mayo. Recommend trying this and the cubano. The paninis are cut in two, so you can share and try multiple flavors!
 
Doughnut holes ($7) served with caramel were tasty but simpler than anticipated. Brought out piping hot, so enjoy them while they're fresh and warm. Enjoyed the contrast of the crunchy shell and warm, fluffy filling.
 
Overall, really glad I persevered and had this experience despite crazy lines and wait time and advanced planning. Was worth the effort.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Hipster place. Through and through. Take something everybody is familiar with and try and bring it to the next level. The one thing I will say positive about the fact that this is a hipster place is that they don't take themselves too seriously which is one of the biggest issues I have with hipster restaurants. 

Now I must say that nothing I had was bad. There was nothing that was inedible. But everything was mediocre. Except the fries but I will come onto that in a minute.  We started with the brussels sprouts which had some very interesting flavors and would have been very good except for the fact that they were halved instead of quartered them which in my case meant that the interiors were still nearly raw. And maybe that's what they were aiming for but I didn't care for it. I like the crispy outer layers and wanted a little bit more cooked in the middle, not mushy but cooked. Also eating half of a Brussel sprout at once can be a little difficult even if you got a large mouth like I do. 

On the fries. This was the highlight of the meal and what the restaurant is known for. Though personally I don't know if I have ever had bad fries cooked in duck fat. It was served with a choice of dressings and I chose horseradish and their Thai chili. Both were fine but nothing exceptional. The viscosity was a little lower than I care for but they weren't aiolis they were something else. 

Now on to the most problematic portion of the meal, the sandwiches. The other big highlight on the menu are the Panini's. I'm not convinced that these are traditional Panini's because they were dry as s---. I'm used to Panini's having some nice butter that helps caramelized the bread and these were just dry. Again I don't know if this is the what they were going for but I certainly didn't care for it and neither did my wife. She had the smoked ham on Rye which was fine but not great. But when you were spending $12 on the sandwich I think I want something better. Maybe our expectations were heightened because everybody talks about this restaurant but the sandwich was just mediocre. 

I took the recommendation of the server and got the duck confit. Again it was fine but not great and since it's the one she recommended and this is what restaurant is known for I really expected something else. When you spent $14 on an al a carte sandwich, mediocre isn't good enough for me.  There was something pickled on it which was nice I really enjoyed that flavor but it over powered everything else and again the bread was just dry. Not grilled, just dry. 

Couple of the notes about the restaurant, it's a hole in the wall place which is kind of fun except the fact that they set us at a community table, and I'm a big guy, next to another big guy which means we were touching shoulders the whole time. I don't have a problem sitting next to people I don't know but I don't want to be touching them the whole time. That's what airplanes are for. Another note is that they are on a wait all the time. That's not a problem for me I'm just pointing it out in case you need to eat quickly. Of course being on a wait actually can't be indicative of a good restaurant though in this case I feel like it was just in emperors new clothes situation.  I for one am not willing to say that I had a good meal just because I paid $46 for two sandwiches a basket of fries and a small plate of Brussels sprouts.

name: duckfat
review_text:
You absolutely cannot go wrong with the poutine here! I've been disappointed by the last few times I've had poutine at other places so it was nice to finally go somewhere where they got it right. FINALLY! The wait here is always pretty crazy if you're looking to sit down (because it's SO SMALL) but we just go the food to go and it was ready pretty quickly. The gravy is on point and the cheese curds are the perfect consistency. Do yourself a favor and if you have one thing here, make sure it's the poutine!

By the way, the photo that I've posted is the small size. Yep. Only in America.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Great service, wonderful food. Food is rich, and delicate. Great location, right in downtown Portland. Nice restaurant if walking around and trying to find a place to eat dinner, but beware they sometimes get a little crowded! A little on the pricey side and a little crowded, but ultimately a beautiful, yummy place to eat. 
Recommend: Poutine with a Fresh Egg and a chocolate milkshake

name: duckfat
review_text: A fun-tastical carousel of crispy Belgian fries with a flight of dipping sauces (fav is the chili aioli). A bountiful bowl of Brussel sprouts with maple bacon, pickled apple mustard vinaigrette and garlic crumbs. Then for entrees, a Buffalo chicken panini for my love and a smoked duck breast and  Asian slaw salad for moi. Then we polished off a thick Tandem Roasters coffee milkshake. Yum-yum-yummo!

name: duckfat
review_text:
The fries that they're known for are definitely worth a try. Their other food options don't quite match up, but the fries and milkshakes make the wait worth it.

Great: fries (get the sauce flight for variety), poutine (the small is huge!), sea salt caramel milkshake
Ok: cubano panini

My group of four came on Sunday right at open (11 AM) and already had a 50 minute wait, so make sure you get there early. Fortunately their buzzer has enough range so we could walk around and explore the stores nearby.

name: duckfat
review_text:
We had to try this place before leaving Maine. Even after the $5/hour parking and the wait it was worth it.

The place is very small and the parking situation around there sucks. Street parking and a garage that was almost full when we were there on a Wednesday around 2:30pm. There was around a 20min wait when we got there so we were given a buzzer and we walked around for a bit.

The place is very small so keep that in mind. They have a couple of larger high tops, a main bar and then some bar sitting along one of the walls. Probably not the best place for a large group.

Service was very good. Everyone from the hostess to our server were all very nice and explained some items on the menu for us.

They had a decent selection of local beers and a nice spritzer of the day. Both my beer and my girlfriends spritzer were great.

We started off with a small order of fries since we got the feeling this is what they were famous for. Didn't go for the poutine because we were having sandwiches and didn't want to get too full. Honestly the fries were good, but there wasn't any different or special about them. Just fresh good fries, but I guess I was expecting something different.

The sandwiches on the other hand were phenomenal! I've had a lot of pork sandwiches being from South Florida but their Cubano sandwich is one of the best I've had. My girlfriend got the special which was a haddock sandwich and that was also amazing. I love how they cut up the fish which makes the flavors blend in more and makes it easier to eat.

We finished off my sharing a chocolate milkshake. Also very good, not overly sweet with nice dark chocolate taste.

I would recommend you check it out even with parking hassle and expense it was worth it!

name: duckfat
review_text: Absolutely amazing food and the service was impeccable. Bit of a wait at the door and there is very limited seating . So be ready to wait and I would not bring a large group.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Heard great things about this place so had to make a stop here during our stay in Maine. And honesty? It didn't live up the hype for me. Don't get me wrong, the food here is really good!! we had the duck poutine, overnight duck confit panini, and sea salted caramel milkshake. The bread of the panini was something else...very toasty, not too heavy, and balanced nicely by the duck, Asian slaw, mayo and cilantro. The fries in the poutine were heavenly!!! Truly addicting as it had the perfect  crispness and seasoned heavily. The sea salted caramel milkshake was decadent, but a bit too caramel-y for my preference. 

...BUT a 40 minute wait for simple orders of paninis and poutine & only to eat our meal on a public bench right outside the restaurant makes it not worth the hype--even if the food is good. Granted, my opinion of this place might change if we had the opportunity to dine inside, but it seems like the sort of place where you'll feel too cramped in that tiny space and guilty for taking your time while there is a line of hungry people out the door. Seems like the smart choice is to come here during off hours, which I might consider the next time I'm in Maine. Glad I got to try this popular spot but wouldn't necessarily wait in line for that long to try again!

name: duckfat
review_text:
Well, if this isn't one of the duckiest places I've been to in a while... wait, this is the duckiest place I've been to. I was lucky, though there was already a line when I got there, I was seated without a wait.

Expectations define experiences, experiences define reality. I would say "Expectations therefore define reality" but this would be an equivocation fallacy. Wait... how did I start talking about logical fallacies... onwards ducklings. 

In terms of the wait, I must say if I had to wait 30-45 minutes, I would have left satisfied with the meal, but other than crossing it off my to-try list I would not 100% say the wait was worth it. 

Fries were very good, seasoned and cooked nicely. I will take them at their word that they're fried in duck fat, however, to be honest I didn't notice a difference between other really good fries. 

Speaking of fries, the sauce flight... for the most part very enjoyable. Except for the garlic mayo, the additives added a pleasant amount of flavor without taking everything over. My two favorites are the Curry and Thai Chili.

- Truffle Ketchup: Great, however since I make it at home occasionally, this was not as special. 

- Horseradish Mayo: What an interesting way to add some heat! Not overpowering by any means, unusual in a great way.

- Curry Mayo: Curry lovers rejoice! If you are a fan of this distinctly yellow spice, you will love this one!

- Thai Chili: This one brought a different, slightly stronger heat than the Horseradish, but still great even for those with low heat tolerance.

- Garlic Mayo - I think the ladle that filled my cup is a vampire. I looked and looked, tasted and tasted, and could not find the garlic in this one. 

Then there's the duck confit panini... 

The portion was more than filling, and unfortunately they can't do half-sizes. If you find it a little large, take it home or better yet, bring a friend! What I also liked is that they didn't skimp on the meat! The slaw added a nice fresh component too! Bread was grilled nicely, and not soggy or mushy in the slightest. 

However, this was far from spectacular. I would have liked for the meat to have a little more seasoning, as it was rather mild for my taste. As for the slaw, while I have no issues with its flavor, it was spread rather thin in places, and I would't call it spicy. Another thing that took my aback was that the sandwich was somewhat dry. They may have used miso mayo as indicated in the menu, but I don't recall seeing or tasting it (same with cilantro, but this isn't as big a deal in this case). 

To drink I had the All Maine Tonic... This was one of the most unusual sodas I've had in a while. Of all the flavors mixed in there, one of them was rather buttery! (in consistency, anyways). I am fond of the gentle level of sweetness, but the something didn't sit right. I couldn't quite put my finger on what it was, but there was a flavor that made this less-than-enjoyable. Looking back trough the menu, though I've not had it before, I don't think it was chaga (a kind of mushroom). My money's on vinegar being the culprit here. 

The service was nice, fairly quick, and surprisingly attentive. Seating is not just cafeteria style, but rather cramped as well. I was almost bumping elbows with my neighbors, but in a small place like this, space is at a premium, so I can't be too upset about it. Board with words you can arrange was cool too! My neighbors were far more creative than "Wants more pesto beneath the lake." This sentence is almost grammatically correct, but for the lack of a subject... because who would want pesto beneath a lake, and why?

The value is also not exceptional, especially when it comes to fries. I know duck is expensive, so I can understand the panini costing what it does. However, I got a rather small helping of albeit very good fries for $5.50.

name: duckfat
review_text:
I thought this was more of a real restaurant, like for dinner. We showed up around 4 on a weekday and while busy there was space. They have a few salads and paninis and shakes. And of course the fries and poutine. 

The poutine was good, the gravy was really rich. A small was more than enough for 2. We didnt upgrade with the duck or egg. 
The kale and smoked duck salad was tasty and filling as it was stuffed with quite and assortment of corn, white beans, farro, small chunks of mandarin orange and chunks of smoked duck. The creamy dressing was good as well.

While the place was good, I am not I get the sure hype. While it was good it wasnt mind blowing and would have been okay not hitting up this spot.The server and staff was most excellent and very friendly and helpful though. If I lived here I would probably frequent more but not a must hit if visiting in my opinion.

name: duckfat
review_text:
I saw that Duckfat was one of the highest rated restaurants on Yelp for Portland, and I was skeptical. I mean, how good can sandwiches and fries be? But was I surprised. I don't even like paninis, but they were delicious.

I would highly recommend the fries. We got the large poutine, and it was so much food. I would recommend you to only get the large if you are either a large eater or you plan on sharing some. 
We also got the turkey panini, and it was perfectly crisp, moist, and cheesy. As for drinks, we tried their Maine blueberry and buttermilk smoothie. It was delicious! We ordered 1, but they gave us some extra and split it into two cups so that we each had our own cup. 

The restaurant is fairly small and crowded. They also do not take reservations, so if you are not going to get there early, you should plan on waiting.

name: duckfat
review_text:
If it's not apparent by word of mouth or the throngs of people outside this little joint, Duckfat is the place to be if you're in Portland, Maine. Located 1 block away from an equally popular (and busy) restaurant, Eventide Oyster Company, Duckfat serves flavorful food you don't want to miss. Since I was only in this nice city for about a day, I didn't have much time to wait for a table. Albeit, I couldn't leave the city without trying something from here, so I got some takeout. I ordered:

1) Hand Cut Belgian Fries - friend is duck fat (with truffle ketchup)
2) "The Original" Duckfat Milkshake - vanilla gelato w/ crème anglaise & fresh Tahitian vanilla bean

These 2 items were a perfect after-dinner snack especially since I was still craving some local Portland cuisine after eating tapas at Central Provisions! The fries tasted amazing and were cooked perfectly. The milkshake also was well-balanced and refreshing.

Because of the crazy popularity of Duckfat, if you're looking for a table without much of a wait, come during non-peak hours or before opening 11AM!

name: duckfat
review_text:
Stopped here on the drive up to Acadia for a quick but worthwhile bite. Got there at 6:15 on a Friday and it was only a 20 minute wait for 3 people, which we thought was short given the great reviews and the small space.

As the name might suggest, they have fries fried in duck fat, which we paired with truffle ketchup and Thai chili mayo. I then had the overnight duck confit panini with asian slaw which sounds better than it was but it was still delicious.

The most delicious thing wasn't even on the menu...they had a special blueberry and buttermilk milkshake that we couldn't not order. It tasted like a creamsicle but blueberry instead of orange. A blueberry pie à la mode in shake form. We almost ordered another but the fries and sandwich were enough with the one milkshake.

Definitely worth a stop when you are in Portland.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Duckfat was on our schedule for the next day but with a 1.5 hour wait at another restaurant we wanted to try, we decided to drop in for a snack while we waited. Unfortunately there was a line out the door here too! We were super excited to find out that they did pick up orders.

Within 10 minutes, we got our poutine with duck confit to go, and sat in a nearby grass area. It was one of the BEST poutines I've had. The fries weren't soggy and perfectly salted, the gravy was delicious and not over powering, and there were actually cheese curds. This really is a one of the must try places in Portland. We may be coming back for more before we leave!

name: duckfat
review_text:
Came here around 6pm and there was a 45 min wait for 6 people. My family and I ordered several sandwiches, 2 large duck fat fries, milkshake, sodas, and I ordered the duck confit salad.

Duck confit salad (3/5): This salad was very small (I was expecting an entree sized portion) and there were very little pieces of duck. I would say that this is a very average salad. Don't get this unless you are trying to be healthy or need veggies.

Duck fat fries (4/5): I think the fries are all right, but the truffle ketchup is AMAZING.

Original milkshake (5/5): Get this. Yes, it's fat and unhealthy but it's very good.

Good service, good ambiance, and my only complaint would be that the space is very small and packed, so seats are not very comfortable.

name: duckfat
review_text: Oh man, came here at 2 and the place was still packed with a long wait. We opted to carry out, which was fast to order and about 20 min to get our food. We ordered a small order of fries, flight of sauces (ketchup and different mayo dips, total of five), and roasted turkey on rye panini. It was so delicious! The dips were good too, but the ketchup with truffle was by far the tastiest sauce. Fries were perfect. I see why there's a hype. Simple menu, delicious food.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Get the poutine fries with the egg and duck. And you will be happy. I'm drooling thinking about them.

If the wait for a table is extremely long, ordering take-out is easy and you can walk around the area while waiting for your food (wait for me was ~15-20 minutes).

While I would've been happy with just the poutine, the duck-kale salad was surprising good and tasted somewhat healthier after the poutine fries. The brisket panini was also drool-worthy.

name: duckfat
review_text: nice place. Make sure to try the poutine and smoked veggie duck breast salad. Just the homemade lemonade soda is too sour.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Waited for just over an hour to get lunch here, and it was worth the wait. This is a pretty tiny spot, so a wait time is going to be very common at anytime. The pager they give you provide about a block and a half radius. 

We had the Belgian fries with garlic mayo and truffle ketchup to start. I enjoyed the garlic mayo, but the truffle ketchup wasn't quite my thing (although everyone else loved it). We also had the poutine. Both of these together is a lot of fries, but we had a party of five...so it was perfect for all of us. 

My main meal was the caprese sandwich, which was cooked to perfection. 

For my drink I had the wild cherry phosphate soda,  which was very cherry and refreshing. They have a handful of craft sodas. I was too full to try a milkshake, but that will be on my list next time I visit Portland!

name: duckfat
review_text:
Review solely on fries. 

Best fries I've had. Duck fat adds an element of luxurious coating in your mouth that no other fries were give me. Fries themselves are crunchy, and they at first seem to be almost light and airy inside but the density is there.. perfect. 2 dipping sauces that came with it were nice and added extra flavors to the snack, though not needed.

We also got the signature milkshake. We loved it due to the fact that it wasn't overly sweet. It was perfect to dip the fries in this. They even split one for the two of us without asking - classy move.

Will be back for sure in the future

name: duckfat
review_text:
You've probably been told to go to Duckfat if you have't. And you should. They don't do reservations and they're (obviously) very popular/ touristy, so you will definitely wait. Luckily they're in a nice area so you will have plenty to keep you busy. 

I suggest getting the Poutine- you won't regret it and you won't leave hungry! It's not really an appetizer- you should consider it part of your dinner because it's dense. Also, ordering plain Belgian Fries is a good option since they come with their homemade sauces. I hate ketchup, but their Truffle Ketchup is to die for! Curry Mayo, too. If you want something sweet to balance out all that salt and greasy duckfat, get a milkshake. You can't go wrong with their Original or the Maine Blueberry (if they have it). Their Paninis are nothing special- I'd focus on the fries and shakes.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Portland is a great foodie town, and Duckfat is one of those cafe's that is putting the city on the food map.

We stopped in after our Mail boat tour to have dinner.  The place is very small, and several tables are family style which is fine with us.  The restaurant does get busy, so take note, you may have to wait a bit.  But the food is so worth it.

We started with an order of Poutine, crispy fries covered in a duckfat gravy and cheese curds, it was delicious.  We shared a Cuban sandwich as the Poutine was a good size portion. The sandwich was perfectly pressed and the meats tender and flavorful.  Top the meal off with a glass of wine and we were in Duckfat heaven.

name: duckfat
review_text:
If you are as obsessed with french fries and shakes as I am, you need to come here! Don't let the wait intimidate you. It moves pretty fast and i doesn't seem to go longer than 30 minutes. Even if it does you can go grab a drink next door. 

I got fries, poutine, panini and a shake. The all stars (and all I really needed) were the fries and shake. Everything else was just okay to me. 

Fries - The fries were obviously great, but it was the dipping sauce that won me over. The curry mayo and truffle ketchup were delicious. They also do a sampler of dipping sauces. 
Poutine with Duck - Still good, but I just preferred the classic fries and dipping sauce. The poutine didn't pack as much flavor. 
Duck Panini - It was just okay. Nothing amazing in my opinion.
Caramel Shake - It doesn't have to be the caramel shake, but GET A SHAKE! They are so delicious. Perfectly creamy and packed with flavor. They fill a glass and then give you a tumbler with extra. If that sounds like too much for you they do let you split a shake between 2 people. 

I will be coming back here every time I am in Portland, Maine.

name: duckfat
review_text:
We came on a Saturday, brisk but not too cold, around 6pm. We put in for a table for 8 and had about a twenty minute wait. We ended up seated in the window area, and our waitress was quickly on hand with menus and recommendations. We got both the regular poutine, with the delicious duck fat fries, cheese curds, gravy and an egg, and the shredded duck poutine. So deliciously rich, but of the two, I preferred the regular poutine. 

I also got the duck confit panini, which was sublime. After that dinner I needed to walk a couple miles on a beer crawl though... It was that rich (good). I can definitely see what all the hype is about.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Duckfat is a main attraction when it comes to the Portland food scene. With it's yellow and orange awning, it screams to be known on Middle Street, and their food is known by locals and tourists as something to be desired. 

When you walk into Duckfat, it certainly has a European vibe, with tables put together in a very tight space. It's always pretty dark inside, but with some modern lighting, it gives it an easy coolness vibe. In the nicer weather, there are also benches placed outside for outdoor eating. 

I have been to Duckfat on multiple occasions, but I have yet to actually eat at their location. If you plan on going to Duckfat, be prepared to wait at least 45 minutes. Due to their small location and limited seating, this causes wait times to fill up fast, and they do not take reservations. Because of the close proximity and the boisterous atmosphere, I prefer not to eat at the location, because I typically like to relax while out to dinner, however, the take out is where it is at. Just the other night, I wanted myself some poutine and a duckfat shake, so I ordered to go, as I normally do. I was told that it would take about 15 minutes. When I went to go pick up my order, I was able to skip the large amount of people waiting to eat-in, and I left with my food in hand! So, if you are able to get the take out, DO IT, and go eat on the Eastern Prom...or in the comfort of your own home. 

The food that Duckfat offers varies from sandwiches, poutine, fries, and some charcuterie and other spreads, which again gives it that European vibe. I have only ever had the poutine, which is beyond amazing. With the Duckfat fries...it's definitely a heart-attack waiting to happen, but it is oh, so good. I may not have had their sandwiches, but they do look amazing, and I will be sure to get one on my next visit. 

Duckfat also provides some milkshake options. I tried the salted caramel duckfat milkshake, and it was an explosion of caramel. Between the duckfat and the salted caramel, the flavors are incredibly elevated to make for a sweet treat. 

Duckfat is an establishment that is sure to stay and be a staple in the Portland food scene. I just wonder when they might expand their venue to fit their demand, however, it hasn't stopped them just yet.

name: duckfat
review_text:
I've heard so many great things about Duckfat and had never been to Portland before so knew I had to hit this place up before leaving. It did not disappoint! Came with a friend and waited outside 10 minutes before opening time on a Sunday so we were able to get seated right away. The space is small and seating is limited so I recommend coming early or you will most likely have to wait quite awhile as this is a very popular Portland eatery. 

Staff was friendly and knowledgeable. I got a blueberry cider to drink - refreshing! Had a hard time deciding what to get to eat because I wanted everything, but went with a small poutine topped with duck confit and a fried egg. Ahhhhhmazing. It's in my top 3 and I've eaten quite a bit of poutine. Definitely on the salty side, but hey, that's what makes my tastebuds dance! I don't quite understand people who like bland, underseasoned foods. Weirdos. 

I left Duckfat with a very happy belly and can't wait to go back and try some other things. Highly recommend this gem!

name: duckfat
review_text:
We went on a weekend and had an hour wait but felt we HAD to try it. We walked around and came back within the hour and found out we missed our table (our bad)...but they seated us shortly afterwards. We were against the wall - bar / stool style which kind of sucked but it's a small and very tight place to begin with so even a table wouldn't have felt any roomier I think. They give you a carafe of water when you get there which is always welcome - especially when it's warm outside. 

I got the New England Clam Chowder and it was super watery... I would not ever get again or recommend (unless you like bad chowdah). We also had the donut holes and the vanilla shake with the duck fat which my friends said they loved! 

The wall has a long blackboard / magnetized panel with tons of tiny magnets to give guests something to do / have fun with.. a nice touch since you're otherwise staring at bricks. 

I would try it again - mb next time I'll get the fries which look delicious.

name: duckfat
review_text: duckfat is overhyped. the poutine was salty, brussel sprouts had too much vinegar, and the duck confit was overpowered by the garlic mayo. we also got the meatloaf sandwich, which was the best bite we had while there, which doesn't say much. the fries were crunchy which was probably the highlight of our trip to the extremely hyped up duckfat. if you aren't a critical eater, this place would probably be fine, but if you're looking for a good bite, go elsewhere.

name: duckfat
review_text:
On our most recent road trip we happened into Portland, ME and found DuckFat. I am so glad that we did! The food was great, portions were appropriate for the price and quite filling, and the food was on point. Between my girlfriend and I we ordered three dishes (see below) and shared. We both got full and had left overs for later. 

Poutine with duck confit and egg 
PERFECT! Just the right amount of gravy and the cheese curds were the perfect size to hold shape but not overwhelm the dish. Egg cooked just right and balanced out the meal nicely. 

Brussels sprouts 
AMAZING! No wonder they are a staff favorite. Perfect balance of crispy and tender and the sauce was great. 

Duck panini. 
Hearty amount of meat. Great choice of bread. Crispy outside and tender on the inside. Sandwich was built so that the sauce and other add ons didn't make bread soggy on the bottom (even after being taken in a Togo box). So nice to have that attention to detail. This sandwich was also great cold later on the road trip. 

Eric, our server, was great! All of his recommendations were on point and made our meal wonderful! The rest of the staff was friendly and welcoming. 

I look forward to coming back and strongly recommend this to other travelers!

name: duckfat
review_text:
Last meal of our trip. We waited about 30 minutes to get seated at a communal table and had their signature duck poutine fries. I was not very impressed by this. It was quite salty and the fries were soggy (yes I know gravy makes it soggy). I disliked how some fries were extremely soggy while other fries were not. On top of that, the duck was extremely dry. We ordered the large for two people - per the waitress's recommendation - and could not finish it. It became more of a chore to try to finish it instead of enjoying it toward the end. My mom and I were stuffed by the end of dinner! If you're eating for two, order a small  to share. A large is just way too much food. 

Cubano panini- I was not a fan of this. My mom enjoyed it, but it was just eh in my opinion. Just wasn't a fan. I felt it was mediocre. 

I will definitely give this place another shot if I have time during my next visit.

name: duckfat
review_text:
I get why this place is so popular. Beyond the stellar Yelp reviews that brings all the tourists in, the food is equally excellent. Be prepared to wait. I somehow timed my visit just right and only had to wait about 10 minutes. The pagers work for about a block and a half and highlight a couple other bars and shops in the neighborhood you can visit while you wait. There is one large table for groups of 8, but you'll probably have a shorter wait if you show up solo or just bring a friend. 

I tried the Belgium fries. If you plan to sample lots of different things, just get a small. The fries are amazing. Honestly I've been to Belgium a couple of times and ate my fair share of fries and the fries at Duckfat were on par with the best fries I had in Brussels. You get your choice of dips. I tried the truffle ketchup. It was good. I also ordered the B.G.T. panini (bacon, goat cheese, and tomato). It was great, and Duckfat was partnered with a charity where if you ordered one of these paninis they would donate a meal to charity. Some of the other menu options I didn't get the chance to try - I was just too full - include milkshakes, doughnut holes, and poutine. There is also a nice list of local craft beers available.

name: duckfat
review_text:
This was one of my favorite restaurants in Portland. Seating is pretty limited so get there early if you can.

Skip the belgian fries and go straight for the Poutine, or get both, nobody will judge you. Always add the egg too, but the duck confit is up to you. I tried it once and thought it was ok.

The duck and kale salad is pretty good. There's chunks of duck breast in it mixed with grains and veggies. As for the sandwiches, I've had the pulled pork cubano, duck confit, smoked turkey, and the meatloaf panini's. They were all pretty good and I don't have much to complain about.

Milkshakes are something you need to try out too. The original duckfat milkshake and the sea salted duck fat caramel are pretty good.

name: duckfat
review_text: The cutest, most adorable, quaint & DELICIOUS little restaurant ever! The paninis are fantastic!! And the French fríes with a flight of sauces??? HEAVEN!! Good selection of beers & wine. And you MUST get a milkshake!! I adore this place!!

name: duckfat
review_text: Ahh Duckfat. Even in the winter when you're not battling tourists, there's still almost always a wait to get in. That's partially due to how tiny the space is- but I really enjoy how cozy it is. The food is pure comfort- whether you're getting poutine it regular fries, it's a religious experience. And their milkshakes are out of this world- my favorite is the blueberry, when they have it. The duck confit sandwich and pulled pork cubano are incredible and two of my go to sandwiches here. Perfect for a casual meal when you need a meal that will stick to your bones, especially on a cold winter's day/night.

name: duckfat
review_text:
3.5 stars 

This place specializes in duck fat fries two styles: plain with a specialty sauce or poutine. I ordered the poutine since there are such good reviews for it. They were incredibly salty, and the gravy left a lot of flavor to be desired. The fries were cooked well though and I think I would have enjoyed their regular fries more. 

We also ordered the meatloaf panini and duck confit panini. The panini bread was terrific in both--super crispy. The duck confit panini lacked flavor, and it was mostly just salty meat. The meatloaf was terrific, I would definitely order this again if I came back. 

The seating is limited, so it might be hard to get a seat at peak time. At some of their seats, there is a magnetic board with words so you can create some poems. Overall it's a pretty cute place and a solid destination to sit and catch up with some friends.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Came to Maine for the weekend to eat some lobster rolls, but wasn't disappointed to stop by Duckfat. We had to wait about an hour to get seated on a weekend evening, but that was a little shorter than other restaurants nearby. The place is small--there's two tables out in a covered patio area and maybe 10 tables inside. It feels a bit cramped, and I'm not surprised that the wait was so long! 

We shared some duck fries and brussel sprouts. The duck fries were good and came with your choice of dipping sauces, but it only came with 2 of them and you need to pay if you want to try the other sauces (though regular ketchup is free!). The fries were really good, but I couldn't tell anything special about them being fried in duck fat.  I got the butternut squash soup of the day and the leafy green salad. They both tasted fresh and were really good. 

Overall, I'd be happy to come hear again, but would probably want to check out the other restaurants in the area if I'm ever back in Maine.

name: duckfat
review_text: After trying to find someplace to eat for a few hours, I'm so glad we stumbled upon Duckfat! The place is super cozy and casual and the food is great! The poutine with duck is a must and the paninis are so perfectly crispy. I ordered a slow roasted beef cubano and I could literally taste each flavor in each bite. The service was great, prices reasonable, and they even had activities to do while waiting. My only complaint would be that I wish it was a bit bigger, but we didn't end up waiting long on a Saturday night. Definitely try Duckfat if you're ever in Portland!

name: duckfat
review_text:
The three stars are for the food, which is fine. But let me inject a dose of reality here....it's f*cking sandwiches! People are waiting in line hours for sandwiches and french fries. For me to wait in line, the sandwich better grow some hands, reach down my pants and give me the best five minutes of my summer. Come on people!

The restaurant is tiny with mostly communal seating. The staff is really nice and the food, again, is good. But don't you value your time? Instead of waiting in line, go spend those two hours in your hotel room getting the experience that this restaurant definitely won't provide.

name: duckfat
review_text: After hearing such raving reviews, I expected the food to be absolutely to die for. I tried the Duck Confit and the Pork Belly BLT paninis. Not the best. The only thing I would return for would be the Duckfat fries, WHICH, if that is the case, you can stop by their Duckfat Frites Shack located on 43 Washington Ave.

name: duckfat
review_text: O.M.G.  Wow.  If you LOVEEE fries like I love fries, you MUST try this place. I think I can actually say these were the best fries I have ever tasted! I only wish I had more time to make another visit there before leaving. They were so perfectly crispy with the right amount of salt. We also had the truffle ketchup & garlic mayo dipping sauces. In addition to these amazing fries we split a quinoa salad and smoked turkey panini. Both were also delicious but those  fries.....YUM!  I wish I had ordered a large order! This was easily our favorite lunch spot during our visit to Portland. The only negative besides the fact that we don't have one here in Michigan is how teeny tiny the restaurant is. Very tight space, I would try to go during an off time.

name: duckfat
review_text:
YO this place is gooooood.

I never really choose duck as my choice of meat but god damn the duck poutine was soo good, my mouth waters every time I think about it. I loved the wall with magnetic words ...great way to kill time while waiting for food.

The place is really small. No space really. On saturday we were not able to be seated but we returned on Sunday and we were able to be seated. The hostess was sweet, she remembered us from the previous day and gave us good ass fresh doughnuts on the house. So nice. 

I'd def go back for more. =D

name: duckfat
review_text: This is the best milkshake I've ever had. Duckfat was packed as soon as it opened and the service was still great. The food was hearty and good. Get your poutine with an egg on top it's only two extra dollars for greatness. Only real downfall to this place is the sitting. The sitting is cramped and you may be sitting elbow to elbow with a stranger. I would say no worries though the milk shake and poutine made it worth it to come back again.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Got the large order of fries with truffle ketchup and garlic mayo and their special drink of the day: a raspberry mint spritzer. The fries were definitely different in flavor and that's because they were fried in duck fat. But it was good! Super crisp, just how I like them. Also the ketchup didn't have much of a truffle flavor and the mayo was a little too rich for me. The flavor in the mayo was a bit strong, but overall everything was good! 

The service was good, but the space is small and BUSY! We got seated pretty quickly cause it was just the two of us and the lunch rush hadn't started yet but by the time we were leaving, there was a line out the door.

name: duckfat
review_text: Wow. The Duck fries with the egg on top is where it is at!! The kale salad is also very tasty, but the poutines are what steal the show here. The servers are also very friendly and they have local beers and wine available. Make sure to get the egg on those poutines though!!

name: duckfat
review_text: We stopped here just for fries and a chocolate shake and both were delicious!! We chose the Thai mayo sauce and it was good with a little heat. I was a little surprised that we had to wait (about 20 minutes) for a table in the middle of the day but this place seems to stay busy and it's very small inside. So glad we stopped by before leaving Portland!

name: duckfat
review_text:
Honestly, this is the BEST poutine that I have EVER had. This place does poutine better than Canada does. 

The service is awesome. The servers are all chill, personable, and efficient. The ambience is awesome, as well. If you go and there is a wait, I'm telling your right now that this is WORTH THE WAIT. It has a great beer selection, yummy sandwiches, and you have got to try a milkshake if you go. 

I was here this past weekend and my fiancé and I opted to go to this place twice in a 24 hour period. We got poutine and sandwiches the first night, and poutine and sea salted caramel milkshakes the second time. I am already salivating at the thought of going back the next time we visit.

Literally I love this place- everything about it.

name: duckfat
review_text:
The dang place is called "Duckfat" - it's impossible not to have a good first impression!

My best friend picked out this place when I was home for the holidays, and after our meal I confirmed we can continue our 21+ years of friendship. First off, the restaurant is quite small with communal seating, but they'll give you a buzzer so you can grab a drink on the block.

We ordered: Belgian fries (famously fried in duck fat, obvs), roasted cauliflower salad, slow roasted pork cubano panini, meyer lemon curd milkshake, and some beer & wine (no liquor). Well, if you go here and don't get the fries then ya goofed hard. They're completely addicting, and I loved the truffle ketchup! I also highly recommend the cubano; the pork was so tender and savory. We weren't a fan of the cauliflower, it seemed to have more raw than roasted pieces, and I hoped for more of a kick from the harissa. But it was nice to eat a vegetable while sucking down the rich sweet meyer lemon curd milkshake!

name: duckfat
review_text: Swung in here after an afternoon of daydrinking; they got me a seat at the bar quickly despite being really busy. It was recommended to me to try these fries before I die so I did, as well as a sandwich and some wine. The server was exceptionally sweet, despite having to serve the really obnoxious patron next to me demanding vegan items and then ordering non vegan items anyway. I like that the device they give you to let you know when your table is ready has recommendations for places to grab a drink or explore while you wait. If I ever find myself in Portland again I'll totally be grabbing a seat here.

name: duckfat
review_text: My favorite meal in Portland took place here, and it was awesome. The place itself is quaint and intimate, not at all what I expected but I enjoyed the cozy atmosphere. We came on a Sunday night and didn't have to wait. We sat at the bar and the service was excellent. The Brussels sprouts were outstandinggggg. Like out of this world. Tomato soup was also the best damn tomato soup I've ever had. You can just tell the ingredients are super fresh! My pork belly panini was excellent as well, but I was way too full to finish the whole thing. Most definitely one of the most flavorful meals I've had!

name: duckfat
review_text:
Food is about balance. Duckfat is woefully imbalanced, though the execution of this imbalance is really quite expert. I suppose when you aim high, you have farther to fall if you miss your target.

We ended up in here by accident-- it's a long story but it involves me being stupid, and we were hungry enough to Just Do It (like Nike, except without the massive donations to Republican candidates mixed with disingenuous marketing to liberals). I was unimpressed by the menu. The preparation was artful and the food tasty, but, with the exception of the caprese, the menu is extremely meat-and-bread heavy. I am mega-unimpressed by restaurants that rely on as their staples the meat-and-bread items with minimal creativity. I'm like, hunny, we ain't in Iowa, we in Portland! (I'm allowed to say that, folks, having spent a few glorious years in the land of the rising pork chop.)

If you ARE in the mood for a meat-and-bread meal, though, then definitely go here. The salad was good, but nothing to write home about.

Please figure your stuff out, folks-- you could really rock this experience if you reorganized your menu to be things other than "fatty meat between two pieces of grilled bread."

name: duckfat
review_text:
Tasty visit to Duckfat! We tried their signature milkshake - which was delicious and even richer than a usual milkshake. We also tried the fries of course - which were also unique and delicious. 
This is a cozy, hip spot with friendly staff. I wish they had a more extensive menu. Would definitely go back for milkshakes and fries.

name: duckfat
review_text: OMG the fries! Tiny and usually packed. However, it's worth it. Fun place and great food.

name: duckfat
review_text: Ok, who doesn't love good fries? Seriously! Love the crispy outside and depth of flavor, so satisfying! Garlic mayo dip is great and a favorite too. I'm not a huge fan of the sandwiches but they're good.  I will say though, if you are in the mood for a great shake and fries this place is a must! Good local beer selection too, so appreciated. Cozy but can be crowded, I like going with a group so we can snag a whole table. You might have to wait but it's worth it!

name: duckfat
review_text: Unique, delicious, fun! My friend had been dying to try Duckfat so we went in at lunchtime hoping to get a table. There was only a ten minute wait, not bad at all, and we were quickly seated in the small interior at a long table by the window. We all had milkshakes, which are big enough to take half home to-go and be full for hours. We also had the frites with the dipping sauces flight. Our favorite was the curry mayonnaise--I would have bought a bottle of it if it was on sale. The truffle ketchup was so weirdly addicting. The tomato fennel soup had such incredible depth of flavor and the grilled cheese croutons are genius. My friend had the smoked salmon crostini, which she enjoyed. Our waiter was fast and funny but never made us feel rushed even though it was crowded. This is a great spot for a top tier snack.

name: duckfat
review_text: Omg. Omg. Omg. SO worth the wait (and the general lack of atmosphere). The food here rocks. The drinks here rock. I would go here every single time I'm visiting Portland, if it were up to just me. Delicious. (Not suitable for the calorie conscious).

name: duckfat
review_text:
I don't live in Maine. For those reading this that are from Maine, I like your state a lot. I feel like a fisherman when I arrive and that's a good thing for me but you may go, "ugh, alright calm down with the whole nautical thing, Hector." But I love you all and I love your state.

Ok, food. That's why you're reading this. Duckfat was recommended by a friend. My girlfriend and I showed up there at noon on a Saturday. We almost didn't go in because people were standing outside and we thought, "no way there's no wait." There was no wait! So when passing by Duckfat, always ask! 

We sat at the bar. There was some cold at our backs occasionally but no big deal because we had great coffee, signature fries with curry mayo (droooooooooooooooooolin'), and a meatloaf panini. I hated meatloaf when I was a kid. If you would've told me I would intentionally order meatloaf later on, I would've said, "shut up crazy adult. I'm moving to Maine where I'm gonna be a fisherman and eat nothing that's meatloaf." But if I had a time machine, I would buy a meatloaf panini from Duckfat and bring it to little Hector in 1987 and ask him to eat it. I'm afraid it may age him too quickly and he will find cafeteria square pizzas beneath him but that's the risk I'd take. It's so good it will convince your younger self to question all his food choices.

Also, if you sit at the bar, you can see rows of panini's getting made and it's like watching a fashion show. It's beautiful and the male staff have beards and wear cool Duckfat winter hats so there's also a side fashion show happening with that. I loved this place. Be your own fisherman ("ok Hector, we get it") and come to Portland for the childhood-altering panini's.

name: duckfat
review_text:
It's funky, it's TINY, but people flock here... we happened to walk in at just the right time and had no wait, but the people behind us waited probably 10 minutes.  You are pretty well packed in inside and there are 2 tables outside (undercover with a heat lamp in winter).

To start: the 4 stars are for the Poutine.  Excellent!  If I was rating the duck confit panini separately it would probably only get 2.  Unfortunately, it lacked taste.  It really could have been a pulled pork panini, but had a duck price tag.

I was tempted to try some of the other items that looked great, but settled on the panini because it was our first time there and it appeared to be their specialty.  Next time (and there will be a next time) I'll go for what looks the best.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Went to duckfat on a hunch - there was a long wait everywhere else and it was getting cold. We decided to share their large poutine without adding anything else to it.

The belgian fries were pretty good though nothing crazy or course correcting. I thought they could have added more cheese curds and chives. The cheese curds were pretty good too but weren't enough for it to be a true poutine dish. 

Overall it was an okay poutine, there were a lot of fries so sharing was definitely the way to go at least for the large portion.

name: duckfat
review_text:
I randomly kept hearing about this place when I was looking up restaurants to eat in Portland. After seeing it's name so many times, I figured I had to try it out. Once getting here however, I was surprised to see how small it was. I was doubtful that this could be such a great place based on the size of the restaurant. However, the size of the crowd waiting for a table said otherwise. 

Since it's so small, we ended up sitting at a bigger table with this couple we did not know. They were friendly so it wasn't awkward or anything (although it can be).

We got the duck salad, poutines with duck and egg, cubano and duck confit sandwich. The salad was a little too salty so it wasn't too enjoyable. The poutine tho did not disappoint especially with the egg and the succulent duck meat we added. That sandwiches are also likely the best panini I've even had as the bread was perfectly pressed with a great texture and just enough filling to make it easy to eat and enjoy without lacking in flavor. 

You definitely have to try this place if you're in the area.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Filing this one under "overrated".  First, at 12:30 on a Saturday, there was a 90-minute wait.  "We don't do reservations."   How nice for you.  If you did, you wouldn't have to waste so much money on pagers.  Once we got in, the place was so cold my wife had to eat with her trench coat on.  Poutine was excellent.  Paninis were okay.  If we'd been seated right away, maybe I go four stars, but a 90-minute wait for a 30-minute experience is unacceptable.  Worth mentioning, as we walked by before noon (no idea what the place was -- never did see a sign) a group of young men standing across the street had the following exchange:

"Alright, I'm gonna head in.  Looks like a busy night."
"Looks like a long, bad night."

Maybe if they took reservations morale would be better.

A lot of hoopla for an underwhelming experience, particularly in a city with so many other options.

name: duckfat
review_text: This restaurant was recommended by a friend while we were visiting Portland. The two of us went at about 1230 PM on Sunday, and we only had about a 25 minute wait. The place is very small, but it was cozy and absolutely worth it. We split a large poutine with the duck confit, and we each had their tomato soup. It was excellent, and enough to fill both of us up. We also had a fun time playing with the word magnets on the wall against the bar where we sat. The service was quick, and the atmosphere was warm and cozy. We had a great time, and I absolutely would go back.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Omg,  the Fries at this place are worth the hype.
Wait in line, get an order and walk around town while.you are enjoying the fries.

name: duckfat
review_text: We stopped here as we had an hour wait at Eventide. We then had an hour wait here as well. We opted to order fries to go. You can pick either one to two sauces based on which size fries you get. We loved the garlic mayo and would highly recommend. The fries were cooked fresh and extra crispy. We took these to a bench on the water. Wish I had ordered a panini as they looked incredible on my way out the door.

name: duckfat
review_text: We have been to Portland a few times and never could get in to eat at this popular restaurant. We finally got in and we were so excited! I wasn't that impressed with the menu options, and was surprised that the menu consisted of mostly sandwiches and not more dinner style entrees. The panini's we ordered were good but nothing that correlated to the 3+ hour waits that are the normal there. The duck fat fries were very yummy  my husband ordered a milkshake and he really enjoyed it. Checked this place off our places to eat but wouldn't wait for hours to get in to this place to eat here again.

name: duckfat
review_text: When my husband and I walked through the door, we knew we were splitting a poutine, but what we didn't expect was how uh-mazing the poutine would be.  Belgian frites, cheese curds, duck gravy, fresh chives...add the confit duck for an additional charge and expect to say something along the lines of, "OMG, this is so good" after your first bite.  It's worth every savory calorie.

name: duckfat
review_text:
Poutine anyone? 

Coming from Jersey there's just no comparison to the poutine at Duckfat. Super crispy fries, cheese curd, savory gravy and even add a fried egg to top it off. 

The only way you could go wrong is if you try to share. Just do yourself a favor and order one to yourself. 

We also split a cubano sandwich, the actual name was a lot longer. However, it was surprisingly really good. 

My impression of this place is that it's super tiny. The good news is that they put your name on the list, give you a buzzer and you're good to get a drink next door or coffee down the street while you wait for a table to open up. We ended up waiting maybe 35 minutes which was great because it was just enough time for a few drinks to help open up our appetite. 

Definitely a cool spot to check out.

name: duckfat
review_text: I'm back again. This place is amazing. I try to go to local restaurants, but I usually don't do repeats. The poutine is to die for. Get it with the duck egg on top. Great service and atmosphere too. I'll be back again when I'm in the area.

name: duckfat
review_text:
I'm really torn on this review because the food is amazing, but not sure if the place is worth the long wait:

Pros:
-Fries are AMAZING!
-Dipping sauces are great! The sauce flight is so worth it. My personal favorite was the truffle ketchup. 
-The duck salad is small, but tasty! The duck is seasoned well and very tender. Staff accommodated my dairy allergy by swapping the sour cream dressing for a sun dried tomato dressing!

Cons:
-The place is TINY, and you're basically sitting on top of each other while eating.
-Our wait time on a late stormy Wednesday night was 20-30 minutes. 
-My boyfriend's duck panini was really spicy, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but took him by surprise since he's not a spicy food fan.

name: duckfat
review_text: Pretty good. The hype exceeded the reality. The waitress was very nice and helpful I just expected a come to god experience, which we didn't get. Again, I'd gladly eat there once a month, but not weekly.

name: duckfat
review_text: This place never disappoints!!! A tiny place, so be prepared to wait a little to be seated but it's totally worth the wait! I always go for tomato basil soup, poutine and Brussels sprouts. Their sandwiches are amazing as well! Highly recommend this place to anyone who is visiting Portland.

name: duckfat
review_text:
WOW. When my friend told me to visit Duckfat in Portland, I thought it was odd she recommended a poutine/duck place in a seafood capital.

The duck poutine was amazing and I still dream about it to this day. The sauce was thick and super flavorful, and the fries remained crispy even while drenched in sauce. The other items we tried weren't as noteworthy, but I would go just for the poutine. 

We had to wait for an hour, but were finally able to be seated outside under a heat lamp. A little cold, but definitely worth it.

name: duckfat
review_text: Yummy! I was worried that people talked this place up but it was worth it! We actually got it to-go and it was pretty fast!

name: fore-street
review_text:
Open kitchen and locally sourced, one of the most incredible restaurants in the region. Open only for dinner, strongly recommend putting in reservation a head of time. 

Ambience 5/5 -
Beautiful decor and lighting, centered around the open kitchen with a large oven. 

Food 5/5 -
The starter bread alone was already very good. We got the oven baked mussels, foie gras, and scallops. Each with distinct flavor, especially the mussels, which is a must try!

Service 5/5 - 
Just great, the waiters are knowledgeable about what they are serving.

This is a place where you expect great food and service, and they deliver it. Can't wait to go back and try other seasonal dishes. Strongly recommend!!!

name: fore-street
review_text:
To start with the you need reservations. They don't open until 5:30.  If you planning on walking in, go early get a reservation and then come back.   They fill up fast.     Be sure that our cell phone is charged, you will need it's light to read the menu.  It was very dark and the small candle on the table didn't make reading easy.  The overall decor is pleasant, just dark.   The kitchen is in the dining room.  It was enjoyable to watch food being made.  The appetizers and salads came out fast for people but entrees took a long time. The head chef and sous chefs looked the least busy of everyone.  For our family of 3 the wait for food seemed long.
