Those were by far the best scallops I've had and there were at least 6 or 7, they did not skimp at all. Same for the Halibut, amazing sauce with toasted hazelnuts. I wish we had room for dessert but sadly did not. If you're only in town for one night, I highly recommend this place, you won't be sorry.

name: scales
review_text:
I like my fish, it is a nice atmosphere,busy, hustle,
Open concept. Friendly wait staff
Beer selection is lame, need better options.
Fish entree's are pricey , I mean it is Maine not NYC.
Overall I would say it is a good experience.

name: scales
review_text:
Scales is a beautiful restaurant and even has fish and seafood on ice when you walk in so you know it's fresh. But don't worry, there's no fishy smell or anything to ruin your meal. There's lots of seating so we didn't have any wait, which was nice. And our server was very attentive and helpful. 

We ordered the clam chowder and lobster stew. I loved the stew and it had lots of sizable chunks of lobster. Definitely got your moneys worth there. The chowder was good too but I definitely prefer the lobster stew. We also ordered the Maine scallops (served with pork belly, pearl onions, and mushrooms) and it was delicious. Seasoned a little heavily but nothing unbearable. The scallops, however, seemed a bit overdone... not "melt in your mouth" as other reviews have stated but still, really good and worth it. However, we ordered the Brussels sprouts with duck confit and it was SO SALTY. It was so salty that we ordered dessert (chocolate frozen custard with almonds and toasted coconut) to offset the saltiness before attempting to finish our meal. The server said they have received comments about it in the past and it comes up every once in awhile, saying some chefs are tasting so many dishes and have a higher tolerance to salt... i don't think that should be an excuse and it is definitely something that should be addressed. Overall, everything was good but I probably wouldn't take my chances with the Brussels sprouts again.

name: scales
review_text:
Great place to eat.   We had a great meal here.  It is pricey but for good food, we are happy to pay the price.   The atmosphere is great.  Large open space with a bar, dining room and open kitchen.  When you walk in you can see you soon to be meal, swimming or already on ice.  The food couldn't be fresher than if you caught it yourself.
    My daughter had a hamburger and fries.  The fries were homemade and really good.    My husband and I both had the lobster stew. I was expecting more in it than a few pieces of lobster.  When I hear stew, I expect meat and veggies.  It was good, but I don't think it is something that I would order again.  
   For entrees, I had the scallop dish.  It was out of this world.    I love scallops and have them when I can.   This was the first time I got more than 3 on my plate at a restaurant.  I got the lobster stew because usually when I order scallops somewhere I leave the table hungry because there are so few.  Not this time.  They were perfectly cooked and more than enough.   I wish I could remember what the sauce under them was, but I can't.     The whole dish was spectacular.    I would highly recommend it.
   My husband got a mix from the raw bar of oysters and clams.  He said they were really fresh and enjoyed every bite.
   As we were leaving, our daughter got to listen to one of the chef's explaining how they choose their fish and were it is supplied from.  She said it was fascinating and interesting.  She is a 10 year old who loves science and environmental topics. She loves cooking shows so this was right up her alley.
    When we make it back to Portland in the future, this will be on our list to visit again.  
  I highly recommend it.

name: scales
review_text: Overall I really enjoy the aesthetic and the experience of scales but it's not the best food I've ever had or even the best ive had in Portland. The location is beautiful inside - right on the docks where you can see fishermen unloading the daily catch. The fresh fish and lobsters and oysters on display is beautiful and gets you excited to try. The interior of the restaurant is sleek and modern and has high Windows perfect for watching the sunset right on the ocean. The cornbread was lovely and warm and very cute. I do wish they'd brought us three though since we were a party of three and they only brought 2. The smoked salmon appetizer was average. The salmon was fresh enough but the star of the dish was the farm tomatoes. The scallops were delicious - I enjoyed the corn that added lightness but found the overall dish too heavy with the dairy or butter sauce. The halibut was average. Definitely not a problem with the portion but the fish felt over cooked and drowned in butter and sauce. The lack of green on the plate also felt heavy and without a new texture or break from the fish. The steak was fine and the potatoes were well cooked but I wouldn't order it again. Overall a great experience but not the most exciting food. Come here for drinks and the view.

name: scales
review_text:
Some old classmates were in town from DC so we decided to make a reservation at Scales to give them a sampling of some good food and even better atmosphere on the water. We weren't disappointed. 

The place was busy (late on a Tuesday) but we were seated immediately and our waiter was prompt in taking our drink order. We looked through the menu and decided to sample some items from the raw bar as well as the regular menu. First course included oysters (all Maine and all 3 types were exceptional) tuna tartare, octopus with chorizo and clam chowder. The chowder was simply divine and the tartare was so fresh and so well balanced it might be the best I've ever tasted.  The hands down favorite, though, was the octopus. Perfectly cooked, well seasoned and ever so subtly balanced in flavors with the chorizo, hazelnuts and a balsamic reduction. So. Amazing. Everything came out quickly and was served promptly. 

Entrees were a bit less adventurous, though equally delicious. We ordered both steamed and roasted lobsters as well as the baked haddock. The lobsters were amazing (no surprise) and the baked lobster is absolutely something that should be on any foodie's bucket list. Rich, savory texture and flavor topped with crunchy breadcrumbs - so good. But the star entree was the haddock. Served in a cast iron gratin with morels, fingerling potatoes and leeks swimming in a rich delicious cream sauce - this dish was pure heaven. I'd go back just for this. Seriously. It was the most ingenious presentation of haddock I've ever seen. 

We decided to sample dessert as well - blueberry crumble and a butterscotch sundae. Both were incredibly good. The crumble was warm and comforting and topped with delicious vanilla ice cream. The sundae was equally good and came topped with caramel popcorn. Such an amazing idea. 

We left Scales completely satisfied and altogether pleased with the experience. It was a truly amazing meal.

name: scales
review_text:
Not impressed overall. 

We know fish. We know good food.

I ordered clam chowder. When it arrived it was not hot. It was so SALTY I had to send it back. I love salt so it was so bad I couldn't eat it. Strike 1

My friend ordered the tuna appetizer and I tried a piece... not fresh. It tasted super fishy. Strike 2

My wife ordered the halibut. Looked good but it was super dry and over cooked. When we complained we were told it was due to the thick cut....?????
We prepare halibut at home all the time-thick/thin in between it doesn't matter. We never have a 
problem. They tried a second time and presented it raw in the middle....really??? Joke. Strike 3.

IF YOU CANT PREPARE A THICK CUT OF HALIBUT  PROPERLY THEN DONT OFFER IT!!!! 

I had the seared scallops that the waiter raved about and said it was the best dish on the menu.
They were ok. Inconsistent sizes of the scallops left the amount they were cooked from raw to over cooked.

Drinks were good and the place was busy. 

Overall I'm sure there are better places to eat in the area. 

Try somewhere else.

name: scales
review_text: The restaurant's appearance is so chic and had great ambience. We didn't make a reservation but we lucked out and was able to get a table. Our waitress was so pleasant and she was very attentive. We ordered a ton of different things to try. Shrimp and corn chowder, steamers, tuna tartare, bluefish pate and some other items I cant remember. But it was all really good. The only thing we didn't like was scallops ceviche which was very salty. The drinks were exactly what we needed after a long day of walking around Portland. Overall it was great and definitely recommend this place. I will be returning.

name: scales
review_text: I was there at 4:45 had a glass of wine, sat at the bar and waited until 5:00 for the steamed clams.  I watched them shuck oysters and then take their bare hands and put lettuce on a plate.  Bare hands really. I was mortified, I asked to talk to the manager, he really didn't care. In this day and age who can take a chance.  I would never go back.

name: scales
review_text:
Happy hour oysters!! Crab claws!! 

We heard Street & Co was the same owners as Scales and we loved Street & Co so much that we had to stop by Street & Co! 

Come early, like at opening. We came right at opening and managed to snag a bar seat. We got the chowder, oysters, fried whole belly clams, crab claws and lobster bisque. Everything was delicious. The presentation was unique. The claws were so good! 

I wish we were able to eat there for dinner, but it was all booked for the day.

name: scales
review_text: OMG, best food I've had...maybe ever.  We celebrated our 19th year anniversary while in Portland.  Scallops were absolutely amazing, service very good.  Not a place to go while on a diet as they cook with all the good stuff.  Unfortunately scallops will never measure up in life moving forward.  Have to try them at Scales.

name: scales
review_text: Made our way to Scales, a T&L recommendation, and were not disappointed. We had a blend of the oysters of the day and a couple of appetizers. Everything was fresh and delicious. The Halibut ceviche was my favorite, but the tuna tartare was also excellent. We sat at the bar. Expect to wait to sit even at the bar. There are multiple waiting lists-restaurant, outside and bar. You can sit in bar area but only order off bar menu. However that does include oysters! Sitting at the bar, you get full menu so if you are two, this is the way to go. Only negative was it is a bit loud.

name: scales
review_text: We recently visited Maine and had an incredible time in Portland. If you have not been to Portland, suggest you go as it was rated best food city of the year by Bon Appétit recently. So good in every way! We went to Scales and it was by far, one of the best and most memorable meals I had. One of the best things on the menu is the Grilled Octopus and Chorizo. It was divine. We also had Crab Fritters and Oysters--all excellent.  One cannot go to Maine without eating lobster and that is just what we did. Five of us ordered the lobster and some of us had Fish & Chips. All excellent and fresh beyond belief.  The food is great and the aesthetic is also amazing--wood and windows and old school lighting--cannot beat that it is right on the water as well. Service was fantastic and we left so happy. Worth it in every way if you make it to Maine.

name: scales
review_text:
Winter is my favorite time at Scales. Less crowds, $1 oyster happy hour and their winter menu scallops. Recommend sitting at the bar to watch some of the food prep and oyster shucking- they make it look so easy! Oysters, winter scallops, and bread are all must haves here. A bit pricey but worth the splurge. Summer time I would say reservations are needed unless you have some time to wait for a seat at the bar or table in "the lounge." 
Additionally, the space itself is beautiful. The windows let in so much daylight and you can see some of the working boats.

name: scales
review_text:
It was a tough place to get into on a Saturday night, especially without a reservation. However, the 1.5 hour wait was worth it.

I started with the grilled octopus with chorizo. It had the right balance of salt from the chorizo and a richness from the hazelnuts. The octopus had a great texture, with some moisture still present, but a tasty char.

Next up was the seafood stew. Again it had a good balance of salt, savory, and a hint of spice.

The service was great. I split a bottle of wine with another person who had a different dish from mine. The waiter paired a good Pinot noir that had minimal fruit coming forward, I.e. not a sweet bomb. It was a perfect complement.

Overall, the experience was a really good one. I'm looking forward to another visit.

name: scales
review_text:
What's not to like? We tried many small plates and an assortment of fresh local oysters.

Everything was fresh and delicious the server was knowledgeable and friendly, atmosphere trendy bordering on overdone but just falling short of cliché. I mean having fish that you're serving on ice in your entryway is original and I like!

Wish we lived closer!

name: scales
review_text:
I was part of a large group dining at Scales last week.  We'd been briefed in advance that, even though we had a reservation, our party would not be seated until everyone was present.  Managed to get everyone there on time except for one person; I explained that to the host who could not have been friendlier and seated us right away.  We were seated at a large, comfortable table between the bar and the main dining area.  From there our group could see the water on two sides and the views were stunning. I loved the large windows and airy setting.  Also, Scales is casual but still feels 'upscale' in a fun way (pardon the pun).

Several of us ordered specialty cocktails.  I don't remember the name of the one I had but I do remember it was delicious.  We were assigned two servers, which meant all of our food and drinks got to the table reasonably quickly--very much appreciated. 

I had the clam chowder, the roasted lobster, and the butterscotch sundae with caramel popcorn.  I recommend them all.  After all that food, I could barely walk back to my hotel but it was worth it to taste so much deliciousness.  

Scales is expensive but if you're looking for someplace special with excellent food, service, and ambiance, it's the perfect choice.  I recommend it.

name: scales
review_text: Great restaurant. We were in town just for the evening and our hotel recommended this restaurant. The food and service were outstanding.

name: scales
review_text:
Great place all around... really enjoyed our meal and the ambiance!
Nelson

name: scales
review_text: The food here was amazing!!! Our first time in Portland and Scales was our first 5 star meal!

name: scales
review_text: Such an amazing spot! The place was warm and inviting even with the open floor concept.  Great views of the harbor and the water. Our server was friendly and knowledgeable about the menu. There was a great variety of oysters.  I had the hake which had a mouthwatering sauce with hazelnuts.  Potatoes cooked to perfection.  My mom had the pan roasted lobster which she said was perfection.  Definitely recommend for a nice dinner, small or large group!

name: scales
review_text: So good we came twice! The first night we came in for drinks and appetizers. Everything lives up to the expectations. Such flavor. The next night we came back and we ordered the same appetizers as the first night: grilled octopus very tender with amazing flavor, halibut ceviche so of the best ceviche I've had, crab fritters, and then everyone ordered lobster rolls for dinner. The dessert also did not disappoint.

name: scales
review_text: Scales is good. Right down by the water in the old port, depending on where you're seated you may get a view of the dock/boats! I've been here a couple times now. Service is always superb. We had a reservation at 8 and they accidentally only took down that we were a party of 2 when there were 3 of us. They were able to still seat us and we only waited 10 minutes. They came by 4 times to let us know they were getting a table ready for us. We kept it pretty simple and stuck with the smaller dishes. The food was good but I left thinking we could have ate somewhere else. Nothing we got left me thinking "wow I could eat that everyday". All that said, I'll be back because my family enjoys this spot when they come to visit.

name: scales
review_text: Everything was very fresh and delicious!! Despite it being a full house, the food was prepared very quickly. Exceptional seafood!

name: scales
review_text:
Great dining experience open kitchen exciting be ready to dine with a hundred noisy diners great cuisine but nothing you could not cook at home I.e. cod poached in butter pricey at $38!!!
$5 in fish market

name: scales
review_text:
Not impressed. 

We had a large party for a special event. Maybe this is where we went wrong. Anyway...

We arrived and our table wasn't ready. The maître d was super and arranged another table for us. Great! That, for me, was the last thing that went right.

Two dozen oysters arrived shortly after we sat down. We hadn't ordered them. It took 10 minutes to notify the server, during which they sat on our table, and after that we're delivered to the poor folks who actually ordered them. 

My calamari appetizer was very good. 
I ordered an octopus appetizer for dinner because I love octopus. It arrived looking wonderful - two large, nicely cooked tentacles. I took a bite - it was cold. I waited 5-10 minutes to get the servers attention and asked "should it be cold?" And it shouldn't so he took it back to the kitchen. No follow up; no suggestion it would be our soon. Nothing. 

Scallops arrived. They were put down in front of my sister and father, but they hadn't ordered them. They sat on the table a couple of minutes, and were then carried to another table- maybe the right table?

10-15 minutes later my octopus returned, or should I say half of it returned. Seriously one tentacle returned. Totally perplexing. Unpleasant. Just bad. 

Go to Street & Co instead. Check out my review. It was excellent.

name: scales
review_text: We made reservations and were seated quickly. Excellent service and food. We tried the clover leaf rolls, baked haddock, greens salad, fried oysters, crab and corn chowder and the blueberry/peach crisp. Totally awesome food!

name: scales
review_text: Went here for my sister's medical school graduation dinner.  The setting is pretty with the water in the background and the interior is nice and comfortable.  The food was excellent.  The lobster roll was fresh and delicious and the scallop entree was amazing.  The service was very nice and professional.  I would definitely recommend.

name: scales
review_text: Overall, good experience. Disappointed our table was not ready upon arrival, although we did arrive 10 minutes early. Also disappointed there was no coat check. Food was amazing and service was great! Solid recommendations from Charlotte! Great prices, great location, very good service.

name: scales
review_text: Excellent food, relaxed atmosphere, friendly, highly competant staff. Super organized and quick service without pushing us to hurry. Great dining experience overall - and the view adds to the pleasure.

name: scales
review_text:
This restaurant is delicious!! So many dishes to choose, from raw bar to salads to lobster rolls. We had the seared halibut and creamed corn with scallops. And then the buttery dinner rolls..heavenly pillows. 
Definitely set a reservation, which we did not and ended up getting an app and drinks to pass the time. 
Service is attentive and friendly

name: scales
review_text: So glad we decided on Scales for dinner tonight. The wait was really long so we took our chance and put our name on the list for the bar seating. Nice concept! Sat down right away. Service was incredible. We tried the corn bread, oysters(served right on the bar in a bed of ice!) clam chowder, halibut and the blueberry peach crisp. My only complaint was that I ran out of room to eat more! Everything that we had was first class.

name: scales
review_text: Really liked this open-space, open-kitchen restaurant with excellent food and atmosphere. Loved the entrance door and restaurant location  sort of hidden in an alley, which surprises you once you come into the main restaurant which is so bright and open and with a nice view of the harbor.  Food was excellent, fresh and on point.  Oysters were amazing and so was the pan seared scallops and roasted lobster which I took a bite of my wife's plate.

name: scales
review_text: Came in here on a chance that it may be good. It was amazing!!! Had the grilled halibut with potatoes. Perfectly seasoned and grilled perfect. Had the apple pear cranberry crisp for dessert. That put me in my happy place. I will come back here if I am in town again

name: scales
review_text:
Been here three times, each time hoping ordering different food items but each time leaving disappointed. I suppose the best bang for your buck here would be the burger. Much better off at some of the other restaurants owned by the same folks (i.e. Fore Street and Street and Co.). 

First of all...who charges for bread anymore?? Scales does. For $4 or so, you can order small bites of very greasy bread (no matter which one you pick...I tried them all). Skip the bread. 

Oysters were fresh and delicious, but nothing special. 

Clam appetizer was FULL of sand. When we ate the first round of clams, the shells were mostly crushed and many were small and dry. We flagged out waiter over after tasting 3 or 4 clams to ask if the dish was supposed to be this crunchy. The waiter was kind enough to replace our dish with another. This time the clams were fatter and juicier...clearly, we got the bottom of the barrel last time. There was also less sand. 

The Scallop entree was good. Scallops were ever so slightly overcooked as the inside flesh started to get a little chewy. Flavor was good and sauce was thick and creamy. 

Cheeseburger - your standard, but juicy burger with a butter bun. French fries were a-ok. Nothing memorable. 

One pro that you can't find in the area is valet parking (for free).

name: scales
review_text:
A plate of oysters, a few littlenecks and some appetizers later and I'd like to go back.

The razor clam appetizer was especially good.  Maybe the cocktails I had made it a bit difficult for me to describe them, but they were cooked well, seasoned well and just all around great.  Octopus was very nice as well.

The cocktails were strong and the service was impeccable.  I'll be back next time I'm in Portland.

name: scales
review_text:
We were in Portland for a long weekend and found it to be a great foodie city! Well, Scales was the capstone of our trip. We saved the best for
last! The lobster roll was the best we had, and we had several. Oysters were so fresh and tasty. The scallops were prepared to perfection. And the craft cocktails, the West End and the Paper Plane, were very well mixed and blended. Our server Sandra was so knowledgeable and helpful. Attentive without being intrusive. Perfection all around!

name: scales
review_text: Had the mussels app which was really good and the lobster stew which was also very good.  The seafood stew was definitely lacking substance.  Tiny portions of whitefish, squid and clams.  Definitely overpriced for that.  The scallops were really good but kind of small.  Not sure if it was worth the hefty price.

name: scales
review_text: This establishment has a valet service that leaves cars idling for the patrons. They could be left idling for hours on end which is terrible for not only the local environment, but also is a massive contribution to climate change.

name: scales
review_text:
NOTE: This review is for cocktails and dessert only.

I would never have a reason to come to Scales. The menu is almost entirely meat/seafood products. And well it should be with a name like "Scales" and a location *literally* on the water. But I was tipped off that they were serving some of the best dessert in Portland, so... 

The first time we came was late on a Thursday and we asked the host if we could just grab dessert and cocktails, he told us the bar was open for that. "Could we maybe sit by the windows instead? We're having a date night!" He didn't seem to like that request much. Dismissively he said, "the answer is always no if you're not going to eat dinner" (side note: seriously?!), "but I'll let you this one time because we're not slammed."

Not the best first impression, I'll tell you that much.

We were seated by the windows and, despite it being dark out, still got to watch a lobsterman set-up his boat for the next morning. Their location is offering hands-down one of the best views in the whole city. Being out on - and almost at level with - the pier like that is something incredibly special. Try to come here for dusk sometime; it's a breathtaking experience.

We heard the cheesecake was out of this world, and it changes seasonally. We were told that for the holidays/winter it's Spiced Autumn Cheesecake (with cider caramel, harvest granola, and a maple flavored whip cream) for $9.00. A bit steep, but well worth it - it tasted exactly like one would hope it would given the listed flavor profiles. I think this was in the top three cheesecakes I've ever had; well worth the price tag. And, come to find out they make all their desserts in house. Then again, why wouldn't they? The folks who own this place are also the same people behind Standard Baking Company. This alone makes me want to come back to order the cornbread with salted honey butter... I wonder if I would be forced to sit at the bar if I only ordered sides though?

The drinks were also amazing: my partner got the "West End" (whiskey, fernet, bitters, and orange) and claims it's one of the best, most balanced drinks he's had in a long time. I got the "Autumn Sangria Infusion" (red wine, herbs, spices) and it was good - it wasn't cloyingly sweet or as heavy as I was expecting and as such made for a solid nightcap choice.

name: scales
review_text:
We stopped in here on a wintery night, Judd looking for seafood and not expecting much more than that. This restaurant turned out to be absolutely fantastic. The  menu had plenty old standbys, but also some very creative twists on regional seafood. Our waitress Isabella was the best. She was very helpful in narrowing the choices for us and her recommendations were right on the money. 

I had an appetizer of scallop carpaccio with caviar and limes that was superb. The contrasts of the flavors really popped. For entrees, I had the branzino done in a almond butter sauce. I have had branzino many times, but never as good as this. My wife had pan seared scallops with bacon and a sauce that she loved as well.

name: scales
review_text: Fantastic! Beautiful space, right on the ocean and seafood that represents the best that New England has to offer! Starting with the freshly shucked oysters  and clams the selection was varied and the individual examples perfect packets of delicious briny goodness! Plus, the way they serve up these beauties is quite fun too (see photo). We followed that up with a beautiful and tasty plate of the smoked mackerel and the salt cod fritters, both of which offered plenty of crunch, savory  flavors and the right amount of chew to please. Believe it or not we actually followed up all the delights  by ordering entrées. The saffron fish stew for me, a delightfully rich treat filled with a nice variety  of seafood and my wife went with the very nicely done fish and chips! I am so glad we finally tried this wonderful spot! Everything really was so delicious (cocktails too)!

name: scales
review_text:
Slick as a salmon, the harbor side seafood emporium deserves it's rep as one of the best in Portland, Maine. It's a long rectangular room that gets full up as quick as the guests fill up on the freshest the sea has to erp up. If they gave you a shovel and a pail instead of utensils, I'd be happy. I'd even be happy going all cave man with no cutlery or plates. So there. 

The decor is ceiling to floor glass so it's like eating in a fish bowl, which is most appropriate given the menu and location next to where the daily catch is off loaded. The menu is not for guppy tummies, either. Sure, you can order dishes by the half but they are still ample for a fisherman's hunger. I suggest you bag the half biz and step/swim up to the task at hand. Wow factor food.    

The place is what Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco could've been instead of the third stop in the air conditioned motor coach (full of oddly dressed tourists) to buy an octopus coffee mug or a ball cap in the shape of a shrimp. 

Scales is a sophisticated yet casual, light, airy and open space. There are lots of tables with elbow room to work that lobster like they was payin' you to eat it. There's a Raw Bar and a Long Bar (at least 100 feet...could be imbibing is the local past time), to enjoy the full bar options. 

Feel free to discount the opinion of Yelpers who only gave 3 stars, dragging the overall average down as one complained at being asked to wait in the bar for 10 minutes. It ain't like a segregation at Gitmo, bisides this place is busy for a reason. Or the one who dissed the joint because he/she/it didn't like sea food. Yo, what was you thinkin? Re-read the name of the place, you enter through a boat door, and the place is drippin' with lures for decor. Go ahead, order the Short Rib Pot Roast but don't roast the place because you don't like fish. You probably wouldn't like Rome either because it has too many old buildings.

The Vibe: Low key. Locals, yocals, and out of towners (and some Yelping downers),

The Bar Program: Lot's of crafty brews, a few ciders for orchard insiders, and an extensive wine list with many by the glass choices. The signature cocktails tend to be on the sweet side So? Just like our server Mikela who was truly sweet, helpful, humorous and enthusiastic. 

The Bug Light was a flute of boozy fruit (which describes half the patrons at the Red Velvet Lounge in OC). Eight Bells Rum, Barrel Aged Maple Syrup, OJ and Brut (as opposed to O.J. the Brute). 

The Fort Sumter was Tanguerey Gin, Muddled Fig, and Fresh Lime served up. Now fully muddled and addled myself, let's eat. 

The Food: This is Sea-forward dining. Duh! Right in the harbor where the fishermen deliver the sea's bounty daily. This is a working restaurant featuring the freshest and best of God's little swimming creatures this side of the Tsukiji Fish Market in Tokyo. Nothing here that's been fried even knows it's been fried. No residue, no oil, no puddle of rendered fish fat on your plate, nothing heavy here so order a pile of whatever sings to you. All good. 

Whole Belly Clams. These puppies were flash fried and served with Smoked Jalapeno Aioli and Lemon. Most places don't bother with the bellies (unless you're at a bar in Vegas). Usually you get only strips (also something reminiscent of Vegas). Here, you get the entire clam corpse, fried by an expert. Each belly had a crisp coating form fitting crunch surrounding a briny juicy little treasure. (Yeah, you can find that in Vegas too, but it will cost.)

The Special off menu offering the night I dined there was Diver Scallops. They too were fried, but it just seemed so right, and besides isn't America's favorite flavor crispy? Generally, scallops are too delicate to fry but the line cook manning that station had earned his fins, gills and tail badge and was truly a Fry Master...and I ain't shuckin' you, neither. And it came with a small hill of fries, done just right...my guilty pleasure. 

The Lobster Roll is a local legend as well. Oh, what a sweet fresh lobster! Look close and make sure in ain't still wigglin' in your bun (figuratively speaking). It is nestled in a split top, house baked, butter grilled roll, filled to over flowing with the crustacean that would drive a Rabbi off the Kosher cart. Served simply with Chives and Mayo, oh, I say, oh how wonderful was that little roll in the Bay? 

Dessert: No complaining that your own clam belly is obscuring the view of your shoes. Have the Concord Grape and Apple Pie baked in it's own ramekin with a crust as flaky as the current Presidential Transition Team. 

Scales tip the scales to terrific.

name: scales
review_text: Huge disappointment!  worst meal in Portland by far.  Our table pretty much ordered the entire menu which was very aggressively priced but the description of the items on the menu sounded very appealing.  Let me preface this by saying I love salt but every item was so salty nobody finish what they ordered and you could not taste any real flavor.   We scooped spoonfuls of salt out of the muscles and made a pile on a side dish,  Yuck!  Our curly blond waitress with lots of tattoos who was originally very friendly ignored us for the rest of the night after alerting her.  After shelling out several hundred dollars and leaving hungry we went across the street for mediocre pizza and a huge drink to counter act the salt which ended up being the highlight of the evening.  We did not see any form of management on the floor or we would have certainly alerted them in hopes of correcting it.  In short, bad service, bad food, acceptable but loud atmosphere, overall not a good value as I have had much better food and service in Portland for far less.

name: scales
review_text: Absolutely delicious, fresh seafood!! The atmosphere encourages good conversation and the décor is simple. I thought it was pretty cool that there's an ice machine dropping crushed ice from the ceiling as well as a huge lobster tank. The Caesar salad was delicious, the Brussels sprouts were a little odd (they're shredded) and the baked stuffed lobster was amazing! I got some sort of cornmeal Brad pudding for dessert, I didn't really dig the flavor or the texture, but the frozen custard was delicious!

name: scales
review_text: Fresh seafood combined with an ambience that says nice but not stuffy! My fave in Portland. From hotel staff to our Uber driver, to our chartered lobster cruise, everyone recommended Scales. Lobster was amazing and appetizers were tasty as well. The seafood stew was also very good. A memorable experience!

name: scales
review_text:
If you only have one night in Portland, go here for dinner - it's fantastic! 

Everything from booking the reservation to the service and the quality of the food was amazing. Scales is conveniently located on the water and has a beautiful ambiance. The interior is elegantly decorated but not over the top or stuffy. 

Our waiter could not have been nicer and was super friendly. He recommended our dishes and even gave us breakfast recommendations for the next day. He was spot on with his wine pairing suggestion and gave us the right amount of attention when needed and space to enjoy our meal. 

What we got:

Half dozen oysters: all local, fresh and delicious

Crab and sweet corn soup: great flavor - creamy but still light. Pleasantly warm and a generous portion of crab meat 

Baked stuffed lobster: "the best lobster I had in Maine" - Alex; the buttery breadcrumbs were a nice addition to the lobster, but not overpowering to the lobster meat. It came with a small cornbread and slaw

Hazelnut halibut: this dish was so flavorful and different. The brown buttery sauce had a ton of whole hazelnuts and was drizzled over a very large halibut filet. There were a few fingerling potatos added to the dish that were also great

Caramel popcorn and vanilla ice cream with whipped cream: 

Bottle of dry white wine from France

Two cocktails

Total bill: $208

name: scales
review_text:
Remember that Yelp's utility is to locate restaurant options in your locale and not to rely upon the vacuous negative reviews of seemingly entitled yet inexperienced diners. There is no better case in point than with Scales, a new, exciting restaurant on the Maine Wharf trying to achieve in its first year what all fine restaurants offer- my wife and I managed a reservation for the first time last night, though we live a scant three miles out in Casco Bay. From the raw oysters at the bar to the ginger cake dessert this was a wonderful experience- here are some tips for you: don't arrive feeling the world owes you a thing; have a reservation or content yourself with remaining at the bar, sampling appetizers, and promising yourself you will return. Ask your server what's good- they know. Look around you and feel what it is they are doing, from the music to the families to the fresh catches on display- realize the seafood is largely brought in from next door, not even trucked from across town. If you want a red carpet, boot-licking, and deferential bows, go to Manhattan.

6/30/18

Two recent ferry trips across the bay to our favorite restaurant- (how do they ALWAYS seem to find a table for us?) - the scallops carpaccio is a must try- one of you at table should order it, pass it around for each a taste, then ask your server how many scallops are used to make the dish. (!)
Oh, have I told you just how fine the oysters are? That our two granddaughters ate 17 raw oysters between them, and that Vivian, age 7, in response to her mother's "Vi-vi, slow down and chew your food!" said , "Momma, you don't chew oysters!"

10/20/18 great anniversary dinner- wine, oysters, fried clams at the bar, then dinner of fluke special and short rib pot roast. The scene humming with families, happy people.

name: scales
review_text: Amazing seafood! Great service. Our waiter Ben was charming and helpful. We don't have one bad thing to say about this place. If you're in Portland, make your way to Scales and soak in all of its upscale, rustic charm.

name: scales
review_text:
Food=fantastic 
Our waitress Sandra= fantastic
Host=not very nice
That's it in a nutshell. Reservation for 6 people. Ridiculous antiquated policy of not seating a party until the entire party is standing in front of the host. Not taking into consideration that the bar was packed, valet parking backed up, so as we waited for our 6th person to walk in the door, (all of 12 minutes) The 5 of us stood in everyone's way instead of being seated at our table, where we could order drinks.... the sassy (man) host would not budge. Come on, if 5 out of ten of your party is there, just seat them! 
On to the positives.  Scallops, fried clams, stuffed lobster, seafood stew, multiple orders of their special breads, clam chowder, crab and corn chowder, multiple sides and fabulous frozen custard desserts. All wonderful. We also sampled wines and specialty cocktails. We were completely happy with our food and cocktails. Our waitress Sandra was knowledgeable and very friendly. 
We spent quite a bit of money this evening, it's not cheap....but we really felt the food was worth it. Now if the owners could just get some friendly accommodating hosts I'll give them 5 stars!

name: scales
review_text: Went here with my husband on our last night in Maine. We wanted a more upscale, "date night" atmosphere (but also seafood), because we mostly ate at hole-in-the-wall places during our trip. Was a long wait without a reservation (understandable) but it was so worth it. The lobster roll and the fish that my husband got were so good. If we're ever in the area again I'd definitely check it out.

name: scales
review_text:
We had a reservation and didn't want to be late so the others in our party dropped us off to park.   When we walked in Adam the host refused to seat us without the other couple.  When I explained we ate at both their sister companies (foresteeet and street and company earlier this week he said too bad that's their policy.   HOW RUDE!   We waited for them to walk in and the were graced with his attention.  

If not for the other couple I would have walked out the door.   Business must be really good to abuse your clients like this. 

FIRE ADAM.   HE IS NOT HELPING YOU WIN CUTOMERS.    

IT GETS BETTER.  THEY CHARGE FOR BREAD!!!

name: scales
review_text: We came here on our cross country tour and I was so excited to get authentic Maine food!!! The only thing I wish I listened to with the reviews is the stuffed lobster. It's literally mostly bread crumbs with very little lobster meat. I wish I had just ordered the regular steamed lobster, but I was so enticed by the description of the stuffed lobster I just had to try it. Luckily I wasn't that hungry because it was quite small lobster. It did however allow me to have delicious desserts they offer! Once we come back to Maine we will be back!!

name: scales
review_text:
Came here when Scales had a $1/oyster happy hour deal. So we ordered 40+ oysters and had the best time. If you happen upon a similar deal, just try them all. Many times.

If you can, sit at the oyster bar and marvel at the freshness of the oysters being shucked for you, then neatly presented on a row of ice. 

The awesome and patient bartenders make it an even sweeter deal.

name: scales
review_text: We waited 2 hours for a table but oh goodness was it worth the wait. The place is super fancy hipster, nice big open space where you can see the fresh fish and chefs cooking away. We got the clam chowder and the crab/corn chowder. Both were fine soups. The clam chowder had a lot of clams and oooh boy were they fresh. We also got the mussels--blown away. Definitely the best mussels I have ever had. They should give you a whole loaf of that delicious bread to soak up the sweet godly sauce the mussels are served in. My friend got the seafood stew, it was pretty good though it could have used some hot sauce. I had the steamed lobster which was bannnggiiinnnn. Definitely the best lobster I had the whole time in Maine. So buttery, so fresh, so delicious. If you want a table make a reservation in advance or get ready to wait. Either way it is 100% worth it.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I've found a new favorite spot in Portland in The Honey Paw!

One a recent long weekend trip to Portland, we got in to town on the later side mid-week and  The Honey Paw was one of the few restaurants open that was in walking distance from our hotel. 

I cannot explain my regret in not having been to this place before!  Service, cocktails, food, decor - everything hits the perfect sweet spot of being hip without being inaccessible.  We started off with a couple cocktails, British Invasion and Oath Breaker, both of which had the perfect balance of sweetness, spice, bitter, and booziness. They were so good that I got a second British Invasion. Next, we split the Fry Bread with Uni Butter - HOLY HELL THIS WAS AMAZING. The bread had an exterior crunch but an interior that was soft and chewy - the chiles, yuzu peels, and herbs strewn atop made each bite unique. While the uni butter was fantastic - do not skimp on this wonderful condiment with its ocean-y and umami interplay of flavors.

We each got a wok fried noodle dish. My husband got the Pork & Crab Mee Goreng (mien noodles, Jonah crab, chili crab sambal, deep fried shallots)-. The noodles had a wonderful chew to them. The Crab was plentiful. And the sambal that topped it was TO DIE FOR. The entire dish had the most amazing combination of textures. It was straight up amazing and I will definitely be ordering a dish of it all for myself next time we're there.  I got the Wok Fried Ramen Noodle (razor clams, littleneck clams, pork XO, preserved lemon, pickled onions) - again, an absolutely delicious dish with great textures. The fried clams were delectable and the onions (there were a few different kinds with different treatments) were plentiful without being overpowering.

We finished the meal off by splitting the Soft Serve ice Cream - their soft serve flavor of the day (burnt honey) with caramelized honey, honeycomb, and chocolate shell. This little sweet treat satiated our sweet tooth without being too sugary.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I'm normally not a fan of Asian fusion, especially a trendy Asian fusion sort of place, but The Honey Paw did a lot of things well.

It was my first meal upon arriving in Portland and was a nice introduction to the eclectic food scene here.  I was seated right before happy hour ended, so I ordered the $3 char shu pork bao.  What came was a surprise as I was expecting a handheld stuffed bao, but it was actually more of a sheng jian bao.  The filling was tasty, but only luke warm.  The pastry part was really good.  The best part was actually the pickles that came with it.

I also had the fry bread with uni butter.  This one was less successful for me.  The bread was a bit tough when I expected something more fluffy on the inside.  The uni butter was my main problem with the dish.  It did not have much uni flavor.  I did like whatever the seasoning on the bread was since it had a great umami-ness to it, but it would have been much better had the uni flavor stood out in the butter.

The beet salad (gado gado) was my favorite item of the night.  It was this complex salad with a large variety of textures, flavors, and temperatures.  It was really fun to eat as no two bites were the same.  The beets were fresh and sweet.  The fried potatoes and hard boiled egg added some substance.  The peanut sauce was super flavorful and packed a punch.  It's a really memorable dish.

For me entree, I had the smoked lamb khao soi.  It was okay, but ate really rich and lacked some depth.  The problem was in the broth itself.  The broth was somehow one-note even though it had all these ingredients that should have given it depth.  The lamb was well cooked and had good flavor.  There were lots of pickled vegetables in it to give some acidity and break up the broth.  But it didn't quite come together.  It was also served sort of luke warm and with all the pickled vegetables, quickly cooled down.  My thought was there was just too much stuff in it.  Give more broth and tone down the additions and it'll seem more hearty and warm.

Overall, a surprisingly good meal.  I like that they melded Maine ingredients with a pan Asian style.  I'm not sure it's a place I'd crave and want to return to, but it was a good experience.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Walked by this place too many times and today was the day I popped in. I'll claim this one for research purposes since I was scoping it out for a company dinner. The food looked great from the reviews, but given I'm scoping for my work.. I have to think of those that would probably be less adventurous when it comes to eating -i mean asian fusion sounds intimidating to some of my boomer coworkers. 

I started out with the lobster cakes and a singha beer. This app is perfect to share among 2..or 1 if you're extra hungry. I was the latter and even if there was 2.. I would have tried to sneak the majority of it. I ordered the fried chicken sandwich for the entree. This had a kimchi-buffalo sauce with lettuce and cheese. The bread seemed to be made in house and the chicken had a nice crisp thin breading to it. It came with kimchi potato chips. Needless to say.. The plate was licked clean. The last bit is by far what you HAVE to order - the soft serve. Jesus this was good. Simple vanilla. Dark chocolate hard shell drizzle. Honeycomb cookie crunchy things. That bowl was licked cleaaan too. 

In case you couldn't tell... I'm a fan. My research scoping was well worth it and I'll definitely be booking them for my work outting. Though "fusion" places can intimidate some.. This one isnt one of them as the chefs here craft some amazing food.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
If you didn't know, Honey Paw is another great creation from the Big Tree Hospitality group-- the same people who own & manage Eventide and Hugo's. I have to say, this strip has THE BEST food in town. The lines for any of these restaurants can get crazy long, and there isn't much seating either. Expect to either be seated at the bar, window, or at the communal table. 

We tried the Honey Lobster Toast: lobster tucked tightly between two perfect buttered toasts, drizzled with a cream sauce over, Lobster Wontons: this was my fave! It tasted like a perfect wonton soup with a twist of lobster, the Halibut Crudo: chili, citrus, & dill were what helped make the dish (However, I still prefer Eventide's crudos), the Soup Dumplings: 2 small pieces, and the dumpling was too doughy (I prefer Empire's), Fried Wings: lime & chili, with coconut on top, this somehow tasted better the next day served with rice!, and lastly, the Nam Prik Ong: rigatoni, spicy pork, and chicharrones SO different, but in a good way.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Our group of normally remote co-workers were in the same place on the same day so we opted for a longer-than-normal lunch. When our first choice ended up being closed for nearby construction, I was a bit dismayed to stop in here as I'm a noodle lover but just wasn't in the mood that day.

I was pleasantly surprised to discover their lunch menu includes three unique sandwiches all served with some equally unique kimchi chips, so we all went with either the fried chicken ("napa kimchi, iceberg, spicy mayo, american cheese") or tofu ("cucumber, basil, pickles, spicy mayo, hoisin") sandwiches. 

My friends both gave high marks to the fried chicken; from sight it's clearly a nicely-sized sandwich that's not over-sized for cleverness' sake, yet big enough to be filling and have a great look on the plate.

The tofu sandwich has a soft, flavorful bun and a large slice of tofu, though it's pleasantly easy to eat and didn't fall apart the entire time. I didn't get much of the flavor I was expecting from the basil or hoisin, and the mayo wasn't particularly spicy, though it was tasty.

Both my co-worker and I added some hot sauce he requested which gave the sandwich a bigger flavor profile and complimented the soft bread and tofu well. While this was definitely one of the better sandwhiches I've had in some time I do think they could zap it with some of the more complex flavors their menu suggested.

The kimchi chips were close to BBQ flavored chips though clearly not as processed or as clumsy with strong flavor, and the portion size was right on.

The room itself is small, though the bar is nicely sized and there are excellent window bar-style seats that are likely wonderful in summer and fall.

I'm looking forward to heading back to try some of the noodle dishes next.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
This place changed my life. 

I'm serious. This is one of those restaurants that checks off all the food wishes on a diner's list. Delicious, creative food? Check! Fast, attentive service? Check! Desirable ambiance? Check, check! Amazing cocktails and well designed bar? Checkkk!

We came here on a recommendation and because of all the good ratings on Yelp and attractive food pictures on Instagram. We were certainly not disappointed! 

We sat at the bar since that was the only seating available for two people. The restaurant is a bit small so prepare ahead of time so you aren't waiting. 

We ordered:

1.) Fried Bread and Uni Butter
2.) Mushroom Tom Kha
3.) Vietnamese Masa Crepe (aka Banh Xeo)

Everything was delicious. I need to go back and try more food! We were stuffed and didn't order the dessert but that was definitely my biggest regret. Can't wait to come back!!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I had some leftovers from this place that a friend gave me at work, AND IT WAS AMAZING.

I wish I wasn't so busy so I could actually go in there and sit down and eat more of their delicious food.

Great location.

Food tastes amazing.

Great prices.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I FINALLY made it to the Honey Paw's Happy Hour!  I had always kind of avoided the HP in the past due to long lines AND my unease over the whole communal table or side-by-side-bar-type-seating thing.
Luckily when I arrived on a random Monday, it was not crowded at all.  I prefer not to sit next to my companions, so picked a corner of the communal table.
While waiting, I started by ordering a glass of wine for $5, an order of three pork bao ($3 each) and 2 orders of chicken wings ($5 each).  Everything, plus a big bottle of chilled water came within minutes, just around the time my friends arrived!  Perfect.
We devoured everything pretty quickly and then added an order of sticky rice, and an app called gado gado from the regular menu.  The sticky rice was wonderful, well seasoned with just the right crisp to soft ratio.  The gado gado was a HUGE hit.  Beets, hard boiled eggs and potato, in a delicious peanut sauce.  Would absolutely get this again!
Finally, we ordered each kind of soft serve they had on the menu for dessert.  The vanilla honeycomb was fantastic as expected, but the big surprise was the beet and turmeric soft serve with oat crumble.  While skeptical when ordering, it turned out to be one of the more memorable parts of our meal!
Overall, I kind of got over the seating, as our waitress, the food and my company were all wonderful.  If you are looking for a place to sit and face your companion for a conversation, this is not the place for you.  
On the other hand, a person dining solo, would feel really comfortable here.  I can definitely see the HP being a great place for dining on your own!  The communal tables encourage cross connection and socialization, which, depending on what you're looking for, could be a definite bonus!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
My friends and I visited the Honey Paw after giving up on going to the restaurants with even longer lines in the same block. We went during prime dinner time and so still had to wait almost an hour to get seated. I got the smoked lamb khao soi and pork and crab mee goreng. The lamb khao soi was delicious. The broth was flavorful and fragrant and rich at the same time. The pork and crab mee goreng was mediocre. It was too salty and lacked any interesting flavors.

We got the famous honeycomb ice cream for dessert. I LOVED it. It came with a coating of chocolate on top and delicious crunchy honeycomb for topping. I would visit again just for this ice cream!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
OMG... that honey comb ice cream. I'll start with dessert, if you save enough room for it, which is difficult because everything on this menu is so freakin good. The Brussels sprouts, the fried chicken (which could feed four people with the half portion), the noodle dishes. I have yet to try something I wasn't over the moon about. 

I also love the seat arrangement. Not an intimate dining experience.  You are in the mix, at a table that will seat more than one party.  Excellent concept, great execution, definitely worth a stop while in Portland. I'm adding the Honey Paw to my "Amanda's Tour of Portland" list...

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Big Tree Hospitality runs this block, but sadly The Honey Paw is a swing and a miss for me (marking the second after Eventide).

I was admittedly apprehensive about a white-owned Asian restaurant, but the menu sounded phenomenal. I've been lucky enough to grow up in NYC and travel around Asia, so I've tried many amazing Asian cuisines with their harmonious blends of ingredients and spices, and complex, richly infused flavors. Unfortunately the dishes here lacked the depth of flavors I was hoping to find.

The lobster wontons were kind of basic with no discernible lobster flavor, and the sauce straight up tasted like a slightly bland miso soup. Moving on to the lobster curry, I actually enjoyed this the most. However, it smelled like it would have some tangy, sour notes on top of savory ones, similar to the laksa it's inspired by. Nope. It was savory and spicy but was missing that something extra, so it fell a little flat for me. Still, I enjoyed the noodles and the lobster was cooked very well. The bun cha gio was... fine. The meatballs were a bit tough and dry. This dish tasted like the standard Vietnamese one, although you can find it for half the price elsewhere. I did enjoy the honey soft serve with bittersweet chocolate and honeycomb.

I'd say this is a decent place to go if you have no real options for Asian food around you, but if there are any at all, please check them out instead.

I don't think I'll wait for a third strike with Hugo's.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Holy crap I love Honey Paw. We've never had to wait long to grab a seat, the staff is friendly and welcoming, and every single thing I've had here has been spectacular. Please do yourself a favor and try to save room for dessert.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
The fact that I decided to go to Honeypaw to spend my first paycheck must tell you something! I LOVE IT HONEYPAW! I've been here twice and have had incredible experiences both times

We arrived on a Friday night in July at around 7pm. There was a 20 minute wait. 
Wok Charred Broccoli: This actually was my least favorite, a little too salty for my liking. 
Assorted Pickles: SO GOOD! Very fresh. Highly recommend. 
Vietnamese Masa Crepe: Delicious! Very unique item
Lobster Curry: To-Die-For 
Dessert: Mint ice cream was a great way to end the night. (Did they know mint is my favorite flavor?)

I just really love everything about Honeypaw. The atmosphere is bright, clean, and modern. Service is always spectacular. I always leave full and happy! This is one place I will confidently say is worth your money!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Seating is along the walls and then a large community table in the middle; which honestly could have been a few inches narrower to make it feel less cramped. I can't forget to note the dope bathroom sink, and soft toilet paper! 

I was hesitant to go to Honey Paw since it's an asian fusion restaurant, and the real reason I went to Portland was for the seafood. But I'm so glad we went because this ended up being one of the best meals of the entire trip.

I will definitely be back next time I'm in town!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Winter in Portland is so much cozier when you're spending it at Honey Paw. The combination of good drinks, wonderfully comforting food and vinyl spinning in the background just can't be beat. In my most recent visit my group decided to try quite the sampling- lobster toasts are always a must, along with the fried chicken and whichever version of crudo they're currently serving up. We also had their dry bread with uni butter, wok charred cabbage and a special that I'm forgetting the name of, but was chicken thighs on a stick in the most delicious sauce. We also had the uni udon (my personal favorite- you can't go wrong with creamy crab noodles), wok fried rice noodle and nam prik ong. To top it all off we finished with the famous soft serve. Do yourself a favor and come cuddle up over here while we don't have hoards of tourists around!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I think I found the crown Jewel of Portland! I decided to try The Honey Paw after a friend gave me a gift card. Sunday's I love to go out for brunch but often find myself solo. I usually feel awkward dining alone but not for one second at Honey Paw! 
I sat at the bar and the bartender, David, was the first Gem! A sweet, cool, down to earth fellow was happy to engage with me. I ordered a noodle soup which was just a mouth full of yum! I have never had a bowl of noodle soup so good! It had lamb and coconut broth, but I can't recall the name of it
So good! Then I had the lobster toast which was amazing! Truly! I love food and all that I ate here was five star, but there is more to it than that. The service and the atmosphere is also 5 star. I feel like I was among friends and that is what will keep me returning to Honey Paw. Thank you !

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Perhaps my favorite meal I had in Maine and I went to over 10 restaurants while I was here.

Small spot that is right next to Eventide (owned by the same folks) but it has floor to ceiling windows with beautiful natural light.

I could have had a couple of bowls of the Smoked Lamb Khao Soi, as well as the honey soft serve ice cream with a chocolate shell and caramelized honey (check out the pictures). I would drive back to Portland just to have those two dishes. When you are in Portland, this is an absolute must.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I was super impressed with this Asian fusion spot from start to finish. 
 The Honey Paw's lamb curry was my favorite dish of the night on our self-guided food tour.  You could have only given me a bowl of the broth, and I would still rank it as my favorite dinner dish in Portland.  We also loved the charred cabbage starter and honey soft serve finisher.  If you want to be wowed by a meal, then The Honey Paw is where you want to be.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Pretty good food but not as amazing as all the other reviews have stated. 
Ambience is minimal and trendy, and the wait is much shorter (if there is even any) than Eventide next door. 
Service is friendly and efficient. 
Prices are standard for the area. 
Would recommend to try once but having tried once, not a place I would return to.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I have waited a while to get to eat here. What great place to come on a chilly summer Portland night. 

1) The location is great. Easy to find close parking. 

2) The bathroom was very clean. That was great. 

3) I have wanted to try the lobster Curry for a while. The broth was really good. A little spicy but not overwhelming. It was a coconut curry and therefore had a creamy texture to it. The lobster pieces, were cooked right. It was delicious. The rice noodles had a good texture. 

4) Staff was nice to us which after long day was great feeling. I would  come back here to eat.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Well, let's first talk about seating. The Honey Paw knows how to put maximum seating in a teeny space. Other Portland restaurants, pay attention! Yeah, so a big communal table isn't perfect but at least more than 15 people can eat a meal at a time. 

The honeycomb light fixtures are adorable and the design aesthetic is chic, modern, and fits the establishment's vibe. Light and airy, The Honey Paw feels huge in a town filled with small eateries. 

For appetizers, we got the pickles. Meh. It is a wide assortment of pickled veg, and the flavor is there. But ...it just wasn't my favorite.

The Bun Cha Gio was my entree. The meatballs are tasty and the cold vermicelli with all the accoutrements was packed full of complex, bright flavors. It's a definite crowd pleaser. My companion got the ramen that's where I'd say Pai Men Miyake has this place beat. There are simply better ramens in town. 

The desserts we ordered were the honey soft serve and the banana split. Yyyaaaaaassssss. Both were good.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Want a quick recommendation?: COME HERE. Food is PHENOMENAL, service is outstanding and the atmosphere is superb.

A little longer review: I came here for lunch, unsure of what to expect I was simply blown away. I ordered a nice cold soda and a bowl of noodles (mushroom one)and I couldn't get enough, just simply delicious. Also ordered the soft serve ice cream.....mouth watering good. Service here was pretty good, very hipster vibe, definitely loved the ambience of the place. I'd come here once a week if I lived in the area. I believe this place can get crowded so plan ahead!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
If you're a foodie, this is the place for you! They do their own twist on different Asian foods. The place itself is kind of small. It's communal and bar seating inside and tables for 2 outside. Probably not the best spot for a large group. 

Warning: we didn't do any entrees we just got a variety of appetizers and dessert. 

Pork Bao - Tiny, but delicious! The outside is a little more fried than a traditional bao, but the egg and pork inside was great. 
Squash Blossom - You couldn't really taste the crab in this. There wasn't too much flavor in this dish. 
Fry Bread - The bread was fantastic. The peppers and miso butter really elevated the dish. It tastes great and has a good kick to it. 
Honey Soft Serve - Really good, definitely worth trying especially if you love honey. The honey comb crisps were a great texture addition. The chocolate helped make the dish not overwhelmingly honey.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
OMG. How is this place not as crowded as the next door Eventide restaurant? This is solid Asian food. My gf and I came here Sunday early afternoon because Eventide was jam packed. We walked into Honey Paw and it was pretty empty.

Their cocktail menu looks delicious (and it tasted delicious too!). We shared the lobster toast (puts avocado toast to shame). The lobster toast is like a play on the shrimp toast that you see at dim sum restaurants. It was really enjoyable and greasy (but not too greasy). The rare beef salad was fresh tasting and it just made me feel healthy. The hash browns were clean tasting and not oily at all. The gochujang sauce added some nice flavor to it (though it wasn't spicy enough). 

The rest of the menu looked delicious. I wanted to eat more here, but I also wanted my gf to try Eventide, so we wrapped it up and went back next door. 

I will definitely be back next time!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
This restaurant is up there with my favorites in the northeast. I'm not being sarcastic when I say this either. I love love Eventide and since this is in the same restaurant group, I came in with my husband while waiting for table at Eventide. We got to the bar, ordered a couple drinks, and instantly decided to stay put instead of going back to Eventide.

Since that initial visit, I've been back every time I'm in Portland. Even if i have dinner plans elsewhere, I stop in to grab a drink and a bite.

The standouts on the menu (which changes often  and there are specials everyday so don't blame me if they're not available!):
- every crudo (especially the fatty tuna (toro) was EXCEPTIONAL)
- the lamb khao soi, which is award-winning (deservedly so!!)
- fry bread & uni butter
- lobster laksa
- soft serve!

Service is friendly and usually efficient (though we've seen some slow days). This is such a unique restaurant that pulls from so many different cuisines -- I can't name a restaurant elsewhere that is not only so innovative, but nails each and every take. 

Next time you're in line at Eventide, walk next door to Honey Paw -- you will not regret it!!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Honey Paw has solid east-meets-New England fare. The interior is modern and has a casual bar atmosphere with lots of light. 

The entrees are a little on the pricer side, but the food and service are great. 

We had the yellowfin tuna poke ($15), one of the daily specials. It was presented in a very delightful way. We also had the lamb khao soi. While the broth was slightly on the over-flavored side, the dish was balanced and the lamb was a welcome addition. 

The atmosphere is definitely one of the highlights at Honey Paw. Their dishes, cutlery, and glassware are all well-curated. 

I'd recommend Honey Paw if you're in Portland!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
For lunch, we decided to visit The Honey Paw. We opted for 3 seats at the bar and our server brought over waters and took our drink orders. Here's where we over ordered! We decided to try the lobster wontons, the chicken wings, and the fried oyster ssam appetizers. The lobster wontons were tender and came in a savory broth. The oyster ssam was bold, crispy, and also came with delicious kimchi. The chicken wings are unique, crispy, and a great mix of sweet and savory. For entrees, we ordered two of the ramen while my husband opted for the banh mi. 

I'll start off by saying that I did enjoy my ramen and others will like it. I'm pretty particular with ramen and I would have preferred my egg to be cooked longer. I also felt the noodles were on the thick side for a ramen. Both other entrees were enjoyed. On the way out I popped into the women's restroom and I just loved the natural looking sink. Very cute touch!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Definitely different than the rest of the food in Portland. From the same people who run Eventide.  The food is solid albeit a little rich at times. Still worth visiting and giving it a try. The fry bread was delightful as was the thai soup.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
The Honey Paw is an absolutely beautiful space full of natural light from their nearly floor-to-ceiling enormous windows. Add on top of that the warmly decorated interior (golden and yellow hues, honeycomb printed lights, exposed brick, etc.), and it's an entirely inviting, comfortable experience unlike any other spot in town. Whether you're seated at the windows, at the communal table, or at the bar you're sure to have a pleasant time. That's what I loved the most about THP: the space.

For me personally, where things fall apart a bit is the food and the service. I came for lunch recently with a friend and there were two servers: one who was working mostly the floor and was very friendly, one who was working mostly the bar and scowled at us the entire time. Guess which one we had? It's always frustrating when you see other customers having great interactions with their server while you're left wondering what you personally did to make yours not like you. Let's assume our server was having a bad day. Unrelated, but why was the music SO LOUD at lunch time? I was sitting directly next to my dining partner and could barely hear him. 

The food I think is beautifully prepared and presented, but it's just not for me. At the suggestion of a friend I got the pickle plate... which was absolutely delicious: I'm pretty sure I could just eat those pickled shiitake mushrooms all day. We also tried the scallion pancakes which were fine, just not especially flavorful, and much more crispy and airy than I was expecting. We filled them with our pickled veggies - just needed some sriracha to make it perfect (I should have asked)! I ordered the tofu sandwich for my main. It's a good banh mi don't get me wrong, but I've had better for cheaper at other places in town. Finally, skip the cake, get the ice cream - GET THE ICE CREAM. And don't forget about the half carafe of tap wine which is also pretty fantastic.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: G still reeling from the lushness and spice of that bowl of smoked lamb and noodles. OH YUM! I think I need to move to Portland so I can nose dive into a bowl like this three times a day! OK, twice.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Big Tree Hospitality has pleased me for the 3rd time! Good job, guys! While not nearly as wow-factor as Eventide, The Honey Paw still serves up some exciting foods. I wanted to try almost everything on their menu when I came for an early lunch on Friday. Most of their specials weren't ready to be served for lunch, only dinner, but they sounded good. I ended up ordering the lamb soup which had a warm, deep rich flavor. It felt like the perfect soup to have on a cold day but it was quite warm outside BUT IT WAS STILL GOOD. Me and 3 friends split 2 of the honey soft serve. They were a great cap off to the meal, and I loved the hard chocolate that topped it.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: This place is baller--a friend and I wanted to try it, but had dinner reservations so decided to grab a cocktail and an app at the bar. We were lucky to  be seated! I got a lambrusco, my friend got a cocktail, and our bartender was lovely. We ordered one app to share--a lobster wonton that came in an amazing broth and made me want to cancel our reservation elsewhere and stick it out at THP. Next time I'm traveling to Portland this is at the top of my list of places to try. Yum!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I took my fiancé here for lunch, we were recommended this place by multiple people so we decided to give it a try. $11 for a "spicy" cocktail that didn't have the spice we were looking for. I ordered the Bun Bo Hue for $18 and it was pretty bland, VERY small, and the soup to noodle ratio was way off. Lots of soup, hardly any noodles. (In the photo, I lifted the noodles to make it look full)
My fiancé ordered the Khao Soi (lamb meat) it was pretty flavorful, not soupy like we were expecting, also very small portion for $22. (We both agreed it should've been served over rice) overall, not satisfied for spending $60 on lunch.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Really loved this place! When you walk in there's a lot of open seating and the bar is highlighted with nice lighting. Party of one so I opted for the bar seat. 

I had a cocktail special and it was great! Also ordered the soft serve with honey comb and it was truly special. Everyone was so nice and it seemed like a neighborhood place. Genuinely good food and craft cocktails. A win win.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I can't say enough good things about this place! My boyfriend and I stopped by for a bite around 1:30 pm on a Sunday. They were serving their brunch menu, which we didn't even realize they served brunch! We decided to get a bunch of small plates/appetizers to share. 

Fry bread with uni butter - amazing!! Must try, we both loved this.

Coconut lime chili wings - Possibly the best wings I've ever had. The sauce on these is amazing. Also love that they're covered in toasted coconut flakes. 

Soup dumplings - These are really good! There's a good balance of the pork and crab flavors in these unlike some other dumplings I've tried where the crab flavor is overpowered by the pork. Just an FYI, these come with 2 dumplings per order. 

Bao bun (filled with smoked char, cream cheese, and capers) - These are really good! Reminded me of a warm bagel ball type snack. There is only one per order. 

Seasame balls (filled with miso caramel apple filling) - Wasn't sure what to expect with these but overall they were good! Served warm. I thought the apple caramel filling tasted a little like a yankee candle but my boyfriend loved these. 

And of course we had the caramelized honey soft serve. I expected this to be super sweet between the ice cream and honeycomb topping, but the dark chocolate shell really balanced it out. Love love love this. Overall we had an amazing meal! Great food and service.

PS: I also love that the music they play is actually records that they change out behind the hostess stand.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Simply divine. Best Asian fusion food I've ever experienced. If this place were located in Boston - I'd be bankrupted. 

The fry bread with miso butter is sinfully addictive; the vinegary pickled peppers were a nice acid punch to cut the fat. The star of the meal were the lobster wontons. In essence these were basically lobster raviolis, prepared with Asian flare; the dashi they were swimming in was so amazing that I almost asked for a straw to suck it up. The lobster toast was a great fusion of basic white girl brunch, Maine, and Asian cuisine; such a great bite of flavor combinations. There was a tuna poke on the specials board, which I had to have, and you have to too. Great balance of salt, heat, and textures.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I came here for lunch on a Sunday after hearing good things and seeing that it wasn't too crowded. Three of us came in and were seated at the bar right away.

The service itself was great! Since it was raining outside and the inside was air conditioned, I asked for hot water. The bartender came back a couple minutes later with an adorable metal teapot and small cup, warning me that the water was hot. I appreciated the accommodation a lot!

Two of us ordered the lobster curry, and another ordered the Hokkaido ramen. The lobster curry soup was very good. It had a powerful, sour flavor that you'd expect from Thai-inspired food, and the soup itself was beautiful. I wasn't a fan of the noodles though. I thought they were too soft and didn't add anything to the dish.

I also had some of the ramen. I wouldn't get this, especially for the price ($17). The broth didn't have much depth or complexity that you'd normally want from a ramen. The flavors were just salty and slightly tangy. The noodles itself, I was a fan of, and the egg was cooked well where the yolk was perfectly runny. However, the overall flavor was very meh and not unique. I've had much better for much cheaper.

I've heard good things about the The Honey Paw, so maybe I'd try something else off the menu if I came back in the future. However, I just feel like I've had better, and especially for the price point, this place was just meh to me.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
This place is more a 3 1/2. The service was super-attentive and quick. The bartender was impressive, making drinks, taking orders, and being charming. The food was excellent. We got drinks and a few appetizers: the lobster wontons, the masa crepe, and the tomato salad. All were delectable and expertly prepared and composed. 

The atmosphere though... First off, all of the seating is high stools. The longer we were there, the more aware I became of how inaccessible this place is for people with mobility issues. The communal seating didn't bother me, but the fact that I couldn't bring my paraplegic mom here did. The place is also loud. Like, REALLY loud. A big part of it is human sound bouncing off hard surfaces, but there was also music that competed with it. As much as we enjoyed the food, we were eager to leave. 

If you are looking for awesome food in a club-like setting, this place is for you, but if you want to enjoy your food in a more low-key atmosphere, trek further down the street.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Stop two on our Portland food crawl....
Another recommendation from friends and family, THP is an Asian-fusion restaurant that populates many a "hit list" for foodie destinations here in Portland, and it lives up to that rep, for the most part.  We were lucky that we planned this visit as our first meal of the day at around 12pm because come 2ish the lines formed for all of these clustered restaurants.  As the pictures show, the decor is kind of austere, and the table layout is awkward if not bordering nonsensical.  We arrived to an empty restaurant by and large and at first we asked to sit outside.  The tables for two are minuscule.... certainly not big enough to support multiple tasting dishes that the menu features.  We sat at the sole larger table in the sunny area which could maybe seat three and we were quickly ushered away in case a true threesome would show.  With the wind slightly gusty we went back inside.  The dining area has seats at the bar, seats on the periphery of the windows and a giant island in the middle of the place.  Not knowing where we "should" seat ourselves, we sat at the island.  Guess what??????? We were told that there too we were not allowed to sit in case a bigger crowd came...... ummmm what?  The place was empty.  And so, feeling somewhat confused and awkward through this bizarre exchange we cozied up to the corner piece of the bar where there would be enough counter top to order multiple dishes.

The bartender was great!  He hooked us up with a cold dry sake and navigated us through the menu and specials, highlighting what he deemed were the better choices.  See pics: among this array, the papaya salad was a fresh melange of greens, herbs, papaya and peanuts in a luscious and spicy fish based dressing.  The lobster won tons came floating in a savory miso broth with ingots of chili oil (?) and veggies like mushrooms etc.... hands down the best of our dishes.
