The tuna dish was slightly light on the tuna and heavier in the cucumber and shaved papaya but the flavors were on point as we found ourselves scooping the veggies into the rice chips that adorned this dish.  The Banh Mi offering was harmonious to the rest of our dishes but I didn't detect the chicken liver mousse that it advertised among the thicket of cold cuts and Vietnamese condiments that topped the meat.  As a huge fan of Kimchi I of course had to sample theirs and it was really flavorful with a great balance of spice, garlic, fish and chili.  My portion may have been a tad over-sauced over the cabbage but the point was well taken..... really really good stuff!!

Now that the awkwardness of the layout is known I would totally come back here to sample what I couldn't today, and now I know how to approach the space.  Hipster vibe abounds here..... over-tatted staff and vinyl turntables for the music.... you know what I mean...... so I'll just put that out there, but the food and flavors are legit!

Robbo, Parker, CO

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
My first thought when arriving was, wow this place is hipster heaven- besides the menu of pricey trendy Asian/noodles, they have a literal record player with a wall of records to choose from. So if that's your jam, this place is for you.

We started with the Asparagus Salad, which was a refreshing bite of food. I got the Lobster Curry for my main, which was chock-full of lobster chunks and had just the right amount of spice. The rice noodles were wide and short and kept slipping off of my chopsticks, but otherwise it was a tasty, solid bowl of soup. In contrast, the Smoked Lamb Khao Soi had good flavor but barely contained any lamb, a bummer for how pricey it was. 

Food aside, I'm not really a fan that every seat is a high-top (not super comfortable for short people), and your only seating choices are along the bar (which rims the exterior of the restaurant) or one common table- this is definitely not a place to come to have an intimate meal or to have a serious discussion. On the plus side, we basically walked right in, unlike its sister restaurant Eventide which always has a crazy line (worth it though IMO). 

Overall, it didn't blow me away (that would be Tiger Mama in Boston, for this type of cuisine) but I did enjoy my food.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: I don't remember what the dish was called but it was the best thing I have ever had in my life. Noodles with a pork/crab mix. Everything else looked awesome too.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Sorry for the delay...this was definitely a different experience for me food wise.  Though it was a pleasant experience and the atmosphere was perfect for me and my Yelp Leader.  We had a great time chatting and learning about each other over various food options.

I would need to go back and try things again or even different options.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Like many townies, we often avoid this stretch of Middle Street during spring, summer, and fall. There are at least two restaurants that have constant lines out the door and the overflow makes the other places busy too (and great for all of them!). 

However on this particular Sunday we had some friends visiting with Honey Paw high on their list. I'm more of a Highlife at Ruski's at 9am guy myself, but turns out Honey Paw has brunch beginning at 11am, so we classed it up in the name of entertaining and I'm glad we did. 

This was after Labor Day weekend, so it wasn't nearly as crazy as I imagined. We arrived around 11:10 or so, passing the already packed Eventide, and found Honey Paw to be wide open including a nice 4-top outside on a beautiful day. Our server must have seen in my eyes that I had postponed my day-drinking by 2 hours at that point and immediately got us set up with drinks as we pored over the menu. 

I will be the first to tell you I know nothing about Asian cuisine or customs, but the brunch here doesn't exactly overflow with typical brunchy things... I think that section of the menu was about 5-6 items deep and had things like crab fried rice, a noodle dish, etc., but sweet jesus the breakfast sandwich!! It's just bacon, egg, american cheese and some fresno peppers, but the togarashi biscuit is everything. I don't even know what togarashi is, but I think it includes bits of seaweed, maybe chili flakes. It was incredibly good and just as important somehow managed to stay completely intact during the 15 minutes it took me to devour it. I can't count how many times I've had a breakfast sandwich on a biscuit only for the whole thing to crumble apart midway, using a fork to pick at bits of it on the plate. 

Aside from the "brunch" section, there's still a full menu. Other things consumed by the group were the papaya salad (wonderful and nice for brunch), lobster toast (wasn't expecting it to be fried, but it's not exactly a staple on the Ruski's menu, so a little out of my element), mapo doufo (wee bit heavy for brunch, but tasty). 

Our server dude was friendly, knowledgeable and never missing for long periods of time, even when they inevitably got busier. I'm glad our friends talked us into this as it was a great way to spend a Sunday morning/afternoon and a good break from the normal bacon, eggs, and potatoes... well, actually I still had that breakfast sandwich, but goddamn was it good!!!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I'm sorry to give Honey Paw two stars since I was excited to come here. I came with a friend who lives in Portland and has been to The Honey Paw and raved about it. There's a long wait, which is typical in Portland. Cute restaurant, no tables, all shared or bar seating. 

Before sitting, I asked about the Pork & Crab Mee Goreng being served without pork - yes, of course, they can do that.  Great. We ordered a couple delicious apps - lobster wontons (highly recommend) and the masa crepe, which is amazing. I order the Mee Goreng without pork.  It arrives and I do notice a few random things in the dish that didn't look right, but my friend said it's not pork. I keep eating, hmmmm, tastes kinda funny, but I still eat it thinking my taste buds are off and everything in the dish is dark since soy based. I'm basically done and notice what I think is pork - it was pork! Long story short, they admit to the mistake, which is a BAD mistake in any restaurant. They took it off our bill. Not sure where the disconnect was especially since I said twice no pork. I think the chef removed the crab instead since I didn't taste it or didn't seem to see any (again because everything is sautéed in dark sauces) Honey Paw is very busy, loud - I highly recommend wait staff writing down orders. Yes, I know, it's more sophisticated today if the wait staff remembers, but obviously, it didn't work this time. Unfortunately, it was my least favorite meal of the weekend.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
The Honey Paw took us by surprise! It was a spot we walked by after snacking at Eventide and we wanted to check it out. 

We ordered the rare beef salad, fry bread with uni butter, the smoked lamb khao soi, and the caramelized honeycomb soft serve.  

You're probably wondering what "uni butter" tastes like, because that's what we were most curious about. Disappointedly, it didn't taste like uni.. I was trying so hard to figure out why it was called uni butter. It had a citrus flavor to it! I was confused. However, that was the only thing we weren't too fond of! 

The rare beef salad was amazing! It had so much flavor and the beef tasted so fresh. Each bite was an explosion of flavor and texture. It was my favorite dish. 

The smoked lamb khao soi is a Burmese egg noodle soup and that was really good as well. A lot of flavor in the curry soup, and the noodles were nice and chewy as well. 

We saw the honey soft serve was their most popular dessert, so we had to try it. It had a pleasant honey flavor in the soft serve, and the dark chocolate on top with the caramelized honeycombs added a really nice crunch to it. 

I also really liked the casual layout of the place. There's a giant center table, and bar like seating facing out of the windows along the front of the restaurant. Service was great, everyone was super friendly. This is a definite recommendation if anyone asks me for spots to eat in Portland!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Okay this is hands down the best food I've eaten in the city of Portland. 

The restaurant itself is very loud and a little cramped. Definitely hipster. There is one giant communal table and then seats along the window and bar. 

The beer list is impressive. I had a Japanese lager brewed with green tea. My husband had a sour from Allagash. They had plenty of local brews. 

The food is phenomenal. It blew my socks off. It was perfect. 

We had from the $5 "snacks" list; kimchi, pickles and scallion pancakes. Best kimchi I've ever had, the pickles included apples and mushrooms which were delicious and so unique, and the scallion pancakes had the same perfect texture as fried dough from the county fair. 

For appetizers we had the charred beet salad with kumquats and the lobster wontons. The beet salad had amazing crispy bits of puffed rice or something. The lobster wontons were delicate and swimming in a delicious broth. 

Next came the vegetarian ramen bowl (can't remember what it was called) with homemade noodles and the star of the show: crab soup with fish cakes. The soup was a coconut lime broth with fresh crab and little fish balls. It was perfectly spicy. Not fishy at all. It is said to have a cult following and I see why! 

For dessert had to get the infamous honey soft serve which lives up to its fame. You could really taste the honey in the ice cream. 

Three beers and all of this food came to $110 which I think is just right. 

It was seriously some of the most delicious food I've ever had in my life. Can't wait to go back!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
The place is conveniently located in downtown Portland - parking is tough though so be prepared to walk 5/10 mintues. 

Service is prompt and really good in general. Portion sizes are on the smaller side though.

Here is what we got:
1) Haddock Rangoons: really crispy on the outside. The inside is creamy but nothing that special.

2) Lobster toast: a mashup of a grilled cheese and lobster roll. Really good!

3) Pork bund: a solitary delicious pork bun.

4) Smoked lamb Khao Soi: This is a non traditional noodle bowl in a coconut-based broth with pickled onions and additional vegetables. The noodles are pad thai-esque. The bowl is topped with really great crispy noodles. Honestly, the lamb is barely smoked though - it seems like it was cooked in a sous vide (which is pretty great too)

5) Lobster laksa: Similar bowl to 4) but with lobster instead of lamb.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Service was really bad. It was 4:30 when we came in, hardly anyone there and it took forever for our server to come get our dishes after we finished, then just as long for her to pick the check up after we put our card down. 

The food.. tastes were good but the proportions in the two dishes we got were both way way off. We got noodle dishes, and each dish had more everything else besides the actual noodles.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Good atmosphere/decor and the wings were amazing! We went during happy hour and had tap wine, fried rice, wings and lobster wontons. All were splendid. They have a lot of interesting dishes on their menu! 
The larger dishes we ordered were not amazing. Pork and Crab Mee Goreng was way too salty and over doused with flavor. Unfortunately we couldn't taste the crab at all and did not finish the dish. Nam Prik Ong was better. The noodles had a great texture, but the flavor of the ground pork wasn't jiving with me and gave off an Italian dish vibe. 

I was beyond excited to try Honey Paw, so I am bummed I didn't enjoy the entrees we picked. Hopefully I will have a chance to try their brunch to see if I enjoy that menu better. I hear their soft serve is a good go-to any time of time!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Excellent restaurant. I had the vegetarian tofu dish and it was wonderful, but spicy. They should really warn you that it is extremely spicy. Great flavors and mushrooms. The fry bread was awesome and a must. The mushroom Tom kaw soup was good, superb flavor. The honey I e cream with hard chocolate and honey crisp was delicious. The restaurant really has limited seating with just one large table in the middle and bar seating surrounding that. All high tops. There is also outside seating too. Super cool sink in the restroom too.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I had dinner for 10 people at the Honeypaw earlier tonight.  My family ordered a half fried chicken dish which was given to us at least 40 minutes after our order and had not been served to us even after receiving our check.  

I had asked our server to remove the dish from our bill as it was not served to us and we had completed our dinner.  The server told us he would not be able to remove the $28.00 dollar charge.  He told us we would need to take it home which we agreed to; however, upon coming home, we found the half chicken dumped into a paper bag - no container, just chicken pieces.  For a high end restaurant with great reviews, I am incredibly disappointed with the service I received at the Honeypaw.  I invited my whole family up from Boston to celebrate a big event together today and could not have been more embarrassed by the Honeypaw's service tonight.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
We waited 40 minutes. at 2:30 in the afternoon. After that wait, we were sat next to the window, aka bar seat made for 2 and we were 3.

The food came out, and I've never seen portions so small that wasn't at a Michelin restaurant.  Did I mention we asked if they were a size-able and everyone said "Yeup!"

Is this "food for ants" we screamed.  Alas no one could hear our woes, over the Trap Rap music that was blaring across the restaurant.  

My friend's tuna don buri - aka the ant sized special.   It didn't have more than 4 spoon fulls of rice.  (Quarter of the bowl at most.) 

I can't wait for the recession to take out this place.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
The Honey Paw is owned by the same restaurateurs as Eventide and Hugo's. It is a very asian inspired menu and quite tasty. 

For appetizers, we tried the green papaya salad and Vietnamese masa crepe. The papaya salad was very delicious and quite spicy. The crepe had nice unique flavors (fried mussels, rhubarb sambal, maple nuoc cham) but the shell was a bit too hard/thick and stale tasting. This is modeled after the Vietnamese banh xeo, but the traditional outer shell is a lot more crispy and light and flaky, so I feel that this aspect could be improved.

Then we had the pork and clam mee goreng with chili crab sambal and peekytoe clam, and this was quite delicious. We ended with smoked lamb khao soi. This had some deep flavors and I liked the crispy fried noodles that juxtaposed against the soft noodles, but it was a little too sweet for me b/c they used a lot of coconut milk. It is extremely thick and filling too. It might be someone else's cup of tea. 

I would be interested in trying other dishes the next time I visit. Overall the menu is very innovative.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Solid 3 star place, decent food with hipster service. Server was ridiculously arrogant, ordered chawanmushi, dude asked if we had it before, said yeah an hour back at miyake.  

Dude says 'oh really weird, thought they were Japanese, that's a Chinese dish'. 

It's not Chinese  its Japanese ignorant f*. Train your staff better.

Ruined it, won't be back

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
As someone who can't eat dairy, I like going to Asian restaurants because I generally have a much wider menu selection. The Honey Paw held up this theory! 

The server asked what I thought sounded good, then assured me neither dish had dairy. I got the scallion pancakes and the lobster laksa. Before she left, she asked how I was with spice. I admitted I had a low tolerance so she said she'd make sure the chef made it mild for me. 

I've never had either dish before and they were both so good! The scallion pancakes were fried but very light and airy so they weren't super heavy - perfect starter. The lobster laksa was crazy-flavorful (in a good way!) and had tons of lobster and these awesome rice noodles I had not had before. 

The location itself has great decor - very bright with a lot of natural light. And they have a wall of vinyl on a shelf behind the hostess stand - let them know if you have a music preference and they'll see if they have it to play for you!

I hope to come back next time I'm in the area and maybe try the ramen.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
My partner and I adore the honey soft serve ice cream at this restaurant, and always stop whenever we're driving by or visiting Portland. We sat down for dinner this past weekend and had the smoked lamb khao soi and bun cha gio - both wonderful. 

I've deducted a star because every time we're here they're blasting music at an unnecessarily loud volume. It's almost impossible to talk to your dining companion(s) and it makes for an unenjoyable dining experience. After eating dinner there (45+ minutes of music) my ears were still ringing the next morning. I recommend eating outside if at all possible.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Have been here a couple different times and have enjoyed this place every time.  The food and drinks are great and the staff enjoyable.  I would recommend this place to anybody who is looking for a great place to go.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: I came here with some of my coworkers for one of our occasional happy hours. We shared a few dishes which I thought where all delicious! The ramen and lobster wontons were my favorites because they were so FLAVORFUL. I enjoyed the chicken wings as well but remember them being a little spicy. An extra bonus: the wait was a little long for one of our dishes so our waitress brought over a papaya salad (that we didn't order and of course didn't get charged for). With all of our food in front of us it looked like we were having a feast. It was great to be able to try a bunch of different things and every single one was good if not amazing. If I didn't have a group I would definitely go back to pick up a ramen for myself!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Food: 5
Service: 1

One of those places where the food is so obscenely good that the staff know they can be as rude as they want because the owner knows you'll put up with it to eat there.  Honey Paw, I wish you were better than this.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: I enjoyed this place, but I feel like it was a bit overpriced. I know it's trendy, but I like a little value with my trends. The assorted pickle plate was great. The lobster wontons were okay. The bread was very good. The service wasn't too bad and they did recommend a good local beer.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Great yakitori, smoked lamb noodle dish was outstanding and fried chicken is a must have.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
This is a very cozy place. Not great for large groups, but they accommodated us 5 at the bar with just a 40 min wait. 
Lobster toast, fried wings, scallion pancakes, and Vietnamese masa crepe, charcuterie board, and lobster wontons to start. We just couldn't decide everything looked so damn good. 
3 friends ordered the 90 day dry ages ribeye (which takes over an hour to cook so don't be rushin!) to split the bartender said it was enough food for the five of us, but I was really craving ramen so I got the vegetarian ramen they had on the menu. Which was absolutely PERFECT. Creamy, salty, and the egg just tied it all together. Spot on dish for this 27degree night. It didn't have the sweet potato in it, but I didn't notice until I ate the entire thing, so it doesn't matter. The boyfriend got the Bo Kho which  was beef shank, confit carrots, heirloom tomatos and rice noodles. This was more of a soup, which I don't think was described in the menu really, but nonetheless it was excellent. My god everything was so beyond delicious. Tender meats, fresh ingredients, and so damn delicious. 
Good prompt service as well! I opted out for drinking, but my boyfriend got the Dickle Sour that i tasted and it was strong and tasty. Did I mention how delicious this place was yet?
A very special thanks to the kitchen!!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: I did enjoy my meal with my boyfriend we got the soup with lamb and crab to share and he got the lobster appetizer. I was disappointed at how small the portions were and how expensive the meal was, but if money is no object to you, I definitely recommend for people who like fusion cuisine. My drink was really good too :)

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
My family and I came here last night for dinner! It was an unexpected visit that we stumbled upon. We really enjoyed the wine, ginger beer, and the two dishes we got, the lobster curry and another summer noodle dish with meatballs. We also got the lobster toast as an appetizer which was incredible!

Our waitress was kind and knowledgeable. They accommodated our 8 month old son very well! This is more of a pop in and enjoy a shorter dinner meal type situation that is unique and tastes good!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Had the lobster wonton and the wings...all was exceptional, lots of flavors. Great drink menu and pleasant staff, can't wait to go back soon!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Tasty,kind of expensive, hipster noodle joint. No individual tables, just counters. Good mixed drinks. Helpful servers with beards and rock tees. Very casual. We walked in on a weekday evening and were seated after about 15-20 mins with no reservation. The food was very good.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: You won't find better Asian food in Maine. The Khao Soi is the best I've had outside of Chiangmai. The fried chicken is outstanding. You won't be disappointed eating here. Tasty cocktails too, try the Oath Breaker

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
This was my second trip to Honey Paw; the first was a great experience - good service and food. This visit was not as great. 

We went on a Sunday evening to celebrate my friends 25th birthday. It started out fairly well with the hostess and waitress shifting some seats around for us when our group was 1 larger than our reservation, although they did make it seem like they were doing us a favor by doing so. Our orders were taken very quickly after that, which was nice!

While we were waiting for our food, the music was suddenly turned up very loudly by some customers and then remained there. I asked the waitress if she could turn it down so that I could hear my friends across the table, but she said "it was broken and we're trying to fix it" but no one touched the record player after this. Don't get me wrong, i enjoy music as much as the next person, but I don't go out to hear loud, non-family friendly music while eating dinner on a Sunday night. 

The food was served slightly staggered, which I thought was due to the fact that we were a group of 8, but the birthday boy's half fried chicken came out almost 15 minutes after everyone else was served. Otherwise the food was good, but a little over priced - $18 for a normal sized portion of pho seems a little ridiculous. 

All in all a decent visit, but the loud music and rude waitress kind of ruined my evening.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
This place is hip. It's a small (prob. 30-40 seater) Asian fusion joint with an extensive vinyl collection providing the soundtrack. Many of the tables are communal eating so get ready to sit and dine next to strangers. 

As for food I went with the Fried Tofu Bahn Mi and it was good but I was hoping for a little more. I've had much better bahn mis that were arguably more authentic, flavorful, and much much cheaper (this was about $15ish). 

I think I just ordered wrong though because the menu looked really appealing and I kicked myself for not getting one of the soups or the ramens, as they seemed to be more popular dishes. I probably wouldn't get the bahn mi again but I'm willing to give Honey Paw another shot -- it has some great elements to it that I enjoyed.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Had a late lunch here on a Monday - no wait. My boyfriend and I ordered the Lobster Wontons (5 pcs), Fried Wings (9 pcs), Fry Bread, and the Fried Chicken Sandwich. The wontons were so good, especially the broth it came in. The wings had coconut shavings which tasted delicious. The miso butter for the bread was sooo good. And the sandwich had a good kick bc of the kimchi, also came with homemade sour cream chips that I thought tasted good. We also ordered their "banana split" ice cream and that also tasted good! So glad we came here!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
This is one of the restaurants I was most excited about going to when I moved here. I finally got here the other weekend and let me start by saying I wasn't disappointed. The flavors were excellent all around. GET THE WINGS. And the fry bread with miso butter. This bread is literally heaven. My friend and I also had the heirloom tomatoes, the chicken sandwich (so spicy and so good if you're into that!!), and the lobster toast. The chips that come with the sandwich are so addicting. The only reason I'm giving 4 stars is because I felt like our waiter really didn't check on us that much. It wasn't too  busy around 2pm, so it shouldn't have felt like we weren't being taken care of. That being said, he was very friendly taking our order; I think maybe he had too many tables. 
We sat along the window facing the street. There's a large communal table in the middle. And also a bar! You need to see the hostess even for bar seating I believe. I will definitely come here again ASAP. Everything on the menu looks amazing. I also need to come for dinner sometime soon. Anyone want to go? :)

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Just had drinks and a few bites, drinks were great food was decent, had uni, a carpaccio type dish and some veggies, all were great. Music and atmosphere was loud and a bit more in your face then I appreciate though so cant say I'll be back

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Stopped in here for lunch today. Really liked this restaurant. Food was quit good for the 4 of us. Loved the Viet pancake with mussels and vegis along with the tomato salad appetizers. The two sandwiches had great fillings but the bread was over toasted. The 2 noodle dishes were quite good. Small place so I wouldn't try this place with a group larger than 4. 
Good service. If bah mi and Korean chicken sandwich bread had of been less cooked/crunchy this place would of been 5 stars. I recommend this place.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
We visited from out of town and this restaurant came highly recommended by a foodie friend of mine. I can see why! The food was amazing, and service was fantastic. I did call ahead to make reservations, even though they do not take reservations for parties under 6 people, but a gentleman by the name of Kevin was very accommodating. I had to change my reservation to later in the evening, and there was no problem. We were seated right away, at the bar. The bartender was great. I'm pregnant but wanted to celebrate my husband's birthday with him so I asked the bartender to surprise me with a mocktail. It was soooo tasty! Super cute and trendy little place. 

The food... wow! We started with the lobster wontons (I regret not drinking the rest of the broth it came in!). I believe it was one of the managers brought out the Heirloom Tomato Salad on the house! So so nice. It was delicious and so fresh. My husband got the Smoked Lamb Khao Soi and it was phenomenal. The coconut curry was delicious and the lamb was so tender and fresh. I got the Pork & Clam Mee Goreng and I'm still thinking about it. The pork was phenomenal and the clam was delicious. Noodles and sauce were excellent. 

Go, HUNGRY! You will not regret it.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Every dish we ordered was spot on! Their ramen as well as a few other dishes can be easily made vegan. Helpful staff and timely service even on a crowded Friday night. Allergy + dietary restriction friendly. We enjoyed the scallion pancakes, lobster wontons, lobster toast, green papaya salad and vegan ramen (see pics for more yumminess lol).

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: My husband and I had been meaning check out The Honey Paw for some time, and after stopping in for dinner the other day, we are eager to get back and try more. I had such a difficult time choosing just a few items off the menu. We started with the poke, which was really fresh and had a nice kick, and the fry bread with uni butter (I could have eaten 5 of these, the lemon and peppers on top are a nice touch). I ordered the smoked lamb khao soi. The lamb was tender and the dish was really complex-- savory, creamy, crunchy, a bit spicy, and just delicious. Not to mention, this looks like a great place to just grab drinks too. There were more than a few cocktails I'd like to try and I noticed the dj stand with plenty of records toward the back.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: There are so many options in Portland, but you should make sure this one is on your list. We stopped in for lunch, were seated right away (freezing cold February day helped with that). I will dream about the lime chili chicken wings. So many layers of flavor! My husband had the bahn mi sandwich and I opted for the fried chicken sandwich, both were very flavorful. Kimchi chips added a nice crunch. Good selection of beers and ciders. Waitress was very attentive and provided great service. Great vibe and ambience.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Came here waiting for the neighboring oyster bar to free up. Also busy, but got seated right away. Great service, drinks, and unique food. Got uni butter fried pancakes. Thumbs up for this modern, fusion restaurant!.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: I can't say enough nice things about this place. We wanted to go to the restaurant next door (event tide oyster) but it was very packed and we were there with a 1 year old so we chanced upon this place to try our luck and boy I'm glad we did! We ordered the fish curry, chicken wings, chicken sandwich and the lobster avocado toast. Every single item tasted awesome! We also felt very relaxed and well taken care of by our server. There's also a parking garage right next door which is very convenient. I'll be sure to visit again and recommend this place to others!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
I have loved everything I've eaten here. Their menu changes often- I don't think I've ever had the same thing twice. The cocktails are stellar and the staff is super knowledgeable. Unique cocktails in a city with lots of fancy cocktail spots is a treat!

Portions are reasonable and the food is all very fresh. The atmosphere is very casual but be ready to get close to the people sitting next to you. Seating is one large table in the center or in at the bar along the window

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
So I love Maine lobster. My husband and I went to Eventide next door to this place and were terribly disappointed in the portion to price ratio, which admittedly though we know seafood is expensive, we left hungry. 
We came in to honey paw with low expectations and found the food and portions infinitely more appropriate and delicious. The lobster won tons were really interesting in flavor, the ramen was also very flavorful and delicious and the lime cake was violently fluffy and creamy without being too sweet, tart, or boring. I would absolutely come back to this place before faring Eventide Again!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Eventide packed so we decided to check this place out. Busy but not overly for a Thursday night. Staff friendly. 

Small draft beer selection but some good stuff. Decent bottle list. 

Lobster wontons were good. I didn't find the dashi broth as savory as desired which made it feel slightly under salted. However the mushrooms in parts were a bit saltier so the combo was fine. Wontons were nice and silky. 

The pork and crab goreng was also too salty. I saw in someone's older pic it was inedible salty. I wouldn't go that far since I ate most of it but it was up there on the scale. The sambal was a little sweet so bites that had more of it were much better.

What I liked least was the texture of the noodles. They are thin and the wok fry makes overly chewy. The menu says house made noodles and this prep really kills that benefit. It could use bigger noodles or less on the fry. 

Wifey got the half fried chicken, plenty for one person and maybe even two average folk with apps etc. This was the star of the show. The brine was tasty. The batter was crunchy and well seasoned. Some of the better fried chicken I have had for sure. Good sweet pickles, really liked them. The chili concoction was much sweeter and looked spicy but had no heat. Otherwise it would have been a great with the chicken. 

Contrast that with the skillet cornbread. Looks amazing but I just don't think the coconut works. Somehow if just gives it an off flavor and the butter wasn't too great either. It certainly doesn't top a classic sweet and soft cornbread with a nice skillet crunch.

I don't find myself in Portland often (far from home) but if in the area I would definitely come back and try some other dishes. The service was fine and the ambiance vibrant. We sat at a bar type counter which runs along the window. Only one bathroom so be careful! Cool sink and clean. Check it out. The bathroom and the restaurant.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Best breakfast sandwich of all time. Ended up here when Eventide's line was too long and it was just what we needed! Great beer, nice staff, amazing food, and window seats. Can't wait to try to Honey soft serve next!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
The food? Superb. Service? Friendly and decent! You might be thinking: "did this dude like slip and press 3 stars." Nah my dude. I ordered a lobster laksa.

So see the attached pic: it looks rich right? Heck yeah it is! But here's the problem: it was the same size as a Ramen cup! My friend described it as an appetizer soup. Here's the real kicker-- it's an entree and it costs $22!

The content of the soups is also a lottery gamble. My friend got 4 lobsters chunks while I only got a single one. Overall, the price and portion ratio in addition to the content inconsistency is what dragged this 5 stars into a 3.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: First place we ate in Portland and it was nice. The service was superb. Our waitress was really friendly and patient with us because we had a child that kept fidgeting. The rare steak salad was excellent.  A fusion of flavors and crunchy with cilantro and herbs, party in the palette. The lobster bread was good. We also had the mi goreng and lamb curry noodles which was ok but salty. Wings were ok, also salty. Had to ask for a side of rice bc things were salty, that's an extra $3. The ambience was great, and friendly. Location was easy to get to.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Honey Paw is a trendy spot but closes at 10, so we came on the late end.  We checked in with the host and got my number on the waitlist for 2.  We were the only ones waiting, and the link texted to me confirmed that.  We were told to wait 10-15 minutes but at around the 20 minute mark, two guys walk in and claim they had waited 25 minutes and were checking on their status.  They of course did not have the texted link and were not in the system by phone number, which is the only way to be on the waitlist.  The host let them cut us even though they pretty much lied about it, so they were seated at the next two seats inside.  We waited quite awhile longer and were eventually seated outside.  Keep in mind we would have been inside if the guys had not taken our seats (note: Eric R. and I decided what happened at the pizza joint in Terlingua where the two people walked in and essentially stole a family's pizza was worse, so see that review for a crazier story).

We ordered our drinks and food and then it started to drizzle.  These patio tables did not have umbrellas over them.  Our first dish came out, the blue fin tuna sashimi.  We started eating it but I was trying to shield it from rain and I put my appetizer plate over my glass of bubbly to avoid that getting watered down.

Our server brought us and our food and drinks inside.  She pointed to two seats at the bar, but when we got there, another woman who was eating outside took two seats so we were left with one.  There was an empty stool at the communal table in the center of the restaurant, so Eric R. reached for it.  The host came over and told him he would have to stand and not take the empty chair because "she was saving it for people waiting for a table and the restaurant was about to close."  Her logic did not make a lot of sense because she said she was seating five people at the bar and only one chair was free, not at the bar.  Because we had more food coming and there was no way Eric R. should be standing and eating when there is a chair available, he moved it to the bar anyway and had everyone to his right move a little so he could fit next to me.  What was the big deal?  We already ordered and were now paying customers.

The smoked lamb khao soi came out next, and it was ridiculously good.  This was Eric R.'s main choice so I tried not to eat much of it but it was hard!  My salt and pepper squid came out next and it was delicious too.  We opted for dessert too, the house-made honey soft serve.  The bartender who served us was very friendly too and the food was excellent.  I was more disturbed that the host let people cut us in line and then yelled at us for trying to take an available chair so we could sit and eat what we already ordered.  She said something along the lines of "we didn't know it was going to rain so you can't sit inside on this chair" to him which makes no sense.  I will also note that every time a group came in to ask how long the wait was, she had to go ask other people when that is her main job to figure it out.

Five stars for the food, service was fine but the host was really obnoxious.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Went on a late Saturday afternoon, we were welcomed very politely and seated at the common table. Ordered chicken wings, beef skewers, pork rigatoni pasta and tofu rice to share. The food is well executed and delicious. I appreciate the minor details of green peppercorn and chicharrones on pasta and leeks with skewered beef. Crispy chicken wings are a must try! The beverage menu is five stars and i could see the bartender very diligent when he was miking cocktails for other customers. My only concern is that from where I was seated i could see the wait staff eating food near the dishwashing area while serving to customers. one of the waitresses still had food in her mouth when she was serving other customers. i do acknowledge the long hours and stressful work but please take a break and have your lunch before you return to work, this multi-tasking was not very appetizing for the customers.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Let me start by saying that the service and atmosphere of this place were great, no complaints. 

The food, while generally tasted acceptable, was so overpriced and overhyped for what it was that I left disappointed. I think if you have zero exposure to a half decent Vietnamese or Thai or Korean restaurant, you might think this place was extraordinary. And judging by the clientele, that was probably the case. The menu is a random hodgepodge of dishes from all over southeast Asia. I'm all good with mixing things up a bit but Vietnamese noodles with Chinese style pickled vegetables, Japanese Ramen and Korean Kimchee just didn't work. Also, the portions were really small, especially for the prices, which are high. 

Additionally, the flavors of the dishes were so tamed and mild that they were neither authentic of any of the countries they represented nor inventive or creative in their own right. I had the Bun Cha Gio which sounded awesome but at the end of the day had very little depth of flavor and the Nuoc Cham sauce was super sweet, monotone and lacking. And the tiny portion of noodles and vegetables for $18 made me feel really ripped off. My wife got the Mushroom Tom Kha which again just tasted like a milder, sweeter, richer version of a mediocre Tom Kha from an authentic Thai spot. Same goes for the Vietnamese Masa Crepe, slightly better flavors but overpriced. I asked for chili sauce (which my Bun badly needed) and it was too salty and unbalanced. 

If you want watered down, unimpressive, overly westernized versions of some potentially awesome dishes, albeit in a nice atmosphere, then it could be for you. I know it's Maine and most of the ethnic food is probably watered down but I wouldn't waste my time. Find me at my local Pho or Korean joint where I could get waaay better food for half the price.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
My three friends and I took a road trip from NYC to Maine in search of some lobster and other seafood.  We actually only stumbled upon on this place because Eventide Oyster Company next door had a wait for over an hour.  Even though we were initially disappointed to be eating here, it turned out to be the best meal of our trip. 

We were seated at the corner of a rather large communal table that we shared with other diners.  The space has high ceilings, is spacious, and has a very hipster vibe which I enjoyed.  

For food, three of us each ordered the Lobster Laksa, and one of us ordered the Country Ham and Smoked Scallop Congee.  While the congee was really tasty and unique, the Lobster Laksa absolutely blew our minds.  The broth wasn't too thick, yet it was so rich and packed with amazing flavors.  It was absolute heaven in a both.  While it is a tad bit pricey, it is well worth it. Trust me!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Top notch experience. The cocktails and food have complex, rich flavors that will surprise and impress you. Highly recommend.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: I didn't eat here but wanted to stop for a beer with my husband. It was early and there was a lot of room at the bar. There were about six customers already there. They wouldn't let us sit at the bar unless we ordered food. The hostess said we had to stand to drink. Just having had foot surgery, they wouldn't make an exception. I've heard the food is great here but I won't be trying it out.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Went here for lunch with a few friends. We had the scallion pancake and chicken & biscuit to start which were delicious! I then had the wonton soup and my friends had the crab soup special. Both were very spicy and a bit pricey but overall they tasted good. I think there are cheaper & better places to get ramen in Portland... but overall The Honey Paw was a fun, different place to get lunch. The honeycomb ice cream was delicious!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Everyone and their mom has been raving about The Honey Paw, and not one to fall behind on the hot new restaurant scene (I'm being  facetious) I FINALLY got to try it. SO GOOD! 
Here's why it was awesome:
1) The service was great, very attentive, and the food came out quickly
2) The food was DELISH. I went with three friends and everything we ordered we loved, and one of my friends is a very picky eater. I had the mushroom udon noodles it was so good, in my opinion the best of all the dishes we had. 
3) The lobster toast- so I had seen the lobster tartine in a lot of reviews and assumed this was the same thing. NOPE. It was shredded lobster meat fried into a rectangle shape with a lobster and scallop mousse, radishes and greens on top. YUM. Although the lobster flavor didn't really pop out at me, it still was quite tasty
4) Wayyyy less of a wait (no wait at all) compared to their neighbor and sister restaurant Eventide Oyster. 

Why I didn't give it 5 stars:
1) We split the scallion pancakes which were meh-nothing exciting. 
2) One friend got the wok fried rice noodle with chinese sausage, squid and mussels and the other friend got the pork and crab mee goreng. Honestly- they tasted the same, the brown sauce they were sautéed in kind of took over the flavors and you couldn't really taste the seafood in either. The major difference was the type of noodle and the rice noodle was BOMB.COM. Salty too- I recommend drinking lots of water before and after.
3) we sat outside and the tables were SO SMALL. Poor choice- should have sat inside

I definitely want to come back and try the desserts, have the mushroom udon again, and try some of their specials.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
We settled with this place because the restaurant next door had a wait for over an hour. But we were so glad we tried this place! We were seated in a big table with other customers, which I thought was something new. I loved the high ceilings and design, it gave the place a very grand feeling. 

For food, I ordered the Lobster Laksa. The flavor was amazing! I don't usually like curry flavored foods but this dish made me like curry. It was the perfect amount of spice and sour. The noodles were really good, it complemented well with the flavors. I wish the bowl was bigger! The bad thing about sitting at those big tables is that I was looking at what other people were eating. I wanted to try everything everyone else was eating; too bad I'm a poor NYC girl.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text:
Delightful restaurant cooking up some delicious food!  The hostess was great and set up two baby/toddler chairs outside for us (there's a few tables outside).  I loved the decor inside, modern and so cute.

The heiwa tofu was delish, I just wish it was bigger!   The mayo, cucumber, pickles, tofu all come together so nicely.  You can tell a lot of thought went into this sandwich, it's so damn tasty.

They made one of the noodle dishes vegetarian for us and o.m.g. how freaking delicious was that dish.  I can't remember the name, but it was packed with flavor.  Seriously, the noodles were perfectly cooked and the dish was perfectly seasoned.  One of the best noodle dishes I've had...even our toddler liked it.  

The puffed bar snack is also fun, the toddler loved it too.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: This was our first time eating here. We heard rave reviews going in so expectations were high to start but the food was even better than expected. I had the Mee Goreng with crab and pork and it was just scrumptious.  My husband had a lamb curry dish that he loved. They certainly know how to prepare Southeast Asian meals and aren't afraid to give it full, rich flavor.  It was the best noodle dish I've ever eaten; can't wait to try other dishes. Portion size was just right, the price was very good. Even though the place was crowded, as luck would have it, we were seated right away, and the service was great.  We ate outside and savored every moment.  We'll be back again soon.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: My boyfriend and I drove up from Boston and were drooling by the time we arrived in Portland. The popular oyster place next door was way too crowded so we opted for The Honey Paw and we're so glad we did! Had a great spot outdoors in the sun, and got the fried chicken and cold cut banh mi with homemade potato chips. SO DELICIOUS- especially the fried chicken sandwich with it's kimchi and cheese mixing together. Ugh. The bathroom is also really clean and has a wicked cool pond inspired sink so check it out. Total for our two sandwiches without drinks or tip was $25.92.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Dinner at the Honey Paw was everything you hope for in a restaurant. The ambiance was delightful, the dinner was delicious, and the drinks were amazing. I became obsessed with this restaurant after tasting everyone's dish with our party of six. The food was so flavourful and the staff was friendly and knowledgeable. I can't wait to go back!

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: This place is very cool. There is bar stools and a counter alongside the windows overlooking the street, a great place to people watch, and a center community bar counter, we chose the window seats. We started with a papaya salad that was the best I have ever had, people that were sitting near us asked us what it was, it was a perfect salad. We had the lobster toast after and it was perfect just the perfect hint of heat balanced by the creamy tarragon sauce. For an hour entree we shared the smoked lamb khao soi, it was amazing lamb in the most flavorful coconut curry sauce I have ever had.

name: the-honey-paw
review_text: Excellent food but poor enough service that I won't be returning. Great drinks (I had something with fish and/or eye in the title and it was delicious). Everything I tasted was very good and my friends raved over the things I didn't. The desserts looked fantastic as well.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
I have been wanting to get here for awhile. Absolutely loved the decor and feel of this place . They had just opened up the staff was very welcoming.  I have no pictures this time as I was with a friend who does not like people taking photos is the food she just likes to enjoy the food.  We got there in time for happy hour specials . We had the chicken skewers with 2 sauces the blueberry BBQ and honey Dijon, both were delicious.  We also ordered the spinach and artichoke dip with pitas. I could have eaten the whole thing with just a spoon it was so good.  At the suggestion of the waitress we got the nachos.  The nachos were a generous portion and we all really enjoyed them. 
We also got a glass of wine that came in a small carafe this was also a good size portion.  The coffee I ordered was dark, rich and hot it was an excellent cup of coffee.  I will definitely be back.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
I really like it in here!

Enter The North Point and you're instantly transported into the coziest little spot in town. It's dimly lit, cozy, and so welcoming. It's really unique.

I've come here a few times with larger groups, and they're happy to accommodate if their larger table is available. Service is always stellar. These folks know how to take care of customers! They are happy to explain the specials (of which they have several!).
Came here on a rainy Tuesday and was immediately warmly welcomed into the squishy corner table. It was $6 mojito day, so I got the strawberry basil mojito. O.M.G. This was probably the best mixed drink I've had in 2018. Fresh basil leaves, a fruity and delicious rum mix - it was spectacular. And at $6 an absolute steal.
We got their nachos, sans meat, which were great. I loved that they were spicy and had sriricha all over them, in addition to fresh jalapenos and corn.

This is a sort of upscale place - it's great for a date night. I love that they have a "no kids under 12" rule... I wish more places would implement that. LOL.
The space sort of reminds me of Timber, but cozier, and with a more laid back vibe. It's fancier than DTL, but a similar layout. As a local, it's probably a rare place for a splurge, but that's what makes it special.

I hope to return and try a cheese plate! A bit on the pricier side, but honestly, the quality is worth it. Definitely check it out! (And don't tell tourists and ruin the secret.)

name: the-north-point
review_text: Our Uber driver recommended this place to us. By happy accident, we sat next to the owner's wife when we stopped in for a drink. Great cheese, great company. Highly recommend. Look for the lovely lady in glasses hiding in the back. The conversation and hospitality are more than worth the stop.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
The North Point is one of those places that really blends in with the concept of Portland. Hipster, cool, and fun. 

The minute you walk into the North Point, you are greeted with very dim lighting, which makes it a great place to meet up with friends, or have a night out with a date. The venue is fairly small with some tables throughout, and they have a decently sized bar. 

The North Point has an extensive menu of drinks and food. Their cocktails range from a variety of selections, they have an extensive wine list with some local draft beer selections, and the food is centered around small plates with the focus being on charcuterie and cheese boards. They have a large list of cheeses and meats that you can mix and pair.

After coming here a couple of times, I have ordered the Rose Sangria and the extra dirty martini. The rose was sweet and filled with melon, and the extra dirty martinis are some of the best I've had in Portland. I have ordered the cheese and meat plates and they decorate the boards beautifully with various homemade sauces and crackers. 

The North Point is one of those hidden gems that certainly doesn't attract tourists during the summer seasons. It is a spot that I frequent and will continue to go to!

name: the-north-point
review_text: If you're looking for a cozy spot for a great cocktail, North Point is your place! There is a pretty decent sized bar and a table scattered throughout the space. The lighting is low and each table has a candle. One of my winter go-tos because of the cozy vibe!

name: the-north-point
review_text:
It appears five years ago I had mixed feelings about this cozy cocktail bar downtown. In the time since, many others have come and gone (RIP Sonny's and Crooner's), while North Point still stands strong. The point (pun!) is, I think I just didn't get it. 

North Point is a fantastic option for a date night or small friend group looking for creative cocktails and a thoughtful wine selection in a chic atmosphere. It's not trying to be the standing-room-only craziness of Blyth or Hunt, though the cocktails are equally good (and more mainstream). There's twenty cocktails on the menu ($11-$13), consisting quite literally of something for everyone. And you may want to Uber.

 The food menu formerly focused on paninis but has transformed to a wide array of small plates. The cheese and meat selection is the best in town. While not inexpensive at $21-$24, the sizable portion could easily satisfy a group. Pair it by splitting an Ultimate Grilled Cheese or Havana Cubano (both $13) and North Point can be an amazing evening without going into debt.

In the past five years, maybe North Point has changed. Maybe Portland has. Or maybe I have. But there's few places downtown with moderately priced food and crowd pleasing cocktails in a naturally hip atmosphere. Highly recommended.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
The food and service here were great. We called on a Friday night, and asked if they could seat a party of five, they had a short wait so we quickly headed over (they don't do reservations or call ahead seating). The place is small inside, but we had a nice corner table with 3 bench seats with lots of pillows and 2 regular chairs.

The food - we loved the wasabi peas they give you to snack on. We even asked for more. We started out with the shishito peppers. These were really tasty. I had the ultimate grilled cheese and really enjoyed it. My husband had fish tacos on special and said they were good enough but nothing special. 

The drinks - great drink selection, and I like how they do their beer and wine menus at the table on the glass and bottle - very creative!

I also wanted to point out the decor in here. Lots of neat things to look at. The old time portraits with silly text printed on them in the bathroom made me laugh while washing my hands. "Afraid of clowns" & "Kept her fathers ear in a locket" were just a few.

Some cons in here. It was sooooo hot and humid the evening we were in here. They had the doors open, and while it was about 10 degrees cooler outside the restaurant was stifling. We all were really uncomfortable, especially once we started eating spicy and hot food. Since it was so hot I was guzzling wafer. Once I got to the bottom of my water I realized there was something caked on the inside of my glass...gross!!! The lighting was really dim, so I didn't see it before drinking my entire water.

name: the-north-point
review_text: Was visiting Portland,ME for the first time and saw this place on Yelp. We went and they had a Sunday happy hour with $6 glasses of wine and other drink specials. The down side is we were the only people in the restaurant on a Sunday at 7. The bartender/waiter was great and the atmosphere was cool but couldn't get over the fact that no one was there. We ordered flat breaded sandwiches. The Cuban was good but the Mexican was cold in the middle. I think it would be a better place just to grab cocktails.

name: the-north-point
review_text: Cucumber Martinis are my favorite. The atmosphere invites laughs and relaxation even with the close quarters to strangers, making it a perfect place to make new friends. The staff is amazing and laid back we love going in to see Kerry!

name: the-north-point
review_text:
Found on Yelp and hope someone else does. Great drinks, food, and service! We had a party of 7 on a busy Saturday night and they still hit it out of the park as a business. I will be back again! 
Definitely recommend.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
If the watermelon martini is on the menu, GET IT.  Do not hesitate.  it has fresh watermelon and also a sour patch watermelon on the rim.  

Besides the watermelon martini, the other drinks are well made and effort was clearly made in their composition.  

North Point bills itself as a restaurant and, indeed serves sandwiches, but I would not actually eat dinner here.  The serving size is perfect for a snack with your drink (or two) but post a snack and a two drink max, I'm always ready to move onto another bar. 

That being said, I like to start at North Point and then migrate to other bars and restaurants for a fun night out!  It's a great, casual starting bar for adventures to come!

name: the-north-point
review_text: Finally made it here for my girlfriend and my annual holiday drinks.  It was a little dark but very cozy.  She had the Thai chili pork tacos and I had the Havana Cubano.  Both were delicious and I'm so happy I had the siracha on the side.  She ordered the mango peach martini and I had the chocolate martini.  She liked hers but when she tried mine, it didn't compare.  We both closed the night with a chocolate martini.  It's a must try.  One thing I would suggest is to deliver water with menus because we had to ask a couple times.  I do understand it was very busy.  We will definitely be back!

name: the-north-point
review_text: I would totally recommend this place. Little quirky but a lot of fun. The owner is very nice and hands on. You want to try the mango-peno and the deviled eggs.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
Don't worry, I won't ever be back, and I will let people know in full detail how immature of a person you are. I cannot believe someone let's you represent them!!! Lol, how professional. 
Keep it classy ‍

name: the-north-point
review_text:
This place is a gem. The drinks are on point, balanced and reasonably priced. But more importantly the staff is incredible. Jamie waited on our group of 7 two nights in a row for a friends bachelorette party. She was informative, attentive and super sweet. She also helped to give us a list pf additional places we should go to. She is an absolute treasure. 
Highly recommend the espresso martini and the ginger jackass cocktails

name: the-north-point
review_text: Jenny was great and drinks were amazing. Awesome atmosphere with dimmed lights and cool music. Perfect for a laid back get together or a date.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
This shop looks like it belongs in reddit.com/r/cozyplaces . The minute I walked in, I noticed the great decor and personality (e.g. funny captions below photos, roosters).

We came on Monday night to catch the 1/2 off wine bottle happy hour and the bartender let us sample a few before making the purchase (ended up being a $19 bottle of Pinotage).

name: the-north-point
review_text: Oh my goodness the most wonderful cheese plate in Maine!! I wish you were around the corner from my house but I'll have to settle for visiting you when I come to Portland. It's no wonder the locals don't want you to find this place.  Thank goodness I'm related to one who let me in on this secret gem.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
Visiting Maine with my girlfriend's family, decided to walk into this great place on a quiet side street.

Immediately noticed the ambience is amazing. It has a old school, artistic feel. The art is refreshing and the set up is unique. Even going into the bathroom you don't want to walk out. 

The food is great. We tried the halloumi, manchego, cranberry orange chèvre. And on the meat side we tried the Black truffle salami and the speck. And honestly it was delicious. I felt like I was in an exotic food utopia. I never write on yelp, and today I did. 10/10 will come again

name: the-north-point
review_text: This place is amazing. The drinks and the food were different but not out of the ordinary, if that makes sense. Our server knew every detail of the menu which was helpful as it's my first time here. She was attentive, knowledgeable, and by far the best service I've ever received in a restaurant.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
Torn on this one.... on one hand, I find North Point to be a secret little gem tucked off the tourist path with great "mixologists" that make fantastic drinks in an intimate bar setting. On the other hand, I find it to be REALLY pricy and find the kitchen to be incredibly slow -- even for appetizers and cheese plates!

My final consensus is to pack your wallet, plan a date night with someone who can keep you company while you wait for food and give this place a try yourself. 

For drinks, I suggest the watermelon martini (comes with a watermelon sour patch as your bar fruit Gaga!) or the gin and fresh cucumber one if that's more your style. 

For food, I adore their cheese boards! The biggest problem, as mentioned, is how expensive they are ($7-$8 a cheese with a minimum of three).

name: the-north-point
review_text: This hip little place is such a gem!! My partner and I were in Portland on vacation and decided to give this spot a try. The food and drinks were delicious and the atmosphere delightful!! The decor was so cool!! Jim and Jamie were very welcoming and friendly. We will definitely return whenever we come to Portland!!!

name: the-north-point
review_text: Mimsy and I stuck our head in the open door at 11:57 and were told that they were not open until noon.  OK, I get it, we were three minutes early, but the door was open... Anyway we shopped around for a few minutes and came back at 12:05.  Cute atmosphere, although a bit heavy on chickens and angels.  They have some corner booths that looked very inviting but we were told no can-do so we sat at the bar.  I think the bar may have been designed by Marquis de Sade.  There's not much overhang so your knees bang into the side of the bar and the back of those wooden chairs dig into your lower back.  Jesus, get different chairs.  Tried to start with the prosciutto bruschetta but they were out of prosciutto.  About eight beers on tap, they cover all the basics, nice craft selection.  The first one I tried to order, they had to change the keg out.  No biggie, it happens.  We ordered deviled eggs to start, Mimsy got the ultimate grilled cheese sandwich, I ordered the chipotle chicken tacos.  The deviled eggs were really very good.  The rest of the lunch, however, took 45 minutes to arrive and the place was dead, there were only 10 people in there.  Mimsy said the grilled cheese was pretty much flavorless, and the chicken breast used to make the tacos was so overcooked it was like chewing little bits of baseball glove.  They tasted good, it's just that the chicken was tough as hell.  The bartender was friendly and helpful, although she had not bothered to get her hair in a ponytail before the place opened so she was flipping around these long locks of hair and fiddling with them while taking our order.  It took an awful long time to get what was basically a couple of sandwiches.  I got the feeling that everybody showed up to open the place about 10 minutes before the doors opened.  For example, the manager kept adjusting the lights in the dining room up-and-down, trying to decide on the appropriate lighting, he ended up choosing one was so dark it felt like night time in there almost.  Isn't there something they should be done before you start letting guests in?

name: the-north-point
review_text: Been meaning to write this review for a few months, but kept forgetting! Went here end of January and I had a great experience. My fiancé and I went out a bit early in the day to day drink and ended up napping and missing our dinner reservations, but I'm glad we did because we ended up at The North Point for a late night snack! Waitress was awesome, she was super friendly and attentive. The cheese board was my favorite thing ever. I talk about it all the time and show people pictures of it! It was the delicious and would go back to Portland just for that. Nutella crepe was also amazing. For some reason we had bad luck everywhere we went when visiting Portland this past time, but going here made our visit better! Highly recommend! I wish I could remember the waitress's name, but I remember it being unique!

name: the-north-point
review_text: We were excited to try this place as we have never been. We ordered the cheese board and found it very underwhelming and very overpriced compared to many other restaurants in the area..it is very very small and tight. The drinks are good but also very overpriced by comparison..the service is also very slow. Many other restaurants in Portland offering better food at better prices...

name: the-north-point
review_text:
Food is good, servers are nice, but the owner is not nice and down right rude. I came in with my service dog and he seemed very uncomfortable with it but knows better than to ask me to leave.  
Than the next time I was there I sat outside and they charged additional for olive oil and the server said that the owner refused to take off the charge.  This is not the way you treat clients!

name: the-north-point
review_text:
I don't have much to go on here. I've only been here briefly. I was here for my birthday in the summer, and sat outside for cocktails and snacks. It was hit and miss- but to be fair- it was by novice cheese/meat selections. We went by some of the descriptions to the items that were unfamiliar, but some just really didn't appeal to our palettes (although, I also don't know who likes to eat mold and rubber bands). Alas, the service was fantastic, the pours were great, and I think I'd like to come here to really dig into some other items. I have known others who love it here, and I'll have to give it another try. 

I made an attempt to stop in recently, but they were closed for a private event. It's on my list.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
*Children under 12 are not allowed after 4PM*

We arrived yesterday, looking forward to visiting with family at The North Point. Unfortunately, when we arrived the bartender greeted us by telling us we weren't welcome here with our 12 week old (sleeping) baby. Apparently, you have a new policy?! as we have been here before with our baby on a busy Saturday evening and you couldn't have been more accommodating. 
She told us your policy is, no one under the age of 12 is allowed into your establishment after 4PM due to the "heavy drinkers." 

I'm sad that we were turned away from one of our favorite places in Portland.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
Holy moly! I believe I just had the most incredible panini ever! I am so pleased with my experience at the north point. I cannot wait to go back!

First of all, this place has such cool vibes. We chose to sit inside at a couch window seat. Our server took a little bit to get us some waters (to which we later learned she was the only server on and it was getting pretty busy). I asked for a sample of the allagash white and my roommate had the pear martini. My roommate said the martini was excellent and it looked beautiful (see picture)! 

Both my roommate and I were stuck between two. I chose the Mexican with no cheese (I don't do dairy) and she chose the New Yorker with extra sauerkraut. While waiting they give you these incredible little crunchy wasabi peas to much on, they were delicious, definitely held me over till the food came. When the food arrived the paninis were bigger than I expected. On the very first bite my taste buds exploded (as corny as that sounds) I was in heaven. It was so delicious and executed so well. I am such a huge fan. My corn fell out but I presume that's because I got no cheese in it. The salsa they give to dip it in is a verde and it went perfectly with the sandwich. 

Sidenote: our server was so knowledgable and really helped us by making some great recommendations. We were very impressed.

What an amazing find. I can't wait to go back and try more!!

name: the-north-point
review_text: 5 words: Meat & cheese plate. Pear Martini! Love this place! Cocktails are pricy, however, I firmly believe that you get what you paid for and it is sooo worth it.

name: the-north-point
review_text: A steady favorite with great drinks and food. It is small but cozy and if you are in a rush go someplace else that slings slip and well drinks. This is an experience to enjoy and savor. Absolutely my go-to and really appreciate the service ! Well done!

name: the-north-point
review_text:
Perfect watering hole in the Old Port. Far enough back from Fore street so its not completely over-run with tourists. At least the two times I've been there anyway....

Couldn't help but notice all the obvious first dates happening around us! It really is a great place for a quiet conversation, maybe some small bites to share, with a slightly-romantic vibe. The lights are turned down low, the benches are cozy with pillows, but not cheezy. Totally chill. 

Wasabi peas are presented immediately as you sit down at the bar. Great marketing strategy because you can't help but eat the whole bowl and your mouth will be on fire and in need of a drink! Interesting cocktail menu, beers on tap and wine. Their draft beer list is printed on a pint glass, and the wine list printed on a wine bottle. I like this strategy as you can really ponder over your drink of choice, and the bartender isn't wasting time reciting.  

Last night I had a $5 raspberry mojhito, without the simple syrup (rum+raspberries was enough sugar). Not sure if this is a Tuesday only happy hour type deal, but it was definitely after 6pm. Its hard for most 9-5ers to make happy hour so its great when you can still get drink specials after 6pm. 

Our bartender was attentive and I felt like she really CARED. Nothing worse than a fake bartender (which are all too common...). 

We also split the spinach and artichoke dip which was just okay. Nothing to write home about. No big hunks of either vegetable which were sorely missed. For $11 also a hefty price tag. Was not blown away but the food last time I went either, but am still intrigued by other things on the menu. 

Overall, The North Point is lovely.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
Tropical Tuesday: $5/mojito!!!!! 

Mango mojito - yum!
Original mojito - so delicious and a good option if you don't want it sweetened even more. 

Such a cute place with ~5 tables and a long bar w/ seats. I'll definitely be back to try some food items and HH during the week!

name: the-north-point
review_text: The North Point was a wonderful treat. Casual but, the food was fantastic. We had breakfast and enjoyed every bit. The biscuits were just like down south and the sweet potato hash was delightful. It was also, remarkable affordable. Thumbs up!

name: the-north-point
review_text:
On a recent visit to Portland, ME we stumbled upon The North Point: We were sitting "across the way" at The Garden Café (at the Portland Regency Hotel & Spa) having a cocktail after a long day of sightseeing. The foot traffic in/out of The North Point (plus the bright yellow paint) caught my eye and the Yelp reviews confirmed this was the sort of place we might enjoy and so after finishing our cocktails we headed over.

As we approached we were greeted by Dan (one of the owners it turns out) who very pleasantly accommodated our outdoor/sidewalk seating request while explaining the menu to us. BONUS! It turns out Monday night is 1/2 price bottles of (select) wine night :)   [We also peaked inside and the indoor side of The North Point looked to be very inviting, too.]

Both my girlfriend and I are cheese and charcuterie fans, so the extensive a la carté meat and cheese choices on their menu made it easy for us to decide to "make a meal" out charcuterie and cheeses; plus soup. 

We started with a shared bowl of the "soup of the day;" this day a black bean and sausage soup. It was delicious!  Very tasty with big chunks of sausage, vegetables and black beans of course.  We loved it!  

While refilling out wine glasses (which she did whenever they were getting low), our waitress, Langley, who was excellent, heard us discussing the "sausage tasting plate" versus "seasonal paté" (she's a sausage lover, and I'm a paté lover) as a possible second course before charcuterie and cheese.  She suggested we choose one or two of the sausage choices on the meats menu plus add the paté to our charcuterie board. This way it would be more economical.  So, we had:

Manchego, New England Aged Cheddar, and CranOrgange Chevré plus Ghost Pepper Salami (Langley explained it wasn't as hot as we we feared it might be), Spanish Seranno Ham, and Toscano Fennel Salami--plus the "seasonal" chicken liver paté.  All of it was excellent, and served with  the usual, and some unusual, condiments plus toast points. All in all an amazing charcuterie and cheese board experience!  

Coincidentally, while visiting Peak's Island a couple days later we got to chatting with a local couple who listed The North Point amongst their top 3 favorites.  :)

I love to try new places when I visit another city, but when I am back in Portland I think it'll be hard to pass up another visit to The North Point.

name: the-north-point
review_text: Drinks and crepes were fantastic. Dan (the owner) and the staff were friendly and knowledgeable. Still here. Only wish I could drink and eat more ... really a great place.

name: the-north-point
review_text: Known more for martinis and cocktails but their food should not be overlooked. We were able to grab a lunch spot on a Sunday when the town was packed with cruisers off the anthem of the seas who swarmed the old port like flies on shit. Great pickled vegetables, awesome cheese plate, teriyaki pork sliders and terrific beer selection. Place has great ambiance and service too. What else could you want?

name: the-north-point
review_text: I was initially a little hesitant when I stepped into the restaurant and sat in my seat. The menu worried me at first, because 1/3 of the food was meat and cheese, and the other 2/3 was a bit eccentric. Note: although Yelp categorizes The North Point as American food, I wouldn't necessarily agree with this; it's a bit of a combination of American, Mediterranean, and some unknown food type. We did enjoy the food, however, and although there were some different and unusual flavors incorporated, we enjoyed that aspect and found all of the wraps/sandwiches to be tasty. The service was pretty slow, and we were informed that the kids in our group weren't technically allowed to eat there after 5, which was kind of annoying, like the staff was trying to get us to leave. The restaurant itself was interestingly decorated in a unique style, but cool and stylish all the same.

name: the-north-point
review_text: This is a great place to grab a drink or get some great food. Tons of options that could appeal to anyone. Kind of a small place off the beaten path from other bars in old port, but worth stopping. Super relaxing place to sit after a long day and de-stress

name: the-north-point
review_text: Went here from yelp reviews and it didn't disappoint. The spinach artichoke dip had the amount of cheese I like (very cheesy). My wife loved the raspberry mojito. I loved the ginger jackass ( will have come it tomorrow) and the blackberry Betty was good too.

name: the-north-point
review_text:
Yay another happy hour to add to the list! The North Point is great no matter what time you come (with deals both before and after 6pm) but the best time to come is clearly on Mondays/Tuesdays at 5:30 so you can grab some light bites for only $5/ea during HH, followed by their drink deals at 6pm:

On Monday from 6-10pm, they do wine bottles 1/2 off and on Tuesdays from 6-10pm, they serve $5 mojitos! I've tried the mango and pear, both are super fun!

Of course, you can also order beers (all listed on a handy pint class) or wines (all listed on a handy wine bottle) on each table. Happy hour prices apply until 6! The food specials are alright, I've tried the stuffed portobello (almost like mini mozarella pizzas) as well as their chicken skewers. The variety of sauces are fun, but the chicken is a tad on the bland/dry side. Spinach dip is always a winner for me, and for $5 it was very filling! 

Regular food is a bit on the pricier side, but I'm really loving the vibe of the place. It's cozy and personable, and a great place to catch up with a couple of girlfriends!

name: the-north-point
review_text: I've been wanting to check out The North Point for a while now & I finally got there last nite and I'm so happy I did.  What a great spot.  The awesome experience starts out the second you enter with a friendly hostess who has a big, warm, welcoming smile.  I was hooked!  We chose to sit at the bar and our server, Shelby, deserves a shout out because she was fabulous, helpful & genuinely nice.  We got the spinach artichoke dip which came with a large portion of pita points, big plus, because I hate when you get a dip & they give you 3 pita points & you have to ask for more.  You could really taste the parmesan & feta cheese, it was a delicious, creamy bite of goodness.  Next, came Loaded North Point Nachos.  Presentation is very cool & fun.  Good flavor, my only comment would be the corn tortillas were borderline stale.  But I was having so much fun I did not even care.  We went for happy hour, got the 2 apps & a total of 3 drinks and the bill was only $38!  That's what I'm talking about!  Can't wait to go back.

name: the-north-point
review_text: one of the best wine/martini bars with a boutique feel. I am a frequent visitor and every visit is just as lovely as the prior one. The food is delicious, I am a big fan of the nachos..... They have a wonderful selection of wines and great craft cocktails. The pear martini is to die for.

name: the-north-point
review_text: Great lunch and drinks. One of our favorite spots in the Old Port.  Shelby was amazing! We haven't been here since March and she remembers us! Defiantly the best spot to have a great meal and fanominal drinks. Service is great, food is amazing! Will continue to come back when ever we are here!!

name: the-north-point
review_text: Let's talk about happy hour!! 4-6pm with drink and $6 food specials!
