She would constantly stare into something behind me instead of making eye contacts while talking to me. Girl did you see a ghost behind me? This is place is certainly overrated. Not a fan.

name: union
review_text:
Stopped in late last night for a drink and dessert. I was very impressed with the decor and ambience. I'm a fan of the solid marble bar top. Wish there was a foot rest under the bar, but no biggie.
Wine list was very well composed. Service was great. Dessert was very well executed. The description on the menu seemed vague compared to the complex, but playful dish we were served. I will definitely be back for an actual meal.

name: union
review_text: Can't say enough good things about their delicious food! Their use of fresh, high quality ingredients was very evident, every bite was incredible! Would highly recommend if you're looking for high-end quality but completely unpretentious and prices are very reasonable for the quality.

name: union
review_text: I'm not usually a fan of restaurants in hotels.  This place was different.  So good.  Would recommend the swordfish.

name: union
review_text:
We loved this restaurant which is located in the Press Hotel in downtown Portland Maine.  It is a lively place, but still quiet enough to enjoy a conversation.  We were there on a Sunday night, so Friday and Saturday nights may have a higher noise volume.

Three of our group started with the Maine Crab pasta as an appetizer.  It is a fairly rich dish and if you order it, you may not want to get a large entree.

For my entree, I ordered the Mountain Trout, and I was not disappointed.  The trout was cooked perfectly and was served with new potatoes, porcini mushroom & asparagus cream sauce.

Another in our party ordered the Faroe Island Salmon and I was told that it was delightful.

Our group's desserts included the Chocolate Budino and Blueberry Sorbet.
Both dishes were big hits.

name: union
review_text: This restaurant is just ok. I had the simple breakfast and they put most of the fruit in the mustard. The cheese wasn't very fresh. The ham was pretty good and so was the croissant. Those were the only things that were good.

name: union
review_text:
Great option if you are staying at the Press hotel. Here's the rundown:

Scallops - A
Brussels - A +
Arugula salad A- 
Erik was great at the bar
Misses - the soup, dessert 

Had breakfast here the next morning and was impressed.

name: union
review_text:
This place has been on my list for a while so I finally went with some friends for an after work cocktail. I was deciding between The Riot and The Down East. I explained my dilemma to the bartender and he asked me whether I wanted to go "tart" or "effervescent." I went for the latter and ended up the tasty and refreshingly light Down East cocktail. We also ordered some Brussels sprouts with chimichurri and cheese curds. I love Brussels sprouts and these did not disappoint!! 

I would like to visit Union again for some more drinks and food. I love the clean lines of the space and the overall vibe of the place. Definitely will go back!!

name: union
review_text: Visited Portland for the weekend and Union was the highlight! The cocktails were out of control amazing, I had the garden party which was extremely refreshing as well as the small sword which was spicy but not overwhelming. The brussel sprouts were unlike anything I have ever had before, charred to PERFECTION! I could have stopped there and would have been fully satisfied but then came the main course. I cannot put into words the way the Maine crab pasta made me feel, but I think I died and went to heaven for about fifteen minutes. I go out to eat a lot, but have never written a review on yelp before; I'm making an exception for Union because this experience was exceptional! Shout out to our lovely server Maria. She was very nice and gave great recommendations. This place is a little on the expensive side but totally worth it

name: union
review_text:
Had a very nice dinner here Saturday, and the service was really excellent, but the flavors in my main course were a little disappointing, especially given rave reviews. I made the reservation a week prior, and I did it over the phone, because the times I wanted weren't available online, and I was so impressed when they asked about any allergies (I have a dairy allergy). It would have been cool if the server had this info when we sat down, but he knew how to help me when I brought it up after we sat down. The hostess too went out of her way to help find some bread I could have to dip in olive oil while the others at our table snacked on their regular bread and butter. I was really intrigued by the homemade venison sausages on the menu, so two of us split that to start, and the other two enjoyed the squash salad. My wine was very expensive at $16 a glass, but it was also one of the best ones I've ever had. For the main course I went with the scallops and clams with pasta and leeks, which I found somewhat disappointing. I would have liked more seasoning for the broth, like thyme, to lighten and freshen up the flavor. 

This place came highly recommended from two contacts from back home in Portland, so I might like to give this place a second try next time I visit.

name: union
review_text: great food, we went for breakfast because we were staying in the hotel upstairs and it was included with our room. i'm more of a greasy diner kind of gal so this was a little fancy for my taste, but delicious nonetheless!

name: union
review_text: Only ordered drinks and an appetizer.. The drinks were slightly above average, but the charcuterie plate was not worth the price.

name: union
review_text:
What a gem in Portland! Got lucky driving around Old Port and saw this place and there was a parking spot outside. glad we decided to go in!

I had the Smoked Salmon tartine (SO GOOD) and my boyfriend got avocado toast, which he added lobster to. We couldn't decide which was better. & the roasted potato side, YUM!

My favorite part was the bloody mary, which was perfectly seasoned and came with everything seasoning spice on the rim. It wasn't  on the brunch menu - so glad i asked if they did brunch cocktails because it was fantastic. 

Highly recommend.

name: union
review_text: Delicious food, great service, warm and relaxing ambiance.  We arrived a half hour early for our dinner reservation but were seated immediately, and served an impressive array of savory dishes.  My dining companion is a vegetarian and I am a pesca-vegetarian, and we were both keeping Passover (gluten free) on top of this - so it's not an easy feat to serve a satisfying dinner with these restrictions!  But Union pulled it off with ease.  I haven't eaten this well for months.

name: union
review_text:
Very surprised and delighted by my meal at Union last night. The 5 star rating is because this is one of the best meals I've had in a very long time. I'm not keen on most restaurants is inside hotels so I was a little ok I started looking for a different place to eat, so I was very skeptical.

I stayed because of the Yelp reviews. I sat in the bar area, a bit cold with the door continually opening and closing. They have a chefs table I could have moved to but I felt bad knowing the tip for the meal would go to someone other than the nice staff who had been serving me.

I ordered the Salmon with beets and horseradish, fingerling roasted Maine potatoes and the bok choy. Honestly didn't know how the salmon, beets and horseradish would work together but it was amazing!! The serving size was huge, happily took home left overs and will enjoy them again. The perks of being out of town working for the weekend.

Happy I ventured out in the rain and decided to stay. If your unsure, you should definitely take the time and try it. I was pleasantly surprised, even sent a thank you to the chef.

name: union
review_text:
I had brunch at Union on a Sunday afternoon and was very surprised by how empty it was. Considering the accolades it has received I figured it would have more than 3 tables occupied.

I was seated by the friendly host and provided with three menus...two of which were for alcohol. I was surprised to see that the only menu available at 1:45pm on a Sunday was the Brunch menu, I always thought of Brunch as being earlier in the day, but I was thankful I had eaten a hearty breakfast of an "Andrew's Behemoth" at Fernald's Country Store in Damariscotta two hours before, on my trip from the Lincoln County down in to Portland. 

At Union i ordered the Baby Arugula salad which had a delicate flavor and texture, save for the green tomatoes which were a bit too green and hard for my liking. The charred corn, and other parts of the salad were fantastic though and I would order it again.

I followed this up with the Spanish Tortilla which is essentially an omelette. I subbed chicken for the chorizo as I'm not a fan of pro and found the omelette to be acceptable. I'm not a big omelette fan but it was the only thing that I could get on the menu which is incredibly small - Duckfat has more options. The wheat toast that came with the egg dish however was quite good and there sure was no shortage of mix ins within the omelette which made for a hearty dish. 

I was really looking forward to one of their sandwiches and was very disappointed to not see any of the menu during my trip. Throughout the 45 minutes I was  there I was looked after quite well by a very competent wait staff, among the best I've experienced in Maine. I'm looking forward to giving Union another try in the future but I doubt I'll revisit for Brunch due to the very limited selection.

name: union
review_text: We had another wonderful meal at Union.   While their preparations aren't without issue or calamity all the time, their promptness to take care of issues and the speed with which they react makes this a 4/5 star experience.    This was our fourth time here.    Last time, I had an entre issue and it was fixed and removed from the bill.   This time, the pork chop was, unfortunately, not cooked at all at the bone.   It had been removed too quickly from the grill, and I found in the last bite it still wasn't cooked sufficiently.    They removed the charge for the entre and I got an extra few swallows of wine in my glass to make amends.    We will come back, unquestionably.

name: union
review_text: This has to be one of the best restaurants in town. The chef... Scott...is great. He's open and friendly and willing to do anything to please your palate! Staff is so friendly and professional. Special cudos to Bridget and Martin for their exquisite advice and conversation. Love this place...I highly recommend it!!

name: union
review_text: Pretty solid cocktail bar, with yummy oysters! Unfortunately, I haven't had a chance to try other meals, but definitely worth going back and trying more. And in Portland, that statement means a lot, what with so many delicious places to become regulars!

name: union
review_text:
We ate brunch there yesterday, and cannot think of any other word to say other than "stupedous".  The ambience, the food, the drinks, the server that we had.....all above the top.  And for the quality of everything, reasonably priced compared to the city in which we live.

The food:::::::so fresh, so creative presented and put together, the ingredients, so imagination of putting certain ingredients together.....fabulous.

The drink:::::::whoever comes up with the drink, a thank you for putting the time and imagination in them.  Never ever had a bloody mary so good!!!!!

The server:::::polite, informative, attentive, cannot say enough about her.  

So,whether you live in Portland or are visiting, do not hesitate to go there.

name: union
review_text: Contemporary, upscale. Uncomplicated but limited menu, according to my taste. Service was pleasant. Prices were pricey. $4 cup of coffee is high. I would not order what I had again. (egg white frittata with spinach, mushroom, tofu.) Slice of wheat toast had substance. Fingerling home fried potatoes were very tasty. Hubby had huevo rancheros, and liked it enough to have it again, but admitted he'd had better. Presentation was simple, creative and pleasing. Still not a fan of what I ordered, or the price of a cup of joe, which is the reason for only 3 stars.

name: union
review_text:
we came here for breakfast on a Wednesday; the food was very good, except for the kids french toast which had very little egg!
there are many servers and managers on the floor, but they are so disorganized they were very slow. nice, but not efficient. i
got my coffee quickly but waited for 10 minutes for milk and sugar. 
we had the hash - delicious! - and the croissant with ham and cheese. very very good, and the presentation was beautiful. also, EXCELLENT coffee!

name: union
review_text: The complexity of spices they incorporate into one meal is an act of love for each customer. We loved our server he was extremely proud of the hotel and restaurant it was refreshing to say the least. Over all excellent service, eye catching decor, and magnificent Brussel sprouts.

name: union
review_text: We had a very good dinner with an out of town guest this past weekend, on our third visit to the restaurant. Grilled brussel sprouts with aioli and fresh peas with bacon were the vegetable standouts. The smoked tomato soup was outstanding, as was the pasta with crabmeat. In a town with many great restaurants, Union held its own.

name: union
review_text:
I was dying to try Union and check out The Press Hotel since the first buzz. Farm to table in a cool hotel seemed like a great experience/date night. 

The atmosphere was cool but it wasn't what I expected. I thought the attention to theme would spill over from the hotel part to the restaurant. Not a huge deal. Just an observation. 

The food was good, but I wasn't blown away. 

For apps we got a seasonal salad and a poached egg (served in jars over mushrooms & whipped ricotta-yum!)

There were a decent amount of vegetarian small plate options but entrees offered the one tried and true risotto. It was a blue cheese risotto with walnut pesto. Flavorful enough but not the best I've ever had.

Service was great and attentive! I got up to use the rest room (have to walk through the lobby of the hotel) and placed my napkin on the table. Someone came around and replaced it with a freshly folded one.

name: union
review_text:
We went to Union last night after looking at multiple different options. It was our first night in Portland and we thought the reviews were promising - and let me tell you, I don't regret going at all. 

I got the three course tasting menu, and my girlfriend got three courses to match so that the timing we consistent. The tasting menu last night was mushroom based which was amazing. The chef came and told us about it and I was immediately sold. The staff was welcoming and the ambiance was warm and friendly (the press Hotel is also beautiful). 

I started wth a mushroom frisée salad with local apples and sherry. It was beautiful light and delicious with hearty mushrooms. My girlfriend got the crispy Brussels sprouts with walnuts and she didn't speak to me because she was too busy enjoying the food! That's when you know it's delicious. Our entrees were taking awhile, but we were too busy speaking to really notice - however the chef sent over a mini course for us (complimentary) of a cauliflower purée with muscles. This unexpected course was actually the best delight of the entire night. It was as my girlfriend said, "one of the lightest and most flavorful dishes" she's ever had! 

As an entree we I had wagyu beef with all kinds of locally foraged mushrooms and fingerling potatoes and my girlfriend had salmon with beets. Both were wonderful. 

The whole experience, including desserts was well worth the money and time. Most importantly, I'd encourage trusting the chef with the tasting menu and follow the recommendations of the staff! They won't lead you astray. Hats off to this restaurant for a wonderful first dinner in Portland.

name: union
review_text:
We come for cocktails in a lovely environment, and have enjoyed it each time. Sometimes we come on a date night, sometime with friends. The drinks are always lovely, and the space is particularly nice. The art in display can't be beat - Erin Hutton's typewriter installation, Matt Hutton's incredible woodworked table, and other contemporary artists are on display. 

*update for brunch*

They don't serve their full breakfast menu on Sunday mornings, and their brunch menu is limited and upscale. 

Excellent coffee and espresso. The decor is very modern, somewhat industrial and very appealing. The kitchen is open and you can watch them cook and expedite. 

I had the Brioche Galette with goat cheese, sundried tomato, an over easy egg, shaved speck, and asparagus. Very rich and flavorful. 

The spouse had the arugula salad (no nuts) and added salmon. She enjoyed it, which is good as there were not a lot of gluten free options on the brunch menu.

name: union
review_text: Recently breakfasted here and what a pleasant romp. The decor, design & architecture are a feast for the eyes. Our Bloody Mary was perfectly balanced. The service was prompt and friendly. My hash was unique & delicious. A tad pricey at the end but worth every penny! Will definitely be back!

name: union
review_text: One of my favorite restaurants in Portland. Always a vegan or vegetarian option. Amazing service always love our servers!! Roomy and not crowded.

name: union
review_text:
My boyfriend and I were very excited to try the hot new restaurant "Union" and stopped in for lunch on a Wednesday. We walked into the restaurant which is part of a hotel and waited at the host stand for someone to seat us or just greet us. 

The restaurant was empty except for a 3 top in the dining room. We didn't see a hostess, a waitress or bartender. After several minutes, a bartender (or barback?) appeared and started pouring ice into the bar directly in front of us. He didn't not look up, doesn't say hello, and doesn't acknowledge our existence at all. I see the chef and make eye contact, but he quickly returns to what he's doing.

We patiently wait even longer watching the bartender unload ice and not look at us. After waiting another several minutes, we start to feel completed ignored and contemplate leaving, which we never do. Having come from the restaurant industry, we can make a lot of excuses, but this was unacceptable. 

We walk out with a feeling no customer should ever have, unwelcome. I get that this place is super fancy now, but this is no way to treat any customer, especially ones that would have dined well and probably would have come back if it was as good as they say. 

I guess we'll never know. Good luck getting noticed at this place.

https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g40827-d8124014-r477557883-Union-Portland_Maine.html#

name: union
review_text:
Stopped into Union for lunch with coworkers and was very pleasantly surprised. The restaurant was dead, which made me nervous since that usually means it isn't that good but that was not the case whatsoever. The five of us, who were here for work for a week and ate at several different spots, all agreed that this was one of our favorite lunch spots. I got the chicken panini with kale pesto and it was absolutely delicious. The foccacia bread it came on was fresh and soft. As a side I got the fingerling fries, which were also delicious.

Service is a little slow but that's what you expect at a hotel restaurant typically anyway. Between the slower service, and the locally produced maine sodas, which I found very odd tasting, it is a solid four stars for me.

name: union
review_text:
I apologize in advance for the novel, but I want you, reader, to know just how incredible this meal, and very special night, was. 

Saturday evening my fiancé (though she didn't know it yet) sat down for our dinner at Union. First off, given that I'd be proposing at the end of that meal I'd been in close communication with the staff in making arrangements so that this meal would be perfect, and it needs to be said that they were incredibly accommodating and kind through the whole process. 
To that effect, when we walked in, we were met by a very friendly host who led us to our table, where a bottle of delicious sparkling rosé was waiting, chilling, for us. Our server, was bubbly and informative, quickly and easily answered all of our questions and smoothly transitioned us into our meal. 
The first course was a season cheese plate that featured a cloth bound cheddar, a mild yet dynamic bleu, and this incredible triple creme whose name I sadly can't remember (even sadder now that I realize I can't track it down to buy without a name), a fig jam, whipped local honey, and toasted walnuts. That bleu was delicious, but the triple creme was easily one of the most delicious cheeses I've consumed, with the ash line running through its center adding a delightful smokiness. 
After the cheeses we ordered the caramelized lamb belly served over white beans, toasted pistachios, and roasted garlic purée, and all I can say is that if a mouth could orgasm, it would with this dish. The lamb's belly was wound like a pinwheel and had a delightful, sweet, crisp to its outside before you make it to the buttery, herbed, and lightly gamey inner layers. The beans were sweet and earthy and were beautifully complimented by the warmth of the pistachios, and the garlic purée was just that perfect extra touch that tied it all together. 
The mains were equally decadent, flavorful, and intricate. I ordered the chef's interpretation of a Surf 'n turf: seared scallops with braised ox tail, roasted shallots, and some sort of a pea purée. Magic. Pure magic. The brine of the scallops melded perfectly with the grounded sweetness of the ox tail, as the smokey, near caramel, notes of the roasted shallots balanced any remaining bite of the other flavors. All in all, an absolutely incredible dish!
Last but not least, dessert. Having just proposed after the last dish, the restaurant brought out a small, yet decadent, plate of treats for us. At the bottom was a truly out-of-this world chocolate cake. Stacked above that was a bar of semi-frozen chocolate moussed that was airy and dissolved on your tongue; next to those two was a shard of cocoa-nib meringue, jutting from a dollop of fresh, lightly sweetened whipped cream. Each element on its own was delicious, but the real fun came in combining them in various configurations. Additionally, the desserts were paired with a lovely sweet Argentinian dessert wine, much like a port, but cleaner. 

All in all, between the extraordinary staff, and equally incredible food, Union is a culinary experience that no one should miss, and is particularly well suited to those who want a romantic, and truly special, night to remember.

name: union
review_text:
I love this restaurant! The first time we came was opening week when they had a limited menu. It was great then, but it is even better now! I have a house on Peaks Island and get into Portland a lot during the summer. How this magnificent restaurant continues to stay under the radar amazes me. Great atmosphere, inspired cuisine and excellent service. No crowds, few tourists, no hype and a terrific value.
UNION never disappoints! The solid kitchen team cranks out delicious farm to table fare that is fresh and interesting. The food at UNION rivals Eventide, Central Provisions and Fore Street. Every staff member is well trained and professional, great wine list, tasty drink menu and a generous pour from the bar. My daughter and I decided to share 2 entrees and waiter took note, the kitchen split plated for us, and our already good experience got even better.
Do not come to Portland and miss this elegant dining experience. When you need a culinary oasis UNION is your spot.

name: union
review_text: The food was utterly fantastic and the wait staff was very kind. We ordered a bunch of stuff to try a few different things, with the intention of taking the left over food home. Apparently this isn't an option here as they gathered our plates, stacked them on each other and then threw our food away without asking. I wanted my food. Very Weird.

name: union
review_text: We enjoyed a great breakfast at Union this morning. Ordering oatmeal and fruit seemed rather mundane, though we wondered what "homemade raisins" might offer. The raisins, along with the berries, were amazingly flavorful. The blueberry muffin had a nice crisp top and loads of blueberries.  And the service from Leonard? Truly outstanding. He was attentive, but also fun and energetic and truly helpful in giving us sightseeing hints.  Union and The Press Hotel are well worth the visit!

name: union
review_text: May have been our favorite meal in Portland. We tried all sorts of apps and split out Cod dinner which was excellent. The Crab pasta app was incredible, probably the highlight of the evening. You also must get the brussel sprouts as a large side, more than enough to share among 2-4 ppl.

name: union
review_text: Came here for breakfast , we were looking for something light after a night of drinking and we got the exact breakfast we were looking for. Avocado toast was ripe and well seasoned. The simple beginning had fresh fruit although the croissant, ham and cheese chunks wasn't a complete meal in my opinion. On a normal day I feel this type of breakfast would leave me hungry for more but on that day it fit the mood.

name: union
review_text: Dreadful food.  Attractive decor. Fishy pasta. Bready "lobster" roll with little lobster. Food tasted old, uninspired, yet pretentious. Eggs Benedict:  eggs undercooked, Hollandaise congealed (it did not flow) and sparse. Strange servers.

name: union
review_text:
Second visit one year on, and again our meal was delicious. Good lamb starter and duck for main course were excellent. On a 'white out snow storm' evening the place was surprisingly full, and the staff were delightful. Good bottle of Barbera... 

Still excellent it has no bloody TV's!

name: union
review_text: The food was good and diverse. The small plates are very tempting and delicious so we went for those instead of the large plates. The cheese and charcuterie boards are large and tasty. The pork belly is tender and flavorful. The service is not the greatest. Our server would disappear where we couldn't see her to get her attention. Parking is expensive, which is a given for the location, so the best bet is the lot across the street. Debating on returning.

name: union
review_text:
Amazing. We had the hardest time finding a place to eat brunch on New Year's Day without having to wait hours, but the Union got us right in. Even if we had to wait, the bar was big, and there were plenty of beautiful couches and chairs right next to the bar with a gorgeous view. 
They catered to my gluten free needs spectacularly. I had the first gluten free Eggs Benedict of my life, and it was superb. Delicious bloodys and mimosas. The staff was super  helpful and polite. 
We left full and satisfied, absolutely no complaints.

name: union
review_text: Waited 20 minutes for drinks with an empty bar.  Don't visit the union if u want good service.  Charcuterie at $22 was more nuts and olives than meat and cheese.  Won't be returning to the Union anytime soon.

name: union
review_text:
This restaurant is my new favorite! The food couldn't be more amazing. And the wait 
staff was better than I've ever experienced. Their suggestion for wine was spot on. The special shrimp dish of the night had umami flavors that were indescribable! And the desserts were just plain joyful! Have the plate of confections - or the peach ice cream sandwich!   And if you want a perfect night, book a room at The Press Hotel, where the restaurant is located, so you can have a leisurely evening and not have far to go when it it over!

name: union
review_text: One of the best breakfasts I've had, period. The raisins that come with the oatmeal are made in house. Eggs Benedict were done flawlessly. Decor is crisp yet not cold. What a pleasant experience. In The Press Hotel, which is worth a visit if only to see the wall of typewriters and other newspaper relics.

name: union
review_text: This was probably the best dining experience of my life. My boyfriend and I were in Portland for our anniversary and let the restaurant know on their online reservation form. They went way above "above and beyond" helping make our night special. They sat us at the chef's table, where we were treated to glasses of champagne and two delicious appetizers. We got the burrata with roasted squash and pumpkin butter, which I honestly did not want to ever be finished because it was so delicious. The chef and manager checked in on us often, chatted with us and made us feel like they genuinely wanted us and the other patrons to have a memorable and enjoyable time at their restaurant. I got the hanger steak which was out of this world, and my boyfriend couldn't stop talking about his rabbit. Thank you so much to the staff at Union for making our evening so wonderful and for the absolutely OUTSTANDING food!

name: union
review_text:
This has been our favorite meal in Portland so far, both for the wonderful service and the delectable dinner we had here. 

The flash-seared tuna was the best dish of the night, and the scallops were a close-second. The burrata dish was also delicious, paired with the great olive oil and fresh spring peas. 

Pair that with the well-crafted cocktails, good wine, and cheese plate to finish and this place gets our seal of approval. 

PS- Sarah was the best waitress ever!

name: union
review_text: Excellent execution of breakfast. Avocado toast was fantastic. Smoked Salmon and accoutrements were very good. Flannel hash was OK. Eggs Benedict was perfectly cooked, though the lobster add-on not worth the extra $12. Would come back for lunch or dinner.

name: union
review_text:
This restaurant is in a hotel. Why do I start my review with that qualifier?  I'm not sure, just as I'm not sure why all restaurants in a hotel have a certain feel. They just do. There is a certain formula that combines trendiness with blandness and spits out the quintessential hotel restaurant that serves food good enough to get by in middle America but not for the exceptional food scene that is Portland, ME. 

It's not bad, it's just not great. And that's the issue, in a city of food greatness, this just doesn't measure up. 

P.S. The food was cold.

name: union
review_text: We stopped at Union before a show at the Merrill Auditorium for drinks and hors d'oeuvres. Amazing food the truffle laced potato chips were sublimely simple. The "Cheese and Charcuterie" (the Chef's seasonal selection of local cheeses and artisan meats along with local honey, fig jam, walnuts, and bread) flavorful. Finally, the bartender was very thoughtful in his drink preparation. A great visit.

name: union
review_text: Lovely lunch today. First time -staff very accommodating and friendly.  Truffle chips were excellent-salads all fresh with nice variety of ingredients.  Bright and inviting atmosphere.  Had the added pleasure of watching a wedding party go across the street to City Hall. Our waiter told us there is still a "tunnel" bit not useable-what fun that would be to explore underground Portland??

name: union
review_text:
Awesome new addition to the Portland dining scene!  The decor is modern, open and fun, and the crowd appeared to be a mix of young hipsters, hotel guests, middle-aged foodies, and local professionals.  The menu was both incredibly creative and wholly welcoming.  Plenty of interesting choices, but nothing fully "expected."  We started with two perfectly made cocktails, fresh and obviously with local ingredients.  Moved on to their wines by the glass list, which avoids the cliche brands and has some well-priced, interesting options.  

For appetizers, we had the local burrata -- a creamy, delicious mozzarella served with thin crisps and freshly shelled peas; and the clean-tasting "compressed peaches" salad which included cured ham and kale.  Main courses were exceptional.  My wife loved the steak -- cooked perfectly medium rare, then sliced and served with an earthy combination of trumpet mushrooms and fingerling potatoes.  The gold star, however, went to the confit of lamb leg, served with heirloom carrots.  The flavor was spectacular:  almost caramelized, with a touch of sweetness mixed with lightly salted meatiness.  Holy yum-ness!  The service was super professional and responsive, and the whole team worked together to support each other.  We can't wait to go back and try the rest of this creative, comfortable menu!

name: union
review_text: Beautiful meal! Had the cleanse drink no ice to start. Followed by the hash and the corn fritters.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Tapas and small plates are the in-thing right now in the restaurant industry, especially the Portland restaurant industry. After a few lackluster experiences with small plate-focused restaurants, I was quick to dismiss the idea of tapas, however, Sur Lie rejuvenated my views on small plate dining. 

Since then, I have been to Sur Lie a few times. I love the aesthetic of Sur Lie, which has a modern, rustic perspective with wooden walls, sliding farm doors, dim lighting, and an open-concept kitchen design. Both times I have come for dinner, it has been quiet with not a ton of people, which also adds to Sur Lie's laid back vibe.

The drinks and food are really well-done, too. They consistently change their craft cocktail menu, and they often try to highlight local distilleries with their alcohol choices. On a recent visit, I ended up ordering the Oh Jeez Rick with Back River gin. It was refreshing and had a nice jalapeño kick to it. As for food, it's suggested that you order 4-5 dishes per two people. My date and I ended up ordering 4 main dishes which included the sweet pea hummus (always a go-to whenever I come!), seared scallops (which were definitely a highlight and perfectly seared), Tonkatsu (the spicy mayo was amazeballs), and the Broiled Spanish Octopus (which was INCREDIBLY tender and good!). 

Honestly, I have never had anything I didn't like here. The food comes out as it is ready, which is something I also like, and it adds to the unique dining experience. I will certainly continue to come back and try more dishes!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Maine Restaurant Week is fun because it allows the broke locals to try out restaurants they never would be able to otherwise.
Enter: Sur Lie! We made a reservation for a Friday night at 8:15 to try out their tasting menu. The hostess was nice, waitress was sweet (a bit stressed and short with us, but quite understandable), and the ambience in here is very romantic and pretty. It's also a lot larger than I thought it would be.

They offered vegetarian options, hooray!
For starters, my boyfriend and I both ordered the Maine Board: salami (none for me per usual), gouda, house pickles, roasted garlic
Pretty good. Small serving and the little bread was like a see through piece of tulle. LOL. I think this is my opinion because I am a working-class and unfancy lady not used to it.

Second course: boyfriend got the fried oysters (which came with some big leaves of cabbage which I inhaled since I am a rabbit), and I got the celery & fennel salad.
HOLY MOLY. This salad. Shredded celery (?), roasted pecans, Pineland Farm cheddar, Maine maple syrup vinaigrette. Light, flavorful, a perfect amount of nuts and fresh cheese. The chef actually came out to check on us and I asked him if this is on the regular menu. He said no and I almost caused a scene. I SO HOPE they make this a regular.

For the third course I got the Red Dragon Udon: bok choy, Chinese broccoli, coconut chili sauce. It was spicy and delicious and perfectly saucy. I thought I'd be hungry with tapas, but by this point I was pretty full. Yay.
For dessert we each got a fresh, homemade and warm donut. Delicious.

For a drink I had the Prisoner of Azkaban, which at $13 and tiny was a bit steep, but when in Rome. It was delicious. The hostess at one point asked us to move tables to seat a larger party, and she comped a round of drinks - um, YES, thank you. Stellar service and stellar idea.

I'll come back eventually, I'm sure. I certainly am not the target clientele, but it's fun to feel fancy sometimes. And if that celery salad is ever on the menu, I will be returning an inappropriate amount.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
I continue to count Sur Lie as my favorite spot in Portland - which says a lot given its competition. I really appreciate the ever-changing menu (both food and bar) though I do miss the City of Gold, that tequila drink I adored so much during my first visits. But, the creativity by the chef and lead bartender is well-executed and keeps the menus fresh and exciting. Thankfully they keep some classics, such as the milk-braised cauliflower and the sweet pea hummus, on the menu. 

The ambience is casual upscale, slightly different feels between the bar (more casual) and restaurant (more formal) sections depending on your mood. They take reservations but are often able to accommodate walk-ins. Through many visits Sur Lie has been steadily excellent, so I recommend you stop in if you're in or around Portland.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
My first time visit with friends who have been before. They told me it is great so my expectations were a bit higher then usual. 

Very casual but yet classy decor. Hang out at the bar area or go fancier and sit in the dining area. Either have the same menu I believe. 

Anyway. I like to try different things and share, this is the perfect place for that. So my friend and I ordered arugula salad, beet salad and mandarin orange, fried pork with slaw and a chicken rice dish. 

OMG. Not sure what to expect, but it was all excellent. Thanks goodness the food comes out as it is ready, so you can pace yourself. Otherwise I would have had a massive pig out session.

I will share pics, which does not do justice for the taste. Wow. The blend of spices, in all the dishes were perfect. 

I look forward to my next visit. Thanks.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
3.5 stars, because the price was great for the quantity: $100 for a 4-person dinner. Our experience here wasn't bad but was ... underwhelming. The only memorable dish was the sweet pea hummus, but it was served with plain, greasy chips not pita bread. The Swordfish Ceviche Tostada and Roasted Beets were alright - I'd definitely had fresher, more flavorful versions. The Taters relied too much on salt for seasoning. The 'Shrooms and Brussels Sprouts left more to be desired, given such great veggie canvases of textures & flavors. The Lamb Bolognese was a solid comfort dish, and we finished with the Coffee Cheesecake which was on point.

After a weekend in Portland, I concluded the Yelp ratings here are hyped up 0.5-1 stars compared to big cities. Maybe because lower expectations are set for small towns, or because most reviewers are on vacation hence in a good mood. :)

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Definitely try and get a reservation if you can! It's small plates so you should share or eat two yourself (which I did). Some of their dishes are not the most interesting, but I picked well! I would choose from the "Pleasant" and "Bold" parts of their menu. 

1. Organic Parsnips and Eggs- sounds so simple, but it was a delightful dish presented in a cast iron skillet with a carrot caramel! 
2. Rossejat de Gambas al Ajillo- still not sure how that's pronounced, but it was basically a toasted noodle skillet with some shrimp and garlic

name: sur-lie
review_text:
I have been to Sur Lie twice - once for dinner and once for brunch - both times I delighted in the presentation and unique flavors of all the plates.

I love tapas, more specifically, I love being able to taste bits of a variety of foods and share flavors with others. I think I would always eat tapas style if my friends didn't mind sharing!

The highlights of dinner, which I would order again every time, are the Fried Milk Braised Cauliflower, the Pinto Bean Dip, and the Sur Taters! The cauliflower literally melted in my mouth, it was divine! And the bean dip and taters, both seemingly normal dishes, were bursting with flavor. Every dish from the cheese to the drinks was beautifully presented. They serve the plates staggered, so you can enjoy each one on its own, but never have an empty table (until you're stuffed). 

For brunch the menu had a variety of savory and sweet options, everything I tried was full of flavor.  They were generous with the coffee refills, and the mimosa was perfectly boozy. Though I was sad to see that they were unwilling to modify their Fat Boy Breakfast (fluffy buttermilk pancake with bacon, sausage, maple syrup, cheddar sauce, fried egg) without meat for us vegetarians. 

I love that they use lots of local vendors, and certainly made a point to go during Happy Hour (4p-6p daily). Meals can get pricey, but I would recommend to friends for a date night or celebratory brunch!

Sur Lie, I will be back to try more of your small plates - and next time I'll probably order two braised cauliflower!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Sur Lie has always been good, but seems to have really hit it's stride. Every single thing we had was better than expected and that doesn't happen a lot. Starting  with a beautifully presented happy hour cheese plate, plus tender yet beautifully spiced salmon pastrami, followed up with scallops perfectly seared with a delightful pineapple mojo and then a fantastic cutlet tonkatsu crunchy and served with a zesty ginger slaw. I really enjoyed it all. Such wonderful shareable plates, perfectly prepared full of surprise and flavor. Even with all we ordered there were plenty of other things that  I wanted  to try, but we were just too full. So good!

name: sur-lie
review_text: A nice spot for dinner. Their charcuterie plate was excellent. I really enjoyed their presentation and the cheeses. The prosciutto felt dry and not as marbled as I would have liked  The lamb bolognese was my favorite but thought it could have used some pieces of pulled lamb throughout. The smoked salmon was okay but could have used more acid. The paella was good with creamy rice but I felt the mushrooms were a little more firm than I would have liked. The drinks were fabulous and fun. I enjoyed the experience and will be back.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
I am totally confused how this place has such a high rating...?! Went here for dinner with my husband, and we left less than impressed. 

Ambiance: lighting is very bright and harsh, weird 80s songs are playing loudly, and overall the vibe feels like a sterile, generic diner

Food: Good, but definitely nothing special. The cheese on the cheese plate was warm/sweating like it had sat out too long. The Sur Taters were so oily I couldn't eat them. I consider myself a bad cook and think the food I make at home is better than the food here. 

Service: terrible. We waited THIRTY minutes before getting our drinks. Our first dish came out right before our drinks showed up. The waitress took 15 minutes to take our order. We legit sat there in disbelief of the bad service, unable to get a waiter's attention. 

Would never, ever return or recommend, especially in a place like Portland with so many other options!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
A bit underwhelmed with our dinner here the other night given all of the great reviews. 

We started with the sweet pea hummus. My wife and I were starving so we dug right in. Initially we were not impressed but halfway through we noticed the large lemon ?sorbet in the middle. We stirred it in and the flavor got much better.  

Next we ordered the cauliflower which was decent. We then asked our waitress whether we should go potatoes or Brussels sprouts. She recommended the potatoes and we weren't that impressed. Almost like home fries + some cheese and jalapeño on top.  my wife didn't want anymore after 1-2 bites. 

The lamb bolognese was the best thing we ordered. Highly recommend it. 

For dessert we ordered the gluten free chocolate cake. Great flavor 

Not the best experience and probably wouldn't come back again

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Excellent all around!

This beauty of a restaurant is exactly what we were looking for; it is absolutely phenomenal all around.  We walked in and were immediately seated. No reservations, but we were fairly early, so there was ample room.  The hostess started us off with an apperatif - a small, non-alcoholic drink to cleanse the palate between dishes - with a different flavor profile daily.

The menu offered many options listed in sort-of themes: essentially, how adventurous you feel.  Our waitress was very helpful in providing us with details on any dish we asked about, and she was personable and rather excited to talk about the dishes.  She seemed to genuinely enjoy working there, and the vibes she gave off as a result were wonderfully inviting.

All of the dishes were delicious.  My companion was not keen on trying the North Spore 'Shrooms I ordered, but they quickly became her favorite of the half-dozen we tried.  Similarly, she ordered a pork chop that sounded interesting but I didn't expect to like it as I don't tend to like pork; however, it was wonderfully cooked, and that aioli was delicious, ranking it as one of my favorites.  And I would clearly be remiss if I failed to mention the arugula salad as it enraptured us from the start!

So what do you do when a restaurant intrigues your taste buds with every bite?  Order dessert, of course!  We both found something to our liking, and the waitress even smiled when I ordered the Sur Lie Dango, noting that she appreciated my adventurous spirit.  And, oh, did that spirit pay off...  It was absolutely wonderful: delightful to both the eye and the tongue.

Excellent food, excellent service.  I highly recommend a visit!

name: sur-lie
review_text: We love Sur Lie so much we had our wedding reception here and it did not disappoint. Chef Emil pulled together the best menu and all the staff was amazing in making our day perfect!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Tonight we celebrated my sisters 30th birthday with dinner at Sur Lie. Many of us had not experienced an environment where it is all small plates (3 menu items is the order recommendation per person). Yet, our waitress Mo was very patient with us which we greatly appreciated! The food was unique and tasteful. Definitely a great spot to try something you've never had before. We must have ordered 18 different menu items amongst the table. Some of my favorites were the honey cauliflower, the brussels sprouts, and the diced potatoes with blue cheese, yum! The coffee cheese cake was amazing as well. And the French Can Can was a delightful drink!

I think our only wish was that we did not have to order all 3 courses at once. There is a recommended order in which they want to send out food, but it came so spastically and seemed just a little all over the place. Had it been a little more structured and everyone got their first course at the same time and then their second course at the same time and so on it would have felt more organized and smooth. But again, we were a 7 top new to the experience so they may have just wanted the order all at once since we were a big party. Most restaurants let you order apps first and think about what to order next, it's a lot of pressure to order 3-4 courses all at once!

But seriously Mo was great! We had no idea what we were doing, my parents especially, and she guided them nicely through the process.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Came here recently before a concert at the State Theatre on a Friday night. Our reservations were for pretty early so we could get in line when we needed to (5:15 PM) and the place was pretty empty, which I honestly expected. 

Sur Lie is a small plates place, so I wouldn't come here if you're looking to get in and out really quickly. They allow you to order a whole bunch of plates when you first arrive, and they bring each to you as you finish them. We loved every single thing we tried. Some real standouts were the fried milk braised cauliflower (I can't believe the flavors they were able to make happen in this one), the salted roasted beets, the North Spore shrooms, and the arroz con pollo. 

Our waitress was so delightful, and made the whole experience so enjoyable and fun! I wish I could remember her name. 

Our bill wasn't cheap as we got a LOT of food, but I'm totally willing to pay for quality, and Sur Lie delivered. 

I'd highly recommend this place for dinner--both the food and service were excellent!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Each time we visit it gets better! Lovely host. Wonderful offerings. Tapas style. Taste is divine. Beverage pairings & dessert selections are great. Atmosphere is calm & inviting. Worth the visit.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Popularly referred to as a Bona-fide Yelp Review Update:

Upgrade in rating to 4-stars.

The following dishes are really quite excellent:

-the swordfish ceviche 
-sur taters
-grilled smoked porkchop

Do you have to order multiple tapas in order to get a complete meal?..  Yes, yes you do.  Though, but still really good and good dining experience.

name: sur-lie
review_text: This place was really great. I tried the cauliflower, the ceviche and the pea hummus, all of which were delicious. I was seated at the bar so I got to watch the bartender mix up lots of beautiful cocktails. I tried 2 and they were both delicious. He was also super friendly and nice to chat with. Service from food runners was also attentive and friendly and the place just had a warm welcoming feel to it. I'm super glad I decided to dine here for one of my dinners while in Portland on vacation. I've already recommended it to friends who will be visiting soon!

name: sur-lie
review_text: The dishes we selected were so flavorful. Loved the presentation and service. Definitely a must try. The scallops were cooked to perfection. I enjoyed the brussel sprouts and sweet pea. The beets was also very good. Ended it with their delicious  Raquel's flan.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Small bar area and the dining room is small as well. Open kitchen so you can see exactly what the chefs are doing. Small plates. We had the pinto dip which was delicious. I was for some reason expecting the beans to be mashed but they were whole. It also had a certain tangy flavor. We then got cheese which had this bread that was paper thin. Bread looks and tastes good, but don't try to put your cheese on it or it will break. Beet salad was on point. The best dish of the night was the lamb ragu. Small pieces of lamb but the sauce was awesome. I almost ordered a second order of it. We finished with the octopus. My husband and I get octopus every time we see it on the menu. We have been trying to relive this amazing octopus we had in Spain. Honestly, this is the closest we have had. It wasn't chewy. It was really good. Drinks were also very good. Staff was friendly. I recommend checking it out.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Very underwhelming. Okay food for about $10/plate. My husband and I shared 4 plates and weren't satisfied with the taste or portion sizes. The drinks were wonderful and the ceviche was good, everything else was just meh.

name: sur-lie
review_text: My new favorite spot in Portland. We had the Chef tasting menu. By far my favorite item was the sweet pea hummus, it was SO good.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Lots to love here - SO many choices of small plates, each one more mouth-watering than the  last. Whether you choose antipasti, charcuterie, cheese, vegetarian, there is bound to be something that will make you say "wow!" The accompanying thin, crispy toasts are beautiful and delicious (gluten free crackers are available), the flavors intriguing and creative. The only drawback is the price - go during happy hour to save a few bucks, but be prepared to spend a lot if you don't want to leave hungry.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Celebrated a friend's birthday at Sur Lie.  The food was average and, by itself, might deserve three stars.  I should note the cauliflower, arugala salad, and potatoes were excellent.  The pinto beans, cheese plate, and swordfish were disappointing.

So why two stars?  Unfortunately, the chef came out to chat after dinner.  What started out as a classy move ended very badly, as he disparaged our home town, made critical comments about our friend's work, and discussed restaurants in other cities in excruciating detail.  It was a bizarre encounter.  Even if the food were outstanding, we would not return.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
We went to Sur Lie for happy hour after reading really good reviews about the fairly new restaurant. I certainly believe that having a happy hour is a sure fire way to get people in the door earlier, plus it's a great value. The more affordable prices let people sample the food and once they do, they won't be disappointed. So, it would be very easy to turn happy hours into many hours of sampling great dishes.

The bar was beautiful and we were served promptly by the bartender, who was professional and serious. We started with beet cured lox with house pickles, roasted garlic, and crème fraîche. The dish was accompanied with really think slices of bread that were chip like but had a lot of holes like bread would. You could see right through them! Everything on the plate worked really well together, creating a sophisticated and delicious taste.

Next, we ordered black bean dip with corn, house bbq sauce, and scallions. This dish came with corn chip strips.  It was evident at this point that everything was homemade. The beans were perfectly cooked and seasoned, which paired perfectly with the local corn. The delicious homemade bbq sauce was the binder that brought it all together. 

The menu prices were very reasonable for the quality of food. It's meant to be tapas style which we like because we rather eat smaller dishes and get to try more of a variety. This is definitely a place to go if you love food and know how to dine.

Sur Lie has a great vibe without pretentious plating and food costs. We really enjoyed our time there and will definitely be back!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
One of my favorite restaurants in Portland. I'm a Moscow mule girl and the Stubborn Mule cocktail here ($10) is my favorite in town. The cocktail menu is delightful. Can't go wrong with any of the choices. Beer and wine too. 

The menu is small plates designed to be shared and will come out from the kitchen as they are ready. They vary in price from $8-$15ish maybe and you want to order 4-5 plates for two people to have a full meal. Every thing I have tried here is delicious and I've tried a lot of the menu! 

Some of my standout favorites are- 
+The fried chicken- it's always moist and delicious and never overcooked, has a great sauce. 
+Sweet pea hummus- besides this dish being beautiful it tastes sooo good :)) You have to get this one!  That green color though!  0..o
+Brussels Sprouts- Large portion and sautéed with almonds. I get this every time and tell myself it's my greens for the day :)
+Potato wedges with aioli- just look at my picture. I have no words.

You really can't go wrong with Sur Lie. Everything is delicious. On my last visit with my girlfriend for dinner, the chef came out and introduced himself while we were drinking coffee for dessert. Top Notch! Keep it classy Sur Lie!

name: sur-lie
review_text: So to start I may be spoiled by the great Tapas and wine bar down the street from me, which is much less pricey and offers bigger portions, at the same if not better quality of food. The service was great the host and server we had were very pleasant. The drinks were delicious as well. I would recommend getting cheese and or charcuterie, we got a bleu cheese, recommended by our server and salami. The cheese was awesome the only downside are the extremely thin toasted pieces of bread that are served with the cheese. It was difficult to get cheese on the bread without it breaking. The other plates were lacking, plates meant to be shared offered just enough for a bite or two each between my boyfriend and I, and at about $8-$14 a plate I didn't think it was quite worth it.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
I can't say enough good things about Sur lie.  We were a party of five women in Portland for the weekend to celebrate our friend's upcoming wedding... AKA bachelorette party.  We started with drinks, I got The Order Of the Phoenix which was amazing, just sweet enough, just tart enough and came with a sprig of rosemary.  My friends renamed it the chicken dinner drink (because it smelled like rosemary) but despite that they ordered a few for themselves and it was the big hit of the night. Someone in our party was not able to drink and the bar went out of their way to make fun and creative Mocktails so she could join in the fun.  We ordered so much food it would be almost impossible for me to list everything but the highlights of the night were the Beet Cured Lox, The sweet pea hummus (not kidding we actually put in a second order because it was that good), Fried Milk Braised Cauliflower,and the sur tatters, but everything was amazing.  

We had such a great experience that we barely noticed when we were the last table of the night.  I share this information for two reasons.  1.  We were having a great time and were totally focused on fun, drink, and conversation and 2.  The staff NEVER made us feel like they were waiting for us to leave or that we were bothering them in anyway.

I can't wait to come back to Portland and bring my husband here.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
My wife and I went to Sur Lie on a Wednesday evening. We both love tapas and this place stood out. The menu is as imaginative and creative as it gets. Maybe the best tapas we have had!

Started with fried milk braised cauliflower with honey milk braised soy and had pinto bean dip, arroz con pollo (fantastic), North spore "shrooms", beat cured lox, broiled Spanish octopus( the best I've had) and finished with lemon curd. If you like tapas, this place is a must!

Great drink menu and extensive wine and beer list!

name: sur-lie
review_text: We came here during our vacation last year and it was great this year the food was a bit confusing the flavors we indecisive. The staff was very friendly and we were treated very well.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Innovative cocktails, fascinating tapas, perfect wine list! Dinner last night was fabulous. Started with one of the house cocktails - do yourself a favor and go out of your comfort zone and try one of these yummy concoctions! Then onto tapas, again with a focus on unusual flavor combos that sync up for amazing. Sweet pea hummus (yes, we licked the bowl!),crispy taters, lamb bolognese, fried milk braised cauliflower - it was all perfect and we didn't leave a drop. Wine list is well-stocked, well-priced - we enjoyed a Vouvray Chenin Blanc which was perfect. Service could not be better.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
My partner and I are both foodies (he a professional) and we chose this restaurant during an overnight stay in Portland based on the interesting menu and positive reviews.  We had a lovely time.  We also had some great small plates.  And some that were less impressive.  We agree that you can have a five-star experience at Sur Lie...IF you know what to order and what not to.  So here is our advice.  You can't miss the Sur Potatoes, but we suggest you order then with your last round of tapas before dessert.  They are so full of flavor and spice they may actually make other flavorful dishes seem bland if you have them too early.  Do have the sweet pea hummus.  My partner doesn't even like peas but for both of us, it was a highlight.  Order the mushrooms,but earlier on.  They are lovely but may be drowned out next to, say, the Sur potatoes.  We did not have them, but by all accounts, have the brussel sprouts too.  And the scallops are worth ordering just for the delightful sauce.  (We were wishing we had some bread just to scoop up the dregs of that sauce!). Also don't miss the Arroz con Pollo.  We have never had a better chicken and rice dish anywhere.  
We were not as impressed with the Parsnips and Eggs or the Octopus. We have had far better octopus at several other tapas joints.  The Rossejat de Gambos Al Ajillo was also disappointing.  I would definitely return but would try a few different dishes in places of these three.
Also, with tapas, sharing a bottle of wine can be a difficult choice, so you can't go wrong with a sparkling wine.  We had a bottle of sparkling rose and it was lovely.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
This is a great place for trying out something unconventional. You definitely have to come with an open mind and down to try some cool stuff. If you're going on your 2rd date and are worried about running out of stuff to talk about, the dishes they serve would probably help stir some conversation. 

I ordered the chef's tasting menu for $55/person and got 4 "waves" of food. It's definitely way more than anyone can finish. It's really well worth the price as each dish there is ~$12 and I was able to try like 7 different dishes.  My favorite dish in this tasting menu was definitely the sweet pea hummus dip. SOOOO GOOOOOD though it's not the fanciest dish.

Though in general it's very good food, I'd say it's not the best tasting food I've had because the chef tries out interesting combinations​ of ingredients so obviously some are gonna agree with the pallet and some aren't. I came here more for a culinary experience rather than trying to satisfy specific craving. The ingredients are definitely very fresh tasting. They boast local farm to table dining!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
This was just "OK" to me, but I only had a snack and a drink here. The menu looked good, but we just stopped in and had the #3 potatoes/cocktails. 

I had a Maker's  on the rocks, mom had a margarita. Both solid.

The people were  friendly, and everything was decent. Definite props to the hosts, very friendly guys. The bartenders sounded friendly, and they interacted with guests. 

 My issue was really just the service. Our waitress was consistently available and checking on us for the duration of the visit. However, when i asked for the check, she seemed to disappear for 10-15 minutes. It was a bit of a sour note to leave on. We ended up asking someone else  to close us out. Kind of odd that she was lingering and had forgotten us so quickly. Im sure, as a server, there is little  motivation to serve a table who arent spending a lot. Yet, im big on dining in Portland, and she could have done a little better to encourage my return. We'll see.

name: sur-lie
review_text: I cant say enough about this place! It is great if you are wanting small plates! We tried alot of things that were on the menu and everything was to DIE FOR! My favorite things of the were the squash blossoms, if you are going here you MUST try these(then order more). The staff is lovely/knowledgeable.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
I have had the pleasure of eating here a few times, and have always enjoyed the food. I'm  personally into the small-plates style, as I like to try many menu items at once, therefore, this restaurant is perfect for sharing! They have an excellent beer beer menu, and the drink menu has some of the most delicious drinks I have ever tasted, some drinks are also so intricately made and beautiful. 

Some of the items on the menu should be approached with an open-mind, but I have never been disappointed in trying anything new.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
We love Tapas and that is why we went.  THe cheese portions were so tiny, before writing this review I could see the evolution from 2014 to now, they portions are 1/2 what they were.  Also, appears not much has changed on the menu.  Olive marinade was great except there what appeared to be Kalamata and they were mush, they should know which hold up.

Arroz con Gambas al Ajillo, the prawns were dry and no juice to suck out of the head.  This is why I ordered them, not many places serve head on, disappointed.

The bartender lacked personality.  Also, it wasn't until the second round where we ordered hot plates that he informed us that it would take 15 minutes, that should have been mentioned at first as we would have placed it so the timing was better.

The sausage was nice, it tasted like merguez though the didn't say if it was.  They served the pickle veg with it.  From the 2014 to 2017 pick, appears they did slices before as the tiny cubes were hard to control and get onto the mini slices.  I found they were pretty stingy with the meat, I am not sure anyone could get those slices any thinner, the should enter a contest.

This place seems to be going the way, of a trend I am finding in tourist areas in New England,  more focused on price pointing their food rather than quality to price point. 

Anyway, although we love tapas places and choose this dining over any other form of eating we will not be returning.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Loved it. Simple but super tasty. I chose the Brussels sprouts and pork. Beautifully done and perfect size. Loved my experience there.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Incredible flavor! The lamb bolognese and brussel sprouts were to die for. You won't regret trying this place it's a hidden gem.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Ever had a restaurant spoil you for many others? Sur lie managed to refine my taste buds with truly fresh ingredients, textures and complex flavors. While many Portland restaurants adopt the farm to table approach, Sur-lie abides and over delivers on quality. 
While the ambience in the restaurant is more for a nice meal with friends rather than an intimate dinner with Tinder dates turned S/O, the staff makes you feel comfortable, keeps the specialty drinks flowing and understands the menu making your work easier.
The Sur taters, the marinated olives and the Maine board. Thank me later.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Great 5 course chefs tasting menu. Wonderful service and imaginative delish food. Two of us really enjoyed letting go of all the decision making and leaving it to the chef. Beautiful cheese board to start, green pea hummus with pita chips, an amazing celery root salad, mussel bruschetta, crunchy roasted cauliflower, lamb bolognese, vegetarian mushroom entree , strawberry doughnuts and a flourless chocolate cake. Add a couple of glasses of Chardonnay and we were in heaven. Definitely worth the $55/person cost. We will be back!!

name: sur-lie
review_text: The food was absolutely delish! The potatoes rocked my world, bolognese was lit, and the pork is still on my mind. However, we ordered our food an hour and some change before receiving it. Would give a 5 star if service was more zesty.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
The food at Sur Lie is pretty good. But it's never really grabbed me; and in a town full of restaurants it's not at the top of my list for food. It is, however, at the very top of my list for drinks. I would say that it's pretty solidly the best cocktail list in town. 

The drinks are delicious, varied, unique, regularly rotated and awesomely named. The first time I went I had  the "What's up Doc?" made with carrot vodka and beef bouillon. Last time I was there I had a "Shelter from the Storm" that had the logo of the restaurant stenciled into it's foam in hibiscus powder. 

Soooo. Yeah. If you're thirsty, it's the place to be.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Fun place to share perfectly plated tasty small plates. Best Brussels sprouts ever which the chef told us was what got him the job. He stopped by our table and speaking with him added to our Portland foodie experience.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Went to Sur Lie for Maine Restaurant Week and was very glad I made the decision. Had a reservation with another couple but had to wait 15 min or so for the previous table to finish up. Service after we sat down was very good and helpful throughout. 

Food was definitely the highlight of the evening as we were given an abundance of options through the Restaurant Week menu. Favorite dish was the Lamb Bolognese which had amazing flavor and was a dish to savor.

Only con was serving size which is pretty small so I wouldn't recommend coming here with a huge appetite, but the quality of the food was well worth the trip.

name: sur-lie
review_text: In town for a few days and found this place on yelp with plenty of good reviews. The 5 stars is both for the food and the service. Food was EXCELLENT especially the cauliflower and the scallops! Our waitress was even kind enough to write down a few recommendations for places to go while here in Portland!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Crazy good. Dynamite. Other non- expletive descriptions. Sue-Lie served us a phenomenal meal and a few glasses of shapely Malbec on a quiet Monday night.

FOOD is CREATIVE and fun. Sweet Pea Hummus had an essence of mint. Blistered and salted Shishito peppers are the best I've ever had. Hanger Steak was nicely served with thin bread and cheese.

As much as we savored those and others, the CLAM CHOWDER just kicks ass. Creamy base, three clams in shell with a nugget of PORK BELLY surrounds a small mound of hash brown potato.

The DECOR is bucolic French influenced..Simple and classic.  Great music in the background.

Maybe we were blessed that the crowd was light. Our servers kept the food, water and wine coming and described each of the shared plates.

Outstanding

(Auto correct botched my photo description!)

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Wow.  In a city full of great food options, it can be tough to stand out, but Sur Lie manages to do so without much effort.  Surprised that this spot is more "under the radar" than some of the other more popular options.

It's a nice and open space, and once seated, we received a delicious shot of some house made ginger honey soda.  Sure, why not.

The menu was pretty appealing with a lot of options, going from light, medium, and bold flavors.  Each of the dishes that came out had a clear sense of purpose, and a lot of thought behind them. This isn't a small plates place that just puts the "ingredients of the month" onto the menu to sound cool, they actually think through what will work together.  I'll just go through each:

Salmon charcuterie: Dynamite.  Everything on the plate was working together, enjoyed each bite and especially the ultra-thin crostini. 

Gazpacho: This might have stolen the show.  The presentation was beautiful, and the flavors were absolutely delicious.  The actual Gazpacho was the best I've ever had, and the fresh tomatoes, balsamic, and goat cheese were all just incredible.  

Sweet pea hummus: Beautiful presentation once again, but not our favorite of the night.  I think that was mostly due to preference, because the execution was definitely there. 

Celery and fennel salad: Delicious.  Crunchy, fresh, zesty, everything you want a salad to be. 

Octopus: Could have been a little better.  Still good, decent flavors, but the octopus itself was a little bland. 

Scallops: This was the only dish where I actually thought they might've tried to do too much at once.  The scallops were super buttery and rich, the potato purée on the bottom was sweet and rich, and then the pickled onions on top.  All together in one bite, it was a little too much going on, but separately, they were all very tasty. 

The meal was also incredibly affordable considering how much we ordered. We came at 10 pm on a Saturday so can't say much about the wait. There was only one other table there at the time. Apparently they also do happy hour if you sit at the bar! I'll be back to try that next time.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Wow. Just wow. My husband booked a celebratory meal here for us and I was very impressed. The style of tapas is fun for the adventurous, but the quality and uniqueness of the dishes were the star of the meal! There was an impressive wine list to start, followed by so many great options. I LOVED the lamb bolognese, swordfish ceviche, potatoes, and some of the cheese options.  We tried about half the menu and I don't think you could go wrong with any of those choices. Hats off to the chef!

name: sur-lie
review_text: My husband and I ate here on a quick stopover in Portland and it was ah-mazing!  We started with the scallops, which were cooked exactly right  and served beautifully with pickled accents that complimented the scallops perfectly.  Next came the local mushrooms that blew us away with their intense and interesting flavors.  We followed that up with a smoked pork chop dish that was quite delicious in its own right.  This was easily one of the best meals we had on our trip, and perhaps in many years -- and we've had some great food over the years... After dinner we talked with the owner a bit and she told us the chef cooks with a secret ingredient:  love.  And it shows - food made with this attention to detail is rare.  Don't miss this place - it's very special and the food is awesome!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Sur lie is definitely the new gem in Portland. I've been a couple times now and even if you're just looking for drinks and small plates this is THE spot. The price tag is a little up there so if you're money conscious it's probably not the best spot. Their drinks are inventive and secretively boozy (just how I like 'em). Their sweet pea, mint oil hummus is a must. The steak was a fantastic dish, cooked perfectly, and the fried cauliflower is just the perfect amount of brown with a savory and light sauce. 

I wasn't a big fan of the lamb but I'm picky about my lamb. Would I eat it again? Heck yes! Are there more items I should probably try before it comes to that? Heck yes!

I had one of their specials the other month and it keeps haunting me. I think it was short rib but they need to bring it back asap. It was out of this world! The servers are very knowledgeable, friendly and go out of their way to make you feel at home. I've had nothing but amazing service here. That alone deserves the 5 stars, cause lawd you know some service here in town could use some polishing up!

Definitely make it a point to check out Sur Lie!

name: sur-lie
review_text: This was my vegetarian/pescatarian heaven and I can't say enough good things about this place! We came on first Friday and it surprisingly wasn't extremely busy. The place is tapas style with tons of options. We started with a cheese/charcuterie platter with Brie cheese and beet cured lox. The lox was so fresh and the Brie came with a sweet yellow mustard that was so incredible. Then we had fried cauliflower with a honey soy glaze - it melted in your mouth and was super light. Then we had my favorite dish that I can't stop thinking about quails egg w/ roasted parsnips and onions. The egg was so buttery and was served in a cast iron pan. It was heavenly. We then had octopus with tomatoes and a chickpea purée which was my least favorite dish - it was a little too savory and salty for me but my mom loved it and it was a good balance with the other sweet things we had. Then we had roasted mushrooms with an aioli and jalapeño which were just the right amount of spicy (barely any) and so creamy!!! We finished with roasted brussel sprouts, almonds and a chili sauce. The whole thing was delicious. They recommend 4-6 plates to share and we got seven and by the end I was stuffed! But it was worth it! I would recommend maybe getting less than we did, but there's so much to try it's hard to resist! Definitely somewhere to check out if you're vegetarian/pescatarian like me they're super helpful and accommodating our waitress allowed us to take meat away from the Brussel sprouts and any other veggie options with meat as a part of it. It was overall, a great time!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
The cocktails here are very interesting. I particularly enjoyed the on with eye whiskey. 
They encourage you to order numerous dishes as they are small portions. I didn't think the food was anything special...can't even remember what I got.

name: sur-lie
review_text: We ate here last night and the food and service were impeccable.  Thanks for a great evening!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Fantastic meal here. Highlights included the pea hummus, strawberry gazpacho, fresh salad with warm goad cheese, lamb bolognese (surprisingly light), and lemon dessert. Great service and drinks, too. Chef also came around which was pretty great. Wish I lived closer so could come back more often!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
We have had drinks here a few times, and dinner twice - dinner both have been excellent. 

We ate here during Maine Restaurant Week, and enjoyed it enough to come back with friends!

Tonight, we did the four cheese options - with additions like dried apricot with the goat cheese, a sweet jam with the blue, a poached pear with the cheddar, and a mustarda with the soft cow and goat cheese. The light, crispy slices of bread are very unusual and good!

I am not a cauliflower fan, but the roasted, sweet soy version is very tasty. 

This was all followed by fried potato wedges, the scallops, the lamb shoulder, and the Brussels sprouts (without almonds due to allergies). It was all amazing. 

Dessert was the flourless chocolate cake with espresso ice cream - decadent!

When we came for Maine Restaurant Week, I had the jam filled donuts, and those wee incredible!

I'm looking forward to another meal there!

name: sur-lie
review_text: We ended up here after a few other places were full and couldn't be happier.  Ruthie was an amazing server and the food and wine were fantastic.  The kids didn't always appreciate the spice but it was never overwhelming.  Truly a fantastic meal!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Delicious dinner!  We loved all our tapas but especially the sweet pea hummus and the scallops!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Sur Lie has become my favorite nice-meal restaurant in the city. Their menu hasn't changed much in the last year, but there are some dishes that keep me coming back. The sweet pea hummus is always a must. They also have a cod dish which may be the most delicious fish preparation I have ever had. The cod is tender and moist and comes with with a sauce that complements it perfectly. You also get a decent size fish for only $11. The Made Man is still my favorite cocktail- EVER. The music continues to be excellent and the staff very friendly and engaging. The best part of Sur Lie though is the ability to pick multiple dishes to try for dinner, its just so much more fun that way.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Sur Lie went above and beyond for Maine Restaurant Week by offering a 4 course meal. All of the food was delicious, however I failed to realize this was a tapas joint. I personally don't mine sharing food, if there is a lot! The "main course" plates were smaller than some of the appetizers which was disappointing. The chocolate espresso orange Madeline dessert was delicious, however the passion fruit panna cotta was not as firm as it should be. Glad I tried it for MRW and recommend trying!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Generally disappointed. They tried reasonably hard, some dishes were ok. Overall it was too expensive for what you get. We were kind of forced to order in a certain order (depending on the menu), we didn't get knifes (just forks), and we certainly weren't filled up with 5 dishes between the two of us. The dishes we did get were a bit too greasy and not super flavorful. I wanted to like this place but I was pretty disappointed.

name: sur-lie
