review_text: Ate here when visiting Portland and enjoyed every bit of the food and the experience. Sat in a booth right up front looking out at the street which was really fun. The presentation of the small plates, quality of the ingredients, and the variety of selections were excellent. My wife had a glass of red and I had a glass of white, both were perfect. Towards the end of the meal, the chef came out to greet us and we let him know how happy we were with everything. You can be sure I will be going back again next time I am in Portland.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Finally found a good old fashion. I got a good one in Sarasota FL and have been hunting for one ever since. Bob here made an amazing one.  He was great at explaining what he did and didn't mind me asking questions.  It literally got better over time! I have tried about 8-10 of them since I got back home and they have mostly been poor flavored or just watered down bourbon. Well done and thank you very much!

name: sur-lie
review_text: In a City filled with fantastic restaurants, this is definitely our go-to spot. We have been for my husband's birthday, a Brooklyn Brewery Beer pairing dinner, and just went Saturday night with our very best friends (all 6 of them) and it continues to amaze. Tony, Krista and their entire staff bring their very best game every time. Every dish we ordered was fantastic, the wine was perfect, the service was flawless. Please go and enjoy this experience! You will be very glad you did!!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Over priced and uninteresting. Putting micro greens on cold meat doesn't make it good. The wine I had tasted like it was open for days. My plate was chipped. The interior design is forgettable and the lighting is poor. They are trying but not quite hitting it. I couldn't recommend it and I definitely won't be back.

name: sur-lie
review_text: The first thought that came to mind for my first bite of every dish was "this is different". I had been wanting to try this place for a while now, and finally gave it a go for restaurant week. We started off with some cocktails which were great, and ordered a variety of dishes. It was a refreshing and unique change of pace compared to your typical American restaurant. They had a great balance of uniqueness and familiarity. For instance, the "potato tomato" dish was essentially a play on fries and ketchup without actually serving that. The only dish that was disappointing was a mushroom ragu pasta (not sure if it's on the regular menu) which tasted like something I made as a poor college student. Dessert was phenomenal and still very different than anything I've had before. Service was excellent and the environment is intimate. If you are feeling adventurous and getting tired of the same old places, go here!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
I'm giving 3 stars but would be so easy for them to move up to 4-5. I went with sister at 8:45pm. Service  was a bit slow from the start. Took about 15 min to get drinks from when we sat down. We each ordered 3 items. The waitress said they bring the items out as they are made. That's fine with me....I thought. The first two items that came out were my sisters and we don't really share. My first item came out 45 minutes after the order was placed and it was the pea hummus. The flavor was very good, only criticism would be that the flat bread for dipping was deep fried and too oily, not in a good way. Almost like the oil wasn't hot enough. I also had Brussels sprouts and poached chicken. The sprouts were ok, the chicken was good. Nice drink selection. 

I can understand small plates take a while to make but had the chef focused on food preparation instead of checking out what was on his phone and chit chat in the dinning room, I'm sure I could've had my food at least 30 min earlier. At one point, there was only one person in the kitchen for about 20 minutes with 20-30 patrons. Maybe breaks or ordering and booty shaking in the dining room should be saved for after the food is presented? Just an idea to speed up service.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Wow. Probably one of the top 5 restaurants I have ever visited. Everything was absolutely amazing - food, drinks, service. Keep doing what you're doing. Chef is an absolute genius!!!! My favorites of the night was the lamb bolognese and octopus. We ordered 7 plates and two desserts... the only plate we weren't thrilled with was the pea hummus but I think it was just a taste preference. Wow is all I have to say.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Their new brunch is one of the most fun dining experiences in town. A total tapas success because of the genial and relaxed atmosphere.

We ordered 4 dishes for 3 people, plus beers and cocktails. Very reasonably just around $100 with gratuity. The verdict: all tied for 1st place. Donuts, Fat Boy Breakfast, Broken Egg, and Kedgeree with trout. These merit a breakdown especially because of the--yep, I'll go there--curated experience provided by the very thoughtful chef, Emil Rivera.

Donuts: crispy crusts, taste more akin to fried dough than a typically sweet donut. Sweetness comes in the form of a cream cheese frosting/drizzle. I am less partial to sweets, for me this was perfect.

Fat Boy: quite sweet for me and still very enjoyable. Basically their very out-there (I think) version of a Benedict. A sizzling skillet with a pancake, sprinkled liberally with bacon and sausage, a browned, lacy, Spanish fried egg (very into this) and a light cheddar sauce.

Broken Egg: what it sounds like, over thinly sliced homefries. There were other features I can't recall. This was the deliriously good part of the meal to me.

Kedgeree: spectacular finish with brown rice and spinach. Light, salty, tender. Wonderful way to round out a decadent meal.

All drinks were delicious. Personally I tried the Pied Piper and the Little Bit of Lima. I am prone to like bitter and spicy and herbal cocktails and both satisfied.

The sunny dining room feels much more reclusive than its location would suggest. I do look forward to having an evening on the bar side.

Extra points: I always love when the owners are hosting, and really appreciate the fresh salt scrubs available in the powder rooms.

name: sur-lie
review_text: We ended up at Sur Lie after unsuccessfully scouting out restaurants closer to the docks and our venture slightly farther uphill was well rewarded. From the moment we arrived, the staff could not have been more welcoming. They quickly seated our party of four, where the server gave an awesome description of their inspired specials and answered any menu questions we had. The plates were reasonably sized for a tapas-style restaurant, and were easy to share between us. Overall, I was disappointed we didn't start here first, as it was precisely what we were looking for.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
For my first visit, I just had a few appetizers.
Agree 100% with everyone else the Sweet Pea Hummus is to die for!
The fried cauliflower in an Asian soy glaze, was just ok.
Also had the Mussels Escabeche, was described to me as a pickled mussels dish,
turns out, I don't like that, LOL.  So next time I won't order that :)

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Really enjoyed this place! It was fun trying the different dishes! Pork belly was amazing and the maple donut desert was out of this world! Having myself gone through oral radiation all summer and having compromised taste buds the flavors of the menu items I had there came through for me in a way that my own " everyday" cooking does'nt! Thanks for a wonderful dining experience! John 
BTW great cocktails too!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Went here for brunch on Easter --SO DELICIOUS. Quickly discovered that the portions are relatively small and are "made for sharing". That being said, The lox toast was scrumptious, the presentation was beautiful and my favorite out of everything we ordered. Our server also informed us that they cure their salmon in house! The donuts were out.of.this.world. Super sweet, yet delectable. I also had the privilege of trying the hash which was also worth every morsel. 
Now, for the drinks... The Bloody Mary tasted "different" than your typical bloody found at other brunch spots in town, but the more I drank it, the more I enjoyed it. It seemed as though they make their own bloody mix from scratch?!
Last but not least...they have 10$ bottomless mimosas! That's what's up. Although this isn't your average brunch or breakfast spot based on prices and portions, sur lie is highly recommended and I am definitely going back.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
In a town overflowing with restaurant options Sur Lie deserves to be listed among the top options Portland has to offer. 

Our waiter was tremendous and guided us to excellent selections with each dish seemingly better than the last. Being that this is tapas you make a lot of choices on your plates and with their great staff our taste buds were overwhelmed with deliciousness. 

Top shelf food without feeling snobby and a really cool bar. One of the best restaurants in Portland.

name: sur-lie
review_text: We flew in from D.C. this afternoon and just finished a delectable feast at Sur Lie. Top choices included That Carrot Dish, seared scallops, and pea hummus. Pleasant classic rock music and mason jar light fixtures filled the atmosphere as crafted cocktails whet our appetites. Thanks for a delightful evening!

name: sur-lie
review_text: New to the area and brought my family from out of town here over the weekend. Great vibe, very calm and spacious. We had the Semi-Booth in the corner and it was very comfortable, the service, food and drinks were great!

name: sur-lie
review_text: We went here for a bachelorette party. The bride is a vegetarian and has a nut allergy and still had so many options to pick from. The food was delicious- she loved it and was so happy we came here. Tony and his staff were so accommodating and welcoming. The service was absolutely impeccable and beyond expectations. Would definitely recommend Sur Lie.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
This place has a great atmosphere, friendly and helpful staff, and tasty food. 

Atmosphere/Ambiance: dim lighting, woods, metals. It's a nice atmosphere to feel like you're having a great dinner in a modern but rustic place. 

Food: I had the scallops, the Brussels sprouts, and the cauliflower. The scallops were perfectly cooked (beware of baby cilantro garnish if you're like me and have cilantro-aversion), the sweet potato purée it sits on is nicely seasoned. Cauliflower was great too. Nice texture and the sauce is a nice compliment but know the honey comes through with the citrus. If you're looking for something savory, this won't be the dish for you. Which brings me to my favorite dish of the three, the Brussels sprouts. It was perfectly roasted, played and the accompanying flavors were superb. 

Drinks: I had the Poseidon's Wrath and another that's name is escaping me. Poseidon's wrath was my favorite of the two and given my liking for not-sweet drinks and bourbon, this was great. Persimmon flavors in it came through without being too tart or sweet. 

Overall, an amazing find for dinner and/or drinks in downtown Portland for the local and traveler.

name: sur-lie
review_text: We had a great experience from start to finish!  We were up here celebrating our anniversary, and I searched for a fun spot to have dinner.  I loved how I could make a reservation on Yelp, and it reminded me a few days ahead.  We got promptly seated, they also served us complimentary bubbly for our anniversary (so nice)!  The food was delicious, our favorite was the Panko crusted pork cutlet.  Don't miss out on the house made donuts, they change the flavor according to the season.  THEY WERE BOMB!  Both owners were there, and they are delightful!  You won't be disappointed

name: sur-lie
review_text:
You know what's more delicious than creative small plates and perfectly crafted cocktails? Creative small plates and perfectly crafted cocktails with incredible customer service (which seems to be the thing new places in town care the least about, because its not what gets them national recognition from food and wine outlets). Sur Lie, without a doubt, has instantaneously mastered the triumvirate of a good night out and for THAT I'm giving them five-stars.

Add on top of that a warm, open space in a more unique part of town and there's very little not to love.

The low-lit, woodsy location is broken into two spaces: there's the long, wide bar on one side that had the biggest, baddest lumberjack looking fella I've ever seen in my life behind (is it weird that I wanted to arm wrestle him?); and to the left was the dining room. We were seated in booths by the windows which was romantic in a way, though I admit a bit chilly.

Our server - Jennifer - was insanely patient, pleasant, and lovely. I used to be polite when I went out, asking a few questions here and there about the menu. Now? I'm outright obnoxious - but it's because I really am genuinely interested in EVERYTHING - the menu, what they like and don't like of it, what's vegetarian ("can you please double check with the kitchen on that?"), the space, the community's reception, the happy hour deals, etc. So when our server first greeted us, I warned her to be prepared for a barrage of direct questions... she handled each with grace and knowledge.

Cocktails: SOOOOOO reminiscent of the bars I've been to in NYC regarding price and size. I had the one-two-punch of perfect autumnal drinks; despite their ingredients, both had the perfect balance of sweet, tart, flavorful, and alcohol-y (if that makes sense). 
- Grey Ghost ($10) - Dickel White Whiskey, Baked Apple & Pear Syrup, Lemon, Angostura Bitters, Pink Peppercorn (love, love, love the addition of the peppercorn!)
- Nectar of the Bogs ($11) - 8 Bells Rum, Vermut, Cranberry Shrub, Decanter Bitters, Angostura (faintly cranberry and verrrrrrry easy to drink!)

Food: large portions than other small plates in town (thank you for that, Sur Lie... small plate doesn't have to mean "one bite") and ever-evolving/rotating. We had:
- Sweet Pea Hummus ($7) - THIS IS ONE OF THE BEST FOODS I HAVE EVER EATEN. Period. My brain exploded in dopamine on that first bite, my heart broke on the last bite, and I have since dreamt about this. It tastes like cold, rich English mushy peas, with a hint of mint oil. The lavash that comes with it is the exact texture and saltiness to perfectly accompany the hummus - and the staff brought us out more lavash when we had run out at no charge. Bliss! Heaven! Yes, please! 
- Pear and Pecorino Agnolotti ($12) - So rich, so creamy, so flavorful! A bowl of this on a cold winter's day could chase away any blues, me thinks. If you like traditional Italian flavors, this will be right up your alley.
- Egg & Tian ($7) - Enh. It's nothing I'd personally eat again. I thought it was a very wet dish along with tasting overly acidic, yet bland.
- Fried Baked Poatoes ($6) - Again, enh. My significant other announced he could eat a bowl of these with a beer for dinner every night and be a very satisfied man, though. I did appreciate the nori dusting on them, though - I think that was a very fun flavor addition!
- Flourless chocolate cake ($7) - I sweet talked my fella into dessert, and we got the flourless chocolate cake with candied orange. This is everything I want in a post meal sweet treat. It was dense, fudgey, rich yet bright and sugary with the candied orange. Just lovely, especially with a cup of coffee!

While Portland is becoming a crowded food and drink market, I think the spill over from other restaurants in town (whether because it's too crowded or you may be disenchanted by it) are going to be beneficial to the new wave of restaurants opening up. For me, Sur Lie - as long as they continue to feel welcoming and have the exceptional customer service they've shown so far - will be my go to small plates in town and a place I would absolutely take my friends when they visit from bigger cities.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Lovely staff and tasty tapas sum up our experience at Sur Lie.
The sweet pea hummus, scallops and pork chop were the highlights of our meal.
The wine list offered decent wines by the glass; all in all a satisfying dining experience. My only suggestion: make the booth seating a bit more comfy- the wood benches are hard .

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Wow. Sur Lie is fantastic!  No matter what we ate (and we ate a LOT), it was all great. 

Fried cauliflower with honey-soy glaze
Gazpacho
Sweet pea hummus with lemon sabayon
Grilled chicken with wheat berries & arugula
Octopus with chickpea purée & tomato confit
Fried turkey drumette with tomatillo salsa, cotijo cheese, & pickled onions

Hands down, the octopus was the best preparation I have ever had. Everything was perfectly cooked, appropriately seasoned (I didn't need to add salt, which is unusual for me), and served at the right temperature. 

Service was helpful & friendly. The restaurant is low-key, but would do nicely for a fancy occasion. Noise is moderate. 

Chef Emil came around, as we were finishing up, to make sure we had enjoyed our meal. Small touches, like this, elevate the experience from very good to great.

name: sur-lie
review_text: We are at Sur Lie after our city hall elopement ceremony in Portland and we couldn't have asked for a better experience. Krista coordinated everything with me via email (we live out of state) and she helped make our special day even better. We had about 15 people in our party and took advantage of their family-style dining. It was course after course of delicious, up-scale small plates that everyone raved about after we left. There was more than enough food to go around and the waitstaff took exceptional care of us during our meal. Their chef is remarkably talented and you could tell by how delicious and beautiful the food was. This eatery takes customer service and food preparation seriously. I highly recommend them to anyone looking for a great dining experience. We can't thank them enough for working with us and making our wedding day memorable and especially delicious.

name: sur-lie
review_text: Fantastic dinner!  We ordered almost everything on the menu for 4 people.  Our favorites were the mushrooms and the fried chicken....oh, and the lemon curd dessert!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
We came for brunch, and everything we ordered unique and tasty. The staff was attentive and the chef came out and greeted us. I was very happy with my entire meal. 

We ordered the Triffle, which was the first thing to come out, and despite the fact that I am generally against sweet dishes I really enjoyed this. 

We got a Lox Toast, which we loved so much that we ordered another. Being from NY I am pretty picky about my lox, but this was fresh and tasty and went along well with the toast and egg salad. 

The Pavo Enchilado was also very nice and added some needed spice to the meal. 

Things took a unique turn with the Fat Boy Breakfast, which was decadent. It was so tasty and made me rethink my general disinclination for the sugary and fatty. 

Everything we ate was yummy and left me wanting to return for a different meal.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Sur Lie is a great new tapas bar on Free Street. You can call it Central Provisions lite. It's a somewhat similar concept but with lower prices and a less elitist vibe.

Like all the newer restaurants in Portland, the long bar dominates the main room, though there is a second lower key dining room. The cocktail menu is diverse and fun, with drinks in the $10 range. A smoky mescal cocktail reminded of campfires and was unique and delicious. A whiskey concoction was equally creative. Of the 4 small plates we ordered, only the mussels disappointed. Maybe I enjoy the experience of removing them from the shell, but this shell-less version in a sweeter sauce was only ok. The green pea hummus was the most original take on hummus I've ever seen, and it worked. Fried oysters were great, as expected. The pork belly was the highlight of the night. It disappeared quickly.

The lead bartender looked like central casting from Sons of Anarchy but was the nicest, most knowledgeable bartender I've had in a while. He recently moved from DC and is a great addition to the Portland bar scene.

Sur Lie has good food, great drinks, and a friendly atmosphere that doesn't have the pretentious vibe of similar restaurants. I can't wait to go back.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Headed here for Maine Restaurant Week and Sur Lie did not disappoint! The menu was a bit different than what was posted online, so I've included it below by course number. We had far more food than expected given the tapas nature of the place. We left very full and weren't able to finish most of the courses. 

The Sur Taters and Pot de Creme were our favorites of all the dishes with the Cauliflower soup rounding out the top three. Special mentions to the ricotta on the Green House Salad and the lemon sabayon on the hummus. I could eat a bowl of each on their own!

1) Sweet Pea Hummus
1) Maine Board - Pineland Farm, Rustic Cheddar, Smith's Log Smokehouse Sausage, house pickles, roasted garlic, toast point
2) Green House Salad 
2) Cream of Cauliflower - shrimp, ham, corn, ricotta, basil oil
3) Sur Taters
3) Lamb Bolognese
4) Passion Fruit Panna Cotta
4) Chocolate Pot de Creme

Drinks: Forest Moon of Endor & Stubborn Mule plus a complimentary aperitif. 

MRW menu was $35 and we each had a drink so including tax and tip, total per person was $57. If we were coming on a regular night, we probably would have kept it to 6-7 dishes for two people. 

I could easily see myself coming here just for drinks and dessert. The food is spectacular and the attention to detail is on point.

name: sur-lie
review_text: My new favorite go-to. I have waited until I ate here three times to review - thinking that maybe I just got lucky the first time I ordered at the bar. Interesting mix of house cocktail ingredients. Great tapas all-round. don't miss the one with the carrot and duck egg. Their frequent use of "micro greens" may be a little cliche, but the flavors in everything I have chosen have been perfectly assembled.  I'll be back again and again.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
Great atmosphere... Went to celebrate my daughter's visit for mother's day. Drinks were good. I made a reservation using Yelp, I ended up sitting an hour later than expected, but that was not a big deal. My only complain would be the time it took our server to bring food to the table. We started with the sweet pea hummus (just ok), our favorite were: Scallops, Ceviche and Octopus all very good!
I would go back to Sur Lie with no regrets... My suggestion, get at least another waitress/er. Good experience for a group gathering and casual diner

name: sur-lie
review_text: Sur Lie features delicious plates to meet your vegetarian and carnivorous needs. The Brussel sprouts and cauliflower dishes are simply marvelous. The swordfish ceviche and beef short ribs were full of flavor and had delicate and mouth watering presentations and delivered fully in that visual promise!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Sur Lie surely lives up to the hype! Everything we tried was delicious. Cocktails were on point. Wait staff was informative, friendly, and attentive. Chef Emil came out and introduced himself. Top notch restaurant. Give it a try, you won't be disappointed.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
From walking in the front door to receiving the check, Sur Lie is amazing. The host was so friendly and accommodating, and seated us right away with a smile and a delicious aperitif to start our meal. The wine list was great and the cocktail list creative, and we appreciated the emphasis on local beers. 
While I have eaten at tapas style restaurants before, the meal at Sur Lie is truly unique. We started with their seared tuna special, which an enjoyable play on the tuna roll, followed by their sweet pea hummus accompanied with lavash bread, which was delightful and refreshing. Next was the grilled chicken (our safe option) which was tasty, but the true star of the meal was the braised short rib that followed. It was a mix of hearty flavors of comfort food with a careful and harmonious balance of flavors, and was probably the best bite of food I have had in a very long time. We finished up with a small plate of cheese, a final glass of wine, and left full and content. 
Thanks so much to the owners, waitress and chef who delivered a perfect dining experience!

name: sur-lie
review_text:
We've heard great things about about Sur Lie and looked forward to the experience. We were not disappointed. We arrived early for our reservation but they were able to seat us immediately which we appreciated. 

The service across the board was friendly and attentive. I did feel a bit rushed by the waitress as she seemed to want us to order all of our small plates up front. We opted to take our time and order 2-3 at a time. She seemed perfectly OK with that and the taste sensations began. 

We were very happy with each selection. Here's what we had: Mixto Olives, Beets, Cauliflower, Fried Chicken, and Brussels Sprouts. Our selections were veggie-centric but there are many nice meat choices as well-we'll go there next time. We finished with the blueberry donuts - so good. 

Great place!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Had a great dinner at Sur Lie, the food and wine were delicious. Our server was also very nice and helpful. We had a 4 month baby with us in a car seat and they were very accommodating to help us find a good place to sit with her. Also, very reasonably priced for the quality. Had a great experience between the amazing food and exceptional service. Highly recommend.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
If I'm being honest with myself, this is my honest review. My friend and I went to try Sur Lie after reading amazing reviews. Womp womp.

I'm going to say part of it was our fault, and some of the blame falls onto the food. We ordered four plates - an arugula salad, the sweet pea hummus, the poached chicken, and the head on shrimp with curry sauce. The salad was dainty and the hummus was good (though not life altering like some reviews suggested - too much hype) 

The poached chicken was blah - a terrible consistency (I like tender, I don't like mushy) but I should have realized that was a possibility with boiled chicken. The shrimp was okay - flavorful enough but not great. 

I love this concept, though it has been overdone a bit in the recent 7-10 years. I might give it another try some day, but I wasn't blown away like most reviewers.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
I like my couch. I mean, really REALLY like my couch. So to get me to go out to dinner is actually quite a coup. Lunch? Sure! Dinner? Rarely. I mean, c'mon people, there's good TV on tonight! That said, I went out to Sur Lie at a friend's recommendation. My hubby and mom were coming with me - he likes lots of meat, she likes lots of veggies, so the menu seemed like it would satisfy both.

And. It. Did!

I expected the food to be delicious, and it was. The beet salad with the very clever name I cannot remember was extraordinary. As were the oyster mushrooms - some of the best I've ever had. And oh my, that pea hummus. Fabulous. So light and airy, yet incredibly flavorful.

Really what was more impressive to me was the service. I had been told the service here could be quite relaxed, which scared me, as we had a show to catch and didn't want to be late waiting for the check. We informed our server and she was not only gracious, she managed to get us out well in time to catch our show. Wonderful!

Little plate restaurants aren't for everyone, true. But if you like little plates and enjoy elevated dishes, Sur Lie is definitely worth your time.

On a side note, they have incredibly attractive hosts, waitstaff and especially bartenders. Not that it matters...but it never hurts to have something nice to look at while waiting for your table!

We shall be back. With more friends!

name: sur-lie
review_text: As far as I'm concerned, Sur Lie is a less crowded version of Central Provisions, which is commonly considered the preeminent tapas restaurant of Portland, Maine. There are small plate inclusions to satisfy any palate accompanied by a fantastic, well-crafted cocktail list and several quality local beer selections on draft. I've never gone wrong ordering any of the specials on the menu as well. 100% recommended as a romantic date night or casual night out for dinner and drinks, especially if looking for last minute reservations.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
3.5 stars. The service here is great -- friendly, helpful, not pretentious. We had an excellent bottle of wine. The cheese plate was really good -- teeny portions of cheese, but that tends to be the case) with a beautiful arrangement of paper-thin crisped bread and watercress. 

The rest of the food was fine, but not particularly special. We had "That Carrot Dish" with a duck egg and meaty, carmelized carrots, which was decent. The Spanish octopus was just OK; the sauce lacked dimension, and there wasn't a lot of flavor to the octopus itself. The brussel sprouts with almonds (I think?) had excellent texture, but overall the flavor was too vinegary. The pot de creme with gelato, which we had for dessert, was to die for. So at least we started and ended on good notes. 

Bottom line, I'd come here again for a drink and a snack at the bar, but probably not for a full meal.

name: sur-lie
review_text:
I can't fully describe how amazing Sur Lie was in accommodating the very large party I brought there a few Saturday nights ago. There were 13 girls for a bacholerette party and I had a very hard time finding a reasonably priced restaurant that could fit so many. Sur Lie was kind enough to agree. They recommended we do a prix fixe chef tasting menu at $40 per person with dessert included. When we got there, the entire staff tended to our every need. The food was amazing! We received SO MUCH for our price and every course was perfect. The entire group raved about their dining experience and when it was time to leave, Sur Lie was able to charge each girl for only their own drinks and food which made life so much easier on me! 

Absolutely wonderful experience!

name: sur-lie
review_text: Very friendly.  Delicious drinks to amazingly tasty dishes.  The roasted cauliflower was magical and duck egg with mushrooms very flavorful.  Vegetarian delight!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
I hadn't been to Back Bay Grill since high school prom, so when a friend lost a bet and owed a free dinner, it was an easy choice. The restaurant instantly feels refined. Manager Adrianne basically conducts an orchestra in a manner you just don't see at other Portland restaurants. In comparison, I preferred my meal and experience here far better than a recent one at Fore Street.

Back Bay Grill is located in perhaps the worst area of Portland, but inside the restaurant is elegant and comfortable. I mildly felt like the elite from every Purge movie, but so it goes. Free truffle popcorn and irresistible freshly baked bread and butter are a fine start to the meal. The menu is traditional large plates, which is so refreshing in an age of small plate mania. Prices overall are cheaper than Fore Street, Scales or Street and Company, with half the entrees below $30. I'm terrible at describing food, so let's just say the famous steak tartare ($15) and duck breast with gnocchi ($35) still monopolize my dreams. The service (in our case the excellent bartender Jesse) is world class. You're paying for an experience at Back Bay Grill, not just a meal, and it won't disappoint. It's unquestionably a top three restaurant in Portland. Just don't park too far away.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
It's rare that I'm at such a loss on how to rate a place. I mean, I usually go by value as it relates to taste, quantity and overall experience. No degree of flair, trendy offerings or pretty presentation is ever going to make up for paying several times more than I should for average food. 

Now you know where I'm coming from, and you can judge the usefulness of the review on that basis. The only reason I'm at a loss here is that I try to be fair in my reviews, and I well know that people do not come here for the value, they often come to mark a special occasion. Only, I think there ought to be more to a high-end dining experience than over-the-top prices and an attentive wait staff. Still, Portland is getting gentrified, and everything is pricy. I get it. I tell you what, you decide.

First, let me state that the service was superb, top-notch, I couldn't have asked for more. The waitstaff and manager reflected better upon the restaurant than any other aspect of the experience (the bread was almost tied). The plates were pretty, in that smallish, gourmet style that is on again off again popular, and the menu, while seafood heavy, was somewhat interesting. Oh, and (again) the bread was great!

Know that the portions and menu structure are such that, unless you are a very light eater, you will be ordering an appetizer, salad and entree. I never order more than an entree, typically, as I just can't pack it in like I once could, but the portions are so very small here that you will likely leave hungry if you don't shell out for all three, and, perhaps, dessert.

For example, I ordered the filet mignon, mashed potato and delicata squash for my entree. The filet was the smallest I have ever experienced (and way overcooked, based on what I requested), sitting on a modest smear of fairly tasty mashed potato, garnished with a single (small onion ring sized) ring of squash (also delicious, I think?). The meat texture/taste was unremarkable. This rang in at about $40, and took me under 2 minutes to polish off, eating slowly.

You want a basic cream soup to help fill the void? That's $12, and, again, more a tease than sustenance. Someone in my party ordered a $12 salad, which consisted of 3 romaine hearts, light dressing, several tiny croutons and a few thin shards of parm cheese (there is a picture of this travesty in another review). I have made the same salad from Trader Joes ingredients for under $1 per salad. Having good friends in the food industry, I understand the economics of scaling up ingredients costs, but twelve times the cost is just beyond the pale.

Yeah, it's starting to feel like I'm just crabbing at this point, so I'll wrap this up. It is possible to come in hungry and leave full here, but not for under $70-80, without drinks. If the food was great, it might even be worth it, for that special occasion. That's just not what we found here. I could have eaten at most other places in the city twice for what they charged here, been served better food, and left feeling positive about the experience. If "special occasion" means that I must ignore the concept of value or quality, to be substituted for pomp and brand, then I'll politely bow out and cook this same meal at home...if I ever figure out how to get my hands on just one thin slice of squash, that is.

And stay off my lawn!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
So I went here last weekend with the lady as we were in Portland celebrating our 2 year anniversary and her 1 year breast cancer free. Woot *$%@#CANCER. 

This restaurant is very small about 35 total seating/tables available in the dining room and then maybe a 12 top or so bar. (Bartender was amazing) 

We walked from our hotel to the restaurant (maybe not the best idea) sadly the surrounding areas of the restaurant aren't that good (community centers, etc) it was very clear that there were some signs of drug use and homelessness in the surrounding area. With that said, I'd advise to just take an Uber or Lyft to the establishment (our driver confirmed this post departure) was the best idea.

Now that that's out of the way. The restaurant is PHENOMENAL. I literally can't say enough good things about this place, the gentlemen who was running the show was beyond attentive and ensured that we had everything that we needed and that it was up to our satisfaction. They have a number of wait staff that ALL checks in / up on you as well which was really appreciated. 

The food here was nothing short of superb. They make fresh bread in house and honestly, I could just sit here and eat the bread all day everyday. We had the mussels for an appetizer and honestly I'd never had mussels that were so decadent, they melted in your mouth. So good. 

Can't wait to go back here again when I'm visiting in the area.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
One of the best dining experiences I've had in Portland yet in the 3+ years I've lived here. We had a reservation, which didn't seem necessary as it wasn't overly busy. They also have free parking available after 5pm just down the street, which was super convenient. 

My fiancé and I like to think that we're wine snobs, but we were slightly overwhelmed by the wine menu. Our waitress was super kind and gave us plenty of time to decide; she gave us space but wasn't completely absent. 

From where we were sitting, I could see into the kitchen area which I found very cool. It was fun to be able to see them preparing dishes before sending them out to be enjoyed. The bar also looked cool and allows you to look into the kitchen. 

We visited during restaurant week and decided to order off that menu, although we saw food from the regular menu go by and were a little jealous. 

Probably the most impressive part of our experience here was actually after we left. I had asked for the other half of my entree to be boxed, but then left before it was given to us (oops). They actually called me (they had my number from our reservation) to tell us that we had left it behind. Thankfully, we were more than a few blocks away and were able to turn around and grab it. It wasn't even a very large portion of left overs, but I'm really pleased that they took the time to call us and offer to hold it for us. 

Definitely plan to come back and 100% recommend to others!!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
This place is on the higher end since but it definitely was all worth it. We decided on this place to end our trip in Maine. We ate seafood for breakfast lunch and dinner for almost a week and this place offered us something different. The filet mignon was on point! Super soft and juicy. It was just the right size too. And the duck, it's been years since I had duck and it was everything I hoped it to be. My parents had a restuarant when I was a child and I could eat duck 24/7 any meal I wanted from the entire menu and I always ate duck. The duck here was definitely different from what I had but nonetheless it was delicious. 

Our server Jesse, was very personable and super nice and easy to talk to. I never felt out of place at all even though it was on the fancier side. My husband had on a tee and jeans while I wore a sweater and everyone else was in nice dressy clothing but we still got treated just the same. 

The creme brulee was a nice dessert to finish off our meal, it had that nice crunch from the caramelized sugar and it wasnt burnt at all. The custard itself had a nice consistency and wasnt overly sweet. Again this reminded me of creme brulees I had back home almost half a decade ago. 

The staff there provided and outstanding dining experience. It wasnt just one person who was with us that night, and all of them were the definition of hospitality. As we left I couldnt help but have a smile on my face, who wouldnt? Great food, full bellies and amazing service. 

10/10 I would totally recommend. Heck if I came back to Maine, I'd come back here!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
I really loved the Back Bay Grill! 

The vibe inside was nice and very traditional. There is more of an upscale feel and I appreciate that. I did not have wine, but the list was extensive. 

The service was phenomenal. The courses came out quickly and they kept up with the requests from our big group (10+). They were very attentive and friendly.

In addition, the staff here bent over backwards to accommodate my vegan preferences. The server brought oil instead of butter for the bread and was able to have the chef prepare a vegan rice dish. It was delicious! The almond milk "ice cream" for dessert was so yummy. A must try with the blueberries.

I would absolutely return to Back Bay Grill and I am so thankful they were kind and accommodating.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
Lovely, old-school spot with spot on food, and warm service. It's a romantic, dim light place so highly recommend it for a date night. My husband took me here while on a birthday weekend trip to Portland. Food was simple, but well done, fresh and great portions for the price. It was in the $30s but the dishes would easily be $40+ in the NY area where we're from.  It's also nice to get a breather from just straight up seafood and in a different part of town. 

Started off with yummy warm bread, and butter (they can refill for you). Then, moved onto sharing a light, yet dry and flavorful Willamette, OR Pinot Noir. They have a big wine list. What we got, was $50 per bottle (Two Messengers). 

Then, we shared the peekytoe crab cake (delicious, meat, big to share) with a yummy tartar. And the crunchy, hearty Caesar with a creamy buttermilk dressing.  Croutons were small and not overwhelming ( a plus). The nice thing about the service was that they split the salad, and the apps for you. 

They change their menu daily. I think eating at 8pm was a bit late for Portland because on a Sat evening, the restaurant was not too busy.  We had such caring, kind, and knowledgeable service.  

I was lucky to grab the last halibut. The portion was huge - got 3 chunks. I think they were just cooking off whatever they had left. They otherwise would move onto scallops. The dish was prepared with a yummy mushroom risotto. 

My hubs got the famed duck breast, also huge, with lots of breast meat and confit. The confit, as usual, was delicious. It said it was brined with lavender but it hardly apparent. I think I liked my fish better actually. But this was good. Came with delicious gnocchi. 

There are many other mains to choose from - filet mignon, stuffed chicken leg, to salmon (it's supposed to be good), to two hearty options. It was yummy all-around. 

For dessert, we shared a decadent caramel sauced, caramel ice cream which came with whipped cream, and an almond lace cookie for yummy crunch.  Overall, I enjoyed it and it wasn't too sweet as the name would suggest. They put a nice candle in it and sent me well wishes along the way. 

Would recommend for something off the beaten path. Apparently it's a James Beard Award winner. 

$200 for dinner which wasn't bad for everything we got.  We were plenty full.  Got a nice seat in the corner and plenty of spots to choose from for 2.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Excellent . Best in Portland. Avoid at special occasions as can be loud, but service and food are exceptional.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
My boyfriend and I were in town and wanted to treat our selves to a nice dinner. We had reservations at the bar at 8pm. We arrived a couple minutes early but the couple who sat there before us ran over their reservation. The restaurant was very accommodating and also brought us a free glass of wine! It was really appreciated and they truly cared. 

Once we sat down we were served truffle popcorn and bread and butter. The popcorn was amazing. We actually ate all of it. The bread was warm and the butter was soft enough to spread. Our waiter who was also the bartender was awesome. He made sure to constantly check in and make sure to ask if we needed anything without being over bearing. We decided to order two appetizers and they were nice enough to split them on two plates before bringing them out. The crab cake was awesome had the perfect amount of acidity and had a bunch of crab meat through out. Next we decided to have the hearts of romaine salad which they also split. It was the perfect salad. 

For dinner I decided to go with the filet mignon which they cooked perfectly to what I asked. My boyfriend got the salmon. Both were amazingly cooked and perfectly complimented with their sides they came with. Overall the food and ambience were amazing. I think the price reflects the service and food you are getting. I would definitely come back here in a heartbeat the next time I'm in Portland!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
Definitely is the fanciest, smanciest restaurant in Portland.  

Food was excellent.  My girlfriend had the duck, and I had the salmon (which was farm raised - they mostly all are unfortunately).  Both of our dishes were really good!

We split the mussels as an app; also excellent.

They don't have any craft beers on tap, that affected the rating.

The service was excellent from start to finish, including the host at the door.

Place has a pretty high price tag.  Special occasion type place - fo' sho!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Over rated, Over priced. Chocolate pound cake dessert was very good. Service was great. I would give 5*'s for the service but I feel restaurants should be rated half for service & half for food. Sorry, I really wanted to love it.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Just returned from Back Bay Grill where I celebrated my 50th birthday. The service and setting were lovely, the Filet Mignon divine and the surprise complimentary Crème Brûlée for dessert the sweetest thing! My pics will do the rest of the talking!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: AWARD-WINNING wine list , Ever-changing tasty cocktails and one of PORTLAND'S finest bar experiences. The food is spectacular and their coffee and dessert list is always a real treat! Everything from appetizers, entrees, salads, and burgers are an A1 choice at Back Bay Grill. We have never been disappointed.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Hands down one of my favorite restaurant experiences ever. The food was perfectly cooked, all of the courses were paced super well, and the staff was above and beyond. Truly an amazing team there both back of house and front of house!!! If you're in Portland, this is a must-try!!!! Also get the créme brûlée :) thank you so much for an amazing time Back Bay!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: One last night in Maine and our friends from Freeport made reservations for the 6 of us still in town after our business meeting ended.  Oh my, were we ever glad they chose Back Bay Grill.  I thought San Francisco's dungeness crab was supposed to be the epitome, but here I had the finest crab cake I've ever eaten in my life.  I DID share, and not sure I made everyone at the table happy.  As my friend remarked, "I have been out-ordered!"  Yet we all enjoyed our selections.  I had a marvelous salmon preparation for my entree.  Wish I could go back again.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: If you like great food, if the presentation of food matters to you, if you like creativity when it comes to menu, if ambience matters to you and most importantly if you look for excellent hospitality - Then you have to visit Back Bay Ribs. By far one of the best restaurants when it comes to food and hospitality that I have come across in Portland. I really enjoy exploring new restaurants in different towns (I travel a lot) and Bay Back Ribs is the one where I would like to take all my special guests and dear ones in Portland. Every dish that we ordered was absolutely delicious, presented extremely well, the wine they recommended was Awesome and the staff kept checking with us every now and then with such a genuine smile. It was a Fantastic Experiece and I highly highly highly recommend this place to food lovers and especially to those who not only looks for great food but also amazing Experiece over all. Double Thumbs Up and 5 Stars from me.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
I unfortunately got sick after ordering our dinner and could not tough it out to stay. We cancelled our meals and the owner did not even let us pay for our drinks. Customer service like this should be celebrated... we'll be back as soon as we can because the menu looked incredible.
Hats off to the staff for how they handled the situation.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: I was expecting a great meal, I was gifted with an outstanding meal. My experience was perfect from beginning to end. The food here is absolutely amazing. The service is wonderful, the atmosphere is elegant, yet cosy. It is a must do in Portland!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
I don't have time to write many reviews - must be exceptional for me to make time. This restaurant is EXCEPTIONAL, and warrants a review.  I frequent GREAT restaurants in New York City, NJ, and pretty much everywhere I travel - point of reference.  Here is a summary on a scale from 1 - 10. 

FOOD: 10 - seriously, a 10.
SERVICE: 10
CLEANLINESS: 10
Great wine list by the glass or bottle. 

Very warm greeting from the moment we walked into this spotless, well-run establishment. Fine linens, and exceptional wait staff started shaping our experience.  Everything homemade. 

The mussels were among the best I've EVER had - plentiful for 3 people, served in a KILLER broth, and freshly baked bread straight from the oven.  The mussels were SO CLEAN and plump - really AMAZING. 

I had the duck, a signature dish. Cooked to PERFECTION, crisp skin, the whole thing just melting in my mouth. So many different flavor profiles, but staying true to the dish. Just AMAZING, and most restaurants fail with duck. 

Generous portions, EXCEPTIONAL STAFF, well paced, and DELICIOUS food. Dessert was homemade, and was the perfect ending to an incredible experience.

I don't use the word ETHEREAL often, but this place was one of the best restaurant experiences I've ever had.  Congratulations to the men and women professionals who NAILED it - well done.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Very good, traditional American cuisine in a classic setting.  All the dishes were perfectly prepared and professionally presented.  The lamb chops were among the best I've had -- lean and meaty and cooked medium rare.  Delicious.  The Duck breast dish was another incredible dish, with a portion of risotto and duck confit beneath it.  Lamb pappardelle was very tasty, but too little pasta and too much water marred the dish.  Deserts were above average, and the service was friendly and knowledgeable.  Overall, a solid, high class restaurant for a nice night out.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
We ate here last night and I am still full! 

It's the type of restaurant that can best be described as "old school." It's a safe bet to bring Grandma here, but the thing is that they do it really well. Saxophones played in the background throughout our meal. 

We had a gift certificate and being mostly vegetarian, we put off coming in because the menu wasn't all that inspiring. When we arrived we sat at the bar for dinner (it was warm and cozy) and were pleasantly surprised by a menu larger than what is listed on their website. 

Our server was extremely polite without being stuffy. She was all about us not eating meat but okay with eating fish. I really liked her!  

We had a glass of champagne ($9) and a Maine Beer Co Big Bottle ($13). Their wine list was quite impressive if that's your thing. 

We were given the (free) bar snack of truffled popcorn. Omg. This is the best popcorn I have ever had, hands down. 

Then came the (free) bread and butter which was warm, fluffy and just perfect. I could have eaten the whole loaf. 

We had our "amuse bouche" of little salmon and cream puffs. (Free) 

Next we split the muscles without the pork belly as an appetizer. The kitchen actually split the order for us so we weren't both hovering over one plate. This was extremely surprising because the order was HUGE. For $13, we were expecting just a couple muscles. 

So at this point, we have spent $13 on food and are pretty much stuffed! 

We each had a salad: the winter greens and baby lettuce. The baby lettuce was basically a Caesar with big shaves of cheese and garlicky croutons. Each component was well thought out and the dressing was delicious. The winter greens came with a hard boiled egg which was perfectly cooked. I think these were each $13. 

For entrees:
-Mushroom linguini which was so so so flavorful. The mushrooms were outstanding. ($18?)
-The Atlantic salmon: huge cut of salmon perfectly seared with what I think was couscous and some kind of root vegetable with baby shrimp. One of the best salmon dishes I have had! ($30?) 

We had to try dessert even though at this point we were busting at the seams. My only complaint is the dessert menu wasn't too diverse (it was old school). It was mostly ice cream which I wasn't feeling.

I went with a decaf cappuccino (delicious) and the vanilla chiffon cake with lemon curd, some kind of vanilla cream, and crumbled almond cookies. It was very good! ($9)

Today, I must run 30 miles to burn the calories off. 

It's a great place for a nice meal, or even to sit at the bar and have a drink, popcorn, muscles and bread and leave extremely full for a cheap price tag. I hope you check it out!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
Portland, ME is a great food town, and Back Bay Grill makes it that much better.  

Duck simply incredible.  This place is a 10.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
I don't live in fancy town. I can't afford to live in fancy town, but every once in a while I like to visit there.  When I take the trip, I pack my bags and head to the Back Bay Grill (if I'm going to fancy town, I'm gonna go to the right place, okay!?!)

When you enter you are immediately greeted by Adrian, who is friendly, energetic, and makes your initial interaction so positive you won't be able to turn and walk away.  The atmosphere is classic, white table clothes, servers dressed in white button ups with black pants, place settings... It's all there, and it looks beautiful.

The cocktails are made to perfection and the bartender, Evie, has a quick wit and gives a great recommendation.  I had a cocktail called the Queequog (I have no idea how to spell this) which was smokey and strong. 

Appetizers are all about presentation and flavor. I think the chef must have sold his soul to the devil because the beef tartare is something from another realm.  I lived in Montana, where I swear they must have slaughtered the cows behind the restaurants, the meat was so fresh.  But, the Back Bay Grill has the most incredible beef tartare I've ever tasted.  It's smooth, perfectly seasoned, simple and elegant. I dream about this. I'm not kidding.

I was there with two friends and we all ordered different entrees.  Each one was delicious. Everything was delicious, from the cocktails to the dessert. We sat there for 3 hours, enjoyed a three course meal, and had a great time.  Next trip I take to fancy town, you better watch out BBG, I'm coming for you!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: This is as good as it gets .... in any city .... anywhere.   First visit to Portland and this restaurant came highly recommended.  Surpassed all expectations.  The service staff moved about flawlessly and discreetly.  And the food?  Just mouth-watering from the amuse bouche of salmon w/capers in an aoli, to the homemade caramel ice cream.  In between there was an other-worldly foie gras served atop a homemade Belgian waffle w/maple/balsamic glaze - true perfection.   The rack of lamb was the most tender I've ever had, and perfectly prepared.   The paintings and decor give a relaxed romantic vibe.  This is most definitely worthy of a return visit!!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Took my husband here for his birthday and they did not disappoint. The service was great and the food was amazing. We had the duck and pork chop and both were devine. They also through in a free desert for his birthday which was very thoughtful and equally delicious.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
There are a LOT of places in this town where you could easily drop $200 for a dinner for two, and many of those other places are pretty, damn good, but in my opinion, none of them touch Back Bay Grill.
Back Bay Grill has been a mainstay in the Portland food scene for about 27 years or so.  In that time they have perfected classic dishes and cocktails, grown long term relationships among their staff and developed a warm and welcoming customer approach. 
I have never been to any restaurant where the staff is so accommodating and flexible.  I can see why "regulars" return again and again. 
This atmosphere spreads among the customers as well.  I have seen patrons eating alone at the bar, and by the time they are ready to go, have made new friends with the people sitting next to them.
Adrian, the Maitre D', and Evie the bartender are of particular note for their warmth and humor.  Adrian has instinctual people skills and greets patrons at the door in a way that can make you feel like you have finally arrived home for a very special meal.  Evie, aside being a gifted mixologist, keeps a congenial conversation going with those eating with her at the bar.
While anything I have ever ordered off the BBG menu has been incredible, particularly memorable are:
Starters
The Steak Tartare-Do not spend a moment on hesitation!  I often dream about this one!
The Mussels-Pair with some of their house baked bread!
The Crabcake-One gigantic expertly prepared crab cake
Entrees
The Duck-I NEVER order duck anywhere else, but ALWAYS order it here!
The Filet Mignon-Medium rare actually comes medium rare!  A rarity!

The salads are all wonderful as are the desserts 

If I lived a different kind of life (and were not an elementary school teacher), I would love to be a regular at BBG.  I pacify myself with the thought that maybe Back Bay Grill is all the more magical if you only eat there on the most special of occasions.  Regardless, if you are looking for a place to celebrate, or are just plain loaded, call and make a reservation.  Let me know how it went!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: An unexpected find, with a fantastic staff and delicious food. We were greeted warmly and treated like royalty by Adrian. The dining room is comfortable and spotless. I thought the prices were a bit high-- $16 for an appetizer comprised of single scallop and some cauliflower-- but the food and drinks (our party had 2 apps, 4 entrees, 2 cocktails and wine) were outstanding and I hope to go back.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Wow we came here for my Birthday dinner and Back Bay Grill did not disappoint. We had the mussels for an appetizer and they were the best I have ever had fresh and cooked in a light sauce I would eat them everyday. For dinner I ventured out and tried the duck. I have never had duck before and now the bar is set wicked high. The duck breast was juicy and cooked to perfection. My husband had the filet cooked Pittsburgh style. The staff is so attentive the first person you see is Adrian and he does his best to make everyone feel welcome and special. Great dinner great staff

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
Great experience all around. Service was impeccable, we had Liana and she was perfection and thoughtful with all that we needed. As others mentioned you don't feel rushed here, this is truly a great fine dining experience down to the smallest of details. They take great care in all they do. Definitely a hidden gem.

Food was fantastic. Out of everything we ordered- mussels, scallops entree, duck and filet the scallop with risotto was an absolute standout. I still think of it now- it was so perfectly cooked and seasoned.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
Just awesome.  When you don't have to incur the high rent of the touristy waterfront locations, you can spend your money on excellent chefs, quality ingredients and experienced waitstaff.  Or that's how I imagine the thinking goes.  Anyway, it works at Back Bay, which is not near the waterfront, but once you go inside you are lost in the cozy ambiance and friendly service

We had the gravlox and romaine salad appetizers, then the fettuccine and stuffed chicken leg.  Everything was delicious and the portions large.  We were stuffed.

Not cheap, but definitely worth a return trip.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: On a Friday night this place managed to squeeze in a party of six. I was drawn to this grill because of the great yelp reviews and am very glad I came here. The kitchen and bathroom were immaculate. The food was extremely tasty and tender. The service is also fantastic. It was little pricy but was well worth it. I will be back next time I am in Portland.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Although this is ostensibly a "great" place to eat, it doesn't compare to all the truly great restaurants in Portland.  The place is very traditional so it is not surprising that the crowd skews decidedly older (55 and over).  The bottom line is that there is really nothing very interesting about the food...which would be fine if the dishes were brilliantly executed, but they aren't.  Our meal was very solid but it was certainly not worth the price.  The salmon was beautifully cooked but not very flavorful.  The duck was not over cooked but was underwhelming.  The hand rolled pappardelle with lamb confit sounded more interesting than it was and was way too salty.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Very happy with the variety of food available. I will be sure to visit this place again when I'm in the area. I'm also looking for a 2001 Ford explorer rear panel gas tank side if anyone in the area can help me obtain it thanks

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Another great meal. Mussels were perfectly cooked and lots to share. Mushroom fettuccine was fab. My husband had the spring salad and a perfectly cooked salmon served over spätzle and English peas. Add a Cosmo and it was a perfect meal.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: One of the best meals I've ever had!! Love the old school vibe with the white linens, frank sinatra music, old paintings! Food was excellent- started w mussels in a beef broth with kimchi ( great salt/acid combo). Had the duck for dinner - wonderfully prepared w both breast and confit leg! Finished w a vanilla bean mousse and they were even nice enough to write congrats on the plate as we were celebrating a special occasion. Will certainly be back and highly recommend for a special occasion. Excellent service too!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
Every aspect of dinner last night at Back Bay Grill was an A+.  I've had amazing dinners throughout the US and abroad over the past year, but this was #1 overall for service, food quality, and for a lively and jovial ambiance.  The Mussels and Foie Gras appetizers were fantastic.  The mussels were rare Bangs Island Mussels that were plentiful and perfectly prepared.  The Foie Gras was incredible and melted in my mouth. The Duck and Lamb main courses were perfectly prepared in accordance with our tightly conveyed specifications. The service staff and the kitchen are in perfect synch, as they clearly communicate and deliver on guest requests.

Adrian and Jesse were at the top of their excellent game in serving, and describing with passion, and with the perfect level of detail the way that each cocktail and dish was sourced and prepared.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: We had sausage stuffed chicken leg that didn't even taste like chicken and NO sausage stuffing, just some spices on whatever it was, filet that was grainy and duck that the waitress said was their house dish. Again. spiced to death and most of it left on the plate. service was VERY slow.  don't get what people are liking about this place. a lot of money for poorly prepared food.  this was our second visit but not again

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: I came here for a vendor meeting, and had an amazing time.  This place is really perfect for business meeting, it is just bright enough, cozy and warm. The wait staff were wonderful and I didn't feel being interrupted at all during dinner. I had the winter salad ($12) which was okay (1 star off). It was really heavy with lots of cheese toppings and dressing. The star of the dinner was the lavender duck breast. I got the tips from other Yelpers and I could not be happier with my choice. It was done just right, and the lavender seasoning went so well with the duck. I also tasted my friend's chicken and it was really good as well. We were too full for dessert but I will sure come back for me. I think the pricing is very fair for what they offer.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Best restaurant in Maine. Service 5/5, food 5/5, beverages 5/5, atmosphere 5/5. Everyone is friendly & professional.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Amazing place, great food and wonderful atmosphere. It's #1 for a reason. Everything from bread to dessert was five stars. And I'm really, really picky! It's not often that a place gets everything right but they do at Back Bay Grill. If I visit Portland again, Back Bay is at the top of my list.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: We had an awesome dinner here with great service. We had 3 courses and they brought out little "extras" in between just to taste. It was amazing and everyone was impressed!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Delicious and great service. I've been celebrating multiple special days here at back bay grill and they've been all great experiences. The food is top notch and the service is outstanding. Everyone is very friendly and the atmosphere is pleasant. Definitely a must try place if you're visiting portland Maine. It's difficult to make a reservation so make sure to call ahead! Great place for dates, group dinners, and any special events!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
This is a tough one ..If I could do a 4.5 star rating I would, I'll try to explain. The restaurant is located in a fairly dark (and coming from the East\North side) and somewhat sketchy looking part of down. They explained where could park, and it was both easy and a short walk to the door, but I have to say I was still a slight bit uneasy. As others have mentioned, it's tiny; 30-40 seats max is my guess, and it's in an old building with 20 foot stamped tin panel ceilings and old style lights. White table cloths and fresh flowers are nice for decoration, the mural in the main dining room is .. interesting. 

The menu our night had some of the things other reviewers have said. It's fairly small (several apps, a few salads, and a handful of entrees) but it all looked great. Had the Foie Gras and Steak Tartare for apps, Lavender Duck for entrees, and a dessert that had pistachio ice cream, small chocolate cake (flourless?) and chocolate and rasberry sauces. The food was all terrific. The staff were all (and several visited our table) extremely friendly, and when I had a question about a Rye based cocktail, they brought not one but two varieties of Rye for me to taste. I did end up getting the drink (a burnt orange Rye cocktail) and it was terrific.

I also wanted to mention that the seating is fairly close between tables, but I found the background music, table chatter and kitchen noise to be a nice level where I could talk to my wife fine but didn't feel like we were hearing conversations from the nearby tables. So, drinks, food, dessert and service were all very good. With 3 drinks, 2 apps, 2 entrees, and 1 shared dessert I believe the total came to $170. Though everything was very good, I'm not sure the menu and overall atmosphere quite justify that price level. But I do think the service was outstanding. So I'm giving it 4.5 stars. Bring the prices down slightly and remedy the dark sidewalk\parking situation and I'd bump that up to the full 5.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
Somewhere between 3 and 4 stars.  Good, but, went in with expectations of something better.  Small.  Elegant, old school atmosphere.  Not pretentious in any way.  Maitre d' was great.  Helped us pick out some very good wine.  Service was sloooooow.  Crab cake appetizer, which I think they are very proud of, was a dud.  Nowhere near the flavor you will find in Maryland (or SF).  Duck was exceptional.  Steak was mediocre.  Neighboorhood is very sketchy.  No parking lot, so you park on the street or in the lot of a municipal building amidst the homeless.

Bottom line, this is a good restaurant.  But, it came recommended as a very good restaurant, which I don't think it is.  Very pricey, all things considered.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
We thoroughly enjoyed our dinner at the Back Bay Grill. The cuisine is delicious fine dining with a more affordable price than other similar restaurants. The interior of the restaurant is simple and cozy with it's white linen tablecloths and plush seats. 

We enjoyed everything we had. The most memorable dishes were:
Truffled Beef Tartare $13 (topped with a farm fresh egg yolk, cornichon, white anchovies, and olive oil crackers)
Maine Crab Cake $14 (with arugula, pickled shallots, chili & lime aioli)
The portion was small but the crab was fresh and very good
Lavender Marinated Duck Breast $30 (duck confit, roasted cauliflower, curried cauliflower risotto, roasted apple)

The Back Bay Grill is an easy decision to make for an intimate dinner with good food in Portland.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
This is a wonderful special-occasion restaurant. Any time would be good, really, but it's pricey although well worth it. We celebrated a birthday here tonight and had an outstanding meal and service. We both had the rack of lamb and it might be the best we've ever had anywhere. We shared a salad of fresh organic local greens with Stilton cheese and candied walnuts, a sublime combination. The bread appeared to have been made in house and was served hot. When we called for a reservation for two, we were given the choice of 5:00 or 8:30, and chose 5:00. We were the only customers for a while, but in looking around saw that they don't have many tables for two, perhaps three altogether. 

Given the quality of our meal, service, and setting (including the music, good selections, neither too loud nor too soft), it's no surprise that Back Bay Grill has stood the test of time.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
The Back Bay Grill is located in downtown Portland on Portland street. The dining room is smartly decorated, with well spaced tables. The menu is culturally varied with Chef Larry Matthews own American influence. The menu offers a nice selection without being too long. 

A starter of Maine Crab Cakes with arugula, shallots, chili & lime aioli was a nice intro dish and was not to heavy. Next was salads, which I had the heirloom tomato salad with arugula, basil, tomato vinaigrette, goat cheese, and a balsamic dressing. My gosh it was delightful, light, and packed deliciousness. My main course was the North Atlantic salmon with a creamy fettuccini, smooth butternut squash puree, roasted red peppers, and seasoned asparagus. 

Service was great and never felt rushed. Though dessert looked appealing we were all to full to indulge. 

Parking can bec tricky on Portland street in the evening as most park there to walk around the city but it is worth the effort.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
My new favorite restaurant in Portland. Exceptionally beautiful, tasty food and thoughtful service. 
They were able to modify a scallop appetizer to omit bacon for me; and we left with the overall impression the waiter would give us his first born child if it would make our dining experience more pleasant. Yeah- they're just that good.
The small touches (their logo carved into the butter, the small amouse before and after dinner were charming) really sets this place apart from other fine dining restaurants. 
And the food? Oh, the food. The crab cake was bright and clean- the fennel slaw on top was a great touch; the salmon entree was cooked perfectly and was a nice reminder how the simple things (like salmon and dill) sometimes are just the best. 
Can't wait to return again next year.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
The crew and I ended up here as part of our monthly Superdate ritual. That is, six of us came on Saturday evening for dinner (in a limo, after finishing ballroom dancing lessons; don't ask - it's a Superdate thing). 

The awesome:

- FOIE. This get its own line in the list, and must absolutely be tried. 
- Service, service, service. Polite, prompt and courteous wait staff who ask questions like "do you have a bourbon preference in your old-fashioned?" 
- All the other food. I had lamb two ways, but the rest of the table had a wide variety of stuff - including the filet, pork, scallops, duck two ways, and other stuff I can't remember. But the three courses were absolutely brilliant, all around. 
- Drinks. Clever selection of cocktails, and an intimidating wine list. 

The could be better (and I'm reaching here):

- Beers in bottles. 
- One-at-a-time bathrooms. 

You're gonna pay for the experience, but I think it should be on your list of must-try spots in Portland.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Five star all day everyday! Even with a picky eater the waiter was accommodating and understanding. Watching the guys in the open kitchen do their dance was wonderful. I had the filet with foie gras which was perfectly medium rare and though I found out I am not a fan of foie gras I would say I'm glad I tried it here. My fiancée had the steak tartare which was nicely clean, fresh and cold. We split an order of fiddleheads because well it was the season and yet another thing for us to try. It's a must in Maine to try during the season which is short and if you must know they taste like asparagus and broccoli had a baby. The other two in our party played safe with the salmon which they enjoyed as well. An espresso and cordial for dessert was the perfect ending!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Great food, atmosphere and service!! My wife and I enjoyed our meal! Mussels were fresh and prepared well. I had the lamb dish which consisted of the rack of lamb and lamb sausage with goat cheese gratin! Delicious!!! If you're visiting Portland and need a great quality meal, this is the place!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
Thank you Restaurant Week!

With a $45 prix fixe menu, Back Bay Grill was an opportunity too good to miss. What made it even better was that neither one of us had ever been to the Back Bay Grill - despite having lived in Portland for years. 

The decor was somewhat dated... With artwork that looked like it may have been hung when Bill Cosby was still the king of Thursday nights. But that's really the only criticism that we could come up with.

The staff was friendly and attentive. Our waitress was familiar with both the regular menu and the Restaurant Week menu and was able to make recommendations to us from both. The wine list was quite extensive but again, we were able to rely on our waitress to provide suggestions that really hit the mark.

We both opted for selections from the three course Restaurant Week menu. I got the pork belly for my first course, potato leek soup for my second and seafood sausage for my entree. My date got the local skate for her first course, hearts of romaine salad second and the pork shoulder with polenta for her third course.

Everything was amazing! We shared each dish but couldn't agree which of the first course we preferred. We liked the skate and pork belly equally. The hearts of romaine was the clear winner of the second round... And based solely on its originality, the seafood sausage nudged out the pork shoulder (barely) for the win in the third round. 

We both agreed that based on the creativity shown in the prix fixe menu, we'll be back to try the regular menu. Soon.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: Absolutely delicious! From the moment we walked in, the waitstaff was attentive, professional and very helpful. Started with drinks which came out quickly and were spot on. Fresh homemade bread that was still warm was served warm with house butter. Appetizers...we had gravlox and the beef tartar. Both were delicious but that tartar was the best I've had since I was very young. Dinner was also delicious. My wife had the hand made pappardelle with lamb confit. I had the duck. The duck was cooked perfectly. The broth served with her lamb and pasta had a complex and amazing flavor profile. I actually dipped some of that fresh bread in it when she was done. Desert...chocolate goodness and creme brûlée. One of the better brûlée I have had and a special birthday wish from the chefs to my wife. Excellent night. We'll be back!!!

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
Extreme service, gorgeous ambiance and selection of food choices.
Loved the selections and the atmosphere.

I will be back 1,000 times.  

The star rating is much higher at a 10 in my opinion.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
After a weeklong trip that included some of the best restaurants in Montreal and Quebec City, I never thought I'd say my single best meal was in Portland. But, as all the other reviewers have noted, Back Bay Grill is absolutely amazing. The menu is compact but diverse, with at least one selection each covering beef, fish, chicken, lamb and duck. 

After much debate, I settled on an incredible corn chowder with potato, bacon, red pepper and lobster. I'm kind of a corn chowder junkie, but this was definitely in my Top 3. For my entrée I ordered the homemade pappardelle with veal meatballs and pancetta. The waitress brought a spoon as part of my set-up, which seemed strange for a flat, non-twirly pasta like pappardelle. But one taste of this dish, and it all made sense: When the pasta and meatballs were gone, I shamelessly tipped my bowl and spooned up every drop of the dark, rich jus. (Sometimes good flavor trumps good manners.) 

Three courses + two drinks = $90 per person, all in. Worth every penny.

Strictly in terms of food and service, Back Bay Grill would earn 5+ stars from me. But the setting definitely affects the overall experience, and not in a good way. The street is dark and kind of desolate, with dark storefronts everywhere, save for a couple of sketchy bars, where patrons slumped in the doorway kept asking for a buck "to catch the bus."

Would I run the gauntlet again to see what Back Bay Grill has on the menu? Um, yeah, in a heartbeat.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: food is good and mostly comfort food. the service is lacking and why I would deduct stars. crab cake was good with more crab than filler. mussels delicious. my husband liked his lamb and I liked my pasta dish mixed with a roast pork stew like sauce. however since the service is so slow and semi neglectful ..it really is not worth the wait.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text: This is clearly one of Portland's best restaurants.  Food, service and ambiance all hit high marks.  I did want to try everything on the menu, but since I was a part of one, I was restricted.

name: back-bay-grill
review_text:
From the moment you walk in the door, you know that you have come to the right place. Beginning with the warm welcome all the way through the meal to dessert, the food is delicious and the service is impeccable! 

They pay careful attention to detail and offer great accommodations for allergies. 

We visited the restaurant to celebrate a birthday last year (visiting from Boston) and eagerly returned a second time. Both times each and every dish was absolutely delicious! 

Don't leave without enjoying the desserts! 

Great place for special occasions! Great place for celebrations! Fantastic service!

name: back-bay-grill
