The ribs were juicy, smoked well and had a nice crust of seasoning that was fairly flavorless. The meat pulled nicely from the bone without coming away in one giant piece. The Brisket was surprisingly juicy and tender, not dry. Also a barely noticeable rub on the exterior.

Two sauces are provided: a vinegary brown and a smoky brown. Both are too similar to discern one from the other except that one reeks of ketchup and the other of apple vinegar while both have the same consistency. 

That being said, nothing can possibly create a modicum of sanity when the price per pound is calculated. The smoked meat is just not that good. I don't care how good it is, nothing is worth $56/lb.

Two varieties of chili are rich, packed with meat and very different from each other. The red chili is borderline fiery and full of brisket. The green chili is cooling and the perfect offset to the chunk of pulled pork that adorns the bowl

The beer and drink menu is sane. Other entrees listed seem interesting but not out of the ordinary. 

I recommend going to many other BBQ joints in Portland until Terlingua gets it's pricing worked out.

name: terlingua
review_text: I had a one day business trip in Portland and I'm a sucker for BBQ. I stopped in on a Monday evening. I had the burnt ends and ribs. The BBQ was amazing. They also have a full bar. The staff was very engaging and friendly. Their bar tender was extremely knowledgeable and helpful. Outside of the south you will be hard pressed to find a better BBQ joint. Highly recommend!!!!

name: terlingua
review_text: Small menu selection and not great vegetarian options. I ended up there because I was hungry and Silly's was closed (which I didn't realize until I got there). Small space and pretentious styling. Expensive for the quality and quantity. I tried an deviled egg sandwich, the pita was the only enjoyable part. Way too much mayonnaise and the tomatoes in it were mushy. I don't plan on going back.

name: terlingua
review_text:
Reviewing a restaurant their second night open may not be fair, but my personal experience was very good on a quiet Friday night, so why not? Terlingua is located in an unassuming facade (only the symbol is on the sign) adjacent to Silly's on Washington Ave. Inside is attractive with reclaimed brass tables from Nosh and a central bar. The restaurant is Latin American BBQ and some of the theme is translated to the decor. It won't wow you, but it's a comfy space.

Our excellent server quickly brought the drink and food menu. I LOVE how the restaurant has half and full portions for most of the entrees. Sometimes I'm not starving and don't want an expensive dinner. Half portions are still plenty filling and the $8-$10 price can't be beat. Even the $13-18 for full portions is very reasonable. 

I ordered the half portion of green chili with brisket (it comes with pulled pork on the menu but they gladly substituted). This was one of the better chilies that I've ever had. A sizable bowl of chili was filled with potato, corn and cheese and topped with slices of tender brisket. It already had decent spice, but adding house made habanero sauce brought me happily to tears. Three generous slices of grilled pita bread helped relieve the heat. 

The girlfriend is a (semi) vegetarian and her options consisted of two salads, a mushroom-based entree and a poblano-based entree. She chose the large ($11) leaf lettuce salad, beautifully presented with avocado, grapefruit, radish and a sesame seed dressing. She raved about it.

Desserts are presented in small mason jars and topped with ice cream. The apple pie was rich and tasty but would have been better warm.

The margarita ($7) was unmemorable, but the Texas Mojito (with Tito's Vodka instead of rum, $10) was perfectly refreshing on a summer night. The beer list is a decent mix of local and afar.

There are also BBQ boards of brisket, pulled pork and ribs that directly compete with Salvage and Elsmere but overall this is a different type of restaurant, and I'm buying the concept. Great food at affordable prices in a chill atmosphere will win me over every time.

name: terlingua
review_text:
We went for an early dinner (5pm) on a weeknight and had a great experience. The server was friendly and he was happy to explain much of the menu. Since it was early we were satisfied with a couple of apps, but we'll come back to try more dishes. 

The shrimp ceviche was awesome. The serving was generous but I still wanted more. 
The ribs were also very good. The first ones were very moist and tender, but a couple were on the dry side. A bit more sauce on the side could have helped with that. Overall they were tasty.

We each got a drink, he loved his bloody mary and my margarita was *not* from a mix (thank you!) with a chili-dipped rim. Both great, and $5 each during happy hour. 

Two apps and two happy hour drinks cost about $40 before tip, so a bit steep for a light fare but for $20 more it would have been a complete meal. We'll definitely go back.

name: terlingua
review_text:
We went for their 1 year anniversary party on Tuesday night and I can see why it has been getting such good reviews!  They have found a great home on Washington Avenue among the newer restaurant and drink scene.  

It was a special menu for the night, but after sampling the food we will definitely be back for their regular menu.  Tuesday night's fare included cucumber and strawberry slices with cream cheese, pork rillettes with a guajillo marmalade (yum!), duck two ways, a spring and asparagus salad, a pork shank and s'mores cake.  The pork shank was gigantic but tender and paired with some wonderfully prepared zucchini and squash, along with crispy grits.  

It was all paired with drinks from Maine Mead Works and Oxbow from right across the street. They all were perfectly chosen for the dishes at hand.  There were a great many of people from Oxbow and Maine Mead there as well and we enjoyed talking to them and finding out more about their drinks.

The restaurant is not large, but it is open and airy and very inviting, with a nice bar.  Overall this is a place that could become a regular for us though it is on the outer edge of our usual walking zone.  Highly recommend it!

name: terlingua
review_text: Excellent BBQ in a cozy neighborhood restaurant.  The waiter was knowledgeable and very attentive.

name: terlingua
review_text: This place deserves its awesome reviews and its place in Portland's foodie scene.  I got a bbq platter with baby back ribs, corn bread, beans and collard greens.  Everything on my plate was absolutely outstanding.  The atmosphere is hip, but even though I'm not hip, I felt comfortable.  The service was great.  HIGHLY recommend!

name: terlingua
review_text: Fantastic service, amazing atomsphere, and the Tequila selections are just amazing. This small place has a big impact, and should be on everyone's destination for food.

name: terlingua
review_text: Walked by the place while looking for a brewery, and decided to stop for dinner because it was full on a Tuesday. Got seated right away, had great recommendations by our friendly waitress, and felt a great vibe with the guitarist playing classics with a twist. The ceviche tostada (scallops that day) was excellent. And if you like spice, definitely try to marg with a chili rim and utilize the chili vinegar on your food!

name: terlingua
review_text: Second visit gets downgraded to 4 stars because of the noise level. The food was as good as it was on my first visit, and the service was great, but the noise was so bad that I probably won't be back. A full restaurant with no soft surfaces to absorb sound is noisy anyway, but add two guitarists and the decibel level becomes truly awful. The guitarists were very good, but the restaurant is way too small for live music.

name: terlingua
review_text: I was there less than a year ago. The speed of service was phenomenal, we got our ribs and the briquette within 5 minutes of waiting time! Meat was flavorful, the sauces could not be better! Truly enjoyed every bite

name: terlingua
review_text:
Girls night out for dinner. I had the Terlingua Barbecue Board. It was good but I found the meat to be a bit too fatty.
The pork belly however was to die for.

name: terlingua
review_text:
Have been into this cute spot a bunch of times and generally sit at the bar with the hubs and get snacks and drinks and have found this is the perfect place to do just that.

Had brunch this past Sunday with a gf - we walked in and it was packed with the exception of a 4-top, (two 2-tops pushed together) - we were asked to wait for a 2-top about 10-15 minutes which was fine since it was actually nice out that day (shocker this winter), so we went outside to get our vitamin d.  After a while we were sat...only to see the table we could have sat at was sat shortly after for just 2 people! Odd.

Server was a bit fresh, just had a cockiness to him, but whatever - when asked if anything could be switched for the pulled pork in the pulled pork benny he gave an abrupt "nope!" - instead of suggesting the kitchen doesn't prefer to do substitutions etc (which I would have totally understood as I have worked on and off in restaurants for years).  The benny sounded amazing but sometimes a girl just doesn't want a pile of shredded pork first thing on her Sunday morning ya know? Anyway I settled on eggs and a biscuit from the a la carte menu which were delicious, and my friend got a pastrami special which she seemed to enjoy.  We had a couple mimosas and were able to chat without being rushed which was very appreciated.  All in all 3 or 3.5 experience this round, but I've had plenty of 4-5 star experiences here thus my rating.  In the future I will just remain at the bar if there's space.

name: terlingua
review_text: First time visiting this restaurant and we will be back.  The food was excellent and the service was top notch. Our host was welcoming and it is quite obvious that he loves what he does along with the folks he serves. The drinks were delicious and moderately priced.  We ordered the bbq platter for 3 people.  Our waitress said that it normally serves 2 but it was more than enough. The collard greens were delish and the meats were so tender and juicy. Thank you for a wonderful experience.

name: terlingua
review_text:
My wife and I took our 2.5 year old son to Terlingua on Friday night.  We arrived just before 5:00 and the place was not yet crowded.  Since the BBQ isn't ready until 5:00, we settled in with some queso and very good, $5 happy hour sangria.  The queso was quite tasty, but served with few chips. Fortunately, the waitress promptly offered more chips that our son kept digging into.

Halfway through our queso and now past 5:00, we put in an order for the larger portion of pork shoulder, the lamb belly appetizer and a side of asparagus.  I must say, I've been here twice before and thought it was good (but not great), but tonight's meal was amazing.  I'm not even a huge BBQ fan, but the latin spin offers flavors more in my wheelhouse (and thankfully no potato salad in sight).

I tried the pork shoulder first, which was extremely tender with a nice bark.  The BBQ sauce they served was fantastic and we were told at the outset that more would be available upon request.  Our son initially didn't warm up to the pork, but he ended up eating a ton of it at the end of the meal after we thought he was stuffed.  We also went through that 2nd cup of BBQ sauce that's the best I've ever had.  Subtle and flavorful at the same time.

Then the lamb belly....wow.  I don't think it's been on the menu in our previous visits.  Otherwise, it's an epic fail on my part for not ordering it sooner.  I don't recall all the garnishes, but I believe there was some feta on top.  Our son loved it as much as we did.  Absolutely fantastic. 

Asparagus isn't my favorite, but the wife loves it and it was dressed up with bacon and some cheese sauce.  I found that dipping it in our remaining queso was quite nice.  Somewhere in all of this we got another round of sangria.  I remember thinking we've got quite a bit of pork to take home, but then it all disappeared. We couldn't stop eating, but didn't leave feeling over-full.

I'd be remiss if I didn't call out the service as friendly and prompt, although the place was just finally filling up as we left.  It seems that getting there right as the BBQ is coming off the grill is the way to go, if you can eat that early.  I have no doubt that the line would be around the corner if Terlingua was closer to the heart of the old port.

name: terlingua
review_text:
First time review on Yelp! Been using this app for quite some time now. Time to pay it forward. 

Just moved to Portland a few months ago and love the food atmosphere so far! I live nearby Terlingua and wanted to try it. 

Stopped by during happy hour (2p-6p). Ordered the tortilla soup and Michelada(adult beverage with Modelo). 

The soup I found to be a bit bland with little flavor and although it was a gorgeous, hot summer day, my soup, unfortunately was a little lukewarm. The Michelada was ok. 

Too bad my first review was not a stellar one. Been to other restaurants in Portland and have been blown away with great food. 

Maybe the dinner menu is better?

name: terlingua
review_text:
Stopped here on a whim, and it was well worth it. Only ones at the bar for a quick beer and sandwich. We meet the owner and his wife, and he was a Philly boy! 
I swear we can smell our own. I went with a short rib sandwich and it was Money.. I wish we had more time, but when we come back we are definatly stopping here again. Thanks guys..

name: terlingua
review_text: Not sure how Teralingua received four and a half stars. Ordered the tacos which I was told was a specialty. Dry meat, no cheese, no diced tomato. Not a value for $10.

name: terlingua
review_text:
This is one of the top five restaurants in Portland. Boom. 

The chili is amazing.  Period. End of story. You don't have to look anywhere else for good fucking chili. Red? Yes. Green? Yaassss! Small is enough for a light meal with an app and large is gut-busting but I won't judge you. Sure,  you can go to salvage and have a great BBQ but it won't have the finesse that it has here. Even as takeout, this food is prepared with the utmost care. 

Winter, summer, whatever the season come to this restaurant for the best smoked meat and some of the most exquisite hipster-brag worthy cocktails. They usually have a smoked meat of the day , tacos of the day ,  and their general standard menu. Good local taps as well (Foundation, Maine beer co., Bissell), mostly hoppy to pair with the barbecue. 

The servers are even pleasant at this restaurant. Only at boda and fore street have I had such consistently amazing food served by such consistently pleasant people.

I can tell you with certainty this is the BBQ dreams are made of.

name: terlingua
review_text:
Wow! Started with Happy Hour & then 
Proceeded to dinner. Had 2 appetizers & drinks then 4 dinners ( there were 4 of us).
The variety, presentation & tastes were 
beyond psentation. So perfect that we 
ordered a 5th dinner.  Go early!  Tiny establishment with limited seating

name: terlingua
review_text:
This place is really good, but not quite great. The smoked meats were, for the most part, really tasty, but the quality of some of the dishes was uneven.

I got the Terlingua board, which came with chicken sausage, short ribs, and lamb's shoulder. The chicken sausage was excellent--smoked to perfection and juicy. The short ribs were really good as well, with tender meat and a strong flavor. The lamb's shoulder was dry and, on the whole, flavorless. I got some flavor out of it by dipping it in the barbecue sauce, which was nothing special in and of itself (mostly sweet, a little tangy, and maybe just a little smokey).

The veggie dishes were likewise fairly unimpressive. The roasted beets tasted pretty much like the roasted beets I make at home. Likewise with the baked beans.

Where Terlingua was good, it excelled. But a lot of the stuff just tasted like good home cooking.

name: terlingua
review_text:
This place delivered! We went in on Friday between rain storms and grabbed a table outside. Having two glasses of red wine already under my belt, I was in the mood for food. Needless to say, I ordered two of the beef cheek tacos and a side of corn, stat. I'd heard good things about the beef cheek tacos so I was ready. The atmosphere inside seemed cozy and bustling but we weren't going to be too long so outside was just the right spot.

They've got a good drink selection, and great beers if that's your thing. The flavor combinations in the other items sounded great so I will definitely be back to try more. There were some vegetarian friendly items on the menu which I'll go back for. It's definitely a meat heavy spot but I think a vegetarian could get by here - a vegan I'm not so sure but I'd be very surprised if they couldn't accommodate specific dietary requests given their pricing and great service.

The beef cheek tacos came and rocked my world. The meat was soft and tender, each on a soft corn tortilla. On the side I had some fresh green chili sauce which made them even more flavorful and just brought out the rich flavors in the meat. My side of corn is something I'll probably pass on next time but I was in "must eat" mode and assumed it was elote. It was definitely more of a deconstructed elote if close to elote at all at this point. It's more like a spicy version of creamed corn - I only say creamed (it has no cream mind you) because it's cooked with pork pieces and the meat really added an aspect of richness to it - it's also topped with queso fresco (I believe that's what this was) and mixed with some fresh veggie components (cilantro, onions), plus spices. Not terrible for a side but I'll probably pass it up next time.

There will definitely be a next time though - this place rocks!

name: terlingua
review_text:
I have been waiting to write a review for terlingua because I never sat down in the restaurant for a full meal. I'm so happy we decided to sit down this past Saturday. 

We started with the daily cerviche. It had shrimp which was so refreshing. Definitely get this as an appetizer the smaller size was perfect for two. I have had this twice and it's so delicious. 

I ordered a sangria which to my surprise was a lot dryer than I usually have but in a good way. It didn't taste too sweet at all. It was a house special with blueberries. Delicious. 

Next my boyfriend and I ordered the green chili with pork and the red chili with brisket. Both were amazing and very filling. Next time I'll get the smaller size. Big bang for your buck here! The Nan like bread that comes with it was great for dipping. The red chili is on the spicier side so if your sensitive get the green. We both had the cauliflower with pobleno and cheese. It so tasty and a must for a side. 

I've had the or shrimp appetizer which is delicious as well and so is their mushroom empanada. 

For dessert I ordered the tres leches cake. And man oh man was it delicious. Definitely save room for dessert because that is amazing. 

I love this restaurant so much. The inside is beautiful and sitting outside is super relaxing as well. Excited to go back!

name: terlingua
review_text:
This place is NOT worth the money. 

The dishes are tiny. We ordered the cheesy cauliflower side and it came out as a few very large pieces of cauliflower that we had to cut to eat. We saw other sides and they were equally as tiny.

The entrees were disappointing at best. My boyfriend had one of the BBQ plates. The pork was incredibly dry and tasteless. The cornbread was stale with no actual cornbread taste to it. 

I got the steak tacos. I like my steak rare, but this was still mooing. The pieces were huge (apparently they're against cutting things in to reasonably sized pieces) and impossible to chew. 

Two entrees and a side and we paid over $50! No alcohol- if we had drank, it would have been over $90 total.

At least our waitress was friendly!

name: terlingua
review_text: My favorite restaurant for quality food with an amazing atmosphere. So much flavor in every bite!

name: terlingua
review_text: Lovely service.  Really good corn bread.  The red snapper special should be on the menu permanently.  It was delicious.  I just wish they served it with brown rice (healthier) than white rice.  The jerk chicken was tasty.  The haddock tacos were delicious, too.  The collard greens were only $3, but it was such a small portion.  I wish I had known that in advance, and I would have ordered two of them to start.  It seems they have music on Tuesdays and Sundays.  Go before six p.m. to take advantage of their happy hour.  Before 5 p.m., there are even more specials.  I also wish they served another type of bread besides corn.  I love bread with my meals.

name: terlingua
review_text:
For the life of me, I can't pronounce the name of this place despite them writing it out phonetically on every piece of online and offline collateral they have. It's "Ter-ling-wah", however that doesn't want to come out of my mouth. "Turr-lyn-gooo-wah", however, does.

When this place first opened, I swear I saw panko avocado tacos on their menu. I SWEAR I DID. It's why this vegetarian wanted to come to the restaurant in the first place despite the fact that they're billed as a BBQ joint. I mean, Portland is one of the world's epicenters for amazing food, but we're missing some quintessential things. Like really amazing panko avocado tacos. So I suggested we come here and much to my chagrin... there are no panko avocado tacos on the menu. What the what?!?!

The space is unsurprisingly small, but seems very spacious given the way they have it currently laid out. Smart on them not to clutter the room with too many tables, oddly shaped tables, or tables in the center of the space. The windows are large and let in a ton of natural light, and the tones of the interior decor are very warm. The house music was there, but barely audible - kind of exactly what you want when you're out!

Our waiter was patient, had a sense of humor (after a friend ordered George Clooney's tequila, we got to hear about the servers personal experience with The Situation's protein filled vodka), and was just personal enough to make us feel welcome and make our experience feel completely authentic. He made suggestions based on what he personally liked, he made suggestions on what he's seen as popular with other customers, and after being told that half of our party were vegetarians he - unprompted - let us know everything on the menu that was vegetarian and what could/couldn't be made vegan. How thoughtful is that?

So, we drank/ate:
+ Sangria ($6): I. Love. Sangria. In my opinion, bad sangria is better than good most everything else. That's a bad segue, because I'm not saying Turrlyngoowah's was bad; it was very, very tasty and hit the spot! And at just a $6 price point? Girl's gonna drink at least two or three errehtime, because it rocks to have a place offering drinks at under $10 a piece when Portland's cocktail prices seem to be irrationally inflated.
+/- Sliced avocado and tomato with salted cucumber ($6): If you're a lover of the marriage between avocados and tomatoes, then of course you're going to appreciate this light, refreshing option. However... it's not anything I couldn't make at home, so I'm not sure I would go out of my way to order it again.
+ Roasted cauliflower with poblano and cheese ($6): YES. All day long. As others have mentioned, it tastes like one of the most creamy, sinful mac & cheese's in the world. Also - you get a pretty good-sized crock-full for just $6. THAT'S AWESOME. Please don't change a thing about this! I could easily come back for this and a glass of a sangria and be perfectly happy.
- Stuffed Poblanos ($16), poblanos stuffed with smoked walnuts, currants, rice, and topped with red chile sauce: Do NOT get this if you don't love spice. I like spice, but this was far to hot for me to handle. Even the stuffing - which seemed to be mostly rice (I didn't see or taste any walnuts, and only a smattering of currants), was infused with heat. Yowza!
+ Mushroom Empanada ($18), mushrooms and winter hill farm cheese with a fried egg and a salad of mixed greens: I really liked this a lot. Like A LOT, A LOT. I thought it was going to be more mushroomy and cheesy, but it seemed more spinachy on the inside. Not that that's a bad thing. Also, while the dough was baked to flaky, golden perfection I was originally concerned about how dry it was. That's when I realized... that's what the egg is for. To dip your empanada crust in the runny yolk. SO CREATIVE. SO GOOD. Do I think it's worth $18? Absolutely not, especially given the Stuffed Poblanos had far more food for a lower price point.
+/- Tres Leches Cake ($?): It was good - just the right amount of sweet. Definitely for sharing, though. Unfortunately mine seemed particularly soupy. It just sort of dribbled everywhere every time I took a bite. 

Even if you can't pronounce the name, this is a place worth coming out of your way for!

(Even if they don't have panko avocado tacos.)

name: terlingua
review_text:
Five of us went for dinner Tuesday, August 15 for our monthly get together. We tend to go to a different place every time.  We have been here before but found the food a little too smokey but wanted to give it another try.  We arrived at around 5:30 and ordered apps, Margaritas and dinner.  The food again was spot on.  The check came and with tip was over $300.00. By then it was 7pm.  We thought it was early so we ordered another round of drinks.  At around 7:15 We ordered yet a third round.  When the waitress came back with the drinks she rudely informed us that we were receiving our last drink order because they needed the table. What? Nobody was waiting for a table.  There were three other large tables empty and overall we dropped over $400.00. If this restaurant represents Portland, then we have big problem. Unfortunately, since there are so many options in the area we will be taking our business elsewhere in the future.
An update as of the next day:  After going back and forth with the owner, we aired our concerns and were rewarded with the response of an outstanding businessman.  Pliny R. explained the restaurant's side as did I and we concluded there were some issues (on both sides) that were resolved.  We will again go back to this restaurant in the future.  Perhaps we can be seated in the back yard next to the Big Green Egg next time.

name: terlingua
review_text: Just moved to Maine and was looking for good BBQ in southern Maine. I cooked at a BBQ restaurant in Bucks county PA, so my expectations were somewhat high. I followed this place on Instagram and drooled over all of their meat pictures! Finally tried it, and it lived up to my expectations. The menu was very small but everything we tried was delicious! I tried the regular item deviled eggs which had smoked mussels on it for a special, burnt ends of brisket and the pork shoulder. The coleslaw and cornbread accompaniments were also delicious. The place is small but if you get there early enough you won't have a problem being seated. I also brought my young kids and they loved it all! Even the jalapeño cornbread was not too spicy for their tastes!

name: terlingua
review_text:
One of the best new restaurants in Portland.  Excellent barbecue, but far more.  The Brussels sprouts are wonderfully prepared - best I've had as a side with that rage going on.  Cauliflower is equally good.

The tacos for the night had.soft corn tacos, a wonderful green sauce, and beautifully prepared pork. Three generous tacos.

The glass of wine was a generous pour and the service was excellent.  Good vegetarian options.  What's not to like?

I'll be back.

name: terlingua
review_text:
Who knew Washington Ave would become the new, hip place to be? It warms my heart that this neighborhood has come alive with so many new places. Now, we can add Terlingua to that list.

First off I'll say that I really liked it here. The space is fairly small but they've made use of it wisely. There are seats at the bar and plenty of tables plus some great outdoor picnic tables for the hot summer nights. The tables are covered in copper and reminded me strongly of the tables at Nosh. The silverware is wrapped up in a tea towel and placed in the water glass. Just a unique little touch to make them stand out from other restaurants.

We started off the meal with the small version of the pork belly chicharron. It came with some dressed greens. It was super tasty with a crispy outside and that wonderful creamy pork belly inside. I wish the portion had been a little larger for the price.

My main course was the large order of chicken pozole with a side of roasted cauliflower. The pozole was wonderful and very flavorful. It had shredded chicken and hominy in a warm broth with sliced avocado on top. It came with a generous portion of grilled bread that we found out was from the Tandoor bakery in town. I'm not sure if it was intentional but my pozole was slightly lukewarm. I'm kinda glad for that because I didn't need scalding hot soup on a warm day in June. 

My roasted cauliflower was other worldly. It was crunchy and cheesy all at the same time. It looked like baked mac and cheese when it came out and in dim lighting could be mistaken for just that. I couldn't resist eating almost all of it. It was a good portion for a side dish.

I'm still trying to figure out the mood they are going for. The decor is very homey and has a bit of Latin flair but the music was all EDM with a heavy emphasis on deadmau5. Those two things didn't really jibe for me.

Overall, I really liked it and I'll definitely be back because I want to try the bar snacks served from 9pm to close and some of the desserts!

name: terlingua
review_text:
I almost never give 5 stars but this one was easy.
First, let me say, I'm from Atlanta- the deep south, where bbq is cooked every weekend. 
This place could teach the south a thing or two about bbq.
I'm sure I'll have to go to church on Sunday to repent for such blasphemy after that statement. I had the brisket and the ribs, both were great. 
I love the area for the lobster, the oysters and the fresh seafood but put down the lobster roll long enough to get bbq! You won't regret it.

name: terlingua
review_text: Nice intimate restaurant. We had brunch there today at the bar. I had a coffee and baileys and the tortilla pulled pork and egg special. Really good. My husband had the granola fruit and yoghurt with a house Bloody Mary. (He's on a diet)  Loved the menu. Small but interesting. Full bar and lots of beer choices

name: terlingua
review_text:
What a pleasant surprise!  I've read other reviews and my experience mirrors the others.  The restaurant is small, about 9 tables, a bar with 7 seats and a side bar with an additional 5 seats facing the wall.  I've driven by this plenty of times, as I'm sure others have as well, and not even given it a second glance.  The neighborhood is what they call "up and coming" and the facade would fit the same description.  Never judge a book by its cover though!  The atmosphere is lively but not too loud and a cool mix of people.

The host was quick to acknowledge and seat us.  The menu is small and to the point.  We ordered the roasted beets with Avocado Crema and Toasted Pumpkin Seeds and Blue Fin Tuna Crudo to start.  For entree's we ordered the Winter Squash Empanada's which were amazing!  

Overall, I was very happy with everything and look forward to returning.

name: terlingua
review_text:
This review pertains mostly to the non-BBQ food items. When we left we just didn't feel right about the amount of money we had spent and the ultimate satisfaction or value of the food. 

Terlingua treated us well and there wasn't anything overtly wrong or bad, but with every dish we had there was something missing to give it that extra oomf that would have made it worth the price. 

Summer tomato salad: $9 for five thin slices of tomato with salt. The dish tasted great, there just wasn't much of it. 

Tostada: Missing that extra oomf-- needed some acidity to cut through the meat and cream.

White bean anchovy salad: Beans tasted like they were out of a can and didn't have a defining flavor. More anchovy and garlic would make it pop. 

Chicken tortilla soup: This was a thick soup composed of mainly dark meat and a dense broth. I would have preferred a lighter, classic one in true Mexican style with beans and other vegetables added, some lime flavor, cumin, and other spices, as well as the shaved lettuce/ cotija cheese on top. It felt gloopy and heavy, missing that zing of freshness and flavor.

Beer: Good beer. 

Brisket tacos: 
- The meat was incredible-- they do barbeque right. Very flavorful and juicy brisket. In the taco, the salsa overpowered the flavor of the meat and detracted from it. The ingredients of the taco were all there (grilled scallions, radishes, onion, cilantro) but all together it didn't come together to give an experience worth $15 for three tacos. They should change the tortilla to the softer, true corn ones-- the tortilla was the stiff yellow kind.
- We ordered two tacos, and literally thought we were ordering two tacos, because at almost all restaurants you order tacos in an individual quantity. It turned out we ordered two taco plates at $15 each and the menu only says "priced daily" and the server only told us what the meat of the day was. We should have asked for clarification, but it would help to have the fact that it is a taco plate more upfront on the menu. 

At the end of the day, we just felt that we could have gotten much better value Mexican food at a more fair price somewhere else.

name: terlingua
review_text:
I love me some good latin food and this place hit it out of the park.

Located in the up and coming East Bayside hood, just on the fringes of Munjoy Hill this little gem is a must visit! It's a small dining room, but very well designed with simple, earthy, industrial decor, outside patio and a fabulous bar. 

The staff is extremely knowledgeable & friendly, which is always a plus...and seem genuinely happy to be there. 

It's great for groups because many of the plates are more tapas style, or for couples who just love to eat. Both instances we fit, so I have a feeling we will be visiting this place often. 

On our first trip in we enjoyed:

Summer Corn Salad - my personal favorite, simple, fresh and delish
Mushroom Empanada - amazeballs
Smoked Beef Tongue & Cheek Tacos - I can't lie, I didn't enjoy this the husband did, but he said it was good. It scared me personally but that's just me!
Smoked Skirt Steak - a little too smoked for me, but still good, just not my personal favorite.
Grilled Corn with Cojita Cheese - can't go wrong with this!
Roasted Cauliflower - oh so delish

We also had dessert....but after all the champs I honestly can't remember what it was called. What I can tell you though is that it was chocolate something and it was incredibly tasty. So whatever is chocolate on the dessert menu just order it.

Can't wait to come back!

name: terlingua
review_text: Amazing place! The building might look a little weird from the outside but inside it's really nice. Our waitress was very nice. I had the baby back ribs that were cooked good but the outside was pretty black. Only the outside though. After the meal it was good until I did find to be a little sick from the steak. Maybe it was my thing or the steak. But really other than that really good for an dinner

name: terlingua
review_text: Great place for small plates and drink or a full dinner as well! Had the privilege of being able to try the special lox deviled eggs and the blue fish tacos!

name: terlingua
review_text: Holy mother of Mexican barbecue!   I have found my church here and I'm ready to confess!  This was one of the best casual, fun meals I've had in a long time, and for Portland that's saying a lot.  From the food to the service, this is a complete five star experience.  Highlights included the shrimp ceviche (super fresh with avocado bits); the carnitas tacos (perfectly cooked, shredded style pork on soft - yet toasted - corn tortillas); and the best dry rubbed BBQ baby back ribs this side of Mexico/The South/Missouri.  The meat was super tender, yet stayed nicely on the bone awaiting my teeth and palate.  BBQ sauce served on the side required us to ask for more - so tasty!  And service?  Bartender/waitress Patricia was sweet, polite and professional.  Two thumbs up!  Overall, this is a terrific joint for some BBQ, some Mexican dishes, and cocktails!

name: terlingua
review_text: This place is awesome! I found it from Food and Wine magazine. Get the tostada of the day and a michelada.

name: terlingua
review_text: First time traveling through Portland and found this gem! Everything was superb, from the imaginative drink section to the best brisket you'll ever find. A whole lot of love has gone in to this place and it definitely shows.

name: terlingua
review_text: Delicious BBQ! Even though I don't eat meat, I was still able to find things that were vegetarian friendly. We started with the polenta and trumpet mushrooms, and then I had the empanadas with a fried egg, and a side of the cauliflower. Very flavorful and a great atmosphere. I think it would be nice to have a veg BBQ option of tofu or grilled veggies.

name: terlingua
review_text: It was good... but not my favorite. I may have just ordered the wrong thing (green chili I think it was called) but I don't foresee myself coming back soon.

name: terlingua
review_text: I rarely write reviews but this place is awesome. My fiancé is almost crying the food is so good. The drinks are strong and yummy as well . We will definitely be coming back often. Come for Sunday neighborhood night for cheaper prices and a great changing menu.

name: east-ender
review_text:
We came here for dinner Saturday night and had a great experience. We had tried to get into another place earlier in the evening and the wait was too long. Our awesome tour guide-relative-Portland resident tried hard to acquiesce our food desires while also finding a place without a 2 hour wait.

We were seated fairly quickly at the bar for drinks and then within minutes found our table to be ready. Ou bartender was awesome; she even checked on our table to see how the drinks were. I'd ordered an amazing drink (a something sling-I really should have written it down) that lasted about 30 seconds in my glass...it was that tasty. I switched to a cocktail after that was just as good. 

We shared an order of chicken wings with chili-lime rub and Maine Mussels with coconut milk, ginger, lemongrass and lime. The wings were crispy and well seasoned, not greasy. The mussel broth was delicious and was served with three thick and crusty buttered slices of bread. We sopped up as much of that broth as we could until one of us (ahem me) ate the remainder with a spoon once everyone else had their fill. 

I wasn't wowed by the main dish options, so I opted for the Braised Local Beets with Miticana Goat Cheese, Celtic Vinegar and Pepitas as well as the Smoked Hake Chowder. The server suggested I layer the beets over the cheese to melt it and she was spot on: the combo was very good. 

The soup came out in such a large and generous helping that was pleasantly surprising. I expected a small bowl and was thrilled it was so copious. I really didn't need anything else to eat.

I've eaten a lot of chowder in my life and this was hands down one of the best I've ever eaten. The smokiness was subtle and there was a hint of sweet to the fish breading. It was perfectly creamy and I loved how all the mirepoix was minced finely so it blended into the soup like a dream.

My s.o. said his fish and chips was excellent and we all agreed that thrice cooked fries are perfection.

I was so eager to eat that it appears I did not take any photos. You'll just have to take my word for it and come here yourself to try out their delicious fare.

name: east-ender
review_text:
Stopped in here on a Sunday night around 830. There were two of us and we did not have reservations. The hostess informed us that they wouldn't be able to sit us at a table, but we could try the bar. Luckily, there was room at the bar.

The place is casual yet classy on the inside, with two floors of dining. We first perused the drink menu,
I settled on trying their house tonic, which is made in-house and seasonal, mixed with rye and lime (at the bartenders recommendation). It was delicious.

For food, I opted for a lighter fare and got the crunchy Asian slaw salad, and topped it with the grilled chicken tikka. We also got an order of fries to start. 

The fries came out and were cooked to a nice golden crisp, with just a touch of salt. The salad soon followed and it was refreshing and satisfying, with a portion that filled your stomach but didn't make you feel like you overate. 

Overall, the dining experience was very good, from the service to the food. Would return and recommend to others.

name: east-ender
review_text:
This place is more like a 3.5/5 stars.
I bumped it up to 4 stars since the manager name is also Jeff... Lol

We wanted to check out eventide for their late night happy hour, but when we got there they told us that they didn't have the late night menu anymore... So we bounced across the street to this place. It was past 9, and people were finishing up, but we got seated right away upstairs.

We ordered mainly snacks and appetizers and four plates were more than good enough for two people. We got the wings, hake chowder, pretzel, and mussels. Out of the four, the hake chowder and mussels were the best. I didn't think the pretzel and the wings were worth it.
However, the hake chowder and mussels were phenomenal. The hake chowder was really tasty... I do wish they added more hake..
The mussels were really interesting since they soaked it with a thai curry. Never had it like that before but we really enjoyed it.

There's plenty of parking on the street, and if you park after 6pm, it's free.

name: east-ender
review_text: The restaurant is eclectic and charming. The flavors of the food are excellent. The hake chowder is a great portion full of Smokey flavor and lots of chunks of fish. The mussels with the curry flavor were great and I'd highly recommend them. The braised pork shoulder was amazingly tender and falling apart. The grits were cooked nicely but i found too sweet. Overall I would have liked more heat and spice in the pork shoulder dish. They have a special $5 wine option and I enjoyed the white wine immensely. The cab sav was round and bold.

name: east-ender
review_text:
Love this place- Natalie is the best bartender! So friendly and helpful with drink suggestions. We joined for their happy hour so everything we ordered was off of it. If we weren't trying to visit more restaurants we would have eaten more. We did comeback upstairs for drinks and an app while we waited for the place next door because the service was so fabulous. 
I shared just a little bit of the hake dip with my hubby since it was so good and he ordered the latte that I will not eat. We both tremendously enjoyed our apps and drinks. I will visit again the next time I'm in Portland.

name: east-ender
review_text:
Brunch brunch brunch! 

Cozy American cafe right near Duckfat in downtown Portland. My mom and I went for brunch on Sunday and they took great care of us! The food was pretty simple but flavor combinations were on par. We shared Eggs in Purgatory with House Ricotta and Grilled Pleasant Bread, and the East Ender Breakfast Sandwich with Fried Egg, Bacon, Kimchi, and Cheese. And you know I had to have their doughnut of the day- Chai Spice!!!

name: east-ender
review_text:
East Ender-- we meet again! 

This is a place that never disappoints. 

Things you can always count on at East Ender:

1. Amazing service
2. Delicious food
3. Solid background music 

Let's start with our waitress Bridgette-- she was fire! So friendly, knowledgeable, and on top of her game. 

We started with the chicken wings. They were so tasty, I never wanted them to end. We didn't use the dipping sauce, it tasted a bit spicy to me. With the side of Brussels for $5, you can't go wrong. They are fabulous. The Caesar salad was very full of flavor as well. They put their own mix on it with a half piece of bread and a soft boiled egg in the middle. You cut it up and choose the bites you want. The "famous" burger did not fall short on flavor. We also added bacon jam to ours for $2. Personally, the smoked flavor isn't for me, so eating through that was hard at times. The bun from Rose Foods is a perfect touch to this burger. As for the fries, my favorite part--none of them were soggy. I guess after being cooked 3 times, how can they be? 

We opted out of dessert even though the options sounded fabulous. They make a few flavors of ice cream in-house. 

We normally make a reservation as it can be hard to get a table here sometimes. So, if you're a planner and don't want to wait, do yourself the favor and make a reservation.

name: east-ender
review_text: I'm going to say 3.5 but I bumped it up to 4 because the guy clearing tables and bringing our food was super helpful!! our sever on the other hand deserves 2 stars. She just was pretty much useless and I think we saw her 3 times. I had a burger that I didn't think was worth $18 after my toppings. (And I live in CT so I never have sticker shock) actually those French fries were awesome. My husband loved his beer. All and all it was the service (server)  that really dropped the ball.

name: east-ender
review_text:
They were so accommodating to our weird little party, me with celiac, a kiddo with allergies, a picky woman and a man who loves everything. The service was perfect. Everyone in the place is friendly. I kind of want to move to Portland based on this dinner. 
PS my food was TRULY GF. For more "sensitive" or strict celiacs, you know what I'm talking about. No minor or mild symptoms afterward.

name: east-ender
review_text:
A quaint and intimate space. Our server was excellent and attentive. 

Fish and Chips were solid. Fries were very stiff and crisp and there is a lot of fish for a good fish:fried breading ratio. 

And...they have Bissell Bros on draft!

name: east-ender
review_text:
This was the first place I ate at in Portland, and it set my standards for the rest of the trip. The food was delicious and the service was amazing (although we were the only ones in the restaurant at that time...)

We ordered the pork belly burger, thrice cooked fries, and the fried Brussels sprouts. Everything tasted so good. The pork belly was tender and delicious and the sauce on the burger was amazing, but it wasn't slathered in sauce like most places would do. The fries were extra crispy on the outside but still had that softness on the inside that I love. And the Brussels sprouts were to die for. I honestly think they could convert any sprout hater. They had a little bit of a charred texture instead of the typical soggy sprouts and it had a slight lemony flavor. I could go for just the sprouts, they were THAT good. 

I definitely recommend this place if you're looking for delicious foods served by amazing staff. Our server even told us about other places in the area to check out as she knew we were from out of town. Great experience here and I'll definitely be back when I come back to Portland

name: east-ender
review_text:
My wife and I found this place for lunch while in Portland on a Saturday afternoon. The menu appeared to be what we were looking for... Burgers sandwiches but not the typical preparation, seemed to be a step above.
There are two levels, with the upstairs used for first come first served. They were busy so we grabbed a seat at the bar upstairs. 
Very good service, and nicely done cocktails. Kind of a mixed bag on the food... The fries were nice and crisp, my wife's chicken sandwich was excellent, however, my burger was a disappointment. It looked better than it actually was... The beef was under-seasoned...tasted quite bland.
I would give it another shot based on the menu and service and try additional items on the menu.

name: east-ender
review_text: My friend and I came to East Ender for drinks at the bar while waiting for a table at a nearby restaurant. We wound up at the upstairs bar which had more seats. As someone who generally shies away from alcohol, I love when I find a place that has an extensive non-alcoholic cocktail menu. I got the Old Ship Fizz (blueberry soda, orange juice, and ginger) which was delicious - it was sweet and fruity with a hint of spice. My friend liked her Ginger Lemon Drop cocktail so much she got two of them. The bartender was also super friendly and chatty. Highly recommend for drinks!

name: east-ender
review_text:
My boyfriend and I were looking for a place to grab dinner while we were in town and stopped by this place. The wait for a table was only 10 minutes which was pretty reasonable as some places the wait was longer. The place was small and only held about 12 people but there was a lounge upstairs that I didn't check out. 

We decided to order a pretzel to start which was a little small but a nice way to start the meal. The mustard was made in house and had a different taste I couldn't quite put my finger on but still delicious. 

Funny to see how chicken is the most expensive thing on the menu, usually that's not the case. Either way I decided to get it to see if it was worth it. My boyfriend got the pasta. The pasta was okay. I liked the sauce it was in but the pasta seemed kinda of chewy, not al dente.  The chicken breast was good a little too charred which skewed the taste. The sauce it came with was good though. It also had broccoli and grits as well. The grits was good a little too sweet or creamy for me. 

For dessert my boyfriend got a black coffee which came out cold unfortunately and some dessert. I'm not a fan of creme fraiche so it wasn't for me but he seemed to enjoy it. The food and service overall were good but nothing spectacular. I think I would try other places out in the city before coming here again.

name: east-ender
review_text: Perfect place for a casual but comforting lunch. The place has a nice atmosphere and was not too crowded. We got the signature entree - fish and chips ($17) and the daily special - swordfish sandwich ($13). The fish and chips was fresh and crispy, perfectly fried. The swordfish was not fried and goes very well with the burger bun. Will recommend this place.

name: east-ender
review_text: This place was so amazing: Food drinks and ambiance. We had the mussles and eat every last one, the Hake chowder was amazing.  It has a wonderful hearty smoked flavor.  Then to top off our already full bellies we split the fish and chips.  The batter is light and airy.  The cucumber gin and Irish good bye signature drinks were of the finest we have had in portland.

name: east-ender
review_text: Delicious. Beyond expectation. Might be in the top 5 burgers ever.  And "thrice fried fries" - shut up. Seated quickly at the bar even with a table wait. Our bartender, Cody was knowledgeable about the menu and just fun. What a delightful place.

name: east-ender
review_text:
We made a reservation for a late lunch on a Saturday in February. They had our reservation and after a little wait, sat us at a table (the room was empty) and then we waited and waited and waited. My in-laws were not happy waiting, so we told them thank you but we're not staying.
This second time we took a friend who we were visiting in Portland, as she loves this restaurant. Again, we had a long wait just for someone to see we were waiting at the door. Then there was a lot of communication issues, but about what I don't know.
We finally decided to just go sit at the bar. And had a great experience with Cody! He took great care in our drink prep (loved the Lemon Ginger Drop) and got our meals ordered and without too long we were enjoying our dinners. Pappardelle, Chicken Salad and a Burger.
I'm not sure why there are communication issues with whoever is supposed to run front of the house. We've never been upstairs either. I just think with all the competition in Portland of fabulous places to eat, they should think about this detail.

name: east-ender
review_text:
High expectations, ok food, poor service.

My husband, son and I stopped in for lunch. We were seated promptly but seemingly ignored while others orders were taken (they came in after us). 

The waiter was not friendly when he came to us, but whatever, it happens. My son ordered a grilled cheese, my husband a chicken sandwich and I got mussels. 

When the food arrived it was luke warm. The grilled cheese was fine, the mussels eh but the chicken - oh the chicken. It looked like raw slices of cold breast. When my husband inquired he was told it was sous vide. Fair enough - but no indication on the menu nor by the waiter that this was a take on a classic chicken sandwich. My husband said it just didn't look appetizing and wasn't what he wanted. The waiter replied that it was "delicious, actually". Not really full of customer service...

At the end of the day they did the right thing and comped the sandwich. That said, we'd suggest more descriptive language on the menu, friendlier wait staff and talking through interpretative dishes with guests before they order. We won't come back

name: east-ender
review_text: This restaurant was a great find in Portland. It came highly recommended and did not disappoint. We had the signature dish, of course, and loved it. The atmosphere was great and the service was very good. I don't remember much of a view or anything, but the interior is nice. Great food and service. I would return.

name: east-ender
review_text: We have been here several times and the service is always great. The food is consistently plated nicely with good flavors and well seasoned. I highly recommend

name: east-ender
review_text: A Great quaint spot.  We came upon this gem after an afternoon of shopping and gallery browsing. Great atmosphere, craft cocktails, service and food.  We had the burgers which were cooked perfectly and the thrice fries are amazing.  (1st timers to thrive fries)

name: east-ender
review_text: Went here for lunch. Had the chowder, interesting/sweet flavors. Got the pork sandwich, sounded really good but was flavorless and a little dry. My friend got a sale, she said it was tasty. Chill vibe but the restaurant was not even half full while the restaurant next door had 15 people waiting outside (cruise ship was in town).

name: east-ender
review_text:
One word: burgers. Their burgers are not large (4-6oz max) but the flavor is unmatched. They cold smoke the burgers I believe, which gives them that charcoal grill smoked flavor even though I am certain they grill them on the flat top. I also enjoyed their fresh cut fries along with it.

Because it was Maine, we had to try to lobster melt and while I liked it, it was definitley more melt than lobster. I think I spoiled myself with super meaty lobster rolls earlier in my trip so I was a little disappointed.

The wildcard was the mussells. They were cooked in and served with a coconut curry broth, something I have never had with mussells but worked really well! I definitley recommend that dish!

I liked the interior decor of the place, the staff was super friendly, restrooms were clean. Check it out, get a burger!

name: east-ender
review_text:
I stumbled upon the East Ender, and boy am I glad I had! The space is upscale, but not stuffy. It's eclectically decorated, with a bit of whimsy.

I'm limited in my choices as I'm gluten-intolerant. I had a couple of options, and chose the duck hash. It's truly one of the best dishes I've ever eaten (and I'm not being dramatic). And, it's beautifully presented. 

I also tried a new-to-me gluten-free beer that I hadn't heard of previously: IPA No. 5. It's a nice option/alternative to my most favorite gluten-reduced beer (Stone Delicious IPA). I had quite a varied beer palate prior to being diagnosed as gluten-intolerant three years ago. 

Everything that I saw come out of the kitchen was beautiful and looked delicious. The burgers and fries, also. It would be especially helpful if they carried gluten-free rolls (Saratoga Gluten Free Goods's Multigrain Rolls are ideal).

name: east-ender
review_text: Hidden gem of a bar! Stopped here for a drink while waiting for our table at Duckfat located next door (apparently this is a regular thing that happens??). The bartender was so nice and welcoming. Bonus: They have fun board games and card games to play! I'd love to come back and have a full dining experience.

name: east-ender
review_text: We came into East Ender for a late lunch on the Fourth of July, and there was no wait, which was great because we were super hungry! I love that they have mocktails on their menu! Sometimes, I have no interest in alcohol but would still love a cocktail! I ordered the raspberry and mint mocktail, which was just a tad too sweet for me. For my meal, I got the burger (which comes topped with cheese, ketchup, and mayo) and I added avocado and tomatoes! It was juicy and delicious! The burger is composed of high quality beef and was perfectly cooked to my preferred temperature. I will say the burger is a little on the small side. The burger also comes with thrice cooked fries. The fries were yummy and plentiful, but not quite was good as the fries I had next door at Duckfat...

name: east-ender
review_text:
Really great spot! Went to Duckfat which was packed... My girlfriend had been to Duckfat and didn't feel like it was worth the wait, so we went next door to East Ender and it wasn't a mistake. 

We sat upstairs by the windows, really nice environment. 

We ordered the burger plus avocado and bacon, the beets, and Brussel sprouts. We shared all of it. The fries were awesome. Burger was great. Girlfriend says the sprouts were too salty, I respectfully disagree:) I hate goat cheese, so didn't eat that which came with the beets, but girlfriend says it was great. 

Would come again.

name: east-ender
review_text: Great little hole in the wall.  Went with the pork shoulder and local chicken sandwiches, with a side of the thrice fried fries.  All fantastic.  Portions could be a bit larger, but the quality is fantastic.

name: east-ender
review_text:
Stopped in here while waiting for a table at Eventide. I could have stayed all night. Tina/Naomi at the upstairs bar hooked up the BEST vodka (Tito's) martini I have ever had in my 20 years of adult beveraging. So smooth and delicious, I could have had two or three easily. My liver is grateful that the Eventide table opened up before I could get there. 

I will be dreaming of this lovely, cozy bar and the best martini I've ever had for a long, long time. Sigh.

name: east-ender
review_text:
There was an hour wait next door at duck fat so we walked right next door. It was 2 pm on a Monday...

Anyways very cute, small local shop. Vintage decor and my friend said "feels like we're on a boat" lol

The rude host sat us outside and when we asked if we could be seated inside since the sun was blazing hot on half our table outside, she said she'll check but never came back. 

Our friendly waitress arrived and we asked the same question. She didn't hesitate and brought us inside. 

Phenomenal Burger with fries, I can see why this place was so highly rated. The meat patty had a nice smoked house flavor and being cooked medium rare, it was still juicy. The double fried fries were delicious. 

My friend said her turkey sandwich was nothing special but I'd return for the burger =)

name: east-ender
review_text: We hadn't been here in almost six years, so we thought we'd try it again. There's a reason they had open tables on the night of an Elton John concert, and nobody else did. We got sat at an awkward table for two and were never greeted so we moved to the bar. Again, we were not greeted until we waved down the bartender (at a bar for ten). Granted, she was one of two bartenders serving the 1/2 full restaurant, but she still could have asked for our drink order at some point. The apps were mediocre, but the wine was good! We didn't stay for dinner and probably won't be back.

name: east-ender
review_text:
Initially I was a bit apprehensive about East Ender due to a few negative reviews on Yelp. After reviewing the reviewers, I decided to see for myself what East Ender was about.
I'm a lover of Fish and Chips! East Ender's Fish and Chips caught my eye and my curiosity so I decided to give them a try. I was fully rewarded for my venture with some of the best Fish and Chips I've had in recent memory! Yes, East Ender blew away my standard go to Ri Ra by quite a bit of flavor and tenderness! 
The Fish comes batter fried in a large encompassing batter that looks more like a small loaf of over-baked bread but don't be fooled! It's simply the color of the battered exterior that contains a delicious fillet of Hake that's delivered hot and perfectly cooked!
The portions are more than ample. The Thrice Fried French Fries are cooked perfectly and seasoned perfection. The ambience is upbeat and both upper and lower dining rooms are nicely decorated. 
The staff was very friendly and welcoming. 
East Ender is a great spot for food and dessert! Give them a try at your earliest opportunity!

name: east-ender
review_text: This is such a cute restaurant right in old port! The food was very tasty. I got the chili lime wings for a starter and the fish sandwich for my meal. Both were amazing! Friendly staff and great food. I would recommend this place!

name: east-ender
review_text: Seriously good burger & fries; fantastic, well curated, local beer selection; and the best decor I've seen in a long time. Worth the extremely steep steps upstairs to chill out and have a fantastic dinner while on vacation.

name: east-ender
review_text: This was another place that had the trifecta of great food, service, and atmosphere. Unlike the super-trendy place we went to the night before, The East Ender has a relaxed environment, music in the background, but not so loud you couldn't carry on a conversation with your dining partner. Service was fabulous: attentive, but not obtrusive. Our server was quick and witty. And the food. was. awesome. I got the ricotta gnocchi with mushrooms and the hubs got the coconut chickpea stew with chicken tikka. The gnocchi were perfect pillows and the mushrooms were rich and flavorful. The stew was everything the hubs likes in a dish: a little bit of spice, a little bit of exotic, and a whole lot of flavor. The drinks were really good too. I got a cucumber fizz that was super-refreshing on a hot August day. We will be back.

name: east-ender
review_text:
We were told to check this place out for happy hour by our bartender from another restaurant we visited while in town. It is located right next door to Duck Fat and often the crowd waiting to get in next door sometimes makes you wonder why the line is not as log for this place. The staff is friendly, the drinks are well crafted and the food was spot on! 

We arrived during the beginning of happy hour. It was a gorgeous day outside so we decided to catch one of the last "Al Fresco" moments we could. We ordered directly off of the Happy Hour menu. They offer these specials Monday - Saturday 3:30pm - 5:30pm. I got the Paloma, a refreshing combination of tequila, house-made grapefruit cordial and lime for $6. We then ordered the Pork Belly Chili-Cheese Fries for $7. They were delicious however the pork belly got lost in the deep smoky flavor from the chili. The star of the afternoon were the wings; Vadouvan spiced chicken wings with cilantro-lime also for $7. They were hot, crispy and full of flavor. 

This was such a great spot to just sit, relax and enjoy the afternoon with great bites and super cheap cocktail specials!

name: east-ender
review_text: Great bartender!!! I cannot say enough. Ambiance upstairs is very nice. Good vibe. Lots of small plates which is great, if they are great as I stopped at one.  Touted as Mussels in coconut milk, ginger, lemongrass and lime, can I say, yum and right up my alley. Unfortunately that is where the excitement ended. They arrived. Nice, no ok portion for $15. But being the mussel lover I am I knew right away these were not what I had envisioned. Barely and sauce and did I say coconut milk... umm they must have forgot! What I got was mussels in a bland sauce with grilled bread that tasted like a gas grill. Sorry, but if it was not for the bartender, it would have been 1 star. I am chalking it up to my menu choice, but this is my second time here. Not sure with sooo many great choices in Portland, I will be back.

name: east-ender
review_text: We've been twice and sat on the 2nd floor up the really steep stairs and the main "bar" room near the window overlooking the streets below. Menu seems to change a lot and is updated daily. We had the burger and waffle for Sunday brunch. Both were terrific. One of the highlights is their amazing thrice fried fries. OMG. Yum.

name: east-ender
review_text: We loved this place, not only for the lovely ambiance but for the amazing bartender, Natalie. We will be back for dinner next time I'm in town.

name: east-ender
review_text: My fiancé and I popped into this adorable place while we were waiting to get poutine from Duckfat next door. We just ordered drinks, and chilled for about an hour and a half. The servers were AWESOME! I guess they close down briefly one day a week before brunch and dinner, but they let us stay in there with them. They were bumping some awesome tunes, and they were super nice and personable! They gave us suggestions for other places to visit around Portland. The beer selection is great, and I got 2 mimosas! Best mimosas I had because they were heavy on the champagne and light on the orange juice. I'm so happy we accidentally stumbled upon this little place!

name: east-ender
review_text:
We came here on a busy Saturday night, and we were lucky to get a table due to a cancelled reservation. I had the Lobster Melt and dayyyuuuummmm I loved it, it was crunchy but soft and flavorful the lobster was fresh. My friend's daughter ordered the Pork Belly and I stole almost half lol, it also came with fantastic cheesy grits. My friend ordered the fish and chips which she said was great! 
No as for the service received... they were fantastic, informative, and so helpful!

name: east-ender
review_text:
Known for burgers and meats,they offer ,in summer a lovely chopped salad for veggie palate. Tonight excellent. 
And a very accommodating staff.tough to find in season.

name: east-ender
review_text: Honestly shocked I haven't written a review yet! In a city full of new restaurants constantly being opened, this one remains a staple for when you just really don't want to wait in a line for over hyped food. I wish I could say I keep coming back for the amazing food (it is really good), the impeccable service (although honestly that has been good too), or the ambiance (this places has one of my favorite atmospheres in Portland). But alas, the real reason this is one of my favorites and why I keep coming back is because they have a sparkling rose that is SO good, and my favorite thing is to sit at the bar upstairs against the brick wall, drinking rose, people watching, and feeling boujee as F*&K.

name: east-ender
review_text:
Started w/ pork belly rillettes and split the ceasar salad. Both were really good. The ceasar was really 4+. I perfer a little more raw garlic and salt/anchovy, but good. The eggs on top was poached perfectly and topped w real quality parm would immediately order again.
For the entrees, friend ordered the green curry lemongrass mussels and I went w the smoked burger w mushrooms. She liked the mussels (I'll defer to her not really my thing). 
The burger was definitely tasty and the cold smoke feature to the process totally impacted the meat really well, but not overpowering ways. Two hairsplitting nitpicks, the bun not really butter toasted, warm or soft on the inside and the burger temp ordered med-rare really was well-done. However, it wasn't overly dry, but there was no pink... So perhaps this is due to the cold smoke  process? Personally I have only cold smoked slabs of pork belly.  So I am unaware of what that process would do to a patty of ground sirlion etc. My guess now is that it would change the color of the meat, but not the meat temp? So perhaps achieving a seared, but juicy pink center is just not possible? Anyway... 
Best parts... Service a 5. No names known, but host was friendly, server knew the menu and was also incredibly patient w a needy table of jackasses behind us.
Drinks a 5. Bissell and lunch on tap. Like that stuff. And the sip I had of a specialty ginger drink (@ the top of menu) was really nice and summertime appropriate. 
AND.. the only reason I wanted to write this review..... Is b/c of the French fries. They are heaven. SUPER crisp. No skin (probably b/c of the 3 x cooking) and just pillowy warm insides. 
I'd recommend East Ender for any occasion. And JFC those fries are delicious!!

name: east-ender
review_text: Decided to come here after the restaurant next door had too long of a wait. We originally planned on just ordering a drink and waiting for our table next door, but after seeing the menu and getting situated in a booth we decided to stay. The food was excellent, but the cocktails were not good. We ordered a Bloody Mary, dirty martini and two specialty drinks off the menu and no one really seemed to enjoy them. I'm guessing maybe the daytime bartender isn't their best. We ordered off of their brunch menu. Grilled rum raisin bread, homemade donut, waffle, eggs and sausage and two local chicken sandwiches. All amazing. There was nothing left when we were done. I definitely have faith in their menu and quality of the food but, I wouldn't order a cocktail there again.

name: east-ender
review_text: Excellent! Amazing food (I had the gnocchi) and great service in a cozy and comfortable setting.

name: east-ender
review_text: East Ender was our first stop in Portland and we were pleasantly surprised by how eclectic this small restaurant was. The decor was unique and fun, almost like the living room of an old-school author. The downstairs bar was inviting and the bartenders made drinks with care and precision. Upstairs, there was a lot more room. The waitstaff was great and knowledgeable about the menu. The music was great! The food was also delicious. The Brussel sprouts were roasted in a tasty oil and the side order was a good portion. The chicken wings came with a refreshing dip, which was not too overpowering. The restaurant also offered a variety of local beers which added to the appeal.

name: east-ender
review_text:
They have a lemon-ginger cocktail that is officially my favorite warm-weather drink in Portland. It's made with FRESH ginger. 

The fish and chips and smoke hake chowder were the highlights of the meal. 

I'll keep coming back for these!

name: east-ender
review_text:
Mystery Solved. Having peeked through the windows at East Ender many times, I always saw an empty restaurant. It made me wonder if there was any life in there and as a result always had me walk past it and into neighboring Duckfat. Finally went in for a meal and discovered that there is an upper section which is lovely. A nice surprise.

Now, the food? Great fries. Highly recommended. The rest of the menu? Not exactly mind blowing. Seems like a very process-oriented establishment. Going above and beyond on the elements used in the dishes. However the results do not really impress much. The menu also seems to lean more toward lunch items. 

Here was my frustration with the establishment. It was a Thursday night and so we thought we hit the jackpot in terms of busy-ness. Yet, we seemed to wait over 30 minutes between our appetizer and main course. For my partner who is not really an app fan, it took an hour before he ate anything. 
And so for the food to further disappoint, we were gutted.
Nonetheless the chocolate torte was pretty good. 

My partner who likes anything and everything, anywhere and everywhere we go, was the first to proclaim he wouldn't go back.

I agreed.

name: east-ender
review_text: My Husband and I enjoyed dinner here while visiting Portland.  We were able to get an open table reservation last minute on a Saturday night and the food and service was really good.  Their wings were very tender and full of flavor and the soft pretzel was pretty good too.  I got the pappardelle chicken dish which was delicious, great flavor and the pasta was cooked just right.  My Husband got the braised pork shoulder which was also really good.  The star of the show though were the fried Brussel sprouts...OMG sooo good!!!  The service was great: quick, friendly and attentive.  Our waiter also gave us a great post dinner drink spot that was awesome.  If we're ever back in town we will be sure to return to East Ender!

name: east-ender
review_text:
Visited East Ender on a Saturday for Lunch after walking into Eventide and learning it was a 2.5 hour wait. We walked in and went upstairs and were able to sit at the bar right away. The bar chairs were not high enough for the bar, but that is my only complaint!

The beer list was great - a ton of local Maine beers both on tap and by the bottle. 

We split the burger and the lobster melt; both of which were fantastic. The bacon jam... to die for. Some people around us got wings and brussel Sprouts, and those both looked so great.

This is a great spot for lunch; I would definitely go back.

name: east-ender
review_text:
What a great start to the New Year. My husband and I ate here after spending the afternoon strolling around the Old Port. 
We each had a ginger/lemon vodka Martini.  Delicious!  We ordered the wings as an app. The cilantro vinaigrette was a nice refreshing and light touch. 
I ordered the best gnocchi I've had in a very long time. My husband had the pork belly with cheesy grits and ate every last bite. 
We will return for sure.  The prices were very reasonable,  the service was attentive,  but not pushy in any way.

name: east-ender
review_text: One of the best fish sandwiches I've ever had.  Fresh, flaky fish perfectly cooked topped with fresh slaw and complimented with a nice side salad.  Cool ambiance with upstairs seating

name: east-ender
review_text:
The table started with the pretzel and the pork belly app, which was disappointing but the entrees were great. Fish and chips and lobster melt were good. The chickpea stew was particularly tasty. 

The service was definitely off. Our waitress tried to take our dishes each time before we finished them and was a bit short with us. 

Overall, would definitely return for the food.

name: east-ender
review_text:
Food and cocktails here are excellent. I had the mushroom Cavatelli. Highly recommended. Also had a few bites of the Pork Belly and it was cooked to perfection. 

Prices are a little steep, but what you'd expect for the quality. Comparable to NY pricing. 

Only one note: our server seemed a little sad. Tried to joke with him, but no dice. Hope he's feeling better!!

name: east-ender
review_text: We went for drinks around 10.00 pm last night (July 10, 2018) and the bartender took care of us so well. She was knowledgable, pleasant and helpful. We looked at the menu and planning to go back for a meal. Excellent place!

name: east-ender
review_text: Great food and beer! Haddock fish and chips were mouth watering and the restaurant looked very chic! Will definitely be coming back again the next time I visit.

name: east-ender
review_text:
This was a great dining experience. Delicious foods, hand crafted drinks and able to accommodate the dietary restrictions of our large group. Service was good, restaurant was clean and attractive. 
Perfect night!

name: east-ender
review_text: Had the fish and chip, the batter was too crispy and very oily, the fish was over cooked and dried out, not enjoyable. My husband had the lobster melt, flat, no flavor, and soggy. We were the only dinners in the restaurant, that should have been our first clue.

name: east-ender
review_text:
Like some others, I stopped in here while waiting for a table at Duckfat and I'm so glad that we did.  We only grabbed some drinks and snacks but everything was delicious and I would definitely go back here for a meal anytime I was in the area!

The drinks are fun! I had the most excellent ginger lemon martini.  It was spicy and very gingery. One of those drinks you could drink all day. Beer list included several local beers on tap including "lunch". We ordered Soft Pretzel With House Made Mustard- this was perfect sized for sharing with very tasty mustard.  We also had a selection of warm olives with toasted almonds. YUM YUM!   
The service is excellent- it friendly helpful and quick.  

Overall great experience here.

name: east-ender
review_text:
Sitting next door to superstar, Duckfat, this place might not be getting the spotlight it deserves! Though I haven't had dinner here yet, I've had brunch twice and was impressed at both visits. Service was the perfect balance of friendly and professional. The waiter competently assisted my sister, who has celiac, with ordering a gluten-free meal. 
Eggs In Purgatory is amazing. Duck Confit Hash is delicious with perfectly poached eggs. The Donut of the day was blueberry!
Lastly, I hate to mention Duckfat again, but next week I'm going back to do a taste test, pitting Duckfat's famous French fries against Eastender's Thrice baked fries. I think it'll be a close contest!

name: east-ender
review_text:
Portland hates people who ask for take-out.

I ended up at East Ender because I had difficulty finding an establishment in Old Port that would allow take-out.  Maybe I could've tried harder, but after a day of walking around in the heat, and hear four nos, I really just wanted dinner and a bed.  I didn't think it would be so difficult finding fish and chips, fish sandwich, fish anything.  I was in... MAINE!

I called East Ender because it was next to another restaurant I was eyeing.  The very pleasant young woman on the phone had to check with the kitchen to see if take-out was allowed.  My wish was granted, but I think I pissed them off by requesting take-out.

I may be from New York, but even in New York, fish and chips are golden crusted and good, in most places.  That's all I wanted.  My standards weren't that high even though I was in... MAINE!  I got back to my hotel room, and I just couldn't believe it.  The fish (Haddock, I believe) was burnt and so were the fries.  There was something that looked and tasted like squash in the container, too.  Well, huh, I didn't even finish it, and I wish I had taken a picture of the sorry non-edibles before me.  I didn't think about taking a photo until someone asked me about the "amazing food" in Portland, and I couldn't get off of my burnt fish and chips from... MAINE!

i like my mac and cheese kind of burnt (around the edges, you know).  I like my meat a little charred.  The corners of my baked salmon?  Sure!  Crispy french fries... depends on the cut.  I would never down an entire restaurant over one dish, but any restaurant who has the audacity to send out burnt, blacked food is not a restaurant deserving of patronage.  I find that to be just disrespectful.
