I know the caesar ones are awesome too, as I've had those in the past. My other friend had a falafel, which I tried, and loved as well. Overall, 5+++ stars for Blue Rooster. I love how they cater to late night on the weekends and I think they are doing everything right with their dishes. SO damn good.

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text: It is a small place. One would miss it while walking past it. We wet as part of the foodie tour. The sandwich was great. They had a lot of interesting toppings on the menu. Sadly we did not go back to try them.

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text:
This place did not live up the hype. We were told by everyone in town to check out Blue Rooster for their delicious sandwiches, so we did. My husband thought his was downright no good. Granted he's not as adventurous of an eater as I am, but he really didn't enjoy the Sweet Caroline. I ordered the beef sandwich with salsa verde and cilantro, and I was paying for it the rest of the day. I could not get the taste out of my mouth and at times felt queasy. It just didn't sit well with me. The sandwiches also don't come with a side, which I am usually okay with but for $10+ a sandwich, I'd think you'd throw in a bag of chips at a minimum. 

The worst part was that this place doesn't have a bathroom. How gross! Is that even legal? I wanted to wash my hands before eating but no dice -- I was instructed to use the bathroom in the parking garage up the street. No thanks!

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text: This place has the most amazing tater tot creations... a little slice of stoner heaven :) As the guy behind the counter told us, most of the city of Portland runs on these tots. My friend and I got the poutine and the buffalo tots... Words cannot accurately describe the yumminess! We also ordered the fried cauliflour and fried brussel sprouts, which were equally as good. Thats how I like my veggies - fried.

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text: Sandwiches were OK, but nothing special. As other posters have noted, perfect "post pub crawl foodie dive joint" with snarky adolescent staff, no AC, no bathrooms and no class. It does not appear that anyone is "in charge" here with lots of goofing around.

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text:
Ordered kimchi and macaroni and cheese. 

The good: wow-me-gently flavor on the creamy mac (but then, I never eat anything so rich at home) paired with the gentle crunch of the breadcrumbs.

The better(?): the gobble-able spice and sourness level on the giant portion of kimchi. I could have eaten the full quarter-pound or so of cabbage I was served if I weren't already full of mac. 

The best: My stomach now sounds like a bluegrass concert. Apparently, the combination of ferment plus dairy = twine time.

The details: The staff members were super nice. Everything is house-made, so it takes a minute more than your average counter service. I wish it were a buck or two cheaper (as far as the kimchi, they could get away with charging $2.50 and halving the portion!) but that's probably because I don't get out much. 

They made "an exception" and gave me tap water; IMO, they should not be so concerned about the bottom line that they are stingy with tap water. Not much room to eat, but it wasn't a problem. I don't love that all the food was served in disposable or recyclable containers as opposed to reusable ones, but I guess it's primarily a takeout business (or at least that's what the very small dining area indicated to me). 

The worst: I put my kimchi leftovers in my purse. I now have a kimchi-flavored purse, which makes vacation harder. The container was leaky!

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text: This is my favorite place to go on a Saturday night. I have never had something here that I didn't like!! Totine is one of my favorites but the fried Caesar Brussels sprouts are surprisingly delicious!!

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text:
I wish I'd known about this place sooner, because the food is fantastic. It's on a side street in downtown Portland, not very conspicuous, but well worth tracking down. 

All the menu items are creatively named, and provide some inventive choices. I had the Dirty Bird tots (chili, cheese, egg, and a bit of hot sauce) and the Pineapple Express Dog (pickled mango salsa, pineapple cilantro jalapeno mustard) and both were awesome. If you're looking for a great place to eat in Portland that's a little different, you can't go wrong with the Blue Rooster.

One side note: the restaurant is pretty small, definitely aiming more for takeout. They have a few booths, but I'd imagine during tourist season you should be prepared to take your food and eat elsewhere.

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text: Yyyyyyyum!  I drag my friends to BR every time we're out til the bars close because there is no better drunk food than poutine tater tots! Don't get it twisted though, the food tastes good when sober also. This place is delish and the flavors are unique to blue rooster! The pita bread is amazing and I add brussel sprout slaw on everything I order because I can that's why! Most people go for the tots and dogs but I recommend the sandwiches!

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text: The falafel wrap just might be the most delicious of its kind! I come here on my lunch break and it's always fast and so yummy. I'm OBSESSED

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text:
The food was good but average. There seems to be too much thought on the hot dog toppings and not enough in the quality of the hot dogs. I tried to growly dog which didn't seem to have nearly the amount of bacon I pictured and I have no idea what the boss sauce is that came on it.  The bun was soft and fresh. 

The  tater tots with all the different topping is a cool idea and a good way to feed those salty food cravings. I tried the buffalo flavor which had an excellent ratio of buffalo sauce to blue cheese. It comes topped with carrot and celery shreds.  Not a very good addition. The nacho tater tots had excellent chili and nacho sauce and what what must be house made salsa. The ingredients were all fresh and had a nice spicy kick. 

Overall it was a good experience with friendly staff, but not one I will be regular at.

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text:
Still waiting for a cup of water.

My husband I are here for the first time tonight. It was empty inside (and has been every time we've walked by), but the menu sounded so good.


 We ordered and paid. Then, I asked for a cup of water. The guy at the counter said "we've just got the bottled water for a dollar". He turned and walked away as he said this. Seriously. You won't give me a cup of water. And you know it's d--- move so you won't look at me while you say it.

We each ordered a hotdog - the Barking Dog and the Pineapple Express. Both were delish. The tots were also really yummy. But, I'm completely turned off that you wouldn't give me a cup of water. Sorry, won't be back.

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text: Fun little spot to duck in and have some unique sandwich options to try. Need more options as 2/3 of the items were hot dogs.

name: blue-rooster-food-company
review_text: Beefsquach and tots.   the name does not reflect how good it was.

name: bramhall
review_text: Get the burger. Make it a double. Maybe feel bad about your life choices but it's so so good.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Looking for a unique speakeasy feel with great cocktails - this is the place for you! 

I love their cocktails here. It is a little dark inside depending on what you're looking for. Their food is good, nothing too special but good quality bar food. 

When it's nice out there's some picnic tables in the back as well. My go to bar for a drink with friends in Portland!

name: bramhall
review_text:
On Friday night (April 19th), a patron at this bar tried to attack me. 

I'm posting this as a warning to any woman considering coming to this bar-- please look out for yourself, as no one there will care or make any attempt to help you, even in the event of evident aggressive and hostile actions.

I have been failed THREE TIMES now by your management-- one time the night-of, when both bartenders and the doorman looked away as this man shouted, poked and shoved me and grabbed my arms to keep me from getting away. I instead quietly and calmly paid my bill and walked out as he physically chased me and tried to restrain me. I couldn't ask for help over him trying corral me, I was just trying to get out. Any one of the three employees could've easily asked him at an absolute minimum to hold up for a minute, giving me time to escape unharmed. But they did not. 

The second two failures came when I mustered up the courage two days later to call and ask to talk to a manager, not to complain or ask for anything, but to chat about how to help other women who may find themselves in my situation going forward. The first time I called (Sunday, April 21, 4:00pm), the guy on the phone told me the manager wasn't around but he'd pass on my number and have him call me "some time this week." He expressed no concern and hung up on me as I was asking if there was another way I could get in contact with him.

I called again on Monday (April 22, 6:00pm), after still hearing nothing. A new guy on the phone was a bit more sympathetic, and said the manager still wasn't in but he would call him now to let him know and ask him to call me that evening. He said he hadn't heard about the incident and asked for my phone number again. So I guess my first call fell through the cracks? I did not hear from any manager last night, and still haven't.

That night, I was scared for my safety. The guy followed me outside as I ran to my car, him jumping in front of traffic to chase me. He proceeded to grab my door before I could close it, and tried to grab me as I struggled to pull my door closed. I screamed for help several times. I was thankfully able to get the door closed after struggling to push him off it, but next time any other woman may not be so fortunate. This all could have been prevented if someone, ANYONE, had stepped in, even just for a moment. 

I tried twice to discuss this directly with the manager in a helpful way, but I think any woman deserves to know that she will be absolutely, totally on her own. The management does not care about your safety. They do not care about you. PLEASE BE SAFE.

name: bramhall
review_text: Bramhall is a great place if you want a dark, sultry environment and a great cocktail. Located in the West End part of the city. The burger is one of my favorites in the city (the special sauce makes it). Try ALL of their specialty cocktails.

name: bramhall
review_text: What a great find! A couple weeks ago, my wife and I came to Portland for a weekend getaway. We heard about this place, but never had the chance to stop by. So glad we did! Having stopped at a few different restaurants that evening already, we were only planning on stopping in and having a beer before calling it a night. But this place was so cool and cozy that we ended up not only staying for a couple beers, but ordering food even though we had been stuffing our faces the entire night. Everything about this place was on point. The staff was incredibly accommodating and friendly. The decor was super cool with it's brick archways and giant brick "candle pit"? Very warm environment. And the food was crazy good. I had the BLT and my wife had a side of Truffle Fries. Highly recommended.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Bramhall is a really cool bar and establishment located at the bottom of Roma Cafe. The minute you walk in, you are welcomed into the darkness with stone walls and dim lighting which gives it a dungeon-like feeling. Think Game of Thrones meets Harry Potter. 

The thing I appreciate about Bramhall is their cocktail selections. They have unique cocktails that are handmade, and they also have a specific selection of cocktails made with local liquor, which I thought was cool. They also provide some limited options of local beer and wine selections. Bramhall also offers some food selections that tend to be pub-like food, ranging from chicken wings, to a burger, to various other shareable plates. I have gotten their fries, which was very thin and good, and I have also tried the burger, which was surprisingly great! 

The only thing that keeps my review from giving it five stars is the service. Every time I have gone in, the servers and bartenders are nice, however, it sometimes feels like the staff are more enthused with their phones over the actual customers. When I went the other night, I was sitting at the bar and I finished my drink, and it took a while for the bartender to notice I was empty to ask if I wanted another drink. A small fix, though, Bramhall definitely has a unique aesthetic that adds to the Portland bar scene. I will be sure to continue coming!

name: bramhall
review_text: Loved everything about this place. Definitely a good pick for a date or romantic spot for drinks; it's dark, mysterious, and intimate. Had our first Bissell Bros Swish here after our server put us onto it, and it was everything he claimed it to be!

name: bramhall
review_text:
I typed in "dungeon bar Portland" into Google and Bramhall was the only place that showed up. I honestly thought the place was called Dungeon Bar after a friend called it that when I asked for a place with a really good hamburger. Regardless, it does live up to that nickname in the form of a dark, candlelit atmosphere with black beamed ceilings and it's location underneath another restaurant. 

We had a rotation of servers who attended to us at our table, so all night we felt taken care of. However, be warned! The seating options are a bit, well, uncomfortable in the back of the space. There are the worlds tiniest stools (restaurants, get a clue--most people have butts wider than twelve inches) or a bench with leather cushions but the cushions get pushed around a lot. There were a few high tops around too, but they weren't available. 

Mild discomfort aside, if you want a good, simple burger I highly recommend. Great taste, potato bun, perfectly cooked and flavorful bacon, a delightfully oozey fried egg, and a special sauce guaranteed to make your mouth crave more. And the chips that come with as the default side are awesome--whatever that spice blend is, keep it coming!  I opted for the fries as my burger side and they are shoestring style. Also, completely excellent. 

I'll be back, but I may bring my own seat.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Cool space- dark basement area under Roma Cafe with candles everywhere....sounds eerie but it's pretty cozy down there (maybe because it was packed!)

Wide range of cocktails and beers and great for date night!

name: bramhall
review_text:
This cute little hidden gem reminded us of an "underground dive" with a mid-evil feel to it. Awesome decor from the candle display to the foot-automated sinks in the restrooms. 
Can't comment on the food, but our server was efficient and let us taste a sample of the wines prior to purchase. We will be back!

name: bramhall
review_text: Great experience; great atmosphere. Staff was very accommodating.  Perfect place to start an evening in downtown Portland. Very rustic feel with plenty of privacy.  Great selection of liquor and local beer.

name: bramhall
review_text:
I had heard so much about Bramhall and knew I wanted to check it out. I just heard it was "different." My friend led the way down the stairs (where aroma Cafe is) and as I pulled back the velvet curtain, it was like I was transported to another time period. It was very gothic feeling with the stone, candlelit ambiance, and overall underground feel. 

When you've time traveled to the past, why not order a whiskey? That's what I did. And I don't drink whiskey. But I enjoyed it! And I felt like it was appropriate for the place I was in! My friend and I ordered garlic fries (happy hour special) and they were delicious. Think shoestring fries-very thing and crispy. 

The bar is lovely and expansive. We got perfect view of the leg lamp from A Christmas Story as well as the bartender separating egg whites to include in some speciality cocktails. There are some small tables as well, if that's more your style or are with a group. The bathroom is fun and clean. You open the doors saloon style. The sink is very industrial with foot pedals. 

I'd love to go back to Bramhall and try some more foods and drinks!

name: bramhall
review_text:
First impression walking in the door, I immediately thought of Harry Potter. Bramhall is right under Roma Café and is almost in a basement style location. All the walls are brick and the dim lighting and old style doors just reminded me of all the buildings at Hogwarts in Harry Potter. It almost had a dungeon feel (not in a bad way though).... Super cool place. 

It is seat yourself, so once you walk in, if you find a table, it can be yours. We came on a weekday around 7P and there was no issues finding a place to sit.... and we were a group of 6. 

The drink menu is extensive with ample selections of cocktails, beers and wines. I ended up getting a couple cocktails, both of which were delicious.... however, for the life of me I cannot remember either of the names (sorry!). 

I am also big on doing a taste test with everyone else's drinks and I can't say there was one I tried that I didn't like. All the cocktails had a unique and different taste. 

The service was consistent and we were checked on regularly and brought our drinks quickly. 

Unfortunately, given our later reservation at Roma Café, I did not get the opportunity to have their food. However, based on the looks and descriptions in the menu, it seems like they have some really tasty options. 

This is definitely a cool place to hang out and get some tasty drinks. And if you want a good Harry Potter vibe, I definitely recommend coming to Bramhall!

name: bramhall
review_text:
First time in the renovated Bramhall Pub. A funky, gothic like vibe. Very dimly lit with lots of stone and brick. The bar chairs don't have high backs, which is a constant pet peeve for me. Bar was nicely appointed spirit wise. Many local craft beer options, and a wide craft cocktail list. 

I would suggest that the food is uninspired here. My first pub grub at most places is their chicken wings....they were below par here. Ultra heavy breading and under spiced. My GF had the pork terrane. I tried a couple bites...it was ok, with mustard, gherkins, and toasted points as a side add. 

I think this is a neat cocktail spot...and they have some side parking below their entrance, which is nice. The food was average, but I'd give it another try.

3 Stars...I'd give higher if I can try some better pub food.

name: bramhall
review_text: I had a delightful evening at this establishment. First of all it is a speakeasy so it is very spooky and covert. Because of this it kind of feels like a dungeon (with a rodeo flair because there are swinging doors to get to the bathroom). My server, Jason, was so lit! It was my friends birthday and she got a lot of perks which was very nice. If you go here you should bring at least $30 with you because everything costs like $10. A lot of people got chicken fingers and a lot of people got burgers. We all had French fries and they were divine! Shoe string fries! Another thing that I liked about this place was the candle display in the center. It was like a shrine and because I was sitting near it, it kind of felt like a shrine to me. For drinks I got the Salty Cat, which was perfectly salty, and the Crowley, which had coffee in it so it was like an upscale four Loko. Overall, I had a nice time here and the only warning I have is that you need to go down a flight of stairs so it is not that accessible (there could be another way to get in so ask ahead) and also it is dark down there so if you are wearing transition lenses you might have a problem because those things never change back to regular glasses quick enough.

name: bramhall
review_text: Great environment and maybe the best chicken wings I've ever had.  Just had bad timing on the IPA selections that night...swish was on the menu, but not available.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Okay, okay. I can overlook the slow service because the food here rules. Their veggie burger is Blue Mango so it's a little on the expensive side, but it's SO GOOD that it's worth the extra dollars. 

The music playing usually fits the ambience of hipster/dungeon. Trivia on Sunday nights rules too. And as I always say.... Bissell on tap means my bf and I will return. Again and again. And again.

This is a great spot for locals. All I have to do is roll down the three staircases in my apartment and across the street to roll down the Bramhall stairs and into the abyss that is the dark lair that is Bramhall. 

You might not get served right away and may wait a bit for a drink, but omg it's worth it.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Wow, talk about a revamp!  As someone else mentioned, I am also old enough to remember the old Bramhall. Dingy and cold, it was a great (divey) bar then and is a great (upscale) bar now.  Where the darts used to be, you now have a beautifully appointed bar and huge selection of craft beers and cocktails.  While the free pizza and hot dogs of happy hour are gone, you now can have amazing fare without wondering just how old the pizza is.

It has a cave feel, with exposed brick and dark lighting in the basement/underground room.  The wait staff are all knowledgeable and friendly. It's a great scene every night and I highly recommend it!

name: bramhall
review_text: Bramhall is okay.. I've never been wowed by the place. Everything is overpriced and the service kinda sucks. I feel like I come here occasionally to be reminded that I don't enjoy it.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Are you obsessed with Vikings?
Or Harry Potter?
Or Game of Thrones?
Or Dungeons and Dragons?

If you said yes to any of those... and you also like flavorful and strong craft cocktails... and you also like candle light... and you also like the smell of leather, pipe smoke, and earth... and you also like when the chances of running into someone you might know are slim to none (and even if you do, it's so dark you can pretend you didn't actually see them)...

Bramhall might be for you.

I have a wild imagination. And sitting in Bramhall, I could:
1. Be in Edinburgh, or San Francisco, or Montreal... it's got a very worldly feeling to it, and transports you right out of Portland, ME. 
2. Be in Ragnar Lothbrook's great hall circa 700 to 800 AD waiting to party after hearing where we're raiding this spring.
3. Be in Diagon Alley having a drink before making a dark magic deal... or busting one. It depends on if my emotional pendulum is swinging towards Good or Evil that night.

Too weird? Okay:
1. The cocktails are varied and delicious; they are also reasonably priced.
2. The scene is very laid back; it's in a subterranean space; there is also an enormous patio that's much more generic feeling.
3. The staff is friendly and quick.

Actually, you know what, please don't come here. This is mine now. I'm claiming this as my East Coast soulmate bar, and only those who can pretend with me are allowed to come.

Þkk! Góða nótt!

name: bramhall
review_text: I am old enough to remember the old Bramhall of the 80's. I loved it then and I love it now. When you walk down the stairs and enter, you immediately feel warm and welcomed. The soft candlelit glow and the quiet chatter of guests just envelopes you. I love the old brick and stone walls and nooks. They always have a great selection of local draft beers. I had a Rising Tide Wayside Porter. Quite excellent with its sweet coffee notes. My friends were impressed with the cocktail and wine list too.Service was quick and the staff was friendly and efficient.  I was meeting with friends before we went upstairs to dine at The Roma which is another welcomed revived loved restaurant that I also loved from way back in the 80's.

name: bramhall
review_text: What an amazing bar and staff! The drink list is great and it's clear that the bartenders know what they are doing. The drinks are unique, delicious and carefully crafted. The food menu is small but perfect. There's something for everyone. We had the frito pie which was a perfect snack to have with a drink. Mike was our bartender and his recommendations were spot on and his conversation was amazing! What a great guy!  Also, the decor? Out of this world. This is my new go to spot when I'm in Portland.

name: bramhall
review_text: This is seriously one of the coolest bars I've ever been to! The other reviews are spot on--definitely has a Game of Thrones meets Harry Potter feel being in a "dungeon". It's such a unique experience you must go if you're ever in Portland. Fancy cocktails and delicious food. I highly recommend the brussel sprouts and Frito pie. Mmmmm. I hope to go back before my Portland trip ends.

name: bramhall
review_text: We went to Bramhall for drinks and an appetizer while waiting for a dinner reservation. A little difficult to find, (just go down the stairs, through the red curtains, and take a left). But once inside, it proved to be a very intimate and unique setting. The drinks were great and the Brussels sprouts were some of the best I've tasted. The bartender was knowledgeable, friendly, and offered recommendations to every one he served. Highly recommended to those in town and locals who have not yet discovered Bramhall !

name: bramhall
review_text: Simple$8 BISSELL substance Common this is Maine not New York really need better pricing. Even the snacks they serve are bland this use to be a good spot n to many other more reasonable priced bars around.

name: bramhall
review_text: I normally love Bramhall but I have been really disappointed lately with the service. Great food and cocktails but the service is awful. We sat on the back deck and our server completely forgot about us, we had to go inside to get service. Cmon!

name: bramhall
review_text:
As a huge cocktail fan, it was a big mistake that it took me so long to discover this place. My partner and I decided to come on a Sunday afternoon for a drink or two and we were not disappointed. 

When we walked it there wasn't much of a crowd so we were easily able to grab a seat at the bar. We were greeted warmly by the bartender upon arrival. Bramhall offers a huge selection of liquor which gives you plenty of options to satisfy whatever you are looking for. 

We weren't planning on getting food but I decided to order to grab the rice krispy bar du jour and was very happy I did. 

Overall the best part of Bramhall was the low key atmosphere where you could enjoy the company of others and also easily meet new people around you. Very friendly staff and great service made this a 5 star place and will definitely go back.

name: bramhall
review_text: This place is amazing! It's like walking through a secret underground bar with great food. The wait staff is very nice and attentive. The happy hour prices are a great discount on very unique dishes and popular beer like allagash. I ordered the pulled pork as seen in the picture attached, the taste was spicy but still savory. The shoe string fries was a great addition for a few extra bucks. The wait for the food was just enough to start a great conversation without feeling like it was forever. The beer I had was a waypoint coffee porter. It had little bite but you could still taste the coffee. Would recommend coming here if your first time in Portland

name: bramhall
review_text:
This place is so cool, I can't even take it. The mishmash of people that are employed and patronize this spot are amazing.  When I sit down to tickle my computer keys, I try to think of how to convey the magic that I feel when I walk down the steps and through the door of Bramhall... but I can't.

Examples of such magic...

1. Constantly lit candles.

2. The porch in the summer.

3.  The amazing brick arches that make you feel like you've slipped back in medieval times.

4.  All the drinks are incredible as are the charcuterie plates.

5. I recently was meeting a lovely lady there for a second date. Upon arrival, there was some loud, head banging music playing over the speakers.  Our amazing server/bartender came over and got my drink order, (they are always very speedy with the service), and told the server my situation. I needed a mood set to which she responded "do you want slow jams or chill?"  Then we had a brief discussion about the vibe and she put on something perfect to hang out to.  

Now this might seem like no big deal, but asking a server or a bartender to change their music selection rarely goes over this well.  When my date arrived (around midnight after work) she was able to get a cheese plate, with olives and a variety of other delicious spreads.  In addition to this, our server let us hang out and finish our drinks after closing, AND was attentive the whole time.  

This whole night was true bar magic and I think that no matter what, when you head down those stairs, you may just feel the magic, too.

name: bramhall
review_text:
One time, many moons ago (think like 2013), I was in here and didn't have a great experience.  Bramhall just didn't fit and I didn't get great service and I hated my drinks.  Because of that, until recently, I have declined to return.  

Finally, one of my friends, Jess B (HAAAAYYY JESS B) talked myself and the Kates into coming back here and I write this review a changed person.  

First of all, sometimes they do fun activities like set up mini golf in the outside seating area.  OMG YAS.  You betcha I played twice.  
The drinks are different or maybe my palate is more refined (haha, no) and are amazing and tasty.  
The service was awesome.  (cough, can you tell me about your meat, cough) Everyone was super friendly and though the place has a hipster vibe, I feel like we have received really great service every time we have been.  

Bramhall, you turned it around and now I love you.  I like you and I'll hang out with you again.

name: bramhall
review_text: This was our first stop on our impromptu cocktail tour of Portland, and it was great! Delicious cocktails, a great whiskey selection, and an interesting vibe. Would definitely recommend!

name: bramhall
review_text: Unbelievable environment and ambience with some of the best cocktails I've had. Tequila and coffee? Game-changer.

name: bramhall
review_text:
I came here for a happy hour on a random Wednesday night and was so happy I did. First of all, the atmosphere here is unreal cool. It's like being in some old castle with candles and alcohol. Absolutely the best. 

I got a beer on draft (Barreled Souls - Rosalia, which I HIGHLY recommend) and the others I was with got a beer and a glass of wine, which they both enjoyed. I also got the California Smoked Turkey sandwich, which was delicious. It was on one of the best ciabatta rolls I have ever had. 

The cocktails also looked incredible and I can't wait to come back soon to try them!

name: bramhall
review_text: I have always preferred the dimly lit, down-tempo sort of place Bramhal exemplifies to more raucous affairs. With curated cocktails that frequently fit my tastes and a very chill gothic aesthetic that calls to mind a catacomb more readily than a club, Bramhall has fallen into place as well-loved haunt among my friends and family. Service is good and quick even on busy evenings and the food on offer is great too. On top of that I'm always happy with the variety of drinks available and the know-how of the bartenders. My go to for the occasional night out.

name: bramhall
review_text:
I have found my new cocktail bar in Portland. I am ashamed to say it took me this long to get down into Bramhall. This place is phenomenal. Please, owners, managers, and staff, don't change a thing; you've got a good thing here. 

The atmosphere is killer. I love dark, subterranean bars. Hell, bars are dark. If they aren't dank, that is a bonus. This, my friends, is a bar. In the basement of a building, exposed brick, archways, you feel like you are in the basement of some bar in Riga, Latvia in the basement of a medieval building. Candle light the joint, and small nooks and crannies of seating add to the romantic ambience and Bohemian vibe of this joint. 

The drinks are to die for. Cocktails are top-notch. The bartenders know their craft, and they do not hesitate to fill a request based off a recipe handed to them. Order cocktails, skip the beer, go somewhere else for that. It will be a shameful waste to drink a pint of suds when you could drink mixed nirvana in a cocktail glass. 

The staff is exceedingly accommodating and friendly. Superior service. 

The food is good. I had a Cubano sandwich and it was good. The bread was soft, the pickles sour, and the cheese melty. 

Yeah. Try it. Love it. Go back for more.

name: bramhall
review_text: Atmosphere was decent, drinks were very meh, service sucked, no rice crispy treats, and really nothing to set it apart from a dirty dive bar. Was very disappointed and would not return.

name: bramhall
review_text: I love this place and the people. It's been delightful from top to bottom. Thank you so much for a great time!

name: bramhall
review_text: Such a cozy vibe! Small but good food menu. Excellent drinks and solid beer tap. It is dark in here, so bring your reading glasses!

name: bramhall
review_text:
I've been a patron of this establishment many times, I've always admired the laid back approach their Resturant provides! I've never been greeted by a host or hostess, which can be rather refreshing and although it kinda seems like your walking into someone's basement (I guess it's because we're  in Portland, right?) I appreciated the friendly staff and they make a decent burger! 

With that said, I thought I was walking into a Resturant to have a burger tonight at 10pm, but instead walked into a scene from the Walking Dead.

Since Brmahall normally has serval seats available, I was shocked when they had a line at the for entry? Once I got the the door and could see inside, I noticed they were the same as most nights, pretty empty. So imagine my surprise, when I was greeted for the first time ever, by a security guard.  

Not a host nor hostess, a security guard. I'm a 35yr old women, I just drove an 1hr from working an 11hr shift in Waterville, to be approached by a security guard to enter a Resturant, seemed strange. So like most normal, red blooded Americans would, I ask, what with the id's? The answer was abrupt and rude: to drink. 

Because Bramhall does serve one of the latest menus in town and I have to work tomorrow morning at 8am and will make the drive again tomorrow morning, my response was, "I'm not drinking." I asked again, did something happen here at Bramhall, why you would need my id at the door and there's security here now? 

Was there a reason for security at a Resturant?
Did something violent happen?
Was Bramhall busted for underage drinking? 

Whatever the case, I do not feel necessary to be harriers by a low life security guard with nothing better to do, than to be an asshole. When walking into an establishment to eat a sub-par burger in a basement. 

There I said my peace and now I'm done with it, you never see my face in your shitty ass basement "bar" (cause it ain't a Resturant) again.

name: bramhall
review_text: A fantastic hidden gem of Portland, tucked away in a basement. The atmosphere was awesome for a low key evening. There are great selections behind the bar, beyond your usual drafts and wine lists. Bartenders were very nice and helpful. Would definitely return and fully intend to do so.

name: bramhall
review_text: I'd come here 8 nights a week if they didn't play awful '80s and '90s music. Cocktails and service are fantastic, but I'm not down with Whitney Houston and Phil Collins.

name: bramhall
review_text: Love the atmosphere. I've been twice for a late afternoon drink. A great place to beat the summer heat. Sandwiches are delicious too!

name: bramhall
review_text:
Yes! Bramhall is exactly what Portland's been missing... well at least since it closed it's doors. However re-opening was exactly the right move. The ambiance in here is perfect if they can keep these candles lit every night. It's got a midievil vibe without being too kitschy. They don't have a cocktail list - or at least didn't when I went in, but after ordering a Manhattan for $7 (I did not stutter..) I was pleased as a peach. Even more pleased was I when the Manhattan was ON POINT (real cherries and all folks). 

This place was packed for opening night and Jerks of Grass playing, but I will definitely be back to enjoy more delicious spirits. I also heard from a friend that the chips are delicious (made in house!). The service was extremely attentive. The new wood bar also compliments the stone interior extremely well. Bravo Bramhall!

name: bramhall
review_text: This bar is definitely my newest favorite bar. I came here twice in twenty four hours after finding out about it. Both times were different situations and both experiences were wonderful. Right as you walk in you are greeted by a romantic brick room lit by candles and low hanging lights. They have a excellent tap selection and great cocktails. They also have tons and tons of different whiskeys, bourbons, and ryes thats bottles took up an entire wall. When I came here on Friday night looking for a table to eat at and grab some drinks around 7. There was a wait for a table so my boyfriend and I grabbed a drink from the bar while we waited. I tried the scofflaw which was a rye based cocktail and fell in love with it. Once sat we had the loaded crisp with pickled onion and jalapeños added to it in suggestion of our waiter with another scofflaw (suggestion of me). When I came Saturday night it was later on around 1030 and there was a doorman. The bar was pretty quiet and we were able to grab seats at it for our drinks. The location of this bar is great for being looking to hang out a little bit outside the old port area. I can't wait to go back.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Decent cocktail spot. We tried 3, all were pretty sweet and not spirit heavy. 

Veggie burger was damn spot on though. A great beer selection and (dark) but nice ambiance made it a great late night drink spot.

name: bramhall
review_text: I loved walking into the restaurant - going down into a "secret" entrance, pulling back the velvet curtain, stepping into the candle lit space with brick and arches and doors leading to .. who knows. Almost like being on a game of thrones set. The drinks were awesome, as a bartender I love a good craft cocktail - I had the salty cat, very refreshing. The menu seemed limited, especially for me - I don't eat pork or beer and there were a decent amount of items with those ingredients; so we went "basic" and got chicken fingers hoping they were scratch kitchen made, nope. Def frozen/made somewhere else. Waffle fries were good, but again, I don't think they were made there. We also had the portabello sandwich - it was dressed right, flavors were good...but the star was the seasoned homemade chips! Finally something I would expect from a place like Bramhall! I could eat an entire plate of those chips haha. So all in all, good experience, service was great - I would go back.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Yes! Yes! I got dragged here, had never heard of it, and was skeptical every moment of the way there. When I stepped through the unremarkable (and slightly dingy) doorway though, I couldn't have had a quicker turn around. 

Atmosphere: Speakeasy, hip, dark, intimate. Brick walls, dark woods tables, largely candlelit. This is the type of place where secret lovers (should) meet and where brooding men come to think, look sultry, and sip on fine whiskey. 

Drinks: I forgot my ID, so I missed out on the Prohibition era cocktails and had water. I see this as an excuse to go back soon!

Food: Started off with the meat and cheese plate. It was so tasty! A broad array of flavors. It was gone in 2 minutes. For my entree I had half of the Kentucky Hot Brown (Rotisserie Turkey, Tomato, Bacon, Mornay Sauce, Parsley, Pullman Loaf, Served Open-Faced, $12) and half of the Grilled Ham and Cheese (Ham, American Cheese, Pickled Jalapeno, House Jam, Pullman Loaf, $10). Both were amazing! The Kentucky was super creamy and melty and was the perfect comfort food for a cold night. The Grilled Ham and cheese, on the other hand, was spunky and flavorful with quite the kick from the jalapenos. 10/10 would order again. 

Service: Our waitress was awesome. Besides clearly being an cool person in her own right, she was attentive and SUPER knowledgable. We asked one question about a whisky and honestly she schooled us with all of her knowledge. She wasn't condescending at all, but rather so interesting that we  just started asking her questions about other things and she kept up with us every step of the way. 

We finished up the night with the cheesecake of the day (Peanut Butter/Chocolate) and some sort of (insanely yummy) rice crispies drizzled in some sort of sweet/zingy dessert sauce. I would eat one every day if I could. 

Amazing spot, great dinner, will definitely be back gain.

name: bramhall
review_text:
I've been wanting to try Bramhall for months based on my friends stories of the "dungeon-esque" type feel. It does kind of feel that way with the brick interior and melting candle display in the center. Unfortunately unless you're literally sitting at the table right next to it you can't really see it. Bramhall is located in the basement in what used to be The Roma (or was it La Roma?) restaurant. I love that this place is far enough away from the old port that you don't get the drunk 20 something's that are finding out what it's like to have their first drink. I also love their cocktail menu, yes they have beer and wine too but the cocktail menu is the star. My favorite drink so far is the "nurses aide". (Disclaimer: I'm a nurse so I had to try it when I saw it on the menu). Cocktail prices are $8-11, pretty typical for this area. Also, no parking lot or garage that I know of in this area. You have to take your chances finding street parking or illegally parking somewhere. 

They have a couple of food items, too. I've tried the peanut butter marshmallow bars, and get this: They have bacon in them! I absolutely loved them. One of my friends really liked them too and another friend thought they were "meh". We also had the loaded crisps which were BBQ chips covered in sour cream, bacon, cheez whiz, and scallions. We all loved this. I would definitely order both of these food items again. The service here has been great here too, they will come to your table and take your order if you don't want to wait at the bar. 

My only complaint is that about half of the seating here are tiny metal un-cushioned barstools. After about an hour sitting on one I was so uncomfortable that I had to stand up. My butt was numb! My girlfriend offered to switch seats with me because she had a cushioned seat. We stayed another hour or so and my friend said her butt was hurting from sitting on the stool too. Get comfy seats so your patrons will stay and drink longer and spend more money!

name: bramhall
review_text:
What an awesome place! My friend and I stopped in here when we were on vacation (after doing some research on Yelp, of course!) and it did not disappoint. We got a little charcuterie platter that was SO good. And we got cocktails that were made with pink grapefruit, which I have been remembering and craving. Possibly the tastiest drink I've ever had. 

And obviously, the atmosphere was extremely cool, too, which is the whole point I guess, but in this speakeasy's case, not the only point.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Yup, mhm, I'll take it. After a pub crawl it was the cherry on top of any otherwise unsatisfying night; I was very surprised and delighted by the vampire decor and dark and moody lighting. All in all not what I expected from the street or the entrance, very drab outside, very chic inside.

I'll be straight - I have been out of Portland for more years than I have been in it, even if I was born here. It doesn't surprise me all that much anymore, but when I see something like Bramhall I really start to wonder if I've really ever known Portland at all to begin with. What a strange and interesting little place. What creative graffiti in the women's bathroom. What a scrumptious pulled pork sandwich. And what a strange dish my husband ordered, which I don't recall the name of, but was absolutely exquisite. 

The place is so bizarre and specifically not-characterizable that I almost wouldn't recommend it to someone visiting Portland. You'll probably walk in and be like, "we have ten of these in MY hometown" so don't bother. But honestly for our cozy and somewhat out-of-the-loop corner of the world Bramhall is very neat.

name: bramhall
review_text: We just had after dinner drinks after having a phenomenal birthday dinner for my boyfriends birthday with an exceptional server named Catie. We went down stairs promptly after dinner with a recommendation from her, and stood by the bar. The bartender was clearly busy so we grabbed a menu ourselves and took a look at the cocktails. While my boyfriend was asking a question, the bartender abruptly stated we should have a seat at the table if we want drinks. A server could take care of us because he didn't have the time. I honestly wanted to leave at this point, but my boyfriend wanted to stay, so I asked him if we should get a table because I was uncomfortable. He didn't want to because we were just getting drinks (which makes sense now thinking back on it.) I said we should just leave because I felt so unwelcomed but he said let's wait for our friends who were talking upstairs to come down. This is where the review turns extremely positive. Chef Ron, their brand new executive chef, stepped in, cleared off a dirty section of the bar, cleaned it, took our drink order, apologized for the bartender, and took care of our entire parties drinks. He was the epitome of hospitality and is the primary reason I will return to this establishment. As a leader he represented your brand with the utmost professionalism and I have full faith that he will correct the major concern that happened tonight. Catie and Chef Ron are all you need for a fantastic service and culinary experience.

name: bramhall
review_text: Great atmosphere, candles music brick... interesting menu, delicious unique drinks! I got the smoked salmon on everything bagel with whipped goat cheese, yum!!! I think the drink was rosemary and grapefruit :)

name: bramhall
review_text: Incredible atmosphere. Cool spot in a basement. My cocktails were good, but not mind blowing. The service was great. Craft beer was great. We had the nachos and they were excellent. So delicious. I would come back here and bring people just for the atmosphere.

name: bramhall
review_text:
I've heard about this place and thought it was supposed to be more of a dive. If you see stairs leading to an abyss you're in the right spot.  

We heard it was redesigned-seems almost trendy-hard to tell. 

Only down side to the amazing 80's jams was that at 11 they turned it up so loud that you couldn't hear the person next to you. Maybe they wanted us to leave-that's my only "yeah--no" moment & reason for lack of full stars. 

Great brick, lighting and it feels like you really are in a dungeon or Harry Potter book. The bartender was super friendly.

name: bramhall
review_text: Awesome underground prohibition atmosphere, kind of True Bloody like your going to be taken by a vampire but that's what made it great. Bartender was very nice even though we ordered shots after shots which I know bartenders hate when they're mixed and three of them were. He pressed on like a champ making them all!

name: bramhall
review_text:
First Experience: 4 stars. We had my sister's birthday party here. Granted, I already had several gin martinis and we had people saving us a table, so it was easy-going to say the least. Our server was super friendly though absent most of the night. Eh, we are a group of servers so we understand a busy and new restaurant working out the kinks. Food was good, well-priced and the atmosphere is the real seller here. Speak-easy vibes and cool basement decor makes for a unique experience. 

NEXT TWO TIMES: I come in with a friend or two, no one talks to us, we have to look for a place to sit, all seats are full. Am I mad that I didn't get a table without a reservation? Of course not! Am I turned off by the fact that both times when I came in NO ONE talked to us. I actually stood at the bar and stare at the two gossiping bartenders, still to be ignored. I had to say "excuse me" to even get the conversation started. Both were unhelpful and visibly annoyed that I interrupted them.

name: bramhall
review_text: The bartenders are super friendly. They give great advice and give you plenty of time to decide.  The ambience is also quite fabulous down in this cool, kind of gothic looking bar.  I would absolutely go back if I was back in Portland.

name: bramhall
review_text:
I used to frequent the Bramhall back when it was more of a hole in the wall. It offered cheap beer, free pool on Thursday nights and a juke box of classic rock (including the Allman Brothers' epic 33-minute version of Mountain Jam... For the same price as any other song)... Upon its reopening, it's been given a facelift. The bar has moved, the pool table has been replaced with table seating and the cheap beer has been replaced with artisanal drinks and nice microbrews. 

The place is dark... Dimly lit by candlelight. It makes for a nice ambiance, but it makes it very hard to read the menu. The menu is still evolving, but it offered a variety of meat options (my friend had the burger and loved it)... As a vegetarian I got the loaded crisps (potato chips with creme fresh, scallions and cheese curds) and the cheese plate (three cheeses, thin-sliced apples, pickled onions, a toasted bread and seasoned nuts). I'm definitely excited to see the full menu once they work out their kinks. The staff was very attentive and enthusiastic... There already seems to be a group of regulars forming so I think the new Bramhall will be a success.

Part of me is pining for the indifferent waitstaff and the devil-may-care attitude of the days of old... when I had only pennies in my pockets and was still able to have a few beers with friends... But another part of me feels like maybe the Bramhall Pub has grown up... As have I... And I'm happy to be able go back... (Now with deeper pockets) and have a few beers with friends.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Portland finally has some decent bars. Bramhall included. 
The atmosphere at the bar was on point- soft lighting, comfortable stools, good music, good selections. 
I was particularly impressed with the bartender, he was attentive and friendly. 

I was not particularly impressed with the food. I got the "famous" crisps for $2 at happy hour- great price but really couldn't tell the difference between these and some lays BBQ chips. 
I also got the "garden nibbles" or some other cute name- which was house made hummus with pita, and some vegetables on skewers. The hummus tasted like nothing; literally had no flavor. The pita was alright- but the grilled vegetables weren't anything special. 

Bramhall is still deserving of 4 stars because the bar is so great. Its like drinking in a cozy dungeon.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Whither not ye decision is to devour thy requests or consume at thy leisure, Bramhall -- a pub supporting meats and cheeses of excellence unparralleled -- will supply and fulfill thy desires without compromise nor contest.

Here were no comparisons nor contenders, and though hours were long, I found myself enthralled by the ambiance. Stone archways fueled by presence whilst acceptable, truthful background music allowed -- NAY! -- encouraged! furthering a conversation I'd spent not a night nor a fortnight, but years procuring and evolving to this very point, a perfect finality to Portland before expanding my experiences of life to a land from here.

Cold. Old. Beautiful. Comfortable. 5 stars.

Add mead on tap, and I'll find a way to put in 6 stars.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Bramhall is a fantastic addition to the west end scene. I think they've ordered a sign, but I like it better without one, because this bar is a true speakeasy. You walk downstairs into basically a classy dungeon, and I mean this in the best way possible. The bar is very dark and mostly brick and stone, but the materials are upscale. This isn't a dive bar, but it's not a cocktail lounge either. It's new and different and I love it.

The lead bartender came from Gingko Blue, so you know you're getting some of the best cocktails around. At about half the price. An old fashioned-like cocktail was $6.50! The beer and wine menu are printed in a faux middle ages book, but the cocktail menu hasn't been finalized. The food looks awesome with burgers, cheese plates, creative sandwiches, etc. The chef came from Duckfat, which is a great sign.

Bramhall was packed on opening weekend and will probably remain that way. It's a great, unique new bar.

name: bramhall
review_text: Cool, speakeasy type place located on the outskirts of downtown Portland. The sign is dimly lit on the outside and is located in the basement. Very cozy atmosphere and self service seating. Have a great cocktail and beer list. Although their food menu is limited they do it well. The sandwiches were plentiful and delicious. Definitely will return

name: bramhall
review_text: Stopped in after watching a Sea Dogs game because it had been recommended by someone we met and we were not let down. A little hard to find if you're not looking for it but totally worth going to. I felt like like we were in an ancient medieval cellar that had been converted to a speak easy during prohibition. It was crowded on a Friday night around 10 so we only had a drink a piece before we got to moving again. The old fashioned I had was expertly made and was fantastic. Even with the crowd the bar was easily accessible and the drinks were made quickly even though they were craft cocktails. Bramhall is definitely worth checking out if you're in Portland.

name: bramhall
review_text: Bopped in for a quick bevy to start our evening and it was terrific. Well constructed cocktails, tasty bar snacks, attentive service and a cool subterranean space--what's not to like?

name: bramhall
review_text:
Yet another 5-star venue in this foodie / bar-ie town! Enter (another) basement venue... hang your coat and join in the buzz of a brick basement with little nooks and crannies and coves with yet more brick and arches with candles and benches and chairs. 

I didn't like the menu one bit, as it was highly whiskey-oriented, but the bar tender was immensely patient with me in devising options based on what I liked (but he didn't quite know how to make) and what he knew how to make. In no way did I feel like I was holding him up from someone else waiting to order a drink, which was awesome given I'm that person who loses a great parking spot because of the fear of holding up traffic to parallel park. Instead, he saw it more as a challenge to solve a problem and please a customer. 

Better yet, the dude at the door checking ID noticed we were hanging out without chairs and grabbed us the moment a table opened up. What service!! 

And, better yet... the server in the back of the bar was just as awesome as the bartender! He took the time to chat, to challenge, to educate and worked with the bartender to create my menu for the rest of that night. I have no idea what I drank--they likely weren't really drinks out of a book (aside from my chocolate martini), but they all tasted good and were priced very fairly (same as an uncustomized drink). And, although at one point the bricks were spinning a little, the server kept us hydrated with water on the side, so we left with a thoroughly great night in the back of our minds. 

Bottom line: I rarely give 5 stars, and this place deserves it hands down.

name: bramhall
review_text: Such a lovely spot to hang out! Space is flexible to accommodate 2 to 10 people comfortable. Noise level is perfect for conversing, place is lit up with candles hence a soft light. I had the cheese and ham plates here and they were always good. My friends come here every week and they never get tired of it. Friday night can be crowded but it gets thin out around 10:30pm.

name: bramhall
review_text:
This is one of my go to bar's for food and drink!  Always great atmosphere and good beer on tap always.  Oh and the food is good too!  I miss the old style burger but the new one does taste good... just not as good.  I now just order other things on the menu where before I use to only ever want the burger!

The service can be a bit slow, even when not super busy, but the drinks aren't usually slow ha ha

name: bramhall
review_text: Bramhall is great! The atmopshere mixed with my father in laws memories of the old days made this one great dinner.  The drinks are strong and the food was right!  I certainly would recommend this place to anyone looking for a great low key meal in Portland. The prices were reasonable and the waitress was dry but quick.

name: bramhall
review_text:
This place is a really cool spot. You enter through basement like doors to go downstairs in what seems like a dark dungeon. Okay, I'm sold on that idea. The bar is a whole is awesome, covered with bricks and stones, with dim lights and candles on every table. There is a great centerpiece in the middle with candles and wax dripping about. I was really digging the vibe in here- it could be a perfect place to hang with friends or an excellent place for a date. The first time I came here the Jerks of Grass were playing, who were great, and as far as I know they play here on Thursdays still? Only thing that I wasn't too fond of were the chairs- little barstools for the tables that were not too comfortable, but I got over it.

So originally, like many places, we just came here for a drink, but natural had to order food as well. They have really good drinks here and the prices are fair too. There are good craft beers on tap and domestics in bottle. They also have Downeast Cider in a can, which I love, and don't see a lot of places.

We were just snacking so didn't get much but they have a decent sized menu, for a place I thought was just a bar with "light snacks". There are sandwiches, appetizers, salads, and desserts. I got the wedge salad, hold the bacon, and it was a lot better than I expected it would be. Not that I thought it would be bad, it was just really good. It was huge, came with a red wine vinaigrette, blue cheese, tomatoes, and garlic breadcrumbs. Yum yum yum. My friend got loaded crisps, which were also so delicious. I don't eat bacon but I picked around because  they looked awesome, and they were. The base tasted like bbq lays chips but I do believe the menu said "house seasoned crisps". I don't care what they were, they were good. They were coated with cheese wiz, smoked bacon, sour cream, and I think scallions. We all inhaled them after saying we weren't going to eat much. My other friends got these bacon infused rice krispie treat things covered in a peanut sauce. They were on special and a few people were intrigued over these. I didn't try them because they certainly did not appeal to me. Other friends were not fans though, and they were happy they were cheap and on sale.

All in all,  good food for the snacks we tried, great drinks, and one of my favorite bar atmospheres I have been in. Will absolutely always return to Bramhall when I am home visiting.

name: bramhall
review_text: Probably my favorite bar and restaurant in Portland. It is cozy, romantic, and a little spooky. They have a fantastic menu, large drink selection, great service and ambiance. I enjoy their daily happy hour and trivia on Sunday nights!

name: bramhall
review_text: Best bar in Portland for local beer with clean lines. Cool dungeon feel with stone walls throughout and knowledgable bartenders.

name: bramhall
review_text: Stopped in here almost by accident, if you're not looking for the entrance it's easy to miss.  Apparently this space used to be a speakeasy during the prohibition.  Very cool brick basement candle lit atmosphere.  Decent liquor selection, we didn't look at the food menu. My husband and I sat at a quiet candle lit table and he had 3 craft beers and I had 2 canned hard ciders.  The bill was less than $30 for all 5 drinks.  This spot was walking distance from our hotel (the Inn at St. John) and while not a fantastic area, it certainly wasn't sketchy or unsafe. Our server was friendly and attentive without being overbearing. If I had to complain about anything I'd say the music was a little bit too loud. Would definitely be back again.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Do you like drinking beer and fancy cocktails? Do you like dungeons? Do you like drinking beer and fancy cocktails IN a dungeon? (I know, who doesn't, right?) If your answer is 'yes' to at least two of the three questions, then this is the place for you.

If you use Google maps to find Bramhall like I did, trust that your iPhone has not accidentally lead you to the gates of hell like I initially suspected; the entrance is a nondescript and completely unmarked stairway leading down into an underground abyss. Perfect for those who like speakeasies, but a nightmare for those who have a low tolerance for ambiguity.

Bramhall is a much warmer and cozier lair than one might think for a basement space made almost entirely of brick - especially on a cold February evening that delves into the single digits.  A group of us came for happy hour on a Friday night. It was really the perfect, laid back vibe we were looking for.  Nooks and crannies hide tables throughout, providing a space for quiet, candlelit conversations over a pint. Pro tip: Don't come soaked in kerosene or apply an excessive amount of hairspray, because there are seriously a lot of candles everywhere.

Happy hour is decent - discounted beers ($3 or $4?) and food menu. They make homemade crisps (chips), either plain or smothered like nachos.  We also tried a hummus plate - both great value for $4. Service was OK - nothing special but not bad either.  I wasn't a great fan of their beer menu on that particular night, but they had the local staples like Substance. The taps'll rotate, so I'm sure it'll be different when you check it out!  Next time, I'll be taking a longer look at their food menu.

name: bramhall
review_text:
I went to Bramhall for two reasons:

First: I frequented the former Bramhall, as a neighborhood bar, to play (and lose) at darts and pool, and was intrigued as to how they renovated the space and the menu.

Second: Jeff is a bartender here. He was fantastic at Novare Res, and I happily follow my favorite beverage schleppers wherever they may be out of personal comfort. If he is your bartender and is for some reason not the friendliest and most accommodating person that I've always seen him to be, either someone has just been a serious ass and he's shaking it off, or, you're probably an ass yourself. 

I have not been disappointed with the changes. I've seen and heard the terms speakeasy-esque, dungeon-y and such associated with the new Bramhall and I'm inclined to agree, in the BEST way possible. The new owners really cleaned up, but it IS in a below street level spot with brick and stonework exposed, so it is going to have that appearance to a point, especially when the candles are lit. While my twenty-something self is a little nostalgic for the slightly more grubby pub it was, the vibe is still fantastic, and my thirty (cough) plus self enjoys the new look. 

During one of my last visits I was feeling indecisive and the bartender, whose name I can't recall, (sorry), made a drink off the menu for me that I chose at random, but then still wasn't quite what I was looking for once I sipped it. While the name is eluding me, it had tequila, ginger beer, pink grapefruit juice...and something else. I asked if he had anything with some heat that could be added and he promptly went to get what he said was a bit of ghost pepper from the kitchen. This was exactly what it needed. SO accommodating! 

Bramhall is still a neighborhood bar, which I appreciate as a West Ender. Come here to meet, for the most part, other locals, and maybe a few adventurous tourists, although this is less likely due to location, drink some craft cocktails, have a few snacks. It's the right kind of cozy that  encourages you to engage with people as you're ponying up too the bar or looking for a table. I've had some great conversations with new people because we bumped into each other while ordering a drink or looking for a seat. Are you going to have to squint a bit, and perhaps pull your cellphone out to see the menu more clearly, likely. If that's your biggest complaint, you should get over it.

name: bramhall
review_text: Decent drinks, but certainly lacking compared to bars close by at similar price points. Food very unimpressive. Will keep walking next time.

name: bramhall
review_text: Cocktails are so original and carefully devised! Had 2 great cocktails... Mad Monk and Souless Simba (an orangey angry potion with rye and bitters) Loved them both!

name: bramhall
review_text: Maybe it's just a coincidence instead of my prediction about Bramhall coming true - in any case, I've been here many times since writing my initial review and I've grown to love it! The service is consistently friendly and prompt, and the cocktails continue to impress. They usually have Maine Beer Co. Peeper on the menu - a plus for when I'm in the mood for some liquid gluteny goodness. I haven't eaten a meal at Bramhall - just some snacks with drinks - but the food has been solid. The reason I keep coming back and bringing friends from out of town is really the atmosphere - the brick and stone, low lighting and tons of candles, and general rustic vibe make me very, very happy. Happy to have Bramhall in my life...

name: bramhall
review_text: Went here last night with my gf, This place is really great. The ambiance is top notch beautiful exposed brick with candles lit every where you look. The service was great out waiter was very attentive, and the food was light and delicious we had the mezze plate, caesar salad and cheese plate all were really great. I will definitely be coming back. The drinks were really nice too. We both had a nurse have mercy, you could taste the strong taste of the rum and the grapefruit juice complimented it so well and the sprig of rosemary added a wonderful aroma to the cocktail.

name: bramhall
review_text: Everything I look for in a bar! Dark, with plenty of cozy nooks to relax with a drink and my sweetie. Oh and the food, the delicious  food! Their small bar menu really is spot on. Having been several, times (my original review was listed under the old Bramble by mistake) I have had a chance to try a lot of the menu, loaded crisps, eggroll, burger, and Porky's Revenge. I loved them all, but particularly loved the burger with its perfect sous vide preparation and bacon incorporated right in the grind. Combined with the low prices, this place checks every box needed to make it an everyday  stop for those that live in  neighborhood.

name: bramhall
review_text: Located in the West End neighborhood, Bramhall is unassuming from the outside and beautiful on the inside.  With exposed stone and candles burning everywhere, it gives off an intimate and possibly romantic vibe.  The cocktails are well prepared and really tasty.  The only reason for the lack of a star is the extreme volume of the live music on my visit.  We met up with some old friends to catch up, and unfortunately the couldn't begin to hold a conversation even while seated at the other side of the building.  When you're underground and surrounded by stone, the electric guitar amp doesn't need to be on 11.  I must also mention that the music was really good and I still enjoyed it.

name: bramhall
review_text:
The days of the Old Bramhall Pub are back... Only cleaner. It "cleaned up nice". 
The place is a bit of a maze being a basement bar and all, but I like that it seems more open now than it used to be. The bar is nice and long and there are comfy nooks with tables, wooden cozy chairs and tables.  If you aren't using the whole table.. Offer to share it with others. 
Then menu is short and succinct and perfect. We shared jerk chicken wings, hot, but they were not killer spicy and had a nice crunch to the skin. We also shared a plate of crisps. All 3 of us are still talking about the crips. Perfectly thinly sliced, fried crisp and seasoned so perfectly to not be greasy nor salty while being "moist". How do they do it????  One companion had the burger, I had the Porky's revenge and another had the garden grazer(?) that had roasted veggies, pita and hummus. We were all extremely happy with our choices, including the beer selection and Old Fashions. Also... Our bill only came to $70 for all of us. Nice!
The bathrooms are single units (yikes on busy nights!). and have pedal faucets for hand washing, pretty neat. 
For a soft opening, the secret is out. The sign isn't even on and the place is full... the best part... We all seemed like locals. It's clear that Portland wanted this little basement bar back and we are glad that they are.  Bring on the Bluegrass and whiskey!

name: bramhall
review_text: Stone walls for last calls. The mortar oozes ambiance while the common man struggles to make it to nirvana. Drunk nirvana. A self awareness only when beer flows freely while liquor waits by the wayside. Liquor, the good times asshole waiting to ruin your night, your week, harnessing the power to turn water into vodka, good into bad, evil into righteousness, beautiful into ugly, decrepit into Marilyn, while we're all getting stoned on the magic school bus to self awareness. Who are we? We are ourselves, living, breathing, eating, drinking, at Bramhall. 5 stars

name: bramhall
review_text: The food here was creative and delicious, with a good drink selection.  Interesting/cool atmosphere, and very good service.  The little stools though, not my favorite.

name: bramhall
review_text:
Bars are great but SECRET bars are better. 
To find this place you have to know about or someone has to bring you. So speak-easy-esque and wonderful. The selection here is insanity and the atmosphere is even better. Every single alcohol selection you could dream of. I got the salad special of the night with a nurses cocktail and I've thought about those beets ever since.

name: bramhall
review_text:
I have fond memories of good friends and so many great nights of live bluegrass! The new place has some tasty food. 

Hope the little bearded man behind the bar learns some manners.

name: bramhall
review_text: The drinks were ok, I have had a lot better in Rhode Island and Boston for about the same price or cheapr. Got something with the word Witches in it and the Night Ryeder. However they had an assortment of complete games which was great, and they weren't super crowded, we got spots right away on a Friday night.

name: bramhall
review_text: Something about this place. ... both bartenders were just beyond gorgeous.  Brittany... o.m.g.  and the service was beyond amazing .

name: bramhall
review_text: Being from NJ it was a blessing to find this place because its one of the few places in Portland that is actually open past midnight! The atmosphere is obviously speakeasy and the bartenders are very friendly make fantastic cocktails!

name: bramhall
review_text: Service is great pork sandwich was amazing. Bouncer couldn't have ruined this experience anymore. To addition of taking up three spots at the bar, including the bar stool for himself. He rolled his eyes and shook his head numerous times as if we were in his bubble. Guy needs to go ruining the mojo. He gets no stars.

name: bramhall
review_text: This speakeasy feels like a dungeon. But a very seductive one. Everything we tried including two appetizers and three drinks were ace. We would enter this cave every time we visit Portland.

name: bramhall
review_text: Awesome speakeasy tribute! The atmosphere is perfect, great knowledgeable employees, and their menu is spot on. Plus their whiskey selection is to die for. Can't wait to go back the next time I'm in the area!

name: bramhall
review_text: Not a standout in any area, but a great all-around spot.  Originally went in for just a drink, but wound up getting an app and burger as well.  Food was good and prices were fair.  I love the extended happy hour for Maine Med employees - just bring your badge.  Ambiance and seating options make it perfect for a date or a group, dinner or just drinks, and happy hour or a late night spot.

name: bramhall
review_text: It makes me so happy that this bar is the closest bar to my house. It's in my top 3 favorite bars in Portland. My husband and our friends come in every Thursday.

name: bramhall
review_text: Nice space, ok food, good service, absolutely ridiculous seating. The stools are so small you may want to bring your own thimble to sit on so you can spread out a bit more than their seats will allow. May go back and sit at the bar for a drink but this is mostly a place to come with your friends and get drunk.

name: bramhall
review_text: I absolutely love coming here for a straight whiskey or whiskey based cocktail. The bartenders know how to do it the right way and are very friendly and knowledgeable. It's one of the few places around that I've found where it's a smooth atmosphere for a few casuals with friends and enjoy a nice cheese plate.

name: bramhall
review_text: An unusual affinity for cleverly repurposing washroom fixtures seems well suited to the reclaimed cellar space where Bramhall now resides. From the Victorian bathtub cooler to  the foot pumps that power their faucets, Bramhall has caught us by surprise. Bright cocktails, fresh draughts, and thoughtful plates are characteristic of any visit. If you find yourself pondering the curious architectural details of Bramhall, just ask for Jeff and he will proudly convey the history. We can't get enough of the way this place plays with the contrast of authentic decorum and cozy comfort. Don't be alarmed by the sensation that you are wandering into the basement of a Congress Street basement. You are. Trust us, it's worth it.

name: bramhall
review_text: Can we agree the seating is UNCOMFORTABLE!?  Otherwise, Bramhall has great food at a great value, strong craft cocktails, and very friendly service!  The atmosphere is so chill and laid back and relaxing...  except those horrible little metal stools to sit on!  We love the place but chose to leave over getting a 3rd round.  Our hamstrings & back thanked us!

name: bramhall
review_text:
The dark, low-key atomsphere was relaxing (I had driven 5 hours from CT for the Spoons show at the State). The food was surprisingly great for pub food. Had to try the Rice Krispie Bacon Treat app because it seemed like a joke. Trust me, they are NOT a joke. They could be an appetizer or a dessert and Peanut Satay dipping sauce really puts this over the top. 
I had the Tuna Melt which came with seasoned homemade kettle chips. Tuna Melt was served open face and was seasoned with tarragon and topped with dressed arugala. Super tasty and light on the mayo. Best tuna melt I've ever had. The chips were so well seasoned that I had to ask the waitress what the recipe was (she swears it's a little bit of everything, but I could taste Garam Masala above everything else?) 
I'm not a drinker, so I don't have anything to say about the beers or liquor, but my buddy Dave loves Bramhall because they serve Oxbow Farmhouse Pale Ale. We had a knowledgable, attentive waitress who didn't hover. 
Inventive menu + flavorful foodie food + good service - pretentious pricing = Bramhall
Me so happy I forgot to take photo of food for Facebook.

name: bramhall
review_text:
This place is okay, but like the rest of Portland, it was better in its previous incarnation, when it it was cheaper and not as pretty.

Only thing going for the newer version is that after a while the old place refused to let me in.

name: bramhall
review_text: Went for happy hour, think it was $5 for a Pilsner- not the biggest selection. And $5 house wine. I stuck with wine. They had some apps too on special- a Thai savory Rice Krispie, and frito pie, didn't care for either, but I'm biased and typically eat really good Thai and have had NM frito pie. The atmosphere is really cool too, seems like there working on some good cocktails also.

name: liquid-riot-bottling-co
review_text:
This review is based solely on atmosphere & service. 

Liquid Riot was one of a few stops for a bachelorette party before going somewhere for lunch. Our party of 12 was able to sit at 2 high tables near each other so we could still talk to one another relatively easily. Some of us ordered some light appetizers in the meantime or a flight of beer for $16.99. I just went with a stout that looked interesting & it was good (Sweet Dreams 11%). 

The atmosphere is really fun! It is a place to hang out at for a while. I did see that they had a lot of merchandise available for purchase. We didn't stay long enough to fully get the full experience but I find that it is an awesome place to go.

Service was somewhat slow (though it wasn't super busy from what we gathered) & our waitress seemed annoyed with us when we had requested separate checks (she didn't even ask how we wanted to divide them when we ordered) but you would think a group that large would want it separated. Of course, we didn't point that out in the beginning, either so both are at fault. 

I LOVE THEIR LOGO!

name: liquid-riot-bottling-co
review_text:
- this place looks so cool on the inside. You can see the beer-making equipment.
- the t-shirts are cool and cheap.
- funny staff.
- beachy area.
- lots of parking nearby.
- cheap drinks for what it is.
- beer tastes very strong and thick. Good for getting drunk.

name: liquid-riot-bottling-co
review_text:
Went here twice during our stay from out of state.

Our experience on Wednesday night was a calm atmosphere. Excellent beer selection. Really enjoyed the NSFW Quadruple IPA.

Staff was friendly.

Went back on Saturday night, totally packed to the gills! Way louder, at times harder to hear our conversation. 

25¢ Pinball was a lot of fun.

name: liquid-riot-bottling-co
review_text: Slightly beer'd out at this point in our Maine travels, we stopped here to pass some time. Their menu was big, although we didn't have time for food. We opted to try the kombucha which is made not in house, but just down the road. It was spectacular, refreshing, and hit the spot. The atmosphere of this place is also great; sit out on the patio with a view of the water if the weather is nice!

name: liquid-riot-bottling-co
review_text:
I can't believe how long it's taken us to walk into this place. I'm not a beer girl but I do enjoy Liquid Riot and it's become one of my husband's favorites. 

Don't go in a hurry. They were busy when we arrived around 12:45pm on a Sunday afternoon and we had a short 20 minute wait. Talking with some of the other diners, we learned that there is typically a wait at the door when they open.
