Was pricey for the neighborhood but worth it.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Been three times for dinner and each one excellent service and food and now they have outdoor tables, yay! And a unique noon-8pm Sunday brunch starting soon.  OK picnic tables are on the busy chaos corner of Woodford but it affords some varied people watching. Love the fried brussel, the beet walnut salad, the cocktails and specials. The latest I had was a hake in mustard, fennel, creme fraisch sauce most perfectly cooked and savory. A dry riesling paired well. Very neighborhood feel, spartan but warm. Tons of parking just past at the Club if you drive.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Great cuisine, service and vibe. Out party had kale salads, a pork chop, roast chicken, and a burger that rivals the East Ender's as my favorite in town.  The staff was great, and genuinely happy we were there. Worth the short drive from downtown.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Unexpectedly excellent food at Woodfords Corner. Food was fresh and well prepared.  Service was attentive and prompt but not overbearing.  Nice variety on menu, something for everyone.  Delicious!

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: We were happy when we learned this restaurant was being added to our neighborhood. After eating there we were thrilled! Food (especially burger), cocktails (some prohibition era drinks) and service were excellent. Parking can be a bit tricky, but the Woodford club is just up the street (like 300 yards) and you can generally park there. Don't miss out on this gem!

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: The place throws me off a little.  It was decorated like an upscale diner or cafe. Has one of the best changing tables for the babies.  Large booth for seating.  The place was marked with $$$, but the selections were limited as we came at 3, in between the change of menus.  Cocktail Shrimp were large and fresh, slightly raw but that's what the lemon was for.  Devil eggs are a must, the York were soft like the ice cream cone, it was just perfectly put together.  Mussels was great, just the right amount of garlic.  My burger was definitely quality over quantity, smaller than what I'd expect from a $18 burger, small buns, thick patty, grilled onions, pickles, bacon, cooked exactly as I ordered medium well.  Fries were some of the best as well. Oh yea, staffs were super friendly, I find this is to be the case everywhere here in Portland.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
Just meh all around. Too pricey for what you're getting- service included. I asked our server about the Tri-tip steak, her response was "It's just a different cut of steak". For $22, I would have liked a little more information. My boyfriend ordered a beer that never came, to which the server did apologize, but we were one of three tables on a weekend evening at 730...

That being said, the food was good. We will probably try again if we're desperate to get off the peninsula.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
My boyfriend and I tried Woodford F&B for the first time Friday night.  It was a solid experience from the time we walked in until we left.  The restaurant was full when we arrived, but we waited just a few minutes before being seated.

The service was on point, our waitress was attentive, knew the specials, and was able to answer our questions about the menu items. Additionally, other waitstaff stopped at our table a couple of times to ask if we needed anything. As a matter of fact, all of the Woodford staff were extremely hospitable and gracious.

The Food:

We had the deep-fried brussel sprouts as an appetizer, the leaves having mostly separated from the heads, arrived with the texture of the charred pages of a novel.  While they retained a pleasant flavor and the accompanying sauce was complimentary, the airy consistency made for an awkward dance on the palate. Both Tiqa and Boda excel in their preparation of this trendy micro- cabbage, Woodford should take note.  I should mention that the portion is sizable, and despite the awkward dance, we finished them.

I had the whole grain risotto, it was the best I have ever tasted.  It was full of grains, wheat berries, farro etc., and mascarpone, it was as moist and creamy as anything I have ever put in my mouth.  Cooked to perfection.

He had the braised lamb shank special.  It was meaty and delicious, and it took everything he had to not pick up the bone to gnaw at the remaining juicy slivers of stringy sinew.  

We also shared a crusty apple crisp-ish dessert with ice cream.  It, too, was delicious.  The dessert to ice cream ratio was spot on, and, again, the overall portion size was, well, it was HUGE, and that's not something I say often.

We liked the atmosphere, the floor to ceiling ceramic tile, the diner tables, and the not quite finished floor...totally felt like a neighborhood joint, no pretension, just great food at reasonable prices.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Enjoyed a visit to this iconic location, a Valles restaurant in my youth. They have done an excellent job with the restoration. While a bit pricy the food was excellent and the service very attentive. It is worth checking out if in the area.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
The service is impeccable, the food is so good (comfort food and some great fresh seafood options) and its walking distance from Baxter Woods. Having tried a few places in our new neighborhood this is a clear standout. I'm a picky drink orderer and my Hendricks Gimlet up with simple syrup came AS ORDERED and that says A LOT about a bar for me. HIGHLY RECOMMEND a stop in for dinner here. Tell Canaan Jen and Chris sent you.!


UPDATE:
We held our post wedding brunch at Woodford F&B this week. Their first dip into private events and they pulled out all the stops for us! My picky eaters LOVED all their food! Thank you Fayth!!

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: From a decor perspective, it's a very modern and clean lined rendition of a semi - classic diner.  Creative cocktail menu, curated beer and wine selection, and daily drink specials.  The menu is creative, but I wish there were a few more dishes.  The weekly specials looked great, but only salmon was available the day I came; not my favorite.  I would have loved to try the skate wing (or any other day's special), but to no avail.  Maybe next time.  Also, every dish seems to have an "aioli."  Perhaps the chef needs to scrap that idea, and focus on creating lighter, more modern sauce versions (just a suggestion).  Brussels sprouts as a starter were incredible, with a crisp smoky flavor we loved.  Cheese selection (of one) was tasty, but it was only one cheese; would prefer three smaller portions instead of just one.  For Main courses, we had the salmon special (simply prepared, for my son), the steak frites, and the pork chop.  Salmon was undercooked; I'm not a fan of the "rare" salmon.  Should be cooked fully or almost fully.  Not to our liking.  Pork Chop was the table hit; thick, juicy and spiced just right.  Steak frites was also above average; medium rare sliced steak over a horseradish cream.  Fries were crispy and tasty.  Service was professional if a bit too stiff.  Overall, three stars for a "good," if not great, dining experience.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
Way over priced for the quality. The half chicken was two small pieces and the sauce was forgettable. Sadly the waitress,while very attentive, had no idea what wine went with any dish. She also didn't know what liquors are offered at the bar. The "chef's taste" was onions with broccoli and cauliflower. That's a side dish, not a sample of the chefs talents.
I'll wait for the next owner before going back. The space is very nice, but they come off as a bunch of kids on trust funds that think they can throw anything on a place and charge $25.00 for it.
I will say that the two stars are for the dessert. That was delicious.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
The fries.  Wow.  Great fries. 

They start with the pre-coated,  frozen variety, which tend to crisp up better than fresh cut, twice- cooked, raw potato version. And it is that crispness, plus their proprietary seasoning,  and the perfect  aioli that make these the tastiest fries I've ever eaten - period. The fries alone make this place worth a visit. 

The rest of the menu is an eclectic mix of classic bistro fare and comfort food with a few American staples mixed in. The entree menu is abbreviated (2 beef, 1 pork, 1 fish, 1 chicken, 1 veggie entree).  A broader selection of appetizers, some salads, and a burger round out the menu, with a list of daily specials adding diversity. There is an adventurous cocktail, wine and craft beer menu with something for all palates, and a kids menu too - often a plus for us. 

The building is a converted space, a former Valle's steakhouse. And while the tables and settings were neat and clean, the hard floor to ceiling surfaces made for somewhat noisy environs.  The plain walls and decor lacked visual interest, offset by a few retro architectural details like the pitched bead-board ceiling.  Hand written signs on office paper taped to doors & windows are an eyesore, belying quality elsewhere.   An interior designer could easily spruce up some of these defects pretty easily. 

Service was friendly, knowledgeable, prompt and attentive, but uneven at times. No major flaws, just a bit choppy in communication and execution. 

The oysters, pate, mussels w frites were mostly well executed -  the baguette was overly tough, and the meunière a bit too garlicky and needing a tad more butter and a green herb. The mussels were just slightly past done, making them a little chewy, and the pate improved as it warmed to room temp. 

But the fries.  Oh the fries.   Go for the fries.   We'll be back to test this place out few times before giving a final verdict.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
I wish I had 5 more stars to give this place. I drive by here at least 4 times a week. I've been saying since I moved here 4 months ago 'I really wanna try that place, it looks cool.' I've followed them on instagram and have drooled over the pictures. WTF took me so long?! Well NYE I finally gave this place a go. Holy shit guys. This place is NOT playing around. From the atmosphere to the music and the lighting you automatically feel like ' hey, this is a cool place.' Doesn't feel too 'hipster' nor too 'expensive' . It kinda encompasses the laid back and cool style of Portland. The service is OUT OF THIS WORLD. You can always tell something about a business and the owner by the attitude of the staff. Everyone was super fucking nice and chill. Our waitress was fantastic. I wish I remembered her name but seriously this woman was awesome! We ordered the Oysters from Damariscotta . If eating oysters was like having sex then I definitely orgasmed like 4 times. So fresh and so tasty! My Boo got the Tennessee ham. He is from Tennessee and it made me happy when he said ' this reminds me of what my papaw used to cook'. It was beyond cool that the dish took him back in time. But that's how awesome this place is. Our waitress told us that the owner is a freak about researching ham and is determined the find the best. This kinda passion definitely shines through in the restaurant. 
For the main dish I got the Casio Bay Flounder and OMG. I can confidently say it was the BEST dish I have ever had. So perfectly cooked and put together. Every single bit was melting in my mouth. I was in disbelief each time I took a bite. My Boo got the steak and fries and he was thoroughly enjoying the meal as well, however he wanted mine more once he got a bite. 
I can't say enough good things about this place. It's awesome. I love that it's not downtown too. Its like a little gem outside the city. 
Can't wait to see what else this restaurant has to off this year. If you are looking for an amazing dinner with fantastic service, great vibes, and cool music.........GO!

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: One of the best meals I've had during a two week long training stint in Portland. Birch, the owner personally waited on us and was excellent at communicating the menu, ingredients and vision of the place. A welcome break from waterfront lobster rolls! Everything was excellent from the unique craft  beer selections to the dessert! Will definitely venture here again when in Portland again.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
I hesitated to try this cool new neighborhood restaurant too soon for fear of not having time to work out the kinks but that was no problem here! These people are pros! They know what they are doing and I loved it here! The food was delicious! I had a burger and it was perfect! The servers were great! No attitudes here even my friend unconsciously made a comment about the bartenders height, (he was very tall!) he was gracious as can be and I was grateful he did not seem offended. I hope to spend lots of time here as it was fun to run into so may of my neighbors. Definitely upscale.


I've been here many many times. My only complaint is I wish the bar was friendlier. They are pretty hard to warm up to. It makes a difference to me as I wait on people all day long too. At the end of the day I wanna sidle up at a bar and be met with a friendly face, not a dry can't be bothered type. Stay focused on kindness guys, it matters.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: I went here with two of my family, and overall it was a good experience. I'd personally give the food a 3/5, based on what we ordered, which was the Burger, Croque Madame (w/o the egg), and mussels. I had the mussels. The Burger (which is the menu name) was AMAZING - soft, juicy, and flavorful. However, it was a grease trap and sent oil running down my brother's hands when he ate it. The Croque Madame has excellent sauce and garnishing, and the cheesy topping was delicious. The meat, a slice of ham, wasn't as impressive, but overall decent meal. Lastly, I would not recommend the mussels. They were worse than the ones you can buy at the store and boil for half the price. I'd say they were severely underseasoned. But the ambience and the service make up for the food. Our waitress was warm and accommodating. They even included a pretty postcard of the restaurant at the end of the meal. Go here for a nice time with your people but possibly not for the dining.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Drinks were great! Very well balanced cocktails which is a simple task but hard to achieve! Nice atmosphere and a great area. I think it used to be a mortgage loan place converted into a restaurant. Woodford FB, Tipo, BigSky, Bayou kitchen and the many ethnic restaurants around this area has been a great addition to the back cove neighborhood. Didn't try the food so can't comment on that but it smelled great!

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Finally checked this place out last night. We loved it. Great new addition to the neighborhood. Caramelized onion dip was amazing. Great vibe.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: WF&B is my favorite place to meet a friend for a drink and our go-to spot for date night dinner. The staff is THE BEST! Warm, friendly, relaxed, attentive without being intrusive. The cocktails offerings are updated seasonally (with frequent specials/experiments) as is the menu. We've sampled most of the dinner offerings over time and we have not been disappointed. Looking forward to trying brunch soon. Bonus points: this place is super family-friendly. I don't just mean they have a good kids menu. I mean that they are genuinely pleased to have families in the dining room with everyone else, and they have appropriate expectations about kid behavior.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: The food was good although a little overpriced.  My biggest complaint would be  that every time I saw a waitress she was either picking at her teeth or licking her fingers.  Hands in mouth or hovering over people's plates is no beuno in the food industry.  One actually wiped sauce off the rim of the plate and kicked her finger. Gross. I kept a close eye when mine came out.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: I've been here at least ten times.  Step aside NOSH, there is a new Sheriff (Burger) in town.  The lamb and Beef burger here is amazing every time, with thick cut bacon and perfectly cooked temps.  I dream about it.  The fries are light and crispy too.  Bartenders Todd and Claire are amazing, and Owner Burch and his wife will be present to make sure your experience is excellent.  You will not find the prices low, but you will get value for your dollar and delicious food.  The Chef is top notch.  Great view of the busy wood fords traffic coming back and forth as well...this gem is a must try.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: A delightful Bistro in an unlikely location. Portland's culinary scene is extending out of the Old Port and into neighborhoods that have previously lacked exciting dining options. Woodford F & B has a chef who spent time at Fore Street and teams her expertise with other experienced players, to create Woodford F&B. The funky building was once a dry cleaner and the big windows and high ceilings make for a happy physical location. The food is Bistro fare with steak frites, mussels, pate, oysters, lovely salads and some delightful seafood and daily specials. Desserts are simple and tasty and the wine list well priced and interesting. We had outstanding service and were thrilled to have our party of 8 so well accommodated on busy Memorial Day weekend. Get yourself to Woodford before the line to get in extends around the block, this neighborhood gem won't be unknown for long.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: It is very rare that Yelps steers me wrong, but I simply don't understand the high ratings for this place. We visited recently on our vacation and were completely underwhelmed. It sort of looks like a converted old 50s/60s diner, which could be really cool if executed correctly -- but mostly it seemed grungy and run-down. But it's always all about the food, right? Well, nothing special here. I tried the onion dip folks raved about -- VERY heavy on the mayo, and it was cold. Also had a salad with asparagus - the most paltry looking asparagus ever. Wilted, rubbery. Salad over dressed and tasted largely of pure vinegar. My partner orderer the chowder, and as a former chef - very unimpressed. Thin broth, virtually void of seasoning, only a couple pieces of seafood. And all this for an over $100 price tag? I just can't recommend it. The only reason it gets two stars is that the service was good, and they were especially nice to my kid.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: I never leave Yelp reviews, but after my dinner tonight I feel compelled. To start with, these guys have some of the best cocktails in town hands down. I arrived close to closing time, but the bartender (Miranda) was very friendly and talkative. I ordered the pork chop, but unfortunately there seemed to be a communication breakdown in the kitchen and it took over 20 minutes for them to prepare it even though there was hardly anybody else in the restaurant. A man who I later realized was either the manager or the owner brought my meal to me and apologized for the wait, but when I cut into it I could see that it was not cooked all the way through. Miranda took it away without a second question and apologized, saying she would comp my drink. At that point I ordered a second cocktail  and tried to be patient, but the second try took the kitchen almost 15 minutes, so at that point I was getting pretty impatient and probably visibly irritated. Again, the owner/manager dude brought my plate out and apologized wholeheartedly. As I ate my meal I couldn't deny that it was delicious, and when I finally asked for the check Miranda had taken about $30 off my bill. I was blown away, and instantly the frustration from the long wait disappeared. To make it even better, the owner/manager dude then came over with a bottle of Fernet and we took shots together. I have worked many years in the restaurant industry and I can't remember a time when a manager has shown such a genuine interest in making up for a kitchen staff's mistake, which happens from time to time no matter how nice the restaurant might be. I really appreciate the care that they took in providing a positive experience for me, and I will definitely be back.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Tried the restaurant after reading reviews and close to home.  Cheese platter had one slab of cheese and a few nuts.  Steak was 23 - should have been a filet at that price. Fries were drowning in salt - painful. Maybe good for drinks but will definitely not be back for dinner.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
My partner and I just finished dinner out with 2 friends, and all 4 meals were delicious!!  Risotto for me, chicken, lamb, and steak for my mates.  We also had great apps, fried Brussels and deviled eggs.  Everything was truly excellent.  Portland had a high bar
 for a good meal, this place exceeded all expectations.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Just ok. We were really surprised when we got the bill and it was $100 for two of us. We did have an app and each had a drink (ok, I had two) but the food and the service were just fair to good (not great), and the atmosphere didn't do it for me. It's an odd building that has been repurposed, but I don't think they achieved the charming feel they were striving for. And I realize that this might be a positive for families with young kids, but there were A LOT of young kids in here on a Friday evening, so if that's not your thing, just beware.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: This place was amazing. I had been wanting to try it for a long time, and it was definitely worth the wait. The staff were polite and attentive. The food was delicious. I was there with a party of 5 and all of us ordered different things, there wasn't one compliant. I ordered the roasted beets and walnuts and the steak tartare, both excellent.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: First place my husband and I walked out of. Pretentious and staff was not too attentive. No idea how the food was as we left annoyed before ordering.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
YES!!!  I am so excited that a quality restaurant has come to Woodford's Corner.  This place has it all - great food, amazing community oriented vibe, awesome interior, owners that are ready and willing to put in the labor and the love to grow an awesome locals spot.... and it's hopefully the anchor for the beginning of the renewal of Woodford's Corner.  So, to elaborate on each of those topics... 
Food - I had the daily fish.  It was pollock the night I went - not always a fish I gravitate to because I feel like it's easy to overcook - no such trouble at WFB.  It was perfectly cooked on a bed of greens and wheat berries.  The deep-fried brussels sprouts were addictively crispy/savory.  Husband had the chicken... comfort food at its finest.  And a good kid's menu to boot.  Friends at a nearby table were raving about the burger and mussels and fries.  The menu features a handful of favorites, and a "plat du jour" section.  The theme seems to be a combination of rich comfort food, super well executed pub classics, and a smattering of ingenious and unexpected details.
Vibe - Well, we showed up at 5 cause that's when our kids get hungry... the place was full within 45 minutes of good-restaurant-starved Deering Center peeps.  Seriously, everyone I know in the neighborhood has been saying, for years, that we need a restaurant with great food and a great vibe to be the gathering spot.  This is it.  
Interior - Husband and I both remarked on how cool the windows and blinds were.  To be honest, blinds are not something I would normally notice, let alone comment on.  But these things somehow transformed the ridiculous Forest Ave snarl of headlights into.... mood lighting.  We also loved the diner style booth seating.
Owners - one of the owners, Birch, came by and said introduced himself.  It's clear this is a labor of love and he and his wife are in it for the long haul.  They're invested in this neighborhood and we couldn't be happier to have them.
 So, mark my words, this is more than a new restaurant... it's a spot for the neighborhood to gather at... it's the beginning of the renewal of Woodford's Corner.  But the food and vibe is good enough to draw you guys from the peninsula.  Don't worry, there's parking for you at the Woodford's Club.  But we'll be walking every time we go, which will be often.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Great atmosphere and delicious foods, super pleasant settings. Thoroughly enjoyed the experience and will definitely come back.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
This place feels like it's having an identity crisis. The furniture and lighting scream "diner" but the cloth napkins, candlelight, funky decor and sophisticated menu whisper "high end." Very confusing atmosphere to say the least. The menu had some classic staples but also a lot of what I as a low-class person can only call 'bizarre' food items. Me and my friend decide to try something new so we each order one of the appetizer specials as our meal (I can only assume they were appetizers because the portions were very small). Both were disgusting. I had what I can only describe as mushroom and eggplant bruschetta which had the consistency of rubber and was borderline unpalatable. I don't often say that food is bad or gross, I might say "okay" or "not very good," but this was seriously unpleasant to eat. My friend had some sort of tuna and avocado tartar which was essentially flavorless. On top of a disappointing meal the bill was outrageous: two beers and two small appetizers totaled $45!

Giving them two stars because it was clean and the service was good. Maybe other things on the menu could change my mind but I'm not chancing another $45 bucks to find out.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: A perfectly delightful meal.  We sat at the bar as the place was packed at 5:30 on a Saturday night. The service was prompt and personal even though it was busy.  We had the caramelized onion dip as an app.  A bit disappointing in that it was not warm and a bit on the sweet side but the excellent chips made up for these small failings. My guy had the pork shank. We loved the sauce but found the pork to lack flavor.  My steak was superb and I am a steak snob.  It was cooked to a perfect med rare and came sitting on a bed of divine horseradish sauce.  The fries were also very good. We will return.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Great food, friendly staff, a wonderful addition to the neighborhood. Nice basic dishes and the stake tartare is awesome (small is huge!)

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Outstanding! The food was wonderful! We brought friends from out of state and everyone was extremely happy with the food. Our waiter was personable and welcoming! He made great suggestions from the menu.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Such a great experience at this restaurant! The hostess, server & owner were all so friendly and welcoming! The food was great, I especially loved the deep fried Brussels sprouts - delicious! The atmosphere is really fun, great new place to try, we'll be back for sure!

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text:
Super nice staff, good branding and interior design, food is mediocre, been once won't return. Bummed cause it looks great.

Caramelized onion dip was like a can of supermarket dip with rosemary sprinkled on it, although harder to eat as the onion pieces are huge. It's cold, house chips are cold, not at all what i was hoping for.

Bib salad was overdressed in a flavorless rendition of green goddess, candied peanuts in it were tasty, but didn't incorporate well.

Crab cakes were way over seasoned, had no lump meat in them, but plenty of cartilage (I'd forgive that if there was discernible crab meat).

Burger was good tasting but way too greasy.

Fries on both orders were so overdone they were like old potato sticks. Flavorless, completely dried out husks.

For this price point there are much better options in Portland.

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: Truly love this wonderful new spot to dine in my neighborhood. I've only been there a couple of times and already wish their menu was more diverse or changed more frequently, but every element of the meal, from drink to entrée, is delicious!! Very friendly staff too!

name: woodford-f-&-b
review_text: I really wanted to like this place because it's got a great location. The waitstaff was nice and attentive. I love the way the inside was remodeled. I tried the Brussels sprouts appetizer which was fine. I was excited to try the burger because I heard it was really good. I felt uncomfortable with the $16 dollar price on the burger but threw caution to the wind. This burger sucked. It tasted like it had been doused in vinegar. Not a little vinegar but ALOT.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Blue Spoon is definitely in my top 5 for favorite portland restaurants. I always suggest this on nights out with friends, family, etc., and it is always a huge hit! Their food is SO good, and seasonally sourced. They also have fun cocktails and great wine. It's a pretty small space so I recommend making reservations or going early and snagging on of the few seats at their little (very cute) bar. In the summer they have great patio right out front as well. Definitely a special place! Great staff, great food and drinks... 5 outta 5!!

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
I used to love Blue Spoon! They had one of the best happy hours in Portland: it was called Wine Time, glasses of vino were just $2.50, and there were super delicious discounted small bites. The polenta fritters, blue cheese toast with garlicky spinach, and Turkish feta dip were some of my faves!

None of those are on the menu anymore.

And their Wine Time is now $5 for a glass.

For me, that's just not nearly as appealing as it used to be, especially considering other places in town (who essentially copied Blue Spoon's original amazing happy hour) are *still* offering $3 glasses of wine and discounted eats during HH. And there seems to have been a pretty substantial change to their menu over the years; I've been back for both brunch and lunch, and I'm not really inspired by the offerings. There's nothing I crave here anymore and the portions seem much smaller than they used to be.

I really want to love Blue Spoon - and in fact, I once did - it's an adorable spot in the East End full of charm, they have fun "patio" seating in the warmer weather that really immerses you into the Eastern Prom life (i.e. it's great people watching!), and the staff has always been so warm and accommodating. Unfortunately, with the way other Portland businesses have changed and with other new spots that have opened since I first discovered Blue Spoon, it's just not a place for me anymore.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
I'm giving it 4 because I really really wanted it to be a 4 though it's probably more like a 3.5. I understand there are new owners but I didn't notice a difference. 

My family and I went at 5:30 before a 7:00 Good Theater show across the street. We hadn't received our apps (charcuterie, Brussels sprouts, salad) by almost 6:00 so let the waitress know about the show and she was able to get it done. We had apps by 6:00 and entrees by 6:20. 

We were psyched that it was wine time with special house wine deals. The red was very good. The charcuterie was pretty with meats and (rather bland) cheese, bread and mustard and fig jam. The sprouts were supposed to be roasted but were awfully mushy. The salad "eh". The steak and trout entrees were fantastic. The fish stew broth was wonderful. I just wish there was a higher end piece of fish, maybe a scallop, along with the few pieces of white fish, shrimp and calamari. 

Service was a little slow at first but our waitperson said she had just been yelled at by a customer on the phone and was a bit frazzled. She made up for the slow start and was great. I'll go back before a show again as it's good and convenient.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Want a nicely cooked, adorable breakfast nook? Then Blue Spoon is your go-to. 

A) The sourdough toast is LIFE CHANGING!!  Omg, you know when toast is just crunchy and crispy and a little chewy and makes your weep with joy?  They have it.

B) Bacon that crunches a bit and melts on your tongue? They have it. 

C) Fluffy creamy scrambled eggs seasoned well and the perfect temperature?  Yep. Here. 

And the service? For being a small place, it is homey and casual yet refined. I would pop by on a lark or plan a brunch date with a cute guy here. 

Yes, I will return! Yes, I'm sure I'll see you there because you gotta try it!!

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Good ambiance, cute little quaint place. Had high expectations.  Went in for lunch, got seated right away. One waitress, took a bit for our drinks. Our app was good, main course was very average. I would not order those items again. Dessert was delicious, otherwise this would've been a one star rating. Wouldn't exactly recommend this place or go back.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Very cozy, chic restaurant in the East End. I had a very pleasant dinner here with some gal friends. It was a little dark for my liking, but I guess that was part of the ~vibe. I ordered their Seasonal Ragu with Homemade Pasta- nomz! It was heavy and a good option for the chilly evening. My friends ordered some tapas as well, and their Roasted Cauliflower with Dukkah stood out most!

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Overall: friendly service and good food. I'd go again but only if I wasn't in a rush due to the slower service. 
Food: went for brunch so dinner menu may be significantly different. I found their blt with rosemary mayo to be too salty but the rosemary mayo and arugula salad was a nice foil. The fish spread was delicious and my favorite was hands down the white fish spread. Would have liked more bread with that for both the spread and the salmon. The duck egg hash was good for a few bites but ended up being very rich and heavy towards the end. The Johnny cake was fun and delightful but I would ate very sweet and I prefer a little more balance to flavors.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
The Blue Spoon is another long standing Portland restaurant, that I had driven past hundreds of times and never stopped in.  I don't know, it always looked so crowded and filled with wealthy locals and tourists, and not like a place I would come to love.  I was really wrong.

After four trips this summer, I now know that Blue Spoon is a very comfortable restaurant with an excellent and friendly staff, that serves consistently delicious and interesting dishes.

The first time I visited was at lunchtime.  We started with the 3 spread app, which was wonderful.  I ordered a polenta dish for my main, which turned out to be far more delicious than I had imagined AND inspired me to add polenta dishes to our dinners at home!  Since then I have tried many things on their menu.  The mussels are delicious and they excel at fish dishes.

I also want to take a moment to give a sincere shout out to their desserts.  Often there might be only 2 or three offered, BUT they are consistently incredible!!  The flan is a standout, so much so, that you might want to ask if they have any when you begin to order and ask them to set aside one for you in advance.  I had one dinner at the Blue Spoon, where they were out of the flan by the time we ordered dessert and it took me a long time to get over it!

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Uh oh.  This restaurant, which used to be my highest rated on munjoy Hill, has just this week changed hands.  The menu that is posted here is no longer accurate, although some dishes have remained. 

The new owners have violated the first and most important rule of taking over a popular restaurant - Rule 1: do not change the menu for the first several months.  

I have to assume that this was due to the new owners being neophytes. Portland Maine is no place to learn how to run a restaurant.  Very sad.  I may try it one more time, but I doubt that this will be the local place I will refer out-of-town visitors to anymore.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: This favorite neighborhood restaurant/bar in the heart of Munjoy Hill is a relaxing venue for brunch, lunch or dinner. The moderate sized room and fabric ceiling panels allow for easy conversation, something not always available when dining out in Portland's popular restaurant scene. The meals are creative, beautifully presented, and reasonably priced. We stopped in recently for brunch after a walk along the Eastern Prom on a glorious end of summer Saturday morning. Very happy with our choices of smoked fish and grilled ciabatta, and griddled Johnnycake with maple butter.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
This was the best meal we had in Portland. Here is why:

1. Vibe. 
I'm no restaurant owner or chef but something about The Spoon and it's staff gives off this really laid back, kind vibe. We went there with our almost one year old feeling overheated and a bit overwhelmed. As soon as we sat down in there, our mood shifted. It finally felt like we were on vacation.

2. Dishes that showcase creativity, thoughtfulness, and fresh ingredients. We went to Duckfat per friends' recommendation and while the food was delicious, it was super heavy and strong (fat and salt). I felt like the ingredients were sort of masquerading in disguise because the richness of the dressing/seasoning that overwhelmed the ingredients.

The Spoon was refreshingly different. It reminded me of our time in The Bay Area. Fresh ingredients perfectly seasoned and made slightly rich by a thoughtful, not excessive amount of fat. You get to really enjoy the true flavors of the produce and the creative combinations of the chef. As I told my partner-if I lived here, I'd come here every week.

3. The drinks we're fantastic. Spicy ginger beer. Perfectly balanced Sazerac. What more could tired parents ask for.

4. A great place for kids. We're not ones to expect folks to bend over backwards for our one year old. However kids are extremely inconvenient and I really appreciate it when people are helpful and kind. Our waiter gave us a tea kettle for a warm bottle. They gave us a place to put our stroller. They put things on the table so our kid couldn't reach it and make a total mess. These small things really make a difference to parents. Thank you The Spoon.

Will be recommending The Spoon hard core to all our friends and family.

Love,
Loe, Peter, and Mischa

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Such a cozy, casual place to grab a Saturday brunch or early evening drinks and appetizers. I live in Woodford's and trek all the way across town for the friendly service and beautiful food. It's small so time your arrival properly to ensure you get a table. Lots of great local produce, one of the only places in town that cooks bacon properly and clearly they're doing something right with their employees because it's the same people every time we come. 

The eggs nest off the brunch menu with scrambled eggs nestled into sautéed greens and fresh ricotta, topped with some kind of yummy, fermented hot sauce is delightful. Also, a big fan of the farmers greens, roasted beets topped in horseradish cream and the blue cheese toast - which is so good I will literally brandish a table knife if someone tries to steal a bite.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Four of us ate here recently and we're all disappointed. Since new owners took over the menu is more expensive, the offerings not as good, and the food quality middling. The squash soup tasted bland and hardly like squash, the beef dish was boring and pricey, the pork chops tasted good but we're very tough, and they are trying to serve pollack as a premium fish.  Pollack? It's the fish they use for fish cakes and processed products. Not a fish you ask people to pay $30 for. Blue spoon has always been a favorite of ours before a show, they should rethink their business model. I.e. Don't fix what ain't broke.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
OMG why haven't I been here before! This little blue (no pun untended) place is so cute, however, the pictures of the bunny man are creepy.  Whose idea was this??

Anyway, we got here for happy hour. $3 for house wine and $4 beer. Sign a sister up.  I had the sparkling wine which was pretty good for $3. Another colleague tried the hard cider and loved it. 

For appetizers we had the dips: carrot, rice and hummus. My favorite was the carrots, it had maple in it and tasted amazing with the flatbread and bread.

For entree,  I had the chicken with  braised kale, prunes and olives with potatoes. I was not expecting the portion size since it was a small restaurant but it was huge, I had some chicken left for lunch the next day. The chicken was very moist in the inside and crunchy on the outside, almost like an oven fried chicken. Highly recommended! My co-worker was has a gluten allergy had the burger bunless with potatoes and loved it. Her plate was wiped clean. The other had the Atlantic Pollack with braised kale and she loved it as well. The best salad was also a hit and so was the cream potato soup and risotto.

Service was great! I definitely will be coming here again.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Delightful. Cutest little restaurant. Intimate and delicious food. Watch out for small bones in the seafood stew though!

name: blue-spoon
review_text: My wife celebrated her birthday dinner and we had an absolutely wonderful meal with dessert of course. Be sure to call ahead as seating is bit limited and tables do get booked up in advance. We ordered the famous NY bistro burger, chicken with potatoes, rissotto and sides of dips and mussels. The mussels were extremely fresh and warm. I had the NY bistro burger and the meat was thick and juicy. Portions aren't huge which is great - just about right to fill you up. Overall great lunch or dinner joint for a small group of 2 or 3.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Food - 4 stars & Delicious (Scroll to FOOD section if that's what you came here for) 
Service - 1 star & Incredibly disappointing and rather insulting 

If you arrive here on a Saturday night an hour before closing (8:15pm),  even if the place is NOT full, let me tell you right now, GO SOMEWHERE ELSE...

Unless you enjoy waiting over an hour for the first bite of your food, cannot order multiple menu items because they "ran out", not receive any service or water for 30 minutes after you are seated because they "are short on glasses", not have your order put in the system for at least 30 minutes after you ordered, AND get charged full price for a an appetizer that shrunk in size because they "ran out" without telling you upfront. 

If I were the owner of this business, I would recommend my diners come back another night if I knew my restaurant wasn't able to deliver our best that night. Although there were multiple things that "went wrong", there were two that stood out to me as REALLY needing to be fixed. 

(1) Over 30 minutes AFTER the waiter took our orders, he came back to our table and wanted to reconfirm the 3 items ordered. Unfortunately, he got part of the order wrong, but we corrected it. The question is...What happened to the paper you wrote everything down on over 30 minutes ago?? Better yet, why wasn't this entered into the system 30 minutes ago when you took our order? We ended up waiting over an hour for the first bite of food to arrive. 

(2) We had ordered a large mussel appetizer. When our plate arrived, I was SHOCKED at how small the plate was with zero explanation from the waitstaff. (I had done my yelp research and browsed pictures) We had to ask, "is this this large size??" Our waiter unapolagetically replied, "No, this is all we had left", and left without an apology.   

SERIOUSLY. If this is the case, you should have the taken the time to at least explain to your diners BEFORE putting in the order that you were out of mussels. Or, when you were presenting it to the table, apologized for the shrunken size, and then perhaps wrote it off the final check. Instead, they charged us for it ANYWAY! 

With all the things that went wrong, our waiter did at two points ask if he could get a drink for us or a dessert "on him". We declined both options because they simply were not items we ever ordered. We are not big drinkers and not big on dessert. Also, he offered the drink while we were VERY empty stomached and had been waiting an hour at that point for our first bite of food. 

Let me clarify, our waiter was at no point rude to us. However, as diners, we felt we received inferior and unprofessional service. Even though the flavor of the food was great, this restaurant obviously needs to get their service act together. This has been THE Most disappointing dining experience I've had in the 2 years I've lived in Maine. Management, PLEASE get on this. 
  
FOOD:
I can't say enough wonderful things about the chef. The 3 dishes we ordered had excellent flavor and balance. Price was reasonable. ~$70 before tax for the 3 below. 

- Mussels: If you are lucky enough to not get the last few mussels of the night (which we did), you will love the flavor of these. The flavor of the broth is light, not too buttery, garlicy, and bright. Mussels were fresh and sweet, just like I like them. Toasted bread on top was crisp and perfect for dipping. 

- Steak entree: Cooked to perfection, this piece of meat and the sauce it came in was decadent and bold. Really delicious if you're looking for something meaty and more on the heavy side. 

- Pollock entree: Fish was tender and flaky. Excellent green sauce on top made the fish pop. Came atop a bed of fingerling potatoes, which were cooked a hair on the raw side so it maintained a bit of crunch. Great option if you're looking for something on the lighter side. 

The service ruined our experience at Blue Spoon. Hopefully, you'll have better luck.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Expensive. Food average. Burgers very salty. Salad very plain. Service very good except had to ask several times for refill. Tight seating. Somewhat dark. Had to send dessert back as walnuts may have been rancid.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Fantastic little restaurant.   Service and food were both outstanding.  Highly recommend this neighborhood restaurant.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: A+++ Saturday brunch. There was a huge crowd in front of Front Room a block away while Blue Spoon had tables available the entire time we were there, which blew my mind. Those suckers don't know what they're missing. If you're into pasta for breakfast (which we clearly are), the caccio e peppe was so good that my boyfriend got seconds. Seriously. I got the cornmeal pancakes, which taste like cornbread and pancakes had a baby (hello YUM) and topped with blackberry compote. The waiters and owners are all rad, there are games on every table, the environment is intimate but laid back... I can't wait to come back to Portland to come back to this place again.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: I went for lunch, and there was plenty of seating. Throughout my time here, there was never a wait, but it was always actively busy. We ended up sitting outside, which was great, and the staff was very friendly. We started out with a trio dip appetizer which came with grilled pita bread. The dips were incredible and varied from a spicy garlic dip, and greek potato dip, and a sweet potato dip. I ended up ordering the pork shoulder sandwhich and my mom ordered the chicken blt sandwhich. We ended up splitting our sandwhiches to share each kind, and they were both fantastic. The ciabatta the pork shoulder sandwhich was on was a highlight. Each sandwhich came with a dressed salad on the side and everything was very fresh. I would highly recommend this place for lunch!

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Over priced ($16) seafood stew -- 5 potatoes 5 mussels -- at the most 5 oz of pollock -- broth was ok. Burger was tasty but I have seen kid burgers bigger. My wife ordered the ($14) burger. Well done.  She received it med rare. Just not a good  experience.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Really nice neighborhood restaurant. Food,vibe and service were all excellent. Will def be coming back.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: First time at Blue Spoon, definitely won't be the last! From the fabulous house red wine to the huge plate of mussels that were listed as a starter but could've been a whole meal and the OUTSTANDING service, I can't say enough about this place.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: My Husband and I stopped in for lunch while visiting Portland.  We got seated right away and enjoyed some yummy mimosas and a Bloody Mary.  My Husband got the burger which was delicious and he especially loved the potato salad that came as as side, so good!!  I got the chicken salad sandwich which was delicious!! The service was warm and friendly, we will definitely be back if we find ourselves in Portland again.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Last night I took a friend from away.  they held our table (with such loyalty) after a phone call when we were twenty minutes late. It was a hopping Saturday night on East end. I have had excellent service in the past here but this was superb. We ordered small plates & shared everything.  we had sautéed greens , local cheese plate , roasted chicken & their hamburger , we ordered it plain.  These were all excellent and also had unique flavors.  This is the place I go to for dinner & drinks when I can get a table.  if you are visiting don't miss it.  I think my friend will always remember this delicious & friendly portland maine experience.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Edgy, small, quaint, off the beaten tourist path and such good food. I ordered off of the starter menu and had fish chowder and a beet salad. Both were exactly what I wanted. Rich chowder and a light pure flavor to the salad. My husband ordered the braised ragu pot which was beef that night. Our waitress was darling and made the experience even better. Take a stroll away from the typical tourist restaurants and eat here-make a reservation though!

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
This very small restaurant on Congress serves up some very good food. While visiting town we met an old colleague for dinner who suggested this place since it is one of her Portland favorites. Given the size of this space a reservation is a must. 

The waitress was very good. She kept things moving in an unobtrusive manner. The water glasses were never empty. Everyone's meals were declared a success from the crostini with the awesome bacon to the very moist and flavorful brick pressed chicken to the delicate hake. 

I almost forgot. Our cocktails were tasty especially the tropically inspired On Holiday.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Probably the most disappointing and insulting hospitality experience I've ever experienced.  Katie, and I don't know if she's the owner, manager or what, should get a new job or at least an attitude adjustment.  

The skinny:

Booked an 8:45 pm reservation thru Open Table a week or so ago

Arrived 10 minutes late - apologies (I flew in from Charlotte and it took a bit to drop my bag at the WONDERFUL Press Hotel before heading up Munjoy Hill w/my wife and friend)

Katie won't seat us; according to her watch it's 9:00 and the kitchen is closing PLUS 

She:  "You didn't book with us, we didn't take your reservation."

Me:  "Well, we booked thru Open Table, the reservation system you use and thru which you set the times when you will accept reservations...."

She (annoyed):  "That's different, you didn't book with us."

Me:  "Well, we'd love to be seated and have dinner.  My daughter and I enjoyed lunch here last summer and there seems to be plenty of seats open."

She (rudely and annoyed): "No.  You were late.  We aren't serving you.  The kitchen is closing."

I'm shocked at the disrespect, annoyance and lack of anything close to empathy Katie displayed.  If this is the experience Blue Spoon aspires to provide its customers, I wish them well.  It certainly was inconsistent with my prior experience there and was very surprising to the staff at our hotel with whom we shared our experience.  

But on a more positive note, THANK YOU Katie for turning us away, as we discovered an AMAZING meal with DELIGHTFUL staff just across the street at Lolita, where we enjoyed an incredible array of rustic Mediterranean dishes, lovely wines and a to-die-for flan for dessert with the most engaging and personable staff who seem to really enjoy people.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Hospitality/service was attentive and friendly. Food was wonderfully simple and straightforward with traditional options. To start, we had a small plate of the mussels followed by a beet salad and the sautéed field greens (perfect size and seasoning - I wanted a small plate and the flavor was excellent). For dinner (it was late) we just opted for the burger and the small portion of the braised ragu. That night's special was a braised beef and eggplant ragu over homemade fettuccine. 
Two items of note: the pasta was deliciously chewy, as homemade dough usually is. The ragu was full of flavor, not oily, with well-balanced flavor.  The burger was juicy and made with locally sourced beef. The real standout, however, was the Dijon (?) roasted potato side dish that came with the burger. If it does not come with your meal, see if you can order it. You won't be disappointed.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
We had a REALLY nice meal here the other night. After sitting down at a restaurant a few doors down and being overwhelmed by the noise level and smoke level we decided to go somewhere else. We had to wait about 20 minutes for a table on a Thursday night (no reservation) so we took a stroll around the neighborhood and were seated when we returned. 

The quiet, intimate space was a welcome contrast to where we had just been. We ordered a charcuterie board for our app and it was amazing. My guess is that the selection will be different every time, but you won't be disappointed. I loved the pickled vegetables. Only complaint is that it only had one cheese, so if you don't like brie you're out of luck (it was excellent).  

For my entree I ordered two small plates, the seared scallop and the warm lentil salad. The scollops were very tasty but the portion was very small even for an appetizer size (three quarter-size scallops). The lentil salad was great, I especially loved the egg and pancetta. The lentils themselves were very bland with no seasoning at all and a bit watery(?), but they did offset the heaviness of the egg and pancetta. While I enjoyed my meal I'd likely try something different the next time I dine there. My husband had the ragu of the day which was excellent, fresh pasta with a hearty sauce and a pile of fluffy parmesan. The portion was generous and he took some home. 

The service was very friendly and was attentive until after we ordered then it tapered off. It was a busy night though, and we were happy so it wasn't a big deal. We'll happily return, and soon!

name: blue-spoon
review_text: If I lived on Munjoy Hill I could come here all the time.  The atmosphere is so warm and the staff is so welcoming that I felt like I was a long lost friend being invited into someone's home.  The wine list was varied and included some of our favorites, so that was a hit.  The food was wonderful and well presented.  There were several very interesting choices and lots of local ingredients.  We sat by the window and watched everyone struggle with the snow, so we even had some entertainment for the evening.  Blue Spoon is one of the top of my list for Portland.  I can't wait for it to get warm so I can walk around the area after dinner.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Let me tell you - this is by far one of the best restaurants I've been to. Between the food, the ambiance, and the service I wish I could give it ten stars. My boyfriend and I were visiting Portland for a weekend and it was our last night visiting and we wanted to really treat ourselves with some good food. We stumbled into the Blue Spoon after our reservations at another restaurant didn't go too well ( so bad we got up and left ). It was down the street from our Airbnb so we walked and upon walking in you see how teeny tiny it is inside which we loved. People had just gotten up from the bar and the servers told us we could grab the bar or a table and we picked bar. The bartender Jason ( I believe that was his name ) was fabulous. He was so personable and funny - not to mention he wasn't over barring or too distant like some bartenders. He was seriously lovely. We started off with the mussels which were probably some of the best I've ever had. My boyfriend got a Manhattan and said it was spectacular ( he's a bartender himself so he can be picky haha ). We also got some soft sourdough bread and oil which paired so well with the leftover broth. 

I had the steak salad with roasted veggies which was cooked to perfection ( med rare is the way to go people!!). Jason answered all my questions and actually seemed excited to answer them. My boyfriend got the burger that came with a potato salad that was dressed in dijon ( amazing ). All the servers were smiling and lovely and the kitchen staff was great as well. We ended our meal with a coconut flan that was to DIE for. We left with our bellies full and our pockets happy too ( it wasn't even as much as we expected - great prices for happy food ). 

Thank you Blue Spoon for a wonderful visit, we will be back!!!!

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
We were in town visiting and took our son here for his 24th bday. What a wonderful evening. The charcuterie platter was a meal in itself and a perfect presentation. Everything on it was top quality. 

The house specialty drinks although pricey are excellent.  We also ordered a bottle of wine. Although the list is small the pricing is excellent. They even had a bottle for $21. Where do u see that??  We had a $30 which was excellent. 

The entrees were top notch. I had the rib eye which was perfectly cooked and simply mouthwatering. The herb butter on top just sent this great piece of meat over the top. My wife and son had the flounder. They could not stop raving or eating it. It was so good neither offered me a taste. 

Topped it all off with a wonderful lemon blueberry cake. Perfect light ending for a great dinner. The homemade whip cream on the top was perfect. 

My only hesitation on giving 5 stars was the service was a little lax. I was ok with it because I think they want it to b a dining experience. My wife and son thought it a little slow. I think we are all so use to being rushed through that when u get to a place that tries to put forth true dining we get anxious

All and all love this place. Next time in Portland it is at the top of my list.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: My first trip to the Blue Spoon left me rather meh. It is a cozy spot as other reviewers have noted. Friendly staff greeted us immediately for Saturday morning brunch. After sitting at our table, I found my fork was dirty. This, IMHO, does not bode well for the meal. I ordered the cornmeal pancakes with strawberry compote and maple yogurt drizzle. The pancakes were nothing special. They were fairly dry and crumbly. The drizzle was overpowered by the compote and I found myself adding maple syrup to get any maple flavor. My son had a breakfast sandwich that came with a side salad. I know breakfast salads can be a thing but this salad felt like an afterthought to make the plate look full. Just greens (fresh) dressed lightly with a vinaigrette (which was light and tasty) but felt confusing with a bagel breakfast sandwich. I was looking forward to another dish on their menu on their website but it appears they've changed their brunch menu. A note on the website might better prepare diners to expect possible changes. Our waitstaff person was attentive to start but almost seemed to ignore us at the end of our meal (there were only a few tables filled). We waited patiently for much longer than should be for a how was the meal? can I get you something else? and for our plates to be cleared. There were too many negatives for a very positive review.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
First impressions were good, menu looked great (what they had online) but it wasn't the same in person. 

The restaurant was very hot, smoky and there were a ton of flies! Had to keep brushing them off our food the entire meal. 

I had the Rose-something-or-other cocktail made with vodka, mint, lime, and watermelon simple syrup. $12. It was SO sweet. Just tasted like a mojhito to me. 

The waitress brought out 4 tiny pieces of bread for the 4 of us. The olive oil it came with was fantastic, wish we had more bread for sopping it up.

I had the beet and hazelnut salad with buttermilk ranch $13- which was good, had plenty of beets, but no creamy cheese to go with like I was expecting. 

The highlight of the meal was the blue cheese, spinach and garlic toast $6. SO GOOD. 

The half portion of pasta was SO small... would even leave a child hungry. The burger looked good, and the Hake was okay but overpriced. 

Would be back for the $2.50 wine time that sounds so popular, and for some more vegetarian apps, but not dinner!

name: blue-spoon
review_text: We arrived without a reservation and despite being very busy, we were seated immediately. Service was on point, the food was excellent (I got the pork belly hash and we sampled from the toast bar-yum!) and before our food arrived, our server offered to move us to a 4 top because she was concerned we would be crowded. So kind but of course we said no-they were turning people away and I'd feel like a giant hoarder! We were so pleased we popped in - it was a great experience. Note: make a reservation - it was hopping the entire time we were there. Note to Blue Spoon- please consider adding avo toast to your nearly perfect toast bar offerings!

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
This little place is has a whole lot going for it.  It's tiny, and they have 3 tables outside as well, but it is tight in there.  But the food and the service is well worth it.  And you might even make some new friends along the way.  

We made reservations but were early, and they let us sit on the patio (really 3 cordoned off tables next to the building) and we were able to order drinks while we waited.  There is about a 6 seat bar, but it was full when we got there.  But our reservation was met on time and we were able to carry over our bill for the drinks to dinner, which was a nice touch.

The food was very good.  We tried the mussels and a beet salad first.  Both were excellent, the mussels were in a somewhat traditional white wine sauce I believe and the beet salad was good, with big chunks of beets and a great dressing.  After that, we got the risotto and the bistro burger, with mushrooms.  Man that burger was good!  I'm not usually a burger guy for dinner, but I had heard good things.  It was amazing and well worth it.  The risotto was a little bland for my tastes but it was prepared well, which is tricky with risotto.

Everyone was friendly and helpful and it has a nice neighborhood vibe; you get the feeling it has a very loyal following.  Sorry, no pictures (I was too hungry to grab for my phone) but the presentation was great too!

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Went to wine time for the first time ever yesterday (Monday -Saturday from 4:30 -6) What a treat! Two glasses of red for six bucks and they don't skimp on the wine either! 

I sat at the bar alone treating myself to some much needed pampering since I am having a weekend alone for the first time in a while, and this is the place to do it.

 I ordered a salad with roasted beets, hazelnuts, spinach, fresh herbs, and baked goat cheese, lightly drizzled with extra virgin olive oil. It was the best salad I have had in portland maine so far. 

The bartender was so sweet and personable. She was engaging and made my experience complete.  My bill came to 20.52, you just can't beat that price for an upscale establishment. I am so happy I chose to go out and enjoy myself here.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: This place was recommended... however the service was absolutely awful. Our waitress ignored us for the first 20 minutes, and then continuously forgot anything we asked. She was not attentive at all, and also gave us so much shade when we asked for straws, just straws! Our group was manageable, the place was not busy but yet they completely ignored us the whole time. Even though the food was good, I'd never recommend this place to anyone. If you like being treated like crap, then go here. Annnnd the Bloody Mary tasted like cocktail sauce.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Perfect spot.  We had great service and all courses were delicious.  It's an intimate, simple place that's done right.   Apps and entrees were terrific.  You'll enjoy.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: I love The Spoon it never disappoints, the food, the service and the mood. Truly one of Portland's best!

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Lovely spot with intimate service and fresh, thoughtfully prepared meals. Had a lemon-squash risotto to die for: rice perfectly cooked, zucchini with some good crunch, beautiful Parmesan. My neighbors had entrees that looked fulsome (ragout) and rich, largely portioned.

My only complaint, And it's a fairly sizable one, was the choice of music--a kind of dance trance track that appeared to be chosen for the kitchen staff. Didn't suit the activity, the small space, or the sophistication of diners. Really ruined the atmosphere.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
We were staying in the east end and I found an article that mentioned the neighborhood ...and Blue Spoon.  It was our first dinner in Portland and the experience was spectacular.

It is a laid back small place On Congress just blocks from the Eastern Prom. It is nestled among the houses in the neighborhood which gives it a quaintness and some modern authenticity. The restaurant is known for local ingredients. And it was evident in all parts of our experience.   

First, the waiter was fun.  I wish I could remember his name.  We had an early reservation because we had our 8 year old and we walked in in shorts.  They didn't blink an eye and the waited chatted with us and our son like he wanted to know us...not just serve us.  

This gets a lot of attention fir wines that are well selected but as a beer nerd it's frankly something that is to die for if you are a beer traveller.  This small list of drafts:  Maine Beer Lunch and Peeper, Bissell Brothers Baby Genius, and one called Green Warden brewed with spruce.  I almost danced when he ran through this small list of world class drafts.

It's not a restaurant with a kids menu so know that your kiddo will eat what adults eat but the have a GREAT bistro burger that was reviewed by the NY Times.  And since it's bigger than a child can eat...I got to have some of it.  A top flight burger that you can dress with thick cured bacon and a Fred egg. It came with a Dijon based potato salad that was unreal.  They looked like breakfast potatoes made into this tangy smooth dressing with lots of herbs.  I'd have ordered it as a side for my entree.  Spectacular.

My wife had a fried polenta appetizer (with a fancier name) and a tomato sauce.  The only thing that was not fantastic...a bit too salty and plain.  I wanted beets and had a beet tapas dish with a horseradish sauce and pistachios.  Wonderful.  The creamy sauce gave them a spicy bite but did not overpower the beets.  The nuttiness came across perfect too.

My entree was a leap for me.  I ordered an encrusted Hake fish dish that came with a tomato jam, served over greens and celery with a spoon for an incredible broth.  It was among the best fish dishes I've ever had.  The flavors were perfect and complex.  It was a leap fir me because the rest of the menu includes a famous risotto, a "from the braising pot daily ragu" and a pork chop that had caught my eye. 

My wife had the ragu which featured pork belly.  Yes!!!  I got to try a bite and it was fabulous too. How can a pork belly ragu not be awesome?

We couldn't eat dessert.  The portions were excellent.  You can get half portions of some items too if you want salads or tapas.  In the end this was an experience I'd do again this week.  The ethics of the chef, the skill and the service all shined.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
The waitstaff is generally friendly and the interior is a bit cramped but cozy. Food is very good but the portions are small. Unfortunately the prices are a bit steep for both the quality and quantity of what you receive.

 Living in the neighborhood, we sometimes like to stop by in early afternoons for a drink and dinner. That said, it's become irritating to see 'reserved' signs on the three tables outside which are coveted spots in nice weather. Most restaurants with such limited seating have a first-come-first served policy.  - On one recent afternoon we'd finally had enough with feeling like we were begging to go here, so we went across the street. I sat and watched as those three 'reserved' tables remained empty for well over an hour.

If the owner or staff is going to hold tables for their friends, etc. (which may or may not be the case), at least have the courtesy to ask people to be on time. We've hit a point where we no longer want to plan our visit with the tactical prowess of the D-Day landing. There are just too many other good spots in the neighborhood willing to seat us appropriately. :-\

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Absolutely Excellent! 

We dined here this evening and had a very friendly server who impressed us with his knowledge of the menu and was able to answer all of our questions (we had a few). The atmosphere is just perfect. Dimly lit with a rustic feel to it, very quaint for a date. The bread is SO GOOD! It is the best way to get your taste buds going! We had the blue cheese and garlic toast as well as the pork belly appetizers to start; both were delicious, the blue cheese toast was a perfect blend of crunchy and creamy and not overwhelmingly blue cheesy tasting as some blue cheese dishes can be. The pork belly was decadent and very highly recommended. It is a fresh appetizer with a fatty component, I loved it! Then for dinner we had the braised ragout and the sweet potato risotto...incredible! Both so rich in flavor and just an A+ in execution. For 1 the pasta is homemade and the risotto is perfectly cooked. Another round of bread was brought to us by our awesome server so we could soak up the sauces of our dishes (extra tip for that move ;) ). We were both extremely pleased with the meal and will absolutely be back!

name: blue-spoon
review_text: One of the best all around meals I have had in a long time. Stumbled upon this place while in town for our son's college graduation. We liked the looks of it and decided to give it a try. We started with The Sauteed Greens and Trio of Dips. LOVED the greens and I live for greens. All the dips were super tasty. My husband got the ribeye and it was cooked to perfection, slightly crispy and carmelized on the outside and moist and juicy on the inside and great flavor, a.k.a. great cut of beef. I had the Seafood Bourride which was a wonderful balance of flavors and textures, elegant and hearty at the same time. Wonderful service and ambience as well.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
The food here was excellent. I'm reviewing this like a week later, so I can't remember the names of what we got (and they aren't on the yelp menu), but we came for lunch and got a seafood stew type thing and a middle eastern pancake with grilled chicken, fennel, and carrots on top. Both were great, the latter was better than the former because I just couldn't eat that much fish. I was pretty stuffed, but my mom wanted desert so we got a piece of cake with grand marnier strawberry coulis and whipped cream on top, and let me tell you, I found out that I had a separate compartment in my stomach for it. 
I reserve 5 star ratings for food that makes me say omg the entire time I'm eating it, but this would probably be a 4.5. :)

name: blue-spoon
review_text: We ordered 3 tapas to start. Grilled rounds of eggplant with balsamic and goat cheese, cauliflower with bacon and cheddar cheese and beets drizzled with honey. They were all fantastic! My main meal was the sausage risotto. Get the smaller portion, it's huge! My friend got the roasted chicken, also very good and large portion. We both had a drink and desserts. The lemon crepes were light and delicious. The chocolate cake was gluten free and very dense and chocolatey. They had a large selection of gluten free items

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Blue Spoon is one of my absolute favorite restaurants in Portland, so much so that I dined her twice within the span of 3 hours while I was home for 4 short days. I will never come home to Portland again for only 4 days- it simply was not enough time to eat everywhere I wanted to. Anyways, Blue Spoon, I love you so much. Reason being for dining here twice within such a short time though all comes down to the blue cheese garlic toast. See, I had been dreaming about this dish since fall of 2014 when I last had it before moving away. I came here for brunch on a Saturday, giddy and over the moon excited to eat my beloved dish. Well, the brunch menu on the weekend appears to be quite different than the regular lunch and dinner menus. It is super limited and not what I was expecting. Needless to say, I was hurt, but I would get over it, and still find delicious food to eat. I had the goat cheese toast to start. I am IN LOVE with goat cheese but I wasn't trying to replace my blue  cheese garlic toast. This was super scrum, came with two pieces with goat cheese, honey, and walnuts. Delicious. I then ordered the mussels because it was really one of the only things on the small brunch menu that appealed to me. I was cursing myself for coming too early, it's okay though, I WOULD be back. The mussels were plentiful in a roasted garlic broth. I do believe we had a coconut flan for dessert which was HEAVENLY. I am IN LOVE with flan and I am IN LOVE with coconut. I left, full, but satisfied, and ready to return promptly when they opened back up for dinner. 

So, I would like to state that I am OBSESSED beyond belief with the blue cheese garlic toast. It is in my TOP FIVE favorite dishes in the city of Portland. That says a lot if you know how many incredible things there are in Portland. I mean, this thing is OUTRAGEOUS. It makes me so sad that I won't be having it again for probably at least 6 months, but realistically much longer. At this point in the day, I was already full from the 2 meals I had had already and maybe a few margaritas and mimosas, BUT, that was NOT going to stop me from going back to get my blue cheese garlic toast. So I was very hung up on this, because it was my last day in town, there was no option of NOT going there. Back we go to Blue Spoon- and I think it was happy hour, they had wines and maybe a few beers on special. I was full, and we were going to dinner after this toast anyways. I really packed it in in these 4 days, I was so proud of myself- still am. Okay, BLUE CHEESE GARLIC TOAST. Please, please, PLEASE, if you come to this restaurant, PLEASE order this. I don't care if you don't even like blue cheese, or garlic, or toast, get this dish. It is truly one of THE best things I have ever had, EVER. It is just perfection. I don't even really know what else to say. I had been raving about it to my friend Blank forever, and she knows I know about good food, but even she was blown away. She said "You're right Blank, it really is the best". I mean, it just exceeds expectations. Also, we had some donut something orgasmic dish as well. It had feta cheese, tomatoes, cucumbers, and some other jazz. I literally have no idea what it was, I do not believe it is on the menu, but it was RIDICULOUS GOOD. I wish I had a good memory. Anyways, it was incredible. So this was all we had because we had more eating to do, but please get the blue cheese garlic toast. 

Having said all this, I have been here a number of times in the past, and truly ever dish I have had here has been amazing. Their prices are extremely fair, the portions are great for yourself or sharing (DO NOT SHARE BLUE CHEESE TOAST), and they have a lot to choose from. I love coming here and ordering 8047 tapas. Also, the service is always wonderful here. Jason IS the best server ever and he deserves all the coolest things in the whole world to happen to him. I will be taking him to India one day.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
Visited here recently with a party of five. We had made a reservation- strongly encourage making a reservation if you can, the restaurant is very tiny with limited  seating! The highlight of my nite- a goat cheese cheesecake; still dreaming of that one. 
The downfalls to the evening- "wine time" is cheap but consists of very cheap tasting wines. Didn't even finish my glass, tasted like it came straight from the box. The other fly in the ointment for the evening was towards the end of the meal (we all ordered apps, drinks, entrees, and deserts) our waiter told us that he had another party coming in shortly so we had to "wrap it up". 
Besides those two things, the food was excellent and the service was decent.

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
A.) I live one block away from this little gem. I feel lucky.
B.) All of the small plates are good.  All of them.  For serious.
C.) You know that feeling after one or two glasses of wine? That warm booze hug? That's this place in brick-and-mortar form.
D.) Whether you live close or make this a destination, you're in for a comfortable experience

name: blue-spoon
review_text:
We've been meaning to try the Blue Spoon, as the burger was rumored as quite tasty. Finally, after missing out on available times in this tiny establishment, we made it happen!

Since it has been several days since attending, and the menu changes regularly, I won't be able to properly name all the consumed items.

I started with a High and Mighty beer, which I thought was very tasty. It was labeled as "German-style" (according to the bottle), but it tasted more Belgian to me. Anyway, my wife and I decided to share 1 small plate (polenta fritters), 2 appetizers (a Moroccan lamb dish and a trout dish), a 1/2 order of the ragu, and a burger (with bacon and cheddar). 

To keep it simple, the first 3 dishes were really great (5 stars). The fritters were salty and well complimented by the sauce, the lamb had very tasty spices, and the trout was interesting and spicy. Both the ragu and the burger were good (3.5 stars), but I would try something else on a future trip.  

In conclusion, I would go again! They have a lot of interesting choices. The service is good and the atmosphere is intimate/romantic. Don't be a buffoon...check out the Blue Spoon. (patent pending)

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Great food! Romantic and cozy. Excellent service. Top of my list of restaurants in Portland!

name: blue-spoon
review_text: Excellent brunch place, also heard it's got a kick ass happy hour/wine time that they are known for. Bloody Mary was good but eggs Benedict was great. Definitely worth the price because food and atmosphere were wonderful. PS make rex on weekend it gets crowded, last time we skipped it because it was too crowded.

name: blue-spoon
review_text: A small, neighborhood restaurant with friendly service and good food.  An especially nice place to duck into on a cold, winter night.

name: blue-spoon
